HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
A Rush to Build Complexes to Care for the Aging

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
WITH the nation's ninth largest population of residents 65 and older, New Jersey is becoming a magnet for the development of specialized housing for the elderly.
Developers are starting or planning a spate of such projects, which provide housing and varying levels of services and health care, from independent to assisted living and nursing beds. Some, called continuing-care communities, offer all three. 
 Several factors beyond the state's number of older people -- which will rise from 1.1 million to 1.3 million by 2010, with those 75 and over growing the fastest, according to state figures -- are stoking the activity, analysts said. They include an improving economy and the trend among the elderly to stay near their families.
As a corollary, the state's Department of Health and Senior Services is advocating less costly alternatives to nursing homes, including assisted-living communities or components of communities that offer residents meals, transportation, housekeeping and personal and medical care.
Since 1994, when the state began regulating assisted-living communities, 15 entire developments or complexes with assisted-living components have been built and licensed. And 457 more are in various stages of the approval or application process, according to the department, which also monitors care.
Many of the projects cater to the affluent elderly, but a few are geared to those with middle incomes. To keep prices affordable three semi-autonomous state agencies are offering construction loans at or below market interest rates. They are the New Jersey Health Care Facilities Financing Authority, the New Jersey Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency and the New Jersey Economic Development Authority.
Qualification differs from agency to agency. For example, the Housing Finance Agency will offer funds to projects by both for-profit and nonprofit builders that reserve some units for people with incomes of 50 to 80 percent of the area's median.
The pace of development has some in the industry worried about overbuilding. "The concern is that this market sector is being perceived as the next get-rich-quick bandwagon to jump on," said James Robbins, president of RAD Consultants, a Fairfield-based real estate consulting firm. "This activity is just the tip of the icebreg."
But developers say that in the short term the demand for such housing is greater than the supply under or nearing construction. And analysts say that some of the activity will be in northern New Jersey, where few such communities are now available.
LEN FISHMAN, Commissioner of the state's Health Department, said that the licensing needed from his department would temper growth because it "puts everyone's cards on the table and considers the potential competition." In turn, he added, securing financing "will not be easy."
Developers also must meet state regulations, find properly zoned land on which to build and address municipal concerns over traffic and sewage capacity, among other issues.
Some municipal leaders are becoming more receptive to such projects, developers say. Among the reasons are that they add to the tax base without having an impact on schools and provide a way to help keep older residents from moving away.
The larger projects offer a transition from independence to assisted living to nursing care. In some continuing-care communities residents pay an entry fee for access to all levels, as well as monthly service fees.
The biggest is the 2,026-unit Senior Campus Living of Baltimore complex planned for Tinton Falls in Monmouth County. The 134-acre site along Essex Road, off the Garden State Parkway, will be the first project in the state for the company, which had advanced two previous development plans in north Jersey that were derailed by community concerns.
Brian P. Froelich, the Senior Campus Living president, said that while the size of his company's projects "does cause concern it is what makes it possible to reach the untapped middle-income market."
The company has won rezoning to build the Tinton Falls project on the once commercially zoned site, but still must reach an agreement to buy the sewage capacity for it from Neptune Township. Company and Tinton Falls officials said they were hopeful a solution could be worked out.
Entry fees, which will be 100 percent refundable upon death or departure, range from $75,000 to $312,000. There is expected too be a monthly charge of $900 to $1,500 for the 1,650 studio to two-bedroom independent-living units and $2,200 for the 136 assisted-living units. The fee for a second person has not yet been set..
The fees will cover everything but advanced medical care, "which residents pay for when they need it," said Mr. Froelich. There will also be a 240-bed nursing wing, as well as four 50,000-square-foot community centers.
In Plainsboro, work is proceeding on the first phase of the Windrows at Princeton Forrestal, which is set up as rentals and a condominium, where units may be bought and sold as in a regular residential condominium and no entry fees are required. It is rising on 45 acres in the 1,700-acre Princeton Forrestal Center, the commercial center owned by Princeton University.
The first phase has 83 assisted-living units, 180 nursing beds and a 22,000-square-foot medical center. Rents, including meals and all other services, are $2,500 to $3,500 for the studio to two-bedroom units, said Bernard N. Plante, senior vice president at Care Matrix of Needham, Mass., the developer. The second-person fee is $650 for independent living, $825 for assisted living.
ULTIMATELY there will be 300 independent-living units, from condominium apartments to villas, as well as a 45,000-square-foot community center. Prices for the residences will be $160,000 to $400,000, with monthly fees of $980 to $2,000 covering all meals. Construction is to start this fall.
Developers are also building assisted-living projects alone or with nursing homes. In Park Ridge, Care Matrix will start construction this month on a project with 100 assisted-living units and 210 nursing beds. Monthly fees will range from $2,950 to $3,850 for studio and one-bedroom apartments, respectively, including all meals and services. The second-person fee is $825. Advanced medical care will cost more.
Mr. Plante said projects were also planned in Livingston and Monroe.
Paul E. Johnson Jr., president and general manager of Marriott Senior Living Services, a division of the Washington-based hotel chain, said his company had put a major focus on the growth of its assisted-living suites nationally and in New Jersey.
It has opened two in the state -- one in Edison with 98 assisted-living suites and 30 nursing beds, the other in Mountainside with 98 assisted-living units and a 21-bed special-care wing for people with Alzheimer's disease and related memory disorders.
Monthly rents, including all meals and services, range from $2,425 to $3,690; second-person fees at both complexes is $500. The fees for the nursing and special-care units range from $5,400 to $5,730 a month at Edison and $3,060 to $3,860 at Mountainside. Mr. Johnson said several more projects were planned, including one each in Paramus, Saddle River and Cherry Hill.
MARRIOTT expects to break ground next year for a continuing-care community in Wayne. It will have 220 independent-living apartments, 20 assisted-living units and 60 nursing beds. Entry fees are expected to be $176,000 to $427,000, which will be 90 percent refundable, plus monthly fees of $1,900 to $3,100. For a second person, there will be an added $15,000 entry fee and an additional $700 monthly fee.
Sunrise Assisted Living, based in Fairfax, Va., has four assisted-living communities under way in Morris Plains, Old Tappan, Westfield and Wayne. Each will have 77 units and a wing for residents with Alzheimer's disease and other memory disorders. Rents for a shared unit with an unrelated person, including meals and services, will be $1,700 to $2,800, a month, said Lori M. High, its regional director of sales and marketing. Advanced and specialized health care will cost more.
Rents for a private unit will be $2,900 to $4,300. The second-person fee will be $725 to $1,075.
Of all the activity Mr. Fishman, Commissioner of the state's Health department, concluded: "We will have to see how it plays out, but the licensing of 15 projects so far suggests a reasonable rate of growth."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Rendering of the Care Matrix project in Park Ridge, which is to start construction this month. (Donkig Lee)

HEADLINE: ON POLTICS;
A Freshman in Congress Faces Up to Democracy

BYLINE: By Melinda Henneberger; Melinda Henneberger reports from Washington for The New York Times.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A couple of union lobbyists recently paid a call on William J. Pascrell, a first-term Congressman so fresh to Capitol Hill that he had arrived in Washington -- Clampett-style, to hear him tell it -- with a carload of his belongings earlier that morning and spent the time just before dawn wrestling with a shower curtain in his new apartment. Mr. Pascrell, a Democrat who gave up steady work as a state Assemblyman and Mayor of Paterson to come to the House of Representatives, was one of labor's few success stories last November. With the help of unions, he narrowly defeated a Republican freshman, William J. Martini, in a campaign that Mr. Pascrell himself calls "a food fight." And the labor lobbyists wanted to let Mr. Pascrell know that they do not much like his support for a balanced budget amendment. His decision will not be symbolic, either: a vote this month is likely to be so close that a change of one heart could make all the difference.
Now, Mr. Pascrell has an accommodating nature. Making his way from one meeting to another along the hallway of his office building, where he's still struggling to find his way ("I think I'll start leaving bread crumbs"), he stopped to greet a small group of strangers who had come to lobby other lawmakers: "Vietnam vets? I'm a vet. You can count on my support." 
 His decision on the amendment seems a particularly tough call because he unambiguously campaigned in support of the hugely popular idea of a balanced budget amendment, yet he speaks of the unions he would be flouting with an almost religious fervor. "Unions are not-for-profit, like churches!" he thundered in an interview. "It would be un-American to do away with their ability to contribute to campaigns!"
But in Washington, as Mr. Pascrell seems to be learning, it is sometimes possible to keep faith with your friends while also keeping a promise to defy them.
When Alan Reuther and Bernie McKinnon, who work for the United Auto Workers, stopped by Mr. Pas crell's office, the three of them began by kicking around what Mr. Reuther called "anti-worker bills."
Mr. Pascrell cursed proponents of a bill that would keep unions from using dues to make the kind of campaign contributions that were so helpful to him. "Nothing makes me madder," he said.
Moving to the topic of child labor, Mr. Pascrell let loose again. "I read of another company like the Kathie Lee fiasco," he said, raising his eyes to heaven. "Another company that was getting away with murder, a large company contracting work out with child labor and saying they didn't know anything about it. And it didn't make the product any cheaper, either. Just bigger profits!"
Eventually, the talk came around to the one big area of disagreement.
"We, like the other unions," Mr. Reuther said, "are very much opposed to a balanced budget amendment, as a threat to Medicare and Social Security and as bad economic policy."
Mr. Pascrell said he wanted to explain his contrarian view to his union brothers. "I think we need to do it to improve the credibility, the credit rating, of the Congress," he said.
Mr. Reuther countered: "The passage of the amendment could do more to hurt the credit rating of Congress. The amendment does nothing to save $1. The amendment is a gimmick. They can say, 'I've done my thing on the balanced budget, and now I don't have to make the hard choices.' "
Mr. McKinnon said: "And once the amendment is passed, how do you deal with these issues?"
"Well, it has to go to the states to be ratified," Mr. Pascrell said. He sounded as if it might not be so horrible if that never happened. "The debate is healthy," he said, sounding as if it might not be a tragedy if that debate went nowhere.
Mr. Reuther said: "I would just hope you would keep an open mind. The key for us is a vote against Stenholm-Schaefer," he added, referring to the Republican version of the measure.
Mr. Pascrell has supported another version, sponsored by Senator Robert G. Torricelli, the New Jersey Democrat, that would protect Social Security from cuts. Critics of that version have called it pretty flimsy political cover for Democrats who want to go on record for a balanced budget amendment without actually having to balance the budget.
"We don't object to other votes" for other versions, Mr. Reuther said, smiling.
"Most of the unions are against it," Mr. Pascrell said, as if to himself. "People are rather shocked that I took the position I did."
"That's why I asked, how far did you go in your commitment?" to support a balanced budget amendment, Mr. McKinnon said, making himself absolutely clear.
And suddenly, everybody seemed in accord.
"I never committed to the Republican bill," Mr. Pascrell said. "That's not a balanced budget. That's strangulation!"
After the meeting, Mr. Pascrell, whose first re-election fund-raising event is scheduled for March, said the support from the union in no way obliged him to support their agenda.
"It's called democracy," he said.

HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT;
SoHo-by-the-Sea? Asbury Park Advances, but Cautiously

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

DATELINE: ASBURY PARK

 BODY:
Here in the downcast remains of what was once a flourishing entertainment capital, people have pinned their hopes on attracting artists to live, work and exhibit amid the leftover downtown grandeur and the still-proud Victorian neighborhoods. At $100,000 or less for a roomy 19th-century house, even artists can afford to live in Asbury Park, residents will tell you, as they voice their hopes that their small city, with its ornate but silenced carousel and its corroded, derelict hotels, will become a SoHo-by-the-Sea.
Therefore, one might think that a proposal to build artists' lofts and gallery space in the boarded-up, blocklong hulk of the former Steinbach department store would be greeted with open arms. That's what John English, a real-estate developer from Brooklyn, has said he wants to do, provided he can obtain financing for the project, as well as a zoning change to allow residents in the commercial area. 
 While some here say the concept is a good one, every discussion comes back to fears that hang like clouds: that either the project will run into trouble, or city officials will destroy it with bureaucratic foot-dragging.
"I'm interested in this building because I would like to live there," said Patrick Schiavino, a real-estate investor who lives in nearby Ocean Grove and is a self-described cutting-edge abstract painter. "But I don't know if anything is going to take off."
Mr. English said he was already so frustrated that he has all but withdrawn from the project. "It's not that they are particularly giving me a hard time," he said. "It's more that they can't get their act together. The politics in Asbury Park are more complex than anything I've ever encountered."
He said he had discussed his plans with the Mayor, Carl Williams, as well as the city planner and other officials. When he offered to go before the City Council, he was told that would be improper, he said.
"I think everybody is in agreement that Asbury Park has to change," Mr. English said. "But as everything they've tried to do has failed, they have become so afraid of failure that they're afraid to stick their necks out."
City officials said that while they had some questions about his plans, the zoning question could be resolved with a proposal that the City Council is likely to vote on by Feb. 27. Mr. English has offered about $150,000 for the building, city officials said. The renovation plan calls for 42 loft condominiums of 1,500 square feet that would sell to artists only.
Among the questions are what to do about parking, said Christopher Armitage, director of economic development for the city.
Mr. Schiavino said parking was hardly a problem in Asbury Park, calling it "a ghost town." Let them make people want to come to the downtown, he said, "and if parking becomes a problem, we'll solve that problem later."
Mr. Armitage described the Steinbach plan as "still up in the air," but said he was hopeful the developer could allay the city's concerns. "We have to make sure somebody who comes to us with a plan is complying with our local ordinances," he said.
It is understandable that Asbury Park's administrators would move cautiously on developers' plans. They have been badly burned in the past.
In 1984, a major deal to revive the waterfront was signed by the city and a group led by Joseph Carabetta, a Connecticut developer who attracted the likes of Johnny Cash, the singer, and Ernie Anastos, the news anchor, as partners. One cornerstone was a high-rise condominium development. The largely abandoned beachfront, where sea gulls wheeling overhead are the only signs of life these days, was supposed to turn into a fabulous attraction once again. As steel girders began to outline the project against the sky, the real-estate market plummeted and Mr. Carabetta declared bankruptcy.
Today, reminders of that venture are mortifyingly plain to see, as the concrete-encased skeleton sits unused along what is known as Ocean Mile.
Mr. Schiavino said the city was well intentioned, but not well informed. "Asbury Park is being very naive because they think artists are just going to move there," he said. "Their idea is good, but they have no idea how it will start. They don't understand that in all those areas that artists gentrified around Manhattan, the artists were basically squatting in those buildings."
Kate Mellina, who owns a shop and gallery called Cleopatra Steps Out and is the newly minted arts-business-development coordinator, said she thought the city had proved its potential as an artists' space.
"We've got a core of arts-related businesses that are starting to come in, and we want to promote that," she said. There are plans for a monthlong arts festival in August, she said, and a promotional day last October attracted 250 artists. The organizers had expected perhaps 40.
She, too, is worried about something undermining the Steinbach plan. "As much as I want to see this happen, we can't risk another Asbury-Park-can't-get-it-together story," she said. She said she wanted Mr. English to "go through the hoops of the planning and zoning boards before we start getting people enthused."
Mayor Williams said he was all for Mr. English's plan. But he said, "It seems like we're our own worst enemy, always tying ourselves up with the wrong people."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Patrick Schiavino, an investor and artist, who seeks to turn the vacant Steinbach store (background) into loft space. "I don't know if anything is going to take off," he says. (Mary DiBiase Blaich for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Future Trucks: Muscular but Soft Inside

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

 BODY:
IF you think today's sport utility vehicles are plush, just wait. Future versions, suggested in hybrid car-truck concept vehicles on display at the Chicago Auto Show, have the high, aggressive look of off-road gladiators but will offer luxury-car appointments and standards of ride, handling and fuel economy that approach those of family sedans.
Lexus, for example, is showing off a prototype it calls the Sport Luxury Vehicle, or SLV. Based on the Lexus ES 300 midsize sedan (itself based on the Toyota Camry), the SLV, with its roof rack and thick lower-body moldings, looks like a sport utility. But it is intended to behave much like a car, providing easy entry and exit for passengers and amenities that include leather upholstery and a premium sound system. 
 Lexus, which already sells the LX 450, a fancy version of the muscular Toyota Land Cruiser, may offer a second sport utility like the SLV within a couple of years.
The Ford Motor Company showed a similar concept car called the Mercury L'Attitude. Based on the Mercury Sable station wagon, it maintains the Sable's carlike ride and handling but has large off-road tires, a roof rack and a side-hinged cargo door that give it a sport utility appearance.
General Motors' Pontiac-GMC Division showed the Envoy, a compact sport utility vehicle based on the GMC Jimmy. A production version of the vehicle, loaded with luxury-car amenities including a communications-navigation system and rear-seat stereo controls, will go on sale within two years.
The old-fashioned pickup is changing, too. The Chrysler Corporation is taking the multiple-door trend on extended-cab models to the next level, offering four doors. Its Dodge Quad Cab has small, rear-hinged doors on both sides behind the large regular doors.
Other trucks are flexing new muscle. Chrysler showed the Dodge Dakota R/T, a high-performance midsize pickup with a 5.9-liter, 250-horsepower V8. And the Ford Powerforce, a concept truck based on the F-series pickup, is equipped with a potent V10 engine now available only on full-size vans.
Power enhancements also found their way into cars unveiled at the show, which opened over the weekend at McCormick Place. The 1998 Ford Contour SVT, a product of Ford's Special Vehicles Team, churns out 195 horsepower from the 2.5-liter Duratec V6, up from 170.
Toyota displayed the Solara, a convertible version of a Camry-based coupe that will be built at an assembly plant in Cambridge, Ontario. The coupe will be in showrooms in summer 1998; Toyota hasn't decided whether it will actually produce the convertible.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Lexus SLV is intended to be a sport utility vehicle with the manners of a car. (Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A.)

HEADLINE: BENEFITS

 BODY:

African-American Relations
TUESDAY -- Kofi Annan, Secretary General of the United Nations, is to speak on United States-Africa relations, and Representative Charles B. Rangel of Manhattan will receive the first annual Ron Brown Award, named for the late Commerce Secretary, at a dinner at the Sheraton New York. The event will benefit the African-American Institute, which promotes relations between the United States and Africa. Talking Drums, a Ghanaian musical group, will perform and there will be an auction of African art. The evening begins with a cocktail reception at 6:30. Black tie or national dress. Tickets, $175, from (212) 838-2660.
 
Help Yourself
TUESDAY -- Stone Phillips, an anchor of "Dateline NBC," will be the host of the first annual awards program for self-help books. The evening, entitled "Books for a Better Life," will benefit the New York City Chapter of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, and will be held at the Millennium Broadway hotel, 145 West 44th Street. Cocktails and hors d'oeuvres at 6. The announcement of the awards will follow in the Hudson Theater, next door. Tickets, $175, from (212) 463-7787. 

A Sporting Dinner
WEDNESDAY -- A buffet dinner and silent auction of sports memorabilia will benefit the Phipps Community Development Corporation, which provides social, educational and vocational programs for New York City youths. Chefs from New York restaurants, including Don Pintabona of the TriBeCa Grill and Henry Chung of B. Smith's, will prepare dishes for the event, to begin at 6 at the Play-by-Play restaurant in Madison Square Garden. After dinner, guests are to attend the St. John's-Syracuse basketball game. Tickets, $125, or $75 for the dinner alone, from (212) 243-9090, ext. 292.
 
Lifting a Voice
THURSDAY -- The singer Michael Bolton will receive an award and perform at a dinner-dance at the Pierre. The black-tie evening will raise money for Mothers' Voices United to End AIDS. Cocktails at 6:45. Tickets, $500, from (212) 730-2777.
 
Preserving Popular Music
THURSDAY -- Celebrity disk jockeys, including the actor Matt Dillon, the fashion designer Todd Oldham and Monica Lynch, the president of Tommy Boy Records, will spin records at a dance party to benefit the Archive of Contemporary Music, which preserves recordings of popular music from around the world. The event, to be held at S.O.B.'s, 204 Varick Street (Houston Street), will begin at 8 P.M. and offers hors d'oeuvres, an open bar and a raffle. Tickets, $100, from (212) 226-6967.
 
Valentine's Day Vignettes
FRIDAY -- Bailey House, which provides housing for people with AIDS, will benefit from a buffet dinner and an auction at the Puck Building, starting at 6 P.M. Robert Monk of Sotheby's and Lorna Kelly, a former Sotheby's auctioneer, are to conduct the auction of Valentine's Day-inspired fantasy room settings created by Cynthia Rowley and other designers. Also to be offered are works by artists, including Kenny Scharf, Louise Bourgeois, Robert Rauschenberg and Polly Apfelbaum. Tickets, $75, from (212) 245-6570, or $100 at the door.
 
For Art Education
FRIDAY -- A party and silent auction at the New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway (Houston Street), will benefit the College Art Association's Professional Development Fellowships for graduate students and recent graduates in art and art history. The evening will begin at 8 P.M. and include an open bar and hors d'oeuvres. Tickets, $35, from (212) 691-1051, ext. 209.
 
Rock-and-Roll With a Heart
FRIDAY -- Joey Ramone, Ronnie Specter and Black Flamingo will be among the performers at a concert at Coney Island High, a club at 15 St. Marks Place, between Second and Third Avenues in Manhattan, to benefit God's Love We Deliver. Doors will open at 8:30 P.M. Tickets, $10, from (212) 674-7959, or $12 at the door.
 
To Rebuild Haiti
SATURDAY -- President Rene Preval of Haiti is scheduled to speak about Haitian economic redevelopment projects at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria. The evening will benefit the National Organization for the Advancement of Haitians, a Haitian-American organization that channels health, education and economic redevelopment aid to Haiti. Cocktails at 7 P.M. Black tie. Tickets, $250, from (800) 201-3714.

HEADLINE: The Bloch Who Left Block

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
EVEN as a teen-ager, Thomas Bloch aimed to become chief executive of H & R Block, the company founded by his father, Henry, and his uncle Richard.
He cut high school classes to join his father on business trips, eagerly signed on as a tax preparer immediately after finishing college and rose to president of tax operations before he turned 28. In 1992, he was named chief executive. 
 No wonder Mr. Bloch, now 42, recalls the April day nearly two years ago -- when he announced his intention to quit the job that had once been his dream in favor of teaching -- as "the first time in my life I didn't have a road map."
His father, like everyone else in the company, was surprised by the announcement. But the senior Mr. Bloch said he was pleased that his son had the courage to move on if he was no longer enjoying the job.
Thomas Bloch had no teaching credentials, but he eventually found a welcoming classroom at St. Francis Xavier, a Catholic elementary school at the edge of a poor, mostly black neighborhood in Kansas City, Mo. In addition to teaching at St. Francis, Mr. Bloch is taking education classes across the street at a community college. He says he hopes his experience will one day make him an authoritative voice for innovation in education.
"I'm going after a totally different kind of fulfillment," Mr. Bloch said, describing his goal of mixing more time for his wife and two sons with work that is focused on people who struggle with poverty and other inner-city woes. He said that leaving behind his former job, at which he earned $618,000 in his last full year, did not create a financial hardship. At the time he left, his holdings in Block were worth $13 million.
"When you are a C.E.O. in a public company," he said, "you are fairly removed from where the good is really being done."
Apparently, plenty of other high-powered professionals harbor similar feelings. Mr. Bloch says he gets calls from business executives and others at the top of the economic mountain whenever a news article about his move appears.
Mr. Bloch is not the only family member open to change.
His uncle, whom Mr. Bloch credits for the entrepreneurial drive that fueled Block's early growth, stepped down as chief executive in 1976, after the company's first wave of expansion, but remained chairman. After recovering from lung cancer, diagnosed in 1977, he stayed on until 1982 when he resigned to devote himself to sponsoring cancer-related projects.
And his father, who is still the company's chairman, managed to stay involved while gracefully and cheerfully turning over power first to his son and then to outside successors, a feat that is far from commonplace in family-bred businesses. BARNABY J. FEDER

HEADLINE: Day of Whines and Roses;
Proposing Marriage? Make It Short, Sweet and Real

BYLINE: By LOIS SMITH BRADY 

 BODY:
TO propose to Bronwen Hruska, Graham Rayman left a letter on a table in their Manhattan apartment, along with a bottle of wine, a glass and a tape he made of their favorite Van Morrison songs. In the letter, Mr. Rayman, a 30-year-old writer, explained why he wanted to spend his life with her, instructed her to put on the tape, drink some wine and think about her answer. If it was yes, he would be waiting at 9 P.M. at their regular hangout, the Paris Commune in Greenwich Village.
"It was a very heartfelt and real proposal," said Ms. Hruska, 31, a screenwriter. "It would have been embarrassing for him to get down on one knee in front of the maitre d' of some fancy restaurant. That would have taken away from what it was all about -- Graham and me." 
 On Friday, many men and women will live through a moment so momentous it verges on an out-of-body experience: they will propose, or be proposed to. Indeed, Valentine's is by far the biggest day of the year for asking the big question. And for them, wedding experts offer this advice: like Mr. Rayman, "think real."
Some people may still imagine extravagant proposals involving billboards, skywriting or buckets of champagne, but the loud, fantasy-filled presentations of the 1980's have been overtaken by proposals that are emotional rather than sensational, more candlelight than neon in spirit.
Joy Lewis, the owner of Mrs. John L. Strong Fine Stationery in New York, which has engraved wedding invitations since the 1930's, describes marriage proposals as if they were shoes: from Mary Janes to Dr. Martins, each decade has its own particular style.
"The 50's was the time when women flirted and waited for proposals," said Ms. Lewis, who calls herself an "arbiter of decorum" and often advises clients on the latest etiquette. "During the 60's there just weren't proposals because no one wanted to get married. In the 80's, it was limousines with moon roofs and couples talking about their dream dog and their dream house and their fantasies of a dream wedding. It was the time of thinking about weddings more than about marriage. Now, people are thinking about marriage. There's more focus on honesty and reality."
And that can present a challenge, even to today's more sensitive proposer. "As the world gets more impersonal, people crave intimacies that really make a difference," said Marcy Blum, a longtime wedding consultant in New York. "A proposal is a lot less expensive to do these days, but it requires much more thought."
Men and women at the prime marrying age -- the median is 24.5 for women and 26.5 for men, the Census Bureau says -- seem skeptical about everything from politics to job security to love, and they no longer fall for the old "Let me sweep you off your feet" proposals, Jane Rinzler said. Ms. Rinzler, who conducts seminars on Generation X and is the founder of Youth Intelligence, a New York marketing company that studies trends among people in the 22-to-34 age group, finds that they want romance in a proposal, but in a down-to-earth way.
"Because Generation X-ers don't see marriage as the perfect institution and women don't expect men to come in as their prince in shining armor on a horse, everything has taken on a different meaning," Ms. Rinzler said. "It's not like the proposal is the beginning of a fantasy. This is the reality generation.
"You can't say: 'Sweetheart, don't worry. We'll get married, and our life will be perfect.' You can't say, 'I make tons of money,' because everyone knows you could get fired. The only thing you can really bank on is your trust in the person as an individual."
Indeed, when describing their proposals, some men these days sound so honest and sensitive you want to, well, marry them.
Allan DeYoung, 33, a director of new media in New York at TVSM, which publishes weekly cable-television guides, said that he wanted to propose in a way that was "romantic, creative, adventuresome and warm." Last year, he presented Kim Martins DeYoung, 32, with a large antique wicker picnic basket filled with gifts and keepsakes.
As Ms. Martins DeYoung remembers it, "There was a mystery book I love; my favorite perfume; a bottle of tequila, because I surprised him by drinking tequila shots on our first date; a bag of chocolate chips, because I'm a chocolate fiend; a roll of quarters, because I love bubble gum from quarter machines; a beautiful candle; Chiclets; matchbooks from all the restaurants we had gone to while we were dating."
When she reached the bottom of the basket, she found a Scrabble board -- she often beats him at the game -- with letters glued to it that spelled, "Will You Marry Me?"
"The most meaningful thing about that box was the thought that went into it," said Ms. Martins DeYoung, the vice president for merchandising at Armani Exchange stores. "It showed he wasn't coming to me because I strong-armed him. He was coming to me because it felt right in his heart."
Because the basket was filled with things that were more sentimental than expensive, she said, it showed that he was committed to providing for her not so much financially as emotionally.
"It isn't like he's providing me with jewels and clothing," she said. "He provides for me in the sense that he listens to me and understands who I am. I view him as a life partner and my soul mate. A friend recently said to me, 'Allan takes care of your heart.' "
Frank Porcelli, a 33-year-old equities salesman in New York, also decided to go for a small, homey touch. He proposed to Jennifer Giordano, 25, by hiding a diamond ring inside a vintage cookie jar exactly like one her mother used to have. He filled it with vanilla wafers, her favorites, and hid the ring among them.
When he gave the jar to her, it was wrapped in a paper bag Mr. Giordano described as "the oldest, crinkliest paper bag I've ever seen."
Ms. Giordano ran through the apartment screaming. "I absolutely loved it," she said. "I grew up with the same cookie jar, with vanilla wafers in it all the time. Anyone can go to a fancy restaurant, but this was very unique and romantic. Men are finally realizing what's important in a relationship -- the little things."
A YUN HALLIDAY, 31, an actress who was partly inspired by several pals who asked their boyfriends to marry them, used little more than glue, paint and paper to put her proposal together. She said she wanted to make it as simple as possible. So one night last year, she greeted her live-in boyfriend, Greg Kotis, 31, at the airport with a hand-painted sign.
"I got the courage up to go to the 24-hour grocery and buy a big piece of red poster board and a little bouquet of flowers they had on sale," she recalled. "I wrote, 'Will You Marry Me, Greggy K.?' on the poster. I felt like I was painting someone's locker in high school. It was homemade, and homemade is our esthetic -- it's cheap, and you have to embrace its flaws, and it's from the heart."
Ms. Halliday added: "It seemed odd to follow some Emily Post outdated propriety and wait for him to ask. Sometimes I pick up magazines and think, 'Wow, there are still articles about how to capture a man.' That's so foreign to my experience."
(By the way, Mr. Kotis said yes, and they were married last November.)
No matter how homespun proposals become, one traditional element remains: the surprise.
When Stuart Sclater-Booth, 27, proposed to Kirsten Oxboel, also 27, they had been living together for a while. Even though they had talked about marriage often, he still wanted to surprise her with the actual question.
Last summer, while on a monthlong trip out West, he led her on a long hike that ended at a picturesque spot known in the area as the Marrying Tree. He knelt and offered her a bunch of wildflowers he had picked along the trail, held together by a diamond ring.
Like a 50's bride, she burst into tears; like a 90's man, he did, too.
"I think it's more emotional with a surprise," said Mr. Sclater-Booth, a graduate student in economics at Boston University. "If we had shopped for the ring and planned it together, we wouldn't have had the moment of hugging and tears that we had."
Not everyone appreciates such sentimentality. When Kim Martins DeYoung's father heard about her proposal and the wicker basket, he called Mr. DeYoung and said: "Are you crazy? You're going to give men a bad name!"

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;
New Split on Columbus, Over BID Plan

BYLINE: By JANE H. LII 

 BODY:
In the last 10 years, as Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue have enjoyed an economic revival of sorts, Columbus Avenue has lagged behind.
Touted as an alternative to Madison Avenue in the late 1970's and early 80's, Columbus attracted hip clothing stores and restaurants, but many closed or moved after the stock market crash in October 1987. Business declined further during a two-year, $65 million project in which the city dug up the avenue from 59th to 110th Streets to replace sewers and repair the roadbed. The work was finished late last year. 
 Today, many landlords say the avenue's economic climate remains so dismal that they have either reduced rents or held off collecting increases to which they are entitled. "At this point, Columbus Avenue is still about 20 percent below the market rent," said Robert C. Quinlan, president of Walker Malloy & Company, a real-estate concern at Columbus and 70th Street.
Mr. Quinlan is trying to form a Business Improvement District along Columbus from 67th to 96th Streets. The proposal calls for the approximately 170 property owners to be annually assessed $$300 to $2,000, depending on the size of their holdings. The BID would have an annual budget of $350,000 and would focus on issues like sanitation, security and attracting more shoppers, Mr. Quinlan said. He said about 74 property owners have indicated support, but acknowledged that some of the 300 businesses that would come under the BID are resisting the idea. Many business owners voiced anger about a clause in their commercial leases that allows property owners to pass along the BID fee to them.
And Stewart Schneider, who owns the Associated grocery story on the block between 82d and 83d Streets, said he feared that formation of the BID would give the city an excuse to reduce police and sanitation services.
Some merchants, like Gerald Spiegel, who owns Indians on Columbus, a fine arts and jewelry store, says a business district would eventually drive out small businesses. "When business picks up, big businesses would want to come in and the landlords will jack up the rent," Mr. Spiegel said.
But Michael Weinstein, who owns an Italian restaurant and a bakery on the avenue, said those fears were groundless. "The movement of rent doesn't have anything to do with the BID," said Mr. Weinstein, whose other businesses are associated with the Times Square BID and the 34th Street Partnership. "It's driven by supply and demand.
Forming the BID requires the approval of 51 percent of property owners along the strip. JANE H. LII

HEADLINE: Zero-Risk Leadership

BYLINE: By Richard Darman; Richard Darman served as the director of the Office of Management and Budget and a member of President Bush's Cabinet from 1989 to 1993. He is the author of "Who's in Control?"

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
President Clinton opened his State of the Union Address by asking Americans to "rise to the decisive moment." In an unscripted aside, he added that he was given a second term "to take the tough decisions." So it seems fair to ask: What exactly are the tough decisions he recommends?
He wants to "make a nation and a world better than any we have known," provide all Americans "the best education in the world," balance the budget, provide middle-class tax relief, advance medical science, build stronger families, end bigotry, and even have "our children grow up next to parks, not poison." Presumably, these are not the toughest of calls. 
 But it is hard to identify what tough calls have been made. The President seems to have over-learned the lesson of his first-term health fiasco. Instead of grand policy schemes, he has shifted to the other extreme: a laundry list of risk-free initiatives. Most of these are unobjectionable: $11 million more for food safety; 100,000 more master teachers; 500 more waste sites to be cleaned up; and so on. Yet, together, the initiatives amount to policy tokenism writ large. They are not scaled to meet the challenges the President has defined. And they leave tough decisions for another time.
The President's budget reflects this approach exactly. A balanced budget is now within relatively easy reach, thanks to the budget agreements of 1990 and 1993, the Federal Reserve's anti-inflationary policy, sustained economic growth since 1991 and private-sector restraint of health costs. With little pain, the deficit can be reduced to zero -- even as popular tax and spending tokens are put forward. That is what the President has proposed.
The problem, of course, is that unless more difficult decisions are made with regard to Social Security and Medicare, the deficit will reach zero (or a token surplus) for at best a few years. Then it moves back up to hundreds of billions of dollars as the baby boom generation enters retirement. To prevent a return of bloated deficits, and to avoid painful adjustments of future benefits and taxes, politically tough decisions on the big middle-class entitlement programs must be made well in advance of the boomers' retirement. That is, now.
The necessary decisions are hardly mysterious. They involve a combination of the following: correcting the overstated cost of living index; reducing transfers and subsidies to wealthier beneficiaries; adjusting the retirement age to reflect advances in healthy life expectancy; and, within reasonable limits, increasing reliance upon market-based approaches to Social Security and Medicare. These proposals have been thoroughly analyzed. All they require is prompt decision.
And that is what the President has explicitly chosen to avoid. Indeed, he has proposed that only after he and Congress have taken the easy approach to a transitory balanced budget should an effort be made to "agree to a bipartisan process" to reform Social Security and Medicare. Thus, not only are essential substantive decisions deferred; so, too, are decisions about the very procedure for deciding!
This habit of avoiding politically tough decisions is not confined to the budget. It is evident throughout the President's program -- even in the areas about which he seems most deeply concerned.
Education is intended as his defining priority. Here, the laundry list of initiatives and exhortations is especially long. In trying to understand the President's tough decisions one might wonder: When middle-class entitlements require restraint, should new ones be created? If the goal is to make American education best in the world, and if the lag is in elementary and secondary school performance, should additional scarce resources be allocated disproportionately to higher education? Strangely, the President's answers are yes. He seems determined to offer a little something for every constituency.
Yet why don't initiatives like an extended school year or market-oriented vouchers for public and private schools make his list -- even if only as worthy experiments? They would reasonably be expected to improve performance and innovation. But by seriously challenging the conventional, change-resistant education establishment, they would entail political risk. The President, by ignoring such initiatives, underlines the driving logic of his "tough" decisions: The politically inconvenient must be rejected.
The effect of the President's zero-political-risk rule is made clear by considering his heart-felt reference to Isaiah 58:12 in the State of the Union Message. He called for Americans to be "repairers of the breach" of racism and bigotry. In the abstract, it seems courageous to put this high on the national agenda -- for the breach is wide. Yet when it comes to particulars, one is again left to wonder: What exactly are the tough decisions Americans are asked to rise to at this decisive moment?
The President has noted a few encouraging statistics. But for much of urban America, reality has not been getting better. Racial segregation is in some ways worse than it was in the explosive 60's. A destructive drug culture is more deeply embedded in America's ghettos. Guns are more prevalent. Random killing is up. Lines between the criminal world and the mainstream are blurred. Public education is strained beyond its capacity to help. Job growth and job opportunities are elsewhere. Social, family and physical infrastructure have all decomposed. An honest reckoning of the cost of addressing this combination of problems would be staggering.
To meet the President's goals of "opportunity, responsibility and community" would require huge commitments from the public, private and volunteer sectors. For those who like such analogies, the necessary investment would exceed the scale of the Marshall Plan and Desert Storm combined. It is measurable in the hundreds of billions of dollars, not in tokens. Even if it were approached incrementally through a series of bold, urban experiments, a serious effort would mean much tougher decisions on the budget. It would not be politically convenient.
And, quite obviously, it is not the approach the President has chosen. His approach to the racial divide combines high rhetoric with low investment. To the inspiration of Isaiah, it adds a political sprinkling of underfunded "empowerment zones." And it leaves most of the practical challenge of repairing the breach to 21st-century decision makers.
It is often noted that the President is no longer campaigning for office; he is running for his place in history. He cites important decisions from America's past as models for America's future. In examining heroic analogies, however, he might do well to observe that much of America's remarkable achievement is the result of courageous risk-taking. And zero-risk leadership is a contradiction in terms.
In a democracy, the challenge of leadership is not to find the path of least political risk. Society can find that on its own. Heading in the lowest-risk direction can yield short-term popularity. But it is an unlikely route to greatness -- and rarely the best way to what President Clinton called a "land of new promise."

TYPE: Op-Ed

COMPANY: MEDICARE (59%);

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;
Church Group Battles Pathmark Proposal

BYLINE: By JANE H. LII 

 BODY:
The block bounded by 144th and 145th Streets, Frederick Douglass Boulevard and Bradhurst Avenue has been an eyesore to local residents for more than 20 years, its three dilapidated buildings on a city-owned, garbage-strewn lot dwelling places for rats and the homeless.
Cuts in government funds stalled the effort by Harlem Churches for Community Improvement to build a retail center with some 150 units of affordable housing above. But now, with the prospect of an economic boom from the nearby Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, developers are vying for a chance to build on the block. This has fueled resentment among Harlem Churches and other local groups that say the city is taking control from them. 
 At issue is a proposal first floated during the Dinkins administration to build a 45,000-square-foot Pathmark supermarket to anchor a residential-retail complex that would take up most of the block. Advocates say that such a store would serve tens of thousands of local residents who now pay more for inferior goods at smaller stores and that it would create well-paying union jobs.
But Harlem Churches for Community Improvement is angry that the city has not allowed the group to select the developer for the site. It says the Pathmark would bring far too much traffic.
The Rev. Preston Washington, president and chief executive officer of Harlem Churches, wants Alpha I Marketing Corporation, which owns the trademark to grocery stores like C-Town and Bravo and is lining up local investors, to build the mixed-use complex. "We want a store that's owned by local businessmen to better serve our needs," he said.
Joining the fight against the Pathmark is Community Board 10, which voted to oppose a zoning variance that would allow such a store on the site. The city has agreed to consider the board's recommendation.
The board chairman, Willie Walker, said members would like to see the retail portion devoted to small SoHo-style boutiques, to give the area a more upscale image, and to have a supermarket built on another city-owned lot, on 155th Street between Macombs Place and Frederick Douglass Boulevard. "We want a quaint residential area," Mr. Walker said. "We don't want people from all over the city coming here to get their groceries."
Sheila Greene, a spokeswoman for the city's Department of Housing Preservation, said the city would issue a request for proposals to develop the block in the spring and would then choose a developer. JANE H. LII

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
A Quick Guide to Big Ideas, if You Didn't Get to Davos

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

DATELINE: DAVOS, Switzerland

 BODY:
DAVOS, the shorthand by which the World Economic Forum's annual jamboree in this ski resort is known, is over for this year. Nelson Mandela, Yasir Arafat, Bill Gates and Jack Welch, among others, spoke. And while they were not talking -- in fact, even while they were up there on the podium -- the business elite used their view from these Alpine peaks to ponder and discuss where the world is and where it may be going, in forums large and small.
So your company declined to pay the $20,000 entry fee, plus expenses, to send you to Davos? Do not despair. If Tom Peters, the consultant, can offer "Business School in a Box," surely what goes on in Davos can be summarized in, say, 1,200 words. Here's the skinny you need to make it look like you were here. 
Think of Davos as a kind of global Renaissance weekend, only bigger, longer (six days) and more serious. With as many as nine panels happening at once -- and many more, somewhat lighter topics (like Chinese medicine and the future of movies and television) programmed for discussion over daily lunches and dinners -- Davos is a pot-au-feu of conversation starters and conversation stoppers.
Except for the plenary session speeches, Davos conversation is considered to be off the record. Here, lacking attributions to protect both the innocent and the guilty, are some of the more thought-provoking tidbits.
 
GLOBALIZATION This year's focus may have been "Building the Network Society," but the Globalization Question reigned in the way that the German Question once dominated European politics. No one doubted the inevitability of globalization, which is a product of the triumph of capitalism. But many fear it, for many reasons.
Some see globalization as the villain behind increased poverty, unemployment and inequality. They believe it threatens the sovereignty of nations, especially small ones that feel obliged to court international capital no matter the impact on their social and development agendas. Direct foreign investment, someone pointed out, is growing faster than international trade.
Globalization may be harmful, too, because it homogenizes the world's cultures. National cultural differences are being sacrificed on the mega-brand altar of companies like Disney and MTV, which thrive by peddling the same products everywhere.
Paradoxically, some experts say quick and nimble small companies may well end up being more powerful than huge corporate titans that fall behind in technology. One man even predicted the demise of America's largest corporations.
 
THE INFORMATION AGE In contrast to globalization, the arrival at last of the Information Revolution won many more plaudits than raspberries. In the political sphere, for example, information technology is seen as undermining repressive governments.
 
GOVERNMENT One drawback to the information age is that it exposes and demystifies all governments, exacerbating the loss of confidence in them. In some areas, governments are struggling to make themselves relevant.
Yet governments themselves contribute mightily to that loss of faith. They tend to do things that succeed in the short term but fail in the long term. For example, the social welfare systems that European nations erected after World War II to protect people are now hurting them, as they steer away jobs and wealth. Unemployment is rampant.
Plutocrats know that these social systems must be dismantled -- after all, not a single net new job has been created in Europe since 1970 -- but they have done nothing to create a constituency for change.
 
BANKS The very existence of banks is in doubt. Some experts believe that new forms of commerce, like the use of cybermoney, will make them obsolete. Others predict that they will thrive in the information age because they are the only institutions trustworthy enough to make electronic commerce work.

CRIME Like everything else, crime is going global. Experts expect organized crime -- drug trafficking, money laundering, financial fraud and corruption -- to increase. They worry about increases in digital terrorism, with hackers wreaking havoc on information networks. And they fear the emergence of black markets in nuclear material that the Soviet republics never tracked after their empire broke up.

HEALTH Nearly half of United States cancer patients are now surviving at least five years -- and the challenge to health care providers is to make that percentage, at the least, hold for the rest of the world.
Scientists are scrambling to discover genetic secrets, but one avenue of exploration -- testing for genetic susceptibility to various diseases -- carries its own risk: nearly everyone will be at risk for some disorder. How genetic profiles will be used -- including by insurance companies -- and who will have access to them remains a huge question. True confidentiality is unlikely.
And what will happen if courts accept the idea that some criminal behavior has a genetic basis?

THE ENVIRONMENT Energy is still being used -- and wasted -- in vast amounts, degrading the environment. Some experts say the only answer is to reduce energy consumption, to make people live more frugally. But others say information technologies can help countries and consumers cut back by eliminating the waste. For example, better traffic management could slash the gasoline wasted in traffic jams.

LEARNING Education must reach more people -- and it must go to them rather than forcing individuals to go to schools to learn. People may then see education as a lifelong activity, rather than something that takes place when they are young.
It's also not too late to join the information age -- worldwide, fewer than 5 percent of people use computers, although the proportion in the United States is upward of 30 percent.

POPULATION By 2000, half the world's population will be under 20, with profound consequences. The vast majority will live in poor nations, many in the streets of mega-cities that cannot provide jobs.
Worriers are certain that these leaps in population will test the world's ability to feed everyone. Still, recent surveys in China show that the amount of arable land there is greater than previously thought, and some scientists see biotechnology as the savior that will increase food production. No matter what happens, food may well cost everyone a lot more.

THE FRENZY Are you tired? Just wait. The pace of life in the developed world will only get faster, leading some to suggest that some people will opt out of post-industrial life altogether and others to predict a big business in building sanctuaries for the harried. Alienation is a huge risk.
Considering that a huge part of Davos is the talk that goes on in the corridors, attendees had a good Davos if they covered anywhere close to the ground outlined here. If it all sounds squishy, however, remember that Davos functions best when it provides questions, not answers. After all, Elie Wiesel said at one meeting, "Questions unite people, and answers divide them."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Up in the Swiss Alps, a global Renaissance weekend that lasts six days each year. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
To Get More Defensive, Try Cost-Cutting Companies

BYLINE: By MICHAEL BRUSH 

 BODY:
WITH the market looking so pricey these days, judicious stock picking may soon gain on broad market bets as an investment strategy. And while selective investors can use many different guideposts to pick companies, one yardstick sounds a very familiar theme: downsizing and similar cost-cutting maneuvers.
Of course, many companies have already improved profits by laying off workers or otherwise revamping. But more are on the way. "This theme is mature, but it is continuing," said Michael Metz, the chief investment strategist at Oppenheimer & Company. "It is still going to be an important theme and a major source of investment opportunities in 1997." 
 Restructuring companies can be found in many sectors; Mr. Metz cited the health, financial and technology industries as good places to look. Companies in Europe, where downsizing has not been as extensive as in the United States, are also good possibilities; Mr. Metz singled out Germany.
"German industry is going to rationalize and get rid of underperforming assets," he said.
Cost cutters can look good in this lofty market because their stocks are often relatively cheap; indeed, these corporate revampings would not be necessary if the enterprises were already lean and mean.
These companies may also appeal to investors who are worried about a market downturn. After all, much of their earnings growth will come from an activity -- cost-cutting -- that management can control. These stocks may not offer as much downside protection as traditional defensive equities like electric utilities, but in a sour economy their bottom lines may hold up better than those of companies that count on sales growth alone to improve earnings.
But analysts warn investors to avoid companies whose earnings growth relies solely on restructuring. "Cost-cutting in and of itself is fine, but if you don't have revenue growth, where do you go from there?" said John Maack, portfolio manager of the Crabbe Huson Equity fund.
Investors should also remember that these companies' stocks can zig and zag before the final payoff. "When you are restructuring a company, things can get delayed, and they don't always go exactly according to plan," said Robert Rodriguez, portfolio manager of the FPA Capital fund, which often invests in such enterprises. "Companies that are restructuring have more control over their economic ship of state. But you still have a degree of volatility because of that uncertainty."
One company that is just beginning to restructure is KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, which trades here as American depository receipts and closed on Friday at $30, just 12.33 times its estimated earnings per share for 1997. Last fall, KLM announced a plan to save $539 million by 2000.
"They are closing some unprofitable routes and planning some head-count reductions, and there are some plans to negotiate more stringently with pilots and employees on wage increases," said Nick Whitridge, the manager of the Babson Value fund, which owns KLM shares. "It is a pretty aggressive move on their part."
By mid-1998, fare increases and fuller planes should begin to substantially increase revenue, said Mr. Whitridge, who predicts an average of 10 percent growth in annual revenue over the next five years.
Another restructuring play is Michaels Stores, whose more than 500 outlets make it the largest specialty retailer of arts, crafts and decorative items in the United States. Its new managers, brought in last year, have been improving the company's inventory management and product mix.
The company has already put in place a new "point of sale" inventory control system in its stores, and is now doing the same at its warehouses. It is also encouraging store managers to order more products through this internal system, rather than through outside suppliers, from whom they often over-order.
These changes will help lower the company's inventory costs, as will a move to insure that high-volume items are never out of stock.
On the sales side, Michaels has been adjusting its merchandise mix to focus on its more profitable goods. The new inventory system can help there, too, by better keeping track of which products are selling best.
Mr. Rodriguez, whose fund owns more than 10 percent of the Michaels stock outstanding, expects these efforts to start paying off in 1998. "Their turnover should increase and the level of markdowns should decrease," he said, "because they will be cycling inventory more rapidly." He said operating margins should rise to about 8 percent, well above the 3 percent the company posted in 1996, exclusive of a $22 million write-down in inventory last September.
The stock, which closed on Friday at $13.125, should be in the mid-$30's within about two years, said Mr. Rodriguez, whose fund has had an average annual return of 22.8 percent for the five years through 1996.
Another company that should benefit from lower costs is National Steel, which had $2.95 billion in revenues for the year ended in December. By reducing the size of its work force through attrition, the company is trimming labor costs by 2 percent to 3 percent a year. New equipment and maintenance procedures are also cutting expenses.
Indeed, Mr. Maack, whose fund owns shares of National Steel, said the company pared steel production costs by about $16 a ton last year, from $512 a ton. It expects to cut another $44 a ton over the next four years, for an overall savings of almost 12 percent. The company is also shifting its product mix to higher-quality steel with bigger profit margins, and hopes to benefit from an upswing in domestic steel demand resulting from booms in auto making and commercial and industrial construction.
ECONOMIES of scale -- lowering average costs by getting bigger -- are the goal at Tesoro Petroleum, an oil and gas company. Tesoro has three divisions -- exploration and production, refining and marketing, and distribution. The last has been by far the smallest, but to save on costs Tesoro recently bought a distribution company.
And some analysts expect more of the same. The enlargement of Tesoro's distribution business "is a good model for what they are going to do with these two larger divisions," said Robert Kleinschmidt, who manages the Tocqueville Fund, which invests in Tesoro and other companies that are revamping. He said he believes that Tesoro, which has a strong balance sheet after winning a contract dispute, is now actively buying more oil fields and may also soon purchase an exploration and production company.
Tesoro will probably also soon form a joint venture involving its Alaska refineries, a move intended to propel it into other markets, Mr. Kleinschmidt said. He expects that this plan and the acquisition strategy will double Tesoro's stock price in three years.
