LENGTH: 3500 words

HEADLINE: From Storefronts to Supermarkets

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo.

 BODY:
LIKE 14 million other Americans last year, Muriel Page turned to H & R Block for help in filling out her tax return. She was pleased enough with the results that Block caught her attention with the flier it mailed last summer announcing its recent entry into the mortgage business.
"It's hard to get in with the big banks around here and I haven't heard the names of the other mortgage companies," Ms. Page said. 
 She ended up refinancing her home in Esmont, Va., a small town south of Charlottesville, with a $71,000 mortgage from Block that cut her interest rate by 2.5 percentage points.
In just over a year of experimenting with mortgages, Block was able to put together a package of $102 million in mortgages that it either originated or acquired from other lenders, and sold it to institutional investors late last month. This year, Block is expanding its mortgage-origination efforts to more than 30 tax preparation stores in Colorado, Indiana, North Carolina and Virginia.
Peddling mortgages year-round is a far cry from filling out millions of tax forms in the space of a few weeks, but it is just part of a smorgasbord of initiatives that Block is pursuing in the hope of re-creating itself as a faster-growing, broad-based financial services giant.
"It just doesn't make sense to have 14 million customers and sell them only one product," said Thomas L. Zimmerman, head of Block's tax operations.
Block, which had earnings of $177.2 million on revenues of $1.7 billion in the year that ended on April 30, is hardly giving up the tax business. In fact, it figures it can gain double-digit growth in the next two years simply from working more aggressively to expand that business. But the 42-year-old company wants to also become known for financial software, annuities and other retirement packages, life insurance and investments like mutual funds to build and broaden its customer base.
The company is also experimenting with using its storefronts, many of which stand empty for much of the year, to process college loan applications and immigration documents.
And it aims to turn its Internet site -- which is at http://www.conductor.com/ -- into a financial cybermall where visitors can trade stocks, check credit balances, connect to on-line banks and buy software like Kiplinger's Taxcut program for home tax preparers.
"Our most significant growth opportunities are with financial services delivered on line," said William Anderson, who heads Block's push into new financial products.
If Block sticks to its ambitious plans, a result will be one of the most sweeping tests of the reach of powerful brand names in financial services.
"The strategy is not illogical because they have a reputation for being trustworthy in a financial area that's pretty anxiety-ridden," said Bill Schneider, a brand management consultant at Lippincott & Margulies in San Francisco. "But it's not necessarily easy."
Indeed, it's not, even for a company with Block's strengths, which include a strong cash flow, a balance sheet free of long-term debt and experience in forming alliances with well-connected partners.
"Sears, American Express, Merrill Lynch all got killed trying to create financial supermarkets in the 1980's," said Bruce Greenwald, a professor at the Columbia University Graduate School of Business who argues that cash-rich companies in mature markets usually reward shareholders more by increasing dividends than by diversifying.
Block has tried to diversify before, without ever finding a business that fit well with its bread-and-butter tax operations. This time, Block clearly will face serious challenges trying to grow on so many new fronts from its narrow base of just 2,000 permanent employees. And while Block is used to having a market largely to itself, many of the new businesses it is thinking about are highly competitive.
WALL STREET is apparently in no rush to bet that Block's latest growth strategy will be a winner. For years, Block outperformed the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, but since 1995, the story has been very different. And this year, while the S.& P. has soared, Block's shares have been hovering around $30 -- well above last summer's bottom of $23.625 but down more than 25 percent from the 52-week high of $42.125 last February. The stock closed on Friday at $29.75.
Many investors are preoccupied with Block's struggle to sort out the woes at Compuserve Inc., the on-line computer services company that Block acquired in 1980, in one of its earlier efforts to diversify.
Shortly after Block sold just under 20 percent of the unit to the public last spring, Compuserve's earnings and share price plunged, dragged down by increased competition among on-line services and the decision by many consumers to bypass the services and go directly to the Internet. Block's shares fell along with Compuserve's. The two companies are now mired in shareholder class-action lawsuits contending that they failed to warn shareholders earlier about Compuserve's earnings plunge, and Block has been forced to shelve plans indefinitely to spin off the rest of Compuserve to its shareholders until the on-line company's tailspin has been halted and earnings are restored.
Nor does it help that Wall Street is still getting to know the new management team led by Frank L. Salizzoni, Block's third chief executive in the last two years. The upheaval began in April 1995, when Thomas Bloch, then 40, sprang some stunning news on his father, Henry, who had stayed on as chairman after passing the job of chief executive to him in 1992. The younger Mr. Bloch said he would soon be leaving the company and his lucrative job to teach at an inner-city elementary school and spend more time with his family.
After an intensive search for its first leader from outside the family, Block excited investors by recruiting Richard H. Brown from the Ameritech Corporation, where he had been vice chairman. Mr. Brown, whose tenure began in September, persuaded the board to go along with the rising shareholder interest in splitting off Compuserve, shook up top management of the tax group and pushed hard to speed the company's three-year-old strategy to expand into other financial services. But Cable and Wireless P.L.C., a leading British telecommunications company, soon came calling on Mr. Brown with an irresistible offer for him to move to London as its chief executive. He left in June, just nine months after he arrived.
Block's surprised board then turned to Mr. Salizzoni, 58, a board member for eight years who had been semiretired since resigning as president and chief operating officer of USAir in April 1995. Mr. Salizzoni became briefly famous on Wall Street during the late 1980's when he led TW Services, the owner of Denny's and other restaurant chains, in a bitter but ultimately unsuccessful attempt to stave off a $1.65 billion leveraged buyout led by Coniston Partners.
Mr. Salizzoni, the son of a Pittsburgh construction worker, had started his career as a financial analyst for Trans World Airlines and eventually became chief financial officer of the airline's holding company at a time when it also owned the Hilton Hotels Corporation and other ventures. Although admired on Wall Street for his strategic experience, he is considered to be more cautious and methodical than Mr. Brown.
MOST analysts now figure that there is no rush to either pile into the stock or to race to the exit.
"Dick Brown got the company going in the right direction, but Salizzoni is conservative," said Martin Romm, who follows Block for CS First Boston. "They are going to be prudent."
Mr. Salizzoni says his immediate priorities are to expand the tax business and to straighten out Compuserve so the spinoff can be completed. On the tax and financial services side, he promises that Wall Street and customers are going to see "lots of tests of different kinds of products."
The job of speeding up growth in the tax business is falling largely to Mr. Zimmerman, whom Mr. Brown promoted to president of H & R Block Tax Services after forcing the resignation of Harry W. Buckley in the fall of 1995. Mr. Buckley says he and Mr. Brown disagreed over how thoroughly to test new programs that might interfere with traditional services.
"When Brown arrived, the shareholder became the most important person," said Mr. Buckley, who now works as a consultant. "Under the Blochs, it was always the clients."
Mr. Zimmerman agreed that Mr. Brown brought a new culture of aggressiveness to the company. When plans were made to try marketing Bloch's tax services on 10 college campuses last year, Mr. Brown challenged the tax group to go after 500 instead. In the end, the program, built around concerts and promotional items, touched 200 campuses.
The results were disappointing. Most college students, it turns out, rely on tax preparers back home if they need help. Still, Mr. Zimmerman said that the process was energizing and that moving faster and harder on new products would pay off in the long run.
To speed the process, Block has been recruiting experienced marketers from consumer products companies. Eric Steinhouse, a longtime executive at Procter & Gamble, Kellogg and Dow Brands, was brought in as senior vice president in charge of marketing in 1994.
Five new products and services were rolled out nationally during the company's last fiscal year, more than in the previous 10 years combined. They include a simple kit for drafting wills in the home and a program to help people who prepare their own taxes to check their results. Block also began offering in-the-home tax preparation for an extra $25 for customers who are unwilling to visit one of its 4,300 company-owned offices. Franchisees, who do about a third of the business from another 4,000 or so offices in mostly rural areas, are encouraged but not required to offer the new services.
It makes sense for Block to work hard on enhancing its tax franchise. Block and its franchisees prepare more than 12 percent of all American individual tax returns, about 17 times the total of any other tax preparer. Some 70 percent of the customers are repeat visitors to its modest storefronts or to the offices in Sears, Roebuck stores that carry the Block name.
More than once since the 1970's, Block worried that the tax business had matured -- only to have new tax laws, new products or other changes rekindle its growth. In the late 1980's, business skyrocketed with the development of electronic filing and refund anticipation loans, or RAL's, which allow taxpayers to immediately receive payments covering most of their anticipated refunds. In return, they have to sign over their rights to the refunds to the banks or other financial institutions making the loans.
CONSUMER advocates complain that many taxpayers do not understand that RAL's are short-term loans with interest rates that can reach 200 percent on an annualized basis. In New York City, Block has repeatedly clashed with the Department of Consumer Affairs over advertising and scripts used by Block phone operators, with the city contending that consumers may be misled about the difference between electronic filing, which leads to quicker refunds, and RAL's.
Last month, Block, while denying any fraud, agreed to pay $250,000 to settle the latest dispute. But it is hardly backing away from RAL's. Indeed, it has formed a partnership with the Beneficial Corporation, a leading RAL lender, to invest Block cash in such loans.
RAL's aside, Block figures that its traditional business can grow rapidly over the next few years simply by opening satellite storefronts, acquiring smaller tax practices -- it bought more than 100 last year -- and raising customer retention rates to 90 percent, a level that some local offices already approach, from the current average of 70 percent.
For the last few years, Block has also been going after more upscale customers -- those earning $40,000 to $80,000 -- with a growing chain of "Premium" offices. (Block says that 80 percent of all of its customers make less than $50,000 a year.) These offices feature posher surroundings, more experienced tax preparers and service by appointment in private rooms. They also offer guarantees to not only pay interest and penalties if Block makes an error in tax preparation, as is the promise at its regular offices, but to also pay up to $5,000 of the increased tax assessment itself, for no additional fees. (Customers at regular Block offices pay $25 for $4,000 of such increased assessment protection.) Block served 643,000 Premium clients last year from about 600 Premium offices, up 16.4 percent.
Mr. Salizzoni said Block was considering opening an even more upscale chain of offices focusing on clients with incomes of $60,000 or more, although it is reluctant to invest heavily in chasing the relatively small number of taxpayers in high brackets and in competing with major accounting firms for such business.
BLOCK sees better growth opportunities for its tax business overseas. The company set up H & R Block International as a separate division last year and put Ozzie Wenich, formerly vice president for finance, in charge of expanding it.
"Taxation systems are changing everywhere," Mr. Wenich said. "There are middle classes emerging, and governments like to tax them."
Block already has more than 1,000 offices in Canada, which it entered in 1964. They handle just over 10 percent of Canada's individual tax returns, or 40 percent of those completed by paid tax preparers. More than 300 offices in Australia handle about 75 percent of that country's professionally prepared returns. Offices are also scattered in nine other countries, most of which traditionally assisted American soldiers stationed overseas.
Mr. Wenich says his first target for a big expansion will probably be Britain. Recent tax changes there have doubled the number of citizens required to file income taxes, to nine million. Block hopes to gain a foothold by acquiring a number of small accounting firms that handle tax forms and standardizing their service, but Mr. Wenich freely concedes that the strategy may not work.
"Trying to organize foreign accountants is like trying to herd cats," he said.
The long-term question for Block, though, is whether the company is such an unusual species of business animal that it is doomed to have trouble expanding out of its tax environment.
Block employs 80,000 workers at the peak of tax season (franchisees hire tens of thousands more) but just 2,000 full time. It trains almost 110,000 workers annually, starting in September. Although it signs year-round leases for offices and equipment when necessary to guarantee their availability in tax season, it still rents huge amounts of equipment and work space for a few short weeks or months a year.
"It's like starting a new business every year," says Henry W. Bloch, 74, the company's chairman, who founded the business in 1955 with his brother Richard as an accounting agency. (They used a variant of their last name to avoid having it mispronounced as "blotch.")
Block's strength has been in building relationships with consumers who are not used to being courted by most American financial institutions.
"People talk to you about everything," said Sophie Wolan, who has been a tax preparer for 15 years, first in a Block office in Chicago and now in a Block Premium office in nearby Elmwood Park, Ill. "They'll even ask you to recommend doctors and dentists."
OVER the years, though, Block has repeatedly bobbled attempts to transfer that consumer confidence and its skills to other enterprises, to sell its customers more products or to find other uses for its offices. Many such experiments have been timid, in part because of the need to make sure tax operations are not impeded and that no information gathered in tax preparation is used illegally for other purposes. But even when Block has moved more aggressively to diversify into related fields or to acquire companies with new technology that could help the tax business, the synergies have been limited.
Compuserve is only the latest and most prominent example. The company, which is based in Columbus, Ohio, was an insurer with spare computer capacity that it marketed to other businesses when Block acquired it in 1980. But the spread of personal computers, the Internet and competition among on-line services forced Block to keep redefining how the two companies might interact. The idea that Compuserve would provide electronic expertise and be Block's primary route for distributing electronic financial services fell by the wayside.
"The more they grew, the less we understood their business," Mr. Bloch said. "Once America Online went public and people saw how highly valued it was, shareholders became almost belligerent, demanding we separate the two companies."
Through subsidiaries, Block has also tried its hand at running a temporary-employment agency, selling business software and conducting management seminars. It has dabbled in travel, advertising, office supplies and insurance.
From 1980 to 1987, it was the major financial backer in the nationwide expansion of Hyatt Legal Services, a chain of storefront legal clinics intended to serve the same kinds of clients that Block has long helped with taxes.
"Everyone has to file a tax return every year, but not everybody needs a lawyer," Mr. Bloch said several years ago, explaining why the Hyatt alliance never made sense for Block. After Block pulled out, Hyatt retreated from storefronts and now concentrates on selling prepaid legal plans to business.
On the bright side, Block's shareholders have rarely had much to complain about. Even when its plans have not worked strategically, Block has usually managed to get out at a profit, or at least with minimal losses. Compuserve, acquired for around $20 million, was profitable for years, and the initial public offering of 19.9 percent of the shares last spring raised $519 million. Interim Services, a temporary-employment agency acquired for $49 million in 1991 and combined with a small employment business Block already owned, was sold in 1993 for $188 million.
Such results, together with the growth of the tax business, have meant that an investor who bought 100 shares of Block when it went public at $4 a share in 1962 would have 41,206 shares today, worth around $1.2 million, assuming reinvestment of dividends. The compound annual growth rate works out to about 25 percent.
The more recent softness in the stock underscores why Block needs to break out of its strategic straitjacket. And business strategists say the steps the company is taking to branch out into financial services are crucial.
"They will have to invest heavily in consumer marketing to have customers make the link between what the brand has historically stood for -- tax preparation -- to other products," said Joel Friedman, a partner in the San Francisco office of Andersen Consulting. "If you can demonstrate once that you have successfully created a new set of relationships around your brand, it becomes easier and easier."
Block is not relying solely on its own name. It entered the credit card business first with a Compuserve Visa affinity card and then with the more generically named Websource Visa card. It markets Kiplinger's Taxcut, Home Legal Adviser and Small Business Attorney software. And the conductor.com Internet site is more a conduit for others to sell their services, for a fee paid to Block, than for Block to market products under its own name.
"This will allow us to expand our marketing to customers with summer and winter homes in our area," said Carol Cone, vice president for operations at Mascoma Savings Bank of Lebanon, N.H., which began offering bill payment and other electronic services last month through that Internet site.
Where the Block name is being used -- in the new mortgage business, for example -- the company is contracting with others to provide it with qualified personnel, including licensed brokers, and crucial services, like payment collections and disbursements.
"The key is to take it at a speed you can manage, and Block is doing that," said David Everitt, a longtime mortgage banker who owns NF Investments in Griffin, Ga., a company that is helping Block get into a specialized area: mortgages for homeowners who are unable to secure Federal loan guarantees.
Still, Mr. Friedman warns, one highly publicized failure during a time of brand expansion can undermine years of effort. Yet another potential pitfall is that the company's traditional clients could become confused about what Block stands for.
One executive who ought to have some insight into the magnitude of the challenge is betting on Block. In a telephone interview from Cable and Wireless's headquarters in London, Mr. Brown was resolute about the company he once ran. "I've hung on to my Block stock," he said.

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By DAVID RAMPE 

 BODY:

WALL STREET
Mating Ritual of Bulls
Forget the bulls' stampede. Now it's the brokers that are making news on Wall Street. The elite Morgan Stanley is merging with Dean Witter, Discover, home of the masses. The resulting powerhouse will knock Merrill Lynch off its perch as the biggest Wall Street firm and seems likely to prompt a cascade of other mergers in the battle for individual investors. Morgan works for the bluest of blue chips, while Dean Witter is a sales machine, with 40 million customers. In mutual funds alone, the firm will have 306 offerings, and all told, it will have $270 billion in assets under management. But Dean Witter, while huge, is not considered to be in the forefront of competitive changes sweeping the industry. Merger speculation immediately focused on other firms, including top investment banks and second-tier companies, and more names were on the list than off it.
 
FISCAL RESTRAINT
Shadows of a Budget Deal
The era of big government is over, Bill Clinton declared last year, a reality that left him a smaller canvas to paint in his State of the Union address, especially when his audience was another Republican Congress. The President did not make a single major spending initiative and urged Congress to balance the budget by 2002. In that general atmosphere of restraint, the President chose other areas to emphasize, chiefly his 10-point crusade "to insure that Americans have the best education in the world." His proposed $1.69 trillion Federal budget for next year was artfully constructed to suggest the terms of a deal with Republicans, who are lusting after a cut in the capital gains tax, presumably one that could benefit the millions who have reaped big paper profits on the stock market. The second part of a meaningful deal would be to find a way to slow the calculated increases in inflation, saving the Government money on benefits. Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, said negotiations could produce a balanced-budget agreement "within six weeks or so."
 
BROADCASTING
Dawn of Digital TV
Broadcasters' ears perked up when they heard that sweet word "free" waft from the White House. The Democrats, under the guidance of Vice President Al Gore, offered broadcasters the use of digital signals, allowing crystal-clear pictures and sound. In return, they are asking only for a modest guarantee of public-interest programming, perhaps a few hours of children's shows each week. Eager to get going, the broadcasters thought about it for a moment and decided: Why not? If Republicans sign off on the deal, digital services could begin soon, by spring 1998. Consumer electronics and computer companies, rushing to build sets, agreed on standards two months ago.
 
ROCK ON
Ziggy Stardust, Financial Innovator
In the dense language of Wall Street, the brokerage firm Fahnestock & Company placed $55 million of asset-backed securities. But cool, dude. It turns out the assets are the recordings of David Bowie, rock legend, who has morphed from the days of androgyny into a star known for his financial and technological savvy. "I wish all our clients were as innovative as David Bowie," said David Pullman, a senior vice president of Fahnestock, who usually works on duller debentures. Mr. Bowie raised $55 million from institutional investors, who got the promise of 7.9 percent annual interest for 10 years from royalties on sales of his past music. Futuristically, Mr. Bowie is also getting a new deal with EMI for new recordings, for perhaps $30 million. The royalties bond is the first of its kind ever, and one reason it went over well, a British banker told The Financial Mail, is that it is "no different from securitizing any other asset." The banker added, "Provided one can come up with a reasonable prediction of what future royalties are going to be, one can package anything."
 
NAZI LOOTING
The Swiss Blink
Old sins have long shadows. More than a half-century after World War II, three giant Swiss banks are putting $70 million into a fund for Nazi victims. This is the first time Swiss banks are using their own money to compensate Switzerland's close relationship with Nazi Germany. The banks still deny that they are hoarding any kind of vast wealth deposited by Jews who sought financial refuge before perishing in the camps. Other gold in vaults under Wall Street and at the Bank of England may form the core of another Holocaust fund.
 
ADVERTISING
Bowing to the Duchess
She weighed in at 203 pounds, was loaded with debt and is not on the best terms with her ex's family, but she's a Duchess, isn't she? Dear Fergie hooked up with Weight Watchers -- actually she's properly slimmed-down now -- and voila, she's pitching products. For a reported $1 million, the high-spirited Duchess of York will travel the United States on Weight Watchers' behalf. She is also thought to be pulling in half that much for pouring a bucket of ice on some paparazzi, all in ads to bolster sales of Ocean Spray juice. The very notion causes shivers in Britain. "Only somebody this vulgar could take the British royalty into this kind of situation," intoned Hugh Trevor-Roper, the historian, in The Daily Telegraph. But state-side, vulgarity and advertising have a way of hitting it off.
 
TAX POLICY
What the Right Hand Doesn't Know
Oops! The Treasury somehow never got around to collecting $1.2 billion in airline ticket taxes last year, and the result may crimp improvements in runways and radar and other aspects of air travel. Granted the tax was a nightmare; twice last year Congress let it lapse, and in the interval, the airlines collected the money but squirmed through a loophole to delay paying it. Eventually the Government woke up and the airlines paid, but by then, the Treasury had lost the authority to write a check to the intended beneficiary, the Federal Aviation Administration.

LENGTH: 1235 words

HEADLINE: Secrets to Maximize Savings;
In Japan, Bankers Make House Calls

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: FUKUI, Japan

 BODY:
IF it ever rains here, people like Miho Shimizu will be well prepared.
Miss Shimizu, a 21-year-old college student, has been saving for a rainy day since she was a young child, and so has just about everyone else in this windy, rice-growing city on Japan's west coast. 
 "I've been banking my otoshidama all these years," said Miss Shimizu, referring to the annual New Year's cash gift from parents and relatives. While a happy-go-lucky American child might have used the money for a new bicycle, Miss Shimizu and many Japanese kids take their money right to the bank.
Americans have been trying for years to bolster their saving rate, which economists say is vital to maintaining long-term growth. But despite individual retirement accounts and other saving plans, nothing seems to work. Americans save only about 4 percent of their household income, but Japanese save nearly 13 percent. This means that Japan essentially borrows from its own citizens, rather than relying on foreign investments that drive up trade deficits.
In Japan, saving seems so second nature it could be part of an ancient tradition. It turns out that saving is no mystery at all; it is not nature, but nurture.
 
Banks That Still Give Gifts
 It would be hard not to save, when faced with the likes of Yoshitake Sakihara, a 30-year-old banker who makes house calls on his motorbike. Mr. Sakihara visits about 40 homes a day, after paydays, and brings gifts of soap, dish towels and Buddhist temple boxes -- a Japanese version of piggy banks.
The soap seems to have hooked Misao Tanuma, a 65-year-old mother who has been saving for decades in her suburban-style house at the edge of Tokyo. Every month she gives 62,000 yen (about $500) to Mr. Sakihara for deposit in his institution, the Sugamo Credit Union.
"It's different from having to go and deposit the money in the bank yourself," said Mrs. Tanuma, as she handed over the money to Mr. Sakihara. "If someone visits me to pick up a fixed amount, I set the amount aside as if it doesn't belong to me."
It is often thought that thrift in Asia is a cultural trait, derived in part from a legacy of Confucianism. Indeed, one of the most common expressions in Japanese life is "gaman," or perseverance through hardship, and children learn the word early on.
"We tell them they can use some of their money to buy something and save the rest," said Masahiro Kusano, a 51-year-old economist whose two sons have saved $3,700 from their otoshidamas. "Savings has to do with gaman, and if you teach them gaman, that leads to savings."
But some experts dispute the notion that Japanese have thrift so deeply entwined in their culture that they are unique. Though statistics are scarce, scholars say savings rates in Japan a century ago may have been lower than in the West.
Charles Yuji Horioka, an economist at Osaka University who specializes in savings, says saving rates in Japan around the turn of the century were usually low, and sometimes negative.
It was policy measures -- and a business climate that promised healthy returns to people who saved rather than consumed -- that lifted savings rates up from scratch after the war. A national push for saving swept the nation and has lasted for years. Newspaper ads and posters in trains and subways occasionally beckon people to save, and the Central Council for Savings Information encourages a nationwide network of more than a thousand volunteers to organize activities to promote savings. The Council, a group sponsored by the Bank of Japan, also runs commercials that preach the benefits of building a nest egg and organizes an annual Saving Day in October. The Council for Savings even holds an annual essay contest on saving; last October 19,000 elementary and junior high school students submitted 1,200-word expositions on prudence with money.
Then, of course, there are the local banks and credit unions, which aggressively encourage savings to increase their deposits. Some banks enroll savers in programs that automatically deduct money from ordinary deposit accounts (the Japanese almost never use checking accounts) and put it into savings accounts.
Bankers sometimes inundate their customers with estimates of future financial burdens. And banks try to grab customers early, targeting fresh graduates of vocational schools or colleges. At the end of the month, when most Japanese are paid, bankers at institutions across the country fan out to homes on foot, bicycle or car to pick up the savings before they are spent.
This way, the banking relationship is sometimes passed on down through the generations. Akemi Sasano, a 32-year-old mother of two young children, met her bankers when they came every month to collect cash from her mother, Hatsue Kaneda.
"The reason I started to save was for my children's education, their high school and university," said Mrs. Sasano, whose family lives with her parents. "My kids are still small, but it takes money."
Indeed, one reason Japanese save so much is that everything is so expensive. In Tokyo, homes can cost up to nine times a typical annual salary, so that a million-dollar home is a matchbox of a house with no yard. College tuition costs are running about $53,000 for four years at a private university, and Japanese spend, on average, nearly $70,000 on a wedding. The $150,000 wedding is not uncommon.
Moreover, though Japan's health care system is somewhat more generous than that of the United States, it does not cover nursing and care for the elderly. Growing uncertainty over the ailing pension system is also impelling many people to save for hard times in old age.
"It's just common sense to keep your money and save up, even though there's no special purpose in mind," said Kazuyoshi Asai, a 47-year-old education official in Fukui. "It's a natural thing to save."
The Government was clearly adept at orchestrating the high saving rate. But its success drew criticism in the 1980's, when Americans complained repeatedly that Japanese thrift meant that Japanese consumers were not buying American goods.
This sensitivity led the Central Committee on Savings Promotion to change its name to the Central Council for Savings Information and to begin promoting consumption. That may have hastened an impending trend.
 
Rampant Retirees
 Because the population is aging rapidly, soon a greater number of people will become net spenders, rather than savers.
"Japan's population is aging probably at the fastest rate ever recorded," said Mr. Horioka. "Japan will be the most aged society in the world by 2010."
In any case, it still seems that Japanese have strong reasons to save, sometimes for unexpected reasons. Harumi Yoshida, a 42-year-old social education official in Fukui, recently bought an education insurance policy -- it would pay a child's education costs if his parents died -- as a savings vehicle.
Her colleague had asked her many times to buy a policy from a friend at the postal savings institution, and somehow the friend found out that Mrs. Yoshida didn't have any saving vehicle for her third son, who is 10 years old. When the postal official, who was pressured to meet a sales quota, appeared at her office, Mrs. Yoshida gave in.
"So as a favor to her, I deposited some of my bonus, just out of a sense of obligation," said Mrs. Yoshida. "I think it's strange. But it's something we do."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Dear Dr. Greenspan

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: DAVOS, Switzerland

 BODY:
"Dear Dr. Greenspan, I have a terrible problem. I'm feeling irrationally exuberant about the U.S. stock market and I just can't shake it. I know you've said 'irrational exuberance' is bad for my health, and I've tried everything: Hypnosis. Valium. Short-selling. Even rereading your speeches from 1987. But nothing works. Every time I come over here to Europe, or visit Japan, I return home itching to invest more in the U.S. market. Please, please help me. Sincerely, Mr. Full E. Invested."
I keep dictating that letter in my head to Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan, ever since he warned that Wall Street's long rise was being driven in part by a certain "irrational exuberance" among investors. I'm sure Mr. Greenspan has a point, but when you look at the U.S. from Europe, or Japan, some exuberance seems quite rational. 
 The Davos World Economic Forum is an annual gathering of the captains of industry and politics from around the world. Each year there is a star at Davos, someone who seems to define the moment. In the past, the stars have ranged from the financier George Soros to the Russian Communist leader Gennadi Zyuganov. This year the star at Davos was America. Whether it was Bill Gates of Microsoft or Andy Grove of Intel or Lawrence Summers of the U.S. Treasury, when Americans were on the dais people seemed to stay a little longer, listen a little harder. It seemed to be their way of saying that the U.S. growth model -- not the rigid Japanese one, and certainly not the inflexible European one that has fallen far behind the U.S. in producing new information technologies -- is now in the ascendancy.
And why not? If 100 years ago someone told you that by the end of this century the defining feature of world affairs would be "globalization" -- the integration of financial, information and trade networks to create a single, high-speed global marketplace -- and that you had to design a country best suited to compete in such a world, in many respects you would have designed today's America.
The U.S. has the world's most diverse and efficient capital markets, which reward, and even celebrate, risk-taking. Anyone with an invention and a garage can hope to raise millions overnight. It has a multicultural population that speaks the language of the Internet, a constantly renewing flow of immigrants, a transparent legal and regulatory environment and a flexible federal political system. It has a job market that enables workers to move easily from one hot industrial zone to another, and a corporate sector that has, unlike Europe's or Japan's, already gone through the downsizing and restructuring needed for global competitiveness. It has multiple economies, with a single currency, on a single continent that looks to both the Pacific and the Atlantic.
And, most important, its big multinational companies and little entrepreneurs think globally and excel in almost everything that is post-industrial: software, computing, package delivery, consulting, fast food, amusement parks, advertising, media, entertainment, hotels, financial services, environmental industries and telecommunications.
Globalization is us.
Of course, the stock market's sustained rise can be easily explained by traditional macro-economic factors -- low interest rates, low deficits, improved productivity -- and if these factors turn sour so will the market. But I suspect that there is another unarticulated, unquantifiable factor behind the market's rise. I would call it "The Globalization Premium." That is a sense among global investors that somehow the whole mix of America -- its society, its culture, its technology, its business environment and its geography -- meshes more naturally with globalization than either Europe or Japan. It is a sense that while many in Europe and Japan are still trying to adjust to the demands of globalization, and are barely up to the starting line, the U.S. is already around the first turn.
There is no way the U.S. can afford to be complacent, or ignore its underlying problems -- our weak public schools and inner cities, our widening income gaps and our low savings rate that makes us very dependent on others. But it still seems to me that something more is going on with America than just another uptick in the business cycle. It is a structural change that makes America a very good fit with the brave new world. Call me crazy, but I think it merits a little rational exuberance.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: U.S.-Jamaica Spat Undermines Region's Anti-Drug Efforts

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: KINGSTON, Jamaica

 BODY:
Hoping to step up its fight against drug trafficking, the United States instead finds itself stuck in a messy dispute with Jamaica that threatens to undermine anti-drug efforts throughout the Caribbean.
The quarrel centers on Washington's attempt to negotiate an agreement that would let American ships operate in Jamaican waters. Nearly a dozen other Caribbean countries recently signed such accords, which typically allow the United States Coast Guard and Navy to penetrate a country's 12-mile territorial limit to pursue ships believed to be carrying drugs. 
 Jamaica does not oppose such an arrangement, so long as the United States agrees to "operate on terms set by the Jamaican Government," said Seymour Mullings, Jamaica's Foreign Minister. But officials here say they are puzzled and offended by what they regard as Washington's strong-arm tactics and intrusions on national sovereignty. These include recent threats that Jamaica could soon be "decertified" for American economic aid.
Though the two countries have long differed over the most effective strategy to cut drug trafficking and consumption, the situation took a nasty turn in December. That was when Patricia Hall, director of Latin American and Caribbean programs at the State Department's Bureau of Narcotics and Law Enforcement, said on a television program seen here that Washington knew of "at least one elected representative" in Jamaica who had ties to drug traffickers.
Ms. Hall said: "We just do not seem to see any progress as far as a concern for controlling the trafficking, production of drugs and passing the legislation that is necessary." She added that extradition of criminals, eradication of marijuana fields and passage of more crime control laws were "lagging," and that this was leading to a situation fraught with "the danger of decertification."
Under American law, drug-producing or transit nations are ineligible for direct American economic aid if the White House does not certify by March 1 of each year that the countries are making adequate efforts to stem the flow of narcotics to the United States. Countries not deemed to be cooperating fully, including Colombia, Afghanistan and Iran, can be subjected to further trade sanctions at the President's discretion.
Jamaica, the largest of the English-speaking islands of the Caribbean, is a major producer of marijuana and an important transshipment point for cocaine bound to the United States. Because of some success in shutting down smuggling routes through Central America and Mexico, American officials estimate that at least a third of the cocaine leaving Colombia now travels on Caribbean routes.
The Jamaican reaction to the threat of decertification has been sharp. Addressing Parliament, Prime Minister Percival J. Patterson said that his nation had done everything in its power to cooperate with the United States. He suggested that an "unequivocal retraction" was in order, saying Washington had brought out its big stick because there had been problems in negotiating a ship agreement.
"We find it difficult to accept that negotiations should proceed with a threat of decertification hanging over our heads," he said. "Indeed, the act of decertification would be unilateral, but would result in significant bilateral and multilateral consequences."
"We intend to maintain our self-respect," he added. "We will not grovel."
Washington's approach has "enabled the Government to couch the debate in terms of the big, bad U.S. pressuring us," said Stephen Vasciannie, a lawyer and professor of government at the University of the West Indies here. He added that the approach had united the country behind the Prime Minister.
Jamaica's position has won widespread support elsewhere in the Caribbean, even among nations that have already signed ship agreements with the United States. In mid-December, after an emergency meeting in Barbados, the Caribbean Community issued a communique in which 14 heads of government "rejected any suggestion or threat of coercive measures as a means of extracting compliance with predetermined policies."
In the statement there were complaints about "unfounded allegations" and "innuendoes" that "undermine the foundation of the good relations" with the United States. Prime Minister Lester Bird of Antigua, chairman of the regional group, wrote President Clinton complaining of "the tactics by certain U.S. agencies" and requesting "a meeting at the highest possible level at the earliest opportunity in 1997."
Caribbean leaders have expressed frustration with Washington's demands for increased cooperation on the drug issue as it cuts economic aid to the region and refuses to grant English-speaking islands the same access to the American market that Mexico enjoys. Washington is also seeking to block the Caribbean's preferred access to Europe for exports of bananas, a crop widely seen as the region's only real alternative to marijuana.
"I can't recall relations ever being so frosty," one adviser to the Cabinet here said. "There are just so many areas where we are banging heads."
In its talks with the United States, Jamaica has stressed the inadequacy of taking a narrow focus on drug trafficking, one that ignores closely related economic and security issues. It prefers what K. D. Knight, the Minister of National Security, calls "a comprehensive package approach," which would include provisions obliging the United States to provide more aid to Jamaican security forces and to step up its own gun interdiction efforts.
With fewer than 2.5 million people, Jamaica had more than 900 homicides last year, nearly the same number as New York City, which is three times as large. Jamaican officials maintain that most of the weapons used in those crimes are smuggled in from the United States, often by the traffickers who are shipping marijuana and cocaine to New York City and Miami.
"The gun issue is integrally connected with the drug issue," Mr. Knight said, "and for years we have been the victims of gun smugglers. Since gun smugglers are also drug smugglers and dealers, it is necessary to attack that aspect of the problem simultaneously."
But American officials say that officials negotiating the ship agreement are not authorized to discuss a broader accord. So with the two countries scheduled to resume talks soon and the certification deadline pending, further friction still seems likely.
"We are the good guys, the ones seeking the partnership," said Mr. Knight, who has recently visited Washington for talks. "It is the drug dealers who are the bad guys, so we must therefore not behave as if we are enemies and do not have a common objective."

HEADLINE: NEW YORK MEMO: You Smilin' at Me?;
The Mellowing of the Quintessentially Crabby City

BYLINE: By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
If a city of seven million people can be said to have moods, which for the sake of argument it shall be presumed that it can, the mood of New York City oscillates perpetually between the extremes of smugness and disgust.
Sometimes its state of mind seems downright visible in the posture of pedestrians or the chemistry of subway crowds. Then it shifts, with a seeming suddenness that says as much about the seeming as the being of city life. 
 This is one of those mood-shifting times. This much might be ventured, without overstating the case: Suddenly (it seems), it has become a given (in certain circles) that life in New York City (or some things about it) have changed for the better (at least for some).
There are a few obvious reasons people might be feeling less glum. The crime rate has dipped below that of Independence, Mo. The economy is not sliding into the plumbing. Tourism and the real estate market are up, and some heavily traveled stretches of the city look strikingly better.
Yet much about New York seems unchanged, at best. Two out of every three public-school third graders still read below grade level. Thousands of families live in crowded, dangerous conditions. The city is still expensive, noisy, infuriating a few dozen times a day.
So, how to explain the apparent magnitude of the mood change, the recent poll showing satisfaction levels rising sharply, the insistence of visitors that the New York they remember has been transfigured, the grudging admission by even skeptics that the place seems improved?
Interviews with dozens of New Yorkers and outsiders, from sociologists and psychologists to lifelong residents and tourists, point to three factors that may help explain the apparently abrupt change of heart.
First, in a city where some things are more visible than others, much of what has improved happens to be highly visible -- public safety, the atmosphere on the streets, the experience of the subway, the look of places like the area around Grand Central Terminal and Times Square.
Second, in a world in which repetition tends to make statements seem credible, especially when the people making them seem likely to know, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, tourism officials, the media and others have repeatedly stated that things are looking up.
Third, New Yorkers need to believe it. They have chosen to live in a place that, not infrequently, leaves them wondering why they did. Perhaps more than many other people -- say, Tahitians -- they hunger for evidence that justifies their choice.
"We like to have our choice affirmed as a wise one, or at least a reasonable one," said Dr. Robert Jay Lifton, the psychiatrist, author and native New Yorker, speaking from his apartment on Central Park West. "Otherwise, we're not very bright."
As Dr. Lifton sees it, people are acutely ambivalent about New York. They hold two extreme images in their head: New York as "the most vital, fascinating, rewarding city on earth" and New York as "the most terrorizing, deteriorated, impossible place on earth."
A mental pendulum swings back and forth -- maybe four times a day, but also slowly over time. "There's a sense in which we reach a kind of rock-bottom horror and resentment and pain and anger," he said. "And then the pendulum starts swinging the other way."
How that mood change comes about is not easy to decipher.
"It's the way a joke goes around town," said Milton Glaser, the graphic designer, who knows something about the mysteries of image, perception and mood. "Who in the world knows why a joke comes to life? It races through the city and, by the end of the day, everybody knows it."
No mood change, of course, is universal or equally felt. Some say New York is a slicker, less interesting, less compassionate place. They say the police are harassing the homeless, corporations are colonizing neighborhoods and people no longer care about the gap between rich and poor.
Yet interviews and polling detect something like optimism in many places, from parts of Manhattan and Brooklyn to the South Bronx, where a Trinidadian woman who regularly shoos drug dealers from her lobby and carries a gun when she walks her dog recently said even she is feeling upbeat.
New immigrants may be among the most optimistic New Yorkers, some sociologists suggested -- which could leave a mark on the city's collective state of mind. After all, 425,000 immigrants moved in between 1990 and 1995, while 780,000 New Yorkers moved out, their discontent in tow.
Nearly everyone, of course, judges the city by the view through his or her own keyhole. Phyllis Ambler, living near Union Square, is pleased to see it looking clean. William Gutman, of Borough Park, says shopping has increased in Borough Park. Mary Fitzsimons, a fashion designer, says Madison Avenue now rivals the Via della Spiga in Milan.
Others imagine a great proliferation of positives. Carlos Rodriguez, a maintenance worker from Jackson Heights, Queens, sees improvement in everything from altruism to voter turnout. "People are not rude anymore," he marveled. "The smog, I don't know what happened with it. It's not, like, polluted."
Is perception outstripping reality? Ms. Ambler was asked.
"Perception is reality," she said.
 
Abstract Impressions
Small Gains Grow Into Symbols
Few issues in New York have the visibility of crime. Fear of crime may bear little relation to the actual crime rate, but notions about crime and public safety have exercised an outsize influence on overall views of the city.
New York is, after all, an especially public city. It is known for its public, more than its private, spaces. When people fear New York, they cannot appreciate its virtues. They stay off the streets, or they stay away.
Public safety is also a highly visible, 24-hour-a-day service. Unlike public education or health care, it affects New Yorkers of all ages and incomes, and visitors, too. If the police appear competent, that seems to signify a lot.
As any sentient New Yorker now knows, the murder rate is lower than it has been in nearly 30 years. Other crimes are down, too: fewer people are being robbed and assaulted, fewer homes broken into, fewer cars stolen.
"The single biggest impediment to getting people to visit New York City was and is perceptions about crime," said Stephen Morello, president of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau. "By turning crime around, we have the single biggest opportunity."
Other recent changes have a different kind of high visibility. Business Improvement Districts have transformed the appearance of some of the most heavily traveled parts of the city, leaving the debatable impression among some that the city in general is cleaner and tamer.
Take Times Square. Each day, 1.5 million pedestrians are said to pass through the Times Square Business Improvement District between West 40th and West 53d Streets. One fifth of the hotel rooms in the city are in the district and millions of people worldwide see images of Times Square.
These days, private sanitation workers scour the sidewalks for litter, corralling 99 pounds of cigarette butts a day. Forty private security guards patrol the streets. The district has installed new lighting, removed graffiti, painted litter baskets, paid for services to get the homeless off the streets.
All of that -- along with the commercial reincarnation of Times Square and the fact that the first high-rise office tower to be built in Manhattan in the 1990's happens to be going up on the northeast corner of 42d Street and Seventh Avenue -- has left among many visitors a broader impression of an entire city rebounding.
"It's what I call the differential visibility of things," said Dr. Norman Bradburn, a senior vice president for research at the National Opinion Research Center, a survey-research center affiliated with the University of Chicago, where he is a professor of psychology and public policy.
"Changes in some kinds of things about the city are more visible than others," he said. "Then there's always a question about visible to whom. One thing that tends to be visible is graffiti and garbage and litter and dirt and a lot of homeless people or beggars.
"People have an implicit, causal theory about why things are littered -- that somehow it's out of control, the city is not paying attention," he said. So by simply removing graffiti, he said, "You may not have changed other things, but you make people feel as if you have."
So while it is by no means certain that the city, taken as a whole, is any cleaner, guerrilla windshield-washing at intersections is down these days. So is aggressive panhandling at automatic teller machines, peddling Rolex knockoffs on sidewalks and other activities targeted by the Giuliani administration's crackdown on quality-of-life offenses.
There even appear to be fewer homeless people in heavily traveled areas of the city, particularly midtown Manhattan (though agencies that work with the homeless say their clients have merely migrated to Harlem, lower Manhattan and other boroughs, where they find the attentions of the police less intense).
None of which was lost on Dr. Raleigh Kent 3d, a 44-year-old surgeon from Birmingham, Ala., who visited Manhattan for the first time in years over Christmas. He found the place quite changed. "I felt safer and it seemed cleaner," he said. "I didn't see bums everywhere."
Dr. Kent's earlier memories had not been terribly favorable -- a lot of panhandling and "crumby-looking people around in the areas where tourists would go." There was a menacing quality to the place: "I always felt like I needed eyes behind my head."
Then came the movie "Home Alone II." . "You laugh?" he said. "It is a huge influence." The footage of Christmas in Manhattan, the Plaza Hotel, and F.A.O. Schwarz all helped persuade Dr. Kent to gather up his wife and two children and come.
There was something else, too -- the "Today" show's studio at Rockefeller Center, where since 1994 crowds have gathered daily outside the picture window to watch. Dr. Kent had seen them many mornings: "All these people are smiling, 'Hey, Mom! I'm here in New York! And everyone is having a wonderful time!' "
New York's profile in popular entertainment happens to be higher than usual these days. The number of film and television shooting days has risen steadily since 1993, according to Patricia Reed Scott, Commissioner of the Mayor's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcast.
From "Spin City" to "Cosby" and "Law and Order," there are more prime-time shows coming out of New York than at any time since the 1960's, Ms. Scott said. As for the "Today" show window, she called it "an early-morning advertisement for New York that goes worldwide."
It is unclear whether the film and television image of New York is rosier, too. But the sheer quantity of footage may matter more than the content. "I can only think that the multiplicity of images puts it in people's minds and on balance that has to do nothing but good," Ms. Scott said.
Daniel Leab, a professor of history at Seton Hall University, who has written about film, suggested that New York simply looks better on color film than in real life, in aerial shots instead of close up. "The movies make New York look great," he said.
 
Three Little Words
Repeat: 'Cleaner, Safer, Brighter'
One other thing inspired Dr. Kent to give New York a second chance. He kept hearing the same reports, over and over. According to Dr. Kent, friends from Birmingham would visit New York and report back: "It looks different, it feels better, it feels safe."
If that phrase sounds familiar, it is. It resembles a slogan used these days by the Convention and Visitors Bureau and the Times Square Business Improvement District. "Cleaner, safer, brighter" is a mantra the city's promoters use frequently.
The phrase made its debut in 1995 at the Travel Industry Association's convention in New York, a tourism-industry bonanza that gave the Convention and Visitors Bureau a captive audience of 1,500 tour operators from 69 countries and 500 journalists, all marooned in Manhattan for a week.
"The city was starting to turn around," Jeanine Moss, director of communications for the bureau, recently recalled. "We had to be clear about what our message was. We wanted them to see that this was a new and revitalized destination that is cleaner, safer, brighter."
Apparently, it worked.
"We got millions of letters afterward saying, 'We had no idea New York had changed so much,' " said Ms. Moss. "They felt it was so safe, clean and friendly." In her job, Ms. Moss speaks with about 1,000 journalists a month. Words like clean, safe and bright now find their way into all sorts of articles about New York.
"You can never underestimate the value of communication," said Ms. Moss, who credits the Giuliani administration with understanding just that. "Why does the Mayor talk about crime 50 times a week? Because it has to be communicated that many times before people act and come and see."
Reporters who cover Mayor Giuliani say he talks about the crime statistics at least every other day, especially now that he is running for re-election. He also regularly suggests that the city is enjoying a "renaissance." Anyone listening is left to wonder: Renaissance? Could it be?
"It's like going to the doctor and the doctor says, 'You're better now,' " said Bill Lynch, a former deputy to Mayor David N. Dinkins. "Then I feel better."
Which comes first? he was asked.
"For me, that's chicken and egg," he said. "It can be a self-fulfilling prophecy."
The media, too, have reinforced the message. There have been innumerable articles and television news reports about the drop in crime. At the same time, some critics say the media's interest in crime stories of the other kind seems to be waning.
"When things are bad, they tend to be exaggerated. When things are good, they tend to be exaggerated," said J. Phillip Thompson, a political science professor at Barnard College and former Dinkins administration official. "Probably because it sells papers and gets people to watch TV. Because it's exciting."
 
Theories of Relativity
Maybe 'Better' Is Just 'Not as Bad'
New Yorkers, like anyone else, want to hear good news about where they live. They may even want it more than others. Dr. Ralph L. Rosnow, a professor of psychology at Temple University in Philadelphia, calls living in New York "the ultimate cognitive dissonance situation."
According to cognitive dissonance theory, people are uncomfortable holding inconsistent ideas. (For example: "I choose to live in a place that drives me nuts.") So, they try to reduce the dissonance. ("Maybe it's not so bad after all.")
"There is a natural, human tendency to try to have a dynamic equilibrium which is pleasant," Professor Rosnow said. If a credible source offers some evidence that life is improving, people might leap to believe it, he said.
On the other hand, improvement is relative. Some changes in the city are remarkable largely in the context of how far New York had sunk. Subway ridership may be the highest it has been since 1990 -- but it is still below what it was in the late 1980's and early 1970's.
As for the economy, 35,000 private-sector jobs were created last year and a total of 145,000 have been created since late 1992; but 342,000 were lost between April 1989 and November 1992. The number of overnight visitors to New York has grown steadily since 1992 -- but only this year is it expected finally to return to the level seen in 1991.
In other words, expectations had dropped. And satisfaction is intimately tied to expectations. As Professor Bradburn, the opinion research expert, said: "Something that, 20 years ago, would not have been viewed as an improvement, we now see as positive" because people adjust their expectations down.
People can, of course, adjust them back up. Too much good news and that could even happen in New York.
"It's like you have no heat in your house, then all of a sudden you get heat and hot water," Mr. Lynch said. "Then you start looking around and saying, 'Do I have any soap and towels?' "

HEADLINE: For Indians, Environment Becomes New Battleground

BYLINE: By JIM ROBBINS 

DATELINE: HAYS, Mont. Feb. 5

 BODY:
A narrow dirt road leads away past a tiny cluster of houses and a stone mission church that make up this settlement on the Fort Belknap Reservation. It runs past the sun dance lodge and the powwow grounds and into the forest that cloaks the Little Rocky Mountains.
At the end of the road is a place where Assiniboine and Gros Ventre Indians still hunt and seek visions. But the look of the place has changed drastically in recent years: now there is a huge open pit and a towering wall of crushed stone there, remnants of a mountain that has been turned inside out for the gold inside. 
 A century ago, this piece of the mountain range was part of the reservation, and many in the tribes still smolder over the loss. They say that in 1896 their ancestors were forced to sell the gold-bearing land because of a form of blackmail typical of the time: if they did not sell, the Government agent for the reservation would have withheld food rations.
Now the mining has led to a new battle over the controversial ground.
Last year, the tribes filed a notice of intent to sue Pegasus Gold, which owns the Zortman mine at the site, for damages to reservation water. The suit forced state and Federal action under the Clean Water Act, resulting in a $37 million settlement, including a $1 million payment to the tribes and a $30 million bond against future damage.
In January, the tribes sued in state court to stop Pegasus from creating a new pit until it cleaned up the old one. And the tribes are considering a lawsuit in Federal court, which would contend that Federal agencies did not prepare an adequate environmental impact statement when they approved the new pit.
Tribal leaders say they are making sure the dynamics are different than they were for their ancestors.
 "They threatened their rations, so they gave in and made poor decisions," said Tracy Charles King, an Assiniboine who is president of the Fort Belknap Community Council, the tribal governing body. "But starvation tactics are over. It's time for us to ask questions, get answers and be treated with respect."
The tribes say the two huge open pits in the area have poisoned wells, have diminished the flow of streams and may have widely contaminated groundwater.
The mining company says those contentions are exaggerated.
"There's been a lot of allegations," said John Pearson, director of investor relations for Pegasus Gold at the company's headquarters in Spokane, Wash. "And there have been studies done that have proved some of them absolutely false. Our environmental record and reclamation effort is a very strong one."
In the last seven years, Mr. Pearson said, the mine has produced about 110,000 ounces of gold a year. At full capacity, the mine has about 300 employees.
Legal actions by Indian tribes have been rare but are becoming more common, in part because Indians have become better educated and more of them are lawyers.
One of the new generation of Indian lawyers who came of age during the political activism of the 1960's and 70's is Tim Coulter. He is the director of the Indian Law Resource Center, a nonprofit organization in Helena, Mont., that helps indigenous people worldwide and is working on the Fort Belknap lawsuit.
"Tribal leaders better understand how to manipulate the legal, economic and political machinery," Mr. Coulter said. "And they're not as overwhelmed with the gross ill health and education problems that used to exhaust their resources."
Legal action by Indians was also aided by amendments in the last decade to several major Federal environmental laws, like the Clean Water Act and Clean Air Act. Tribes got the same standing as states to enforce environmental standards. Many tribes are using Federal money to set up programs to monitor and enforce environmental quality.
A rekindled interest in traditional tribal ways is also helping to inspire tribes' participation in environmental affairs. Many young Indians are taking part in vision quests and other ceremonies conducted at traditional sacred sites outdoors. Many of these sites are off the reservation and threatened by development.
One such site was the mountain that the Zortman mine destroyed.
"That mountain they tore down was Spirit Mountain," said Virgil McConnell, 72, an Assiniboine tribal elder who lives near Hays. Mr. McConnell said the other mountains were still used extensively for vision quests, several days of praying and fasting in the mountains in search of a gift from the Great Spirit.
"You pray, you do a lot of crying and pray to the Great Spirit," Mr. McConnell said. "But you can't go on a vision quest when there's blasting and a lot of noise. We tried to tell the mining company this, but they wouldn't pay any attention."
The mine does stop activity for four days in June during the annual Sun Dance, he said.
The ascendance of a new generation of leaders has also made Indians more assertive. On the Assiniboine and Gros Ventre council, the oldest member is 49, and the chairman, Mr. King, is 39.
Tribes are also becoming more involved in environmental programs because of their traditional relationship to nature. The Nez Perce won a Federal contract to manage the recently reintroduced gray wolf for the state of Idaho, a role usually filled by the state.
Such new roles for tribes do not come without controversy. The Kootenai and Salish tribes in northwestern Montana recently received authority from the Environmental Protection Agency to implement water quality standards on the reservation. The move provoked howls of protest and a lawsuit by the state.
"Eighty-five percent of the people who live within the reservation boundary are nonmembers," said Paddy Trusler, who owns land within the reservation and also administers land within the reservation boundaries for Lake County.
New tribal authority, he said, "adds a layer of government that, unless you are a tribal member, leaves you without rights."
But Indian leaders say the tribes need to keep in mind what is at stake in the battle over the environment.
"Eternity," said Poncho Bigby, the director of the Fort Belknap Natural Resource Department. "We'll suffer the impacts of that mine for eternity."
