HEADLINE: An Inquiry Clouds a Lobbyist's Success Story

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER with STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand

 BODY:
A few years ago, Pauline Kanchanalak wanted to become a Washington lobbyist for the Government of Thailand. Officials turned her down, believing that she lacked the connections to be effective in the corridors of power in the United States capital.
But Mrs. Kanchanalak eventually succeeded on her own. Only last June, she and a prospective client from Thailand sipped coffee in the White House with the President of the United States and his political aides. Their discussion focused on United States trade policy toward China, where the client, a businessman, is one of the largest investors. Mrs. Kanchanalak and her client also joined State Department officials in encouraging Mr. Clinton to visit Thailand, and in November he became the first American President to do so in 27 years. 
 But Mrs. Kanchanalak's standing in the world of lobbying and deal making began to fall apart a few months after the White House meeting, when the Democratic National Committee returned $253,000 in donations from her after concluding that some of the money might have come from someone else. Not only are the donations under scrutiny but so are some of the contacts in the Federal Government whom she had worked with as a lobbyist and Democratic Party activist.
The story of Mrs. Kanchanalak's evolution from low-level Thai embassy official to well-placed lobbyist illustrates the zeal with which foreign businesses seek influence and access in Washington, especially in a global economy where the actions of the Federal Government can affect businesses with few or no operations in the United States.
Indeed, some of those caught up in the current investigations of Democratic campaign fund-raising are Thai and Indonesian companies that were trying to influence United States trade policy toward China and other Asian countries, where they have far more extensive holdings than in the United States.
In interviews with businessmen and officials in Washington and Bangkok, Mrs. Kanchanalak emerges as a smart and sociable woman who glided easily through business and political circles in two disparate capitals. Over five years, along with her husband, Chupong Kanchanalak, she cultivated ties with Democratic fund-raisers and Arkansas insiders who were interested in doing business with Thai companies. And she was able to use her ties in the United States to advance her own business interests: Dhanin Chearvanont, the prospective client she took to see Mr. Clinton, is one of the richest men in Asia.
"She was trying to develop a business relationship," said William Hou, the lawyer for her American consulting company, Ban Chang International. "A lot of people, when they're developing business relationships, try to do things like that. If I can take a potential client to the Super Bowl, obviously it wouldn't hurt."
Mr. Dhanin's conglomerate, the Charoen Pokaphand Group, based in Thailand, is one of Asia's largest and most successful business empires and the largest foreign investor in China. It controls more than 250 companies that sell products as diverse as chickens, shrimp, petrochemicals, motorcycles and telecommunications equipment.
Politically well connected throughout Asia, Mr. Dhanin is widely known in Bangkok as having contributed millions of dollars to political parties in Thailand, where there are no campaign finance disclosure requirements. Mr. Dhanin, who is ethnic Chinese and lived in China as a boy, also advised Chinese officials on issues that included their Hong Kong negotiations with the British.
In November, when Mr. Dhanin started a motorcycle factory in Shanghai, Mrs. Kanchanalak was with him, as was Neil Bush, a son of former President George Bush.
Mrs. Kanchanalak's ties have now become the focus of a widening investigation of the Democratic Party's fund raising. As for $253,000 in donations that were returned by the Democratic National Committee, Mrs. Kanchanalak, who along with her husband declined several requests to be interviewed for this article, has said some of the money came from her and the rest from her mother-in-law, Praitun Kanchanalak. American investigators are trying to determine whether she was actually a front for other interests that could not legally make campaign donations in the United States.

Diplomat Becomes Woman of Influence
Mrs. Kanchanalak was born in Thailand in 1950. In the late 1970's she attended Stanford University on a scholarship, graduating in 1983 with a bachelor's degree in philosophy. She then went to Washington and took a job in the press section of the Thai Embassy, said Kasem Kasemsri, the Thai Ambassador to the United States from 1982 to 1986and now a business associate of hers.
She had good connections, charm and excellent English, Mr. Kasem recalled in an interview. As a result, she was effective in promoting Thailand's profile in Washington and in getting important people to attend functions at the Thai Embassy. "We needed help," Mr. Kasem said, because "we didn't have a lot of money like the Koreans."
After Mr. Kasem left the embassy, so did Mrs. Kanchanalak and with her husband, known as Jeb, she began lobbying for private clients. Their first major effort was against farm legislation that would have made it more difficult for Thai agricultural products to enter the United States, according to The Nation, an English-language daily newspaper here. "After that, the couple established their lobbying mark on U.S. politics," the paper wrote recently.
She also worked in Washington for The Bangkok Post, another English-language newspaper here, writing mostly about trade policy. She occasionally appeared on a CNN journalists' program discussing trade and foreign policy issues.
"She had excellent sources," recalled Paisal Sricharatchanya, the Post editor then. But in 1992, the paper decided that she was not writing enough to justify a Washington operation and let her go, Mr. Paisal said. So Mrs. Kanchanalak turned to lobbying full time.
In some instances, she sought out senators' wives, and through them persuaded their husbands to visit Thailand, according to people who have worked with her. And two Senators with influence over foreign policy -- Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia and now retired, and William S. Cohen, Republican of Maine and now Defense Secretary -- were squired around Thailand by the Kanchanalaks. Mr. Nunn and Mr. Cohen did not respond to questions on the subject.
Mrs. Kanchanalak's influence in Washington grew to the point that she knew about impending Congressional visits before the United States Embassy in Bangkok, said one diplomat here. And the embassy would frequently turn to Mr. Kanchanalak to set up meetings and tours.
"Where some see conniving or a conspiracy, I see successful business people connecting with government, which is supposedly what it's all about these days," a senior Western diplomat said.
The Kanchanalaks opened an office on the second floor of a high-rent building in Washington, overlooking the Potomac River. They entertained prospective clients, lawmakers and other lobbyists at the Jockey Club. And they sought American investors for enterprises in Thailand.
One of Mrs. Kanchanalak's main clients was the Ban Chang Group, a Thai real estate conglomerate with developments and projects throughout Asia. Ban Chang International, her consulting company, is partly owned by the Ban Chang Group, according to records in Thailand.
The Ban Chang Group is headed by Pairoj Piempongsant, whose penthouse office in the Glas Haus -- one of the first high-rise buildings in Bangkok, built by Mr. Pairoj -- is scattered with framed photographs of him with President Clinton and Mrs. Kanchanalak.
Mr. Pairoj declined a request to be interviewed. But to his friends, Mr. Pairoj has made little secret of his desire to be close to Mr. Clinton.
"He's very boastful of his connections, how he's close to this senator and that senator," a Thai friend said. "If he's able to introduce himself into political circles in Washington, it gives him an edge above other Thai businessmen to Thai politicians."
 
An Organization Grows And Gains Power
 One of Mrs. Kanchanalak's biggest accomplishments came with the help of John Huang, the former Commerce Department trade official and former Democratic campaign official at the center of the fund-raising investigations.
In 1994, at the request of the Thai Government, she helped form a United States-Thai Business Council, to promote trade between the two countries. Such councils proliferate through Washington, providing a forum for lobbyists to invite lawmakers and influential officials to rub elbows with their clients.
Mrs. Kanchanalak had great ambitions for her group. She wanted President Clinton and the Thai Prime Minister to bless it by showing up at its inaugural meeting.
On Sept. 30, 1994, Mrs. Kanchanalak telephoned Mr. Huang at the Commerce Department, recently released Government records show. That same day, Mr. Huang wrote a memorandum urging a more senior Commerce Department official to support the establishment of the business council, and to try to get the President to attend the first meeting.
Mr. Huang noted that National Security Council officials like Sandy Kristoff, an Asia specialist, might object to the arrangement. "There are quite a few members in this proposed Council from Arkansas," Mr. Huang wrote to David Rothkopf, the more senior Commerce official. "They may want to utilize their contacts to get this matter squared away directly from the top even if they offend Sandy and the N.S.C."
Among the other proponents of the Thai council was Mark Grobmyer, a lawyer from Little Rock, Ark., who has close ties to the President and Vice President Al Gore and who was working on business deals between American and Thai companies.
In October 1994, shortly after Mr. Huang wrote his memorandum, Mrs. Kanchanalak attended meetings at both the Commerce Department and the White House. Within days of those meetings, at least some of which involved the establishment of the Thai council, she donated $32,500 to the Democratic Party, Federal Election Commission records say.
The council was established, and at its first meeting at the White House, on Oct. 6, 1994, President Clinton and Thailand's Prime Minister stopped in to congratulate the group. Mr. Clinton's tacit endorsement of the council gave it extra clout and credibility in Thailand, even though the Administration had declined a request for a grant by the group.
Investigators from the Justice Department and Commerce Department are examining whether Mr. Huang may have been involved in Democratic fund-raising efforts at the time in connection with the establishment of the council.
 
Donations Raise Questions of Timing
Investigators have also been struck by the timing of Mrs. Kanchanalak's contributions last year, around the time that she had arranged the kaffeeklatsch that included President Clinton, Mr. Dhanin and a senior official from the Thai Foreign Ministry.
Around the same time as the coffee meeting on June 18, Mrs. Kanchanalak gave the Democratic National Committee $135,000 and her sister-in-law Duagnet G. Kronenberg, who listed the same home address in Virginia as Mrs. Kanchanalak, contributed $50,000.
The main discussion at the coffee was over United States policy toward China, one participant said. The meeting was arranged through Mr. Huang, who had left Commerce and was working as the vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee's financing arm. Mrs. Kanchanalak brought three executives from Mr. Dhanin's conglomerate, the Charoen Pokaphand Group.
Accompanying Mr. Dhanin at the meeting with Mr. Clinton was Sarasin Viraphol, a senior official in the Thai Foreign Ministry at the time. Mr. Dhanin and Mr. Sarasin, who now works for the Charoen Pokaphand Group, are among the cadre of ethnic Chinese businessmen who run many of Asia's largest corporations.
Ultimately, the President decided to visit Thailand, as some of the visitors at the June 18 meeting had asked. Shortly before the White House announced the visit, a friend of Mrs. Kanchanalak said, she was told by Mr. Clinton that he intended to come to Thailand for a brief visit in November. On Nov. 26, the President ended a 12-day Asia-Pacific tour with a 24-hour state visit here.

HEADLINE: Unromantic Economic Facts Cast Pall Over Niagara Falls

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

DATELINE: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Feb. 8

 BODY:
Winters have never been kind to the Honeymoon Capital. The city grit seems to transform the curbside snow into oatmeal clumps. The spray rising from the falls stings the face. And the Twist o' the Mist ice cream stand, which is shaped like a huge, cherry-topped cone, is closed until springtime, when the tourists return.
But this winter has brought particular hardship to a city that, while blessed with a natural wonder, struggles with the unromantic realities of unemployment, municipal debt and a sickly downtown that seems immune to revitalization. 
 First, a casino opened nearby -- in Ontario, Canada, just across the Rainbow Bridge. Second, the State Senate voted against permitting casinos in several communities, including Niagara Falls. Then, on Thursday, the latest indignity: an ultimate fighting bout, scheduled to take place in the sold-out Niagara Falls Convention and Civic Center Friday night, was suddenly moved to Alabama because its promoters did not like the state restrictions on the sport.
For Niagara Falls, the effect was immediate, severe and oh so familiar. The Radisson Hotel had 30 percent of its reservations canceled within hours. The convention center lost hundreds of thousands of dollars in food sales and parking fees. And Mayor James C. Galie could not help but dream of the free advertising his city would have received from the event's pay-per-view broadcast. Instead, he says, "the people who came here will remember it as a bad experience."
The Mayor will get no argument from two couples from Michigan, the Stearnses and the Gregorys. They had driven five hours to attend the bout and to spend the weekend in the city. Once they learned that the event had been canceled, they drove into the downtown to find a restaurant, but the only business open was an adult-video store; they passed.
They wound up going to the casino in Ontario, where the restaurants and wax and horror museums are decidedly more appealing and therefore help attract the bulk of tourists to the falls. The Michigan couples checked out of the Radisson two nights earlier than planned.
"We drove around and saw a lot of empty buildings," Martin Stearns said, before turning his white Riviera westward. "This area definitely could have used the money."
Hearing of the Michigan couples' experience, Mayor Galie pursed his lips and shook his head, like a father being told that his child had failed a test. He has spent all his 55 years in Niagara Falls, including 31 as a police officer. He pointed to a photograph of a busy street scene that hangs behind his desk. It is like an oversize postcard: Greetings from Falls Street, 1953.
"It's nothing like it was," he said. "I mean, it was so hustle and bustle."
City planners here say that Niagara Falls has suffered the economic hardships of many Northeast cities, only more so. Dozens of steel and chemical plants once benefited from the electrical power generated by the Niagara River. The Hooker Chemical Company made chlorine, the Carborundum Company made abrasives and the forerunner of the Nabisco Company made that breakfast treat known as Shredded Wheat. Meanwhile, the city became the place for marital consummation.
But an economic and social winter followed World War II. As families moved to the suburbs, some of the housing fell into disrepair. The collapse of a private power plant in 1956 wounded an already declining industrial base. Imbued with the urban-renewal hope of the 1960's, the city leveled part of downtown and, as Thomas J. DeSantis, the city's senior planner, put it, "waited for development to come." As an added lure, the city erected the convention center that now looms over downtown like a massive concrete Calder sculpture.
The plan did not work, he said. "Since the 1970's, the city's been struggling to redevelop its downtown, to interest people into coming down to this wasteland, this botched-in-the-60's downtown."
If Mr. DeSantis sounds bitter, his is the bitterness of a hometown son. Through the 1980's and into this decade, he said, he has witnessed a series of flawed courtships between the city and several developers. Many of the suitors either broke their promises or stuck the city with low-interest loans to be collected.
A monument to these ill-fated romances is Niagara Splash, a water slide park that the city inherited from a financially troubled developer several years ago. But the city has given up efforts to preserve the attraction; it has pulled the plug on the Splash for the 1997 season. "We were probably losing about $200,000 a year," Mayor Galie said. "We just don't have the money to sink."
The Niagara Falls of today is nothing like the city of Mayor Galie's childhood, or that of Mr. DeSantis. Close to half of the city's families receive some form of public assistance; almost 19 percent live in poverty. In 1989, more than half of the housing stock was estimated to be substandard. And when businesses close or move, they leave behind ghostly buildings that the city cannot afford to raze.
But businesses have not been the only ones leaving town. When Mayor Galie was a child, 102,000 people lived here; when he began walking the police beat in the mid-1960's, there were 90,000 bustling around him. "Now," he said, "we're probably between 55,000 and 58,000."
Although migration to the suburbs explains some of the decline, city officials say, younger people simply cannot find jobs in Niagara Falls. Robert Antonucci, the city's project administrator for community development, said that his meetings with residents always elicited the same plea: "Provide jobs. Keep our young people here. Keep our families together."
This plaintive cry can be found in the grammar school projects that have been taped to the wall of City Hall. One child proposed the construction of the "Niagara Falls Fun Center -- for all people," while another offered the "new Niagara Cinema." In crudely drawn blueprints, they laid out the locations of the swimming pool, the restaurants and the six theaters. The implied request to observers was to imagine the tourists and the jobs.
Given these circumstances, the city wastes little time discussing the moral implications of casinos and ultimate fighting bouts: if they bring revenue, they are welcome. Mayor Galie was elected to office in 1995 based in part on a campaign promise to try to attract an American Indian casino to Niagara Falls.
As if to underscore his argument, the Canadian casino opened in December; from Mayor Galie's City Hall, it is a 15-minute walk across the Rainbow Bridge. Close to 20,000 people a day are visiting the 24-hour casino, but so far, the Mayor said, the city on the American side of the falls has picked up only modest spillover business.
Undaunted by the State Senate's vote against casinos last month, Mayor Galie said he was continuing to hope that an Indian tribe -- preferably one with an aboriginal connection to Niagara Falls -- will want to establish a casino in the troubled downtown. But a recent discussion with the Seneca tribe ended with its leaders informing the Mayor that, for now, they are interested only in bingo.
The Mayor struggles on, raising taxes, cutting city jobs, holding out hope. Last year, he persuaded a Denver telemarketing company to move to downtown Niagara Falls, bringing several hundred jobs. A Hard Rock Cafe opened here last spring. And he courts developers with yet more plans for family-style entertainment centers.
And in the end, Mayor Galie, Mr. DeSantis and the rest will always have Niagara Falls. The obligatory kitsch notwithstanding, the falls remain an international attraction. Some 10 million people a year come to watch the mesmerizing glide of water over cliff and to hear the soothing low roar.
Here, this geologic formation is the center of the world, the symbol of hope and movement. In the anteroom of the city administrator, there are no fewer than 12 lithographs and photographs of the falls. And the falls figure in yet another of Mayor Galie's vaguely promising plans.
He is trying to get United States and Canadian parks officials to reverse their decision not to allow Jay Cochrane, a professional daredevil, to cross over the Niagara Falls gorge on a tightrope later this year. Such stunts have been banned here since 1897. "It's not dead," the Mayor of Niagara Falls said. "But it's not alive that much either."

GRAPHIC: Photos: This ice cream stand will reopen in spring, when tourists return. But a Canadian casino is drawing visitors from the New York side of the falls; Main Street in the depressed downtown section of Niagara Falls, N.Y., has suffered as dozens of steel and chemical plants that once benefited from electrical power generated by the Niagara River have closed. (Photographs by Don Heupel for The New York Times) (pg. 43)

HEADLINE: Black, Yet White: A Hated Color in Zimbabwe

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: HARARE, Zimbabwe

 BODY:
John M. Makumbe is a professor of political science. Richard Nyathi is chief librarian for a Government ministry. Stanley S. Gunda is a senior financial officer in another ministry. Not so long ago, they might have been killed at birth.
Even today, pregnant women refuse to shake their hands. On crowded buses they sit apart. On the street they see mothers point and warn their children, "If you don't behave, I'll let that monkey get you." 
 Messrs. Makumbe, Nyathi and Gunda are albinos. In Africa, far more than on any other continent, that is a lifelong curse. They lack the gene that codes the skin pigment melanin, and they are very nearsighted. As white-skinned men in a black society, they are shunned and feared as the products of witchcraft, taunted by children and drunks as "peeled potatoes," "monkeys" and "ghosts."
There is a stereotype that all albinos are intelligent and accomplished, as these three men are. But Professor Makumbe said successful albinos were "a teeny-weeny minute number." Most, he added, languish at home without education because they cannot see the blackboard at school or because their parents, told such children die young, will not pay for their schooling.
In parts of Africa, albinos rarely live beyond 40. Mr. Nyathi has already lost a 30-year-old brother to skin cancer. And Professor Makumbe said he thought "many just die of frustration -- of broken hearts."
With a handful of other albinos, Professor Makumbe has founded the Zimbabwe Albino Trust. He dreams of a powerful human rights organization that battles prejudice on albinos' behalf. But his first goals are almost pathetically humble: to raise enough money to buy sunscreen lotion and spectacles for albinos who cannot afford them, and to raise $20,000 for a survey to count albinos in Zimbabwe and see what they need most.
In the United States, about 1 person in 20,000 is an albino, according to doctors at the University of Minnesota Medical Center, which has a clinic that studies the genetics of albinism. The condition is more common among blacks than among whites, and almost unknown among Asians.
In parts of Nigeria, as many as 1 in 1,100 are albino; in parts of South Africa the incidence is 1 in 1,800. It varies sharply from country to country and tribe to tribe, said Jennifer Kromberg, an expert on albinism at the South African Institute for Medical Research. For instance, in South Africa it is twice as high among Tswana as among Zulu, she said, because Tswana encourage marriage between cousins while Zulu forbid it.
Estimates for Zimbabwe vary. One done early last year found that 1 schoolchild in 4,700 was albino. An earlier one found nearly twice that rate in Harare.
Albinism comes from a recessive gene and must be inherited from both parents. Not all children in affected families are albino. Mr. Nyathi, for example, has two albino siblings, while his parents and eight other siblings are black.
The condition may skip generations, reappearing to cause confusion and ruin marriages.
Lloyd Thuchila, a pipe fitter, said his father had left his mother shortly after he was born. "He said, 'Why do I have to be the one with an albino child?' " Mr. Thuchila said. " 'No one in my family has an albino.' "
Professor Makumbe, who is married to a black woman and has three black children, said that when his first child was born, one of his colleagues at the University of Zimbabwe asked if the baby was "black, white or colored."
"He's a physicist," Mr. Makumbe said. "He should know better."
Many men accuse their wives of infidelity when albinos are born. Some even accuse them of having had sex with a tokolosh, a devil's imp who is said to be produced by witchcraft from a tree root and to live under beds.
Superstitions are strong in rural Zimbabwe. The practice of killing suspected witches survives, and albino children were once smothered at birth. The belief that adult albinos do not die, but simply vanish, is still widely held.
There is also a lingering belief that albinism is somehow contagious. Many Africans admit to spitting when they see an albino, to ward off the "spell." At parties, Mr. Gunda said, people hesitate to shake his hand. Some albinos say they bring their own food on group outings to avoid embarrassing incidents.
"When my nephew got a rash when he was 18," Professor Makumbe recalled, "my own sister said, 'You must have got this from your Uncle John.' "
Professor Kromberg said surveys she had done among young albino adults in Soweto, South Africa, found that they were rarely shunned on buses or in the classroom but did have much lower marriage rates and believed that they would have difficulty finding work. She said she had come across anecdotal evidence that black children were reluctant to share food with albino classmates.
More disturbingly, she said studies she had done in the 1980's found that mothers of albino children took about nine months to accept them fully. "They keep a distance that's not normal between mother and child, and talk to them less," she said.
She conceded that discrimination might be worse in other African countries. For 25 years she and a social worker have been visiting clinics and reminding nurses to explain to people that the condition is genetic "and not caused by witchcraft or by the mother drinking orange Fanta during pregnancy or by laughing at an albino or other things people believe," she said.
Many albinos have developed a bitter humor about their lot. Twice in the 1970's during the war against the old white regime, Mr. Nyathi was almost shot by guerrillas who took him for a white man. He was very funny as he described walking home from a rural bus stop and seeing three soldiers leap up from behind a bush, pulling back their rifle bolts, then halting in astonishment when he started shouting at them in Ndebele, the language of southern Zimbabwe. "Oh, look, he's an African," they said. "Sorry, brother, sorry!"
Sibongile Chitiyo, a 27-year-old albino studying social work at the University of Zimbabwe, said she could judge a man's feelings for her by his behavior in public. "If people ask who I am, and he says 'Oh, she's my sister,' then I know he's ashamed," she said.
Mr. Nyathi, 36, Mr. Gunda, 33, and Mr. Thuchila, 24, met in the library of the Ministry of Industry and Commerce recently and talked about the difficulties of doing ordinary things like dating and looking for jobs. The day-to-day discrimination that albinos face sounded hauntingly like that suffered by black Americans.
Mr. Gunda recalled how the mother of "the first girl I wanted to marry" declared, "I will commit suicide if I have an albino son-in-law."
All three men mentioned having co-workers who were friendly at work but avoided them socially.
Mr. Nyathi described job interviews he had set up by phone, and the shock and confusion of the interviewers when he walked in. "You know you have failed before you start talking," he said.
Several times as the men spoke, ministry employees came around the bookshelves that hid Mr. Nyathi's desk. Each one started at the sight of several white-skinned men, and retreated, apologizing.
Mr. Nyathi smiled ruefully and reflected on the peculiar shame that discrimination creates in those who must face it. "Albinos tend to unconsciously avoid each other," he said. "If I see another albino on a bus, I won't go stand next to him. Other people will assume he's my brother or something. But you look at each other, and you both have this sense of, 'They're on to us.' "
All three men did well in school, despite vision problems. The genetic differences that cause albinism also change the connections between the optic nerves and the brain. Many albinos have nystagmus -- "dancing eyeballs" -- and myopia that, even with thick glasses, can only be corrected to about 20-200.
"Albinos seem more intelligent because they try harder," Mr. Nyathi said. "You have to get out of your seat, go up to the board, squint, write two sentences, go back, and still finish the test in the same time as the others."
Dr. Kromberg said her intelligence studies had confirmed that. "Albinos have normal I.Q.'s but a higher capability," she said. "I think it's because they don't play in the sun all day. They stay inside and do their homework."
But poverty and discrimination often hold them back.
Mr. Thuchila was a good student but could not afford glasses. He became a pipe fitter in a Government motor depot but had to give up the job because the oils on the lathes he used damaged his fragile skin. His bosses, he said, would not give him a different job, or one he could do with gloves on.
For those who do poorly in school, there is even less hope. "It's pretty common to see an albino with a little bowl, begging on the street," Professor Makumbe said.
His trust is seeking outside money, but without much success. "Foreign embassies usually say, 'Give us a development project, not charity,' " Mr. Thuchila said.
At Christmas the Mayor's office gave $500, an anonymous donor, $300. Johnson & Johnson's local subsidiary donated 50 small bottles of sunscreen lotion and some toothbrushes.
John Chinyandura, a 48-year-old unemployed albino who asked Professor Makumbe to pull together the rights group, knows what he would do if there was more money.
He said he would go on speaking trips throughout Zimbabwe, "to tell people that we are the same blood -- that we are people."

HEADLINE: 2 Giuliani Advisers Prosper From City Lobbying

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
Two of the most influential members of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's kitchen cabinet, Raymond B. Harding and Herman Badillo, have built a prosperous lobbying business at their law firm even as they continue to serve as close advisers to Mr. Giuliani, who controls the very city agencies that they are lobbying.
New York City records show that in the year before Mr. Giuliani took office, the law firm had 3 lobbying clients. It now has nearly 60, including companies and nonprofit groups whose executives acknowledge that they hired the firm -- which charges up to $350 an hour -- to try to gain an advantage in winning contracts or favorable rulings from the Giuliani administration. 
 The firm, Fischbein Badillo Wagner Harding, has done so well that Mr. Harding, in serious financial straits just a few years ago, said he has been able to pay off hundreds of thousands of dollars in debts, including a sizable sum of money he owed in back taxes.
The firm has grown in power despite Mr. Giuliani's repeated contention that he has brought an independent administration into City Hall -- free of patronage, favoritism and other vestiges of clubhouse politics.
Mr. Harding and Mr. Badillo have not been accused of breaking any laws by lobbying the administration; they are unpaid advisers to the Mayor, not municipal employees, who are legally constrained by city conflict of interest laws.
While it is common for lobbyists to be on good terms with elected officials, it is unusual for two of the city's best-known lobbyists to be close mayoral advisers. So the firm's lobbying has stirred questions about conflicts, the perception of conflicts and what the appropriate roles are for people who are the Mayor's confidants but are not on the city payroll.
When he ran against Mayor David N. Dinkins in 1993, Mr. Giuliani made an issue of Mr. Dinkins's friendship with another top lobbyist, Sid Davidoff, arguing that the relationship had compromised the way the city awarded contracts. Now, in this election year, Mr. Giuliani's critics have begun to make similar accusations against him because of his ties to Mr. Harding and Mr. Badillo.
Mr. Harding and Mr. Badillo are both prominent advisers to the Mayor on politics and policy. Mr. Harding, the leader of the state Liberal Party, is also spearheading the Mayor's re-election campaign and has numerous supporters in key jobs in the city administration. Mr. Badillo, an unsuccessful candidate for city comptroller in 1993 as Mr. Giuliani's running mate, is now the Mayor's special adviser on education and a liaison to Hispanic groups.
Fischbein Badillo said it took in $366,849 in lobbying fees last year. But that amount does not include money that it earned doing legal work for its lobbying clients that did not fall under the firm's interpretation of lobbying, which is defined in city law but subject to differing readings. The firm reaped many hundreds of thousands of dollars more last year from those other services, its clients said in interviews.
Fischbein Badillo has also done legal work on a handful of municipal bond deals involving two city agencies, the Educational Construction Fund and the Economic Development Corporation.

A Perception of Power Follows a Law Firm
 The Mayor declined to comment on Mr. Badillo and Mr. Harding, who left his solo legal practice to join the firm in April 1994, soon after Mr. Giuliani moved into City Hall. The Mayor has not publicly discussed whether he has tried to limit the law firm's lobbying activities.
Top mayoral aides insist they show no favoritism toward Mr. Harding, Mr. Badillo or other members of their law firm, but the aides also concede that Mr. Harding's and Mr. Badillo's phone calls are often the first they return. "A major effort is made to make sure that everybody is treated fairly," said John S. Dyson, who was Deputy Mayor for economic development in the first two years of the administration and is now an unpaid special adviser to the Mayor. "But I think that it's natural that people whom you know you tend to talk to."
Mr. Dyson's successor as Deputy Mayor is Fran Reiter, a former Liberal Party chairwoman and a protegee of Mr. Harding. Ms. Reiter, who was Deputy Mayor for community relations before she rose in the administration last year, is one of the Mayor's most important liaisons to the business community. She said she spoke with Mr. Harding regularly, but emphasized that to prevent conflicts of interest, she did not talk with him about substantive matters involving his clients.
She did say that she occasionally advised him on whom he should contact in the administration on behalf of his clients. "I am sure that the perception out there is that it is a leg up" to hire Fischbein Badillo, Ms. Reiter said. "But I can't help that perception. That is always going to be out there, whether it is Fischbein Badillo in this administration or another lobbying firm at another time. I can't control that. All I can do is control my own conduct."
Mr. Harding's influence is familial as well as political. After Mr. Giuliani took office the Mayor not only hired Ms. Reiter, but also gave jobs to both of Mr. Harding's sons: Robert Harding is the city's chief lobbyist in Albany, and Russell Harding is executive vice president for corporate communications at the Economic Development Corporation.
Even if Raymond Harding and Ms. Reiter vow to avoid discussing his clients, he is still lobbying people whom she supervises. Last year, for example, Mr. Harding registered with the city to lobby personally for about 15 clients, including companies that are involved in some of the most hotly contested battles over contracts or rulings.
Lobbying records show that Mr. Harding is representing Donald J. Trump in his bid to develop the Columbus Circle area; Adshel, which is vying for a contract worth hundreds of millions of dollars to build newsstands, portable toilets and bus shelters; Brooklake Associates, which owns Fulton Landing in Brooklyn, and the National Helicopter Corporation, which is fighting neighborhood groups over its use of the 34th Street Heliport in Manhattan.
Ms. Reiter is the Mayor's chief negotiator on many of these issues.
Fischbein Badillo has also lobbied on behalf of at least two clients who are being investigated by the city's Department of Investigation: Promesa, a health care company, and Nemco, a construction company.
Ms. Reiter said she had repeatedly told other officials to treat Mr. Harding like any other lobbyist, and was confident that they were doing so. "I have been very straight with my staff about this," she said.
But some officials at city agencies said it was not so easy to regard Mr. Harding, Mr. Badillo or other lawyers from their firm as just any other lobbyists.
"There is pressure to accommodate those companies," that are represented by Fischbein Badillo, said one high-ranking administration official who spoke on condition of anonymity. A former senior aide who left the administration last year said, "Nobody wanted to cross Fischbein Badillo. You didn't want to get caught in that situation."
It is those kinds of reactions that have spurred criticism of Mr. Giuliani. "How can he even say he's anything like a clean, good-government Mayor, and have as his closest adviser Ray Harding?" said former Mayor Edward I. Koch, an erstwhile Giuliani enthusiast who is now feuding with the Mayor. Mr. Koch questioned whether Mr. Giuliani had allowed Mr. Harding to lobby the administration because Mr. Giuliani needs Mr. Harding's political backing.
"Harding has him by the throat, because Rudy needs the Liberal line," Mr. Koch said, adding that Mr. Harding's support was critical to Mr. Giuliani's 1993 victory and may be again, because the Liberal Party line gives the Mayor, a Republican, credibility with Democratic voters in an overwhelmingly Democratic city.

For Clean Government, Some Very Gray Spots
In an interview, Mr. Harding maintained that his firm's growth in lobbying clients stemmed from the skills of its lawyers, not from political connections. He said he never lobbies the Mayor and dismissed the notion that he receives special treatment.
"The fact that I may see the Mayor socially," he said, "or maybe even talk political matters with him, or maybe rarely be asked views as to the general policy directions of the city, has no bearing at all on these subject matters, which are rather mundane and specifically focused."
Acknowledging his success since joining the firm, Mr. Harding said that in the last year, he had paid the Internal Revenue Service $258,794.14 in back taxes, interest and penalties for taxes he had owed from 1988 through 1993. He said he had fallen behind because he neglected his solo law practice while building the Liberal Party.
Mr. Badillo declined to be interviewed. He said through his partner at the firm, Richard Fischbein, that he, too, does not lobby the Mayor. Mr. Badillo also said that because he advises the Mayor on education, the firm does not lobby on education.
To be sure, several lobbying clients of Fischbein Badillo have not received the contracts or rulings that they wanted from the administration. But interviews with more than a dozen clients indicated that even if they lost, the firm usually won them access to senior officials.
"They have entree to City Hall," said Edward J. Hardy, a spokesman for the American Red Cross in Greater New York. In an unresolved dispute, the Red Cross says it is owed fees by the city, and hired Mr. Harding to lobby Peter J. Powers, who was First Deputy Mayor, as well as his successor, Randy M. Mastro.
Another client, Earle W. Kazis, said he hired the firm to find out what he could not on his own: whether the city would continue renting space in one of his buildings. Mr. Kazis said Fischbein Badillo quickly got him an answer -- that the city was moving out.
The portrayal of Fischbein Badillo as a politically connected law firm angered Mr. Fischbein. He said the lobbying fees that the 70-lawyer firm earned were less than 2 percent of its revenue. "The lobbying issue has as much to do with our firm as the man in the moon," Mr. Fischbein said.
He said the number of clients the firm disclosed had jumped because the city tightened its disclosure rules in 1993. Lobbyists at other firms, though, said the new rules had not had a marked impact. Either way, Fischbein Badillo was 10th in the city in lobbying fees collected in 1995, the last time the city issued rankings.
Lobbying is exhaustively defined in city law, but the language is subject to interpretation. And lobbying experts said the firm was certainly earning money from its lobbying clients that it did not make public, because it did not believe it was required to under the law.
"It's incredibly hazy," said Chris Meyer, an expert on lobbying at the New York Public Interest Research Group.
For example, in 1994 and 1995, the firm reported billing Star Recycling for $21,415 for lobbying. But a person familiar with the the company said he believed that Fischbein Badillo had done lobbying worth at least $100,000 for Star, but had labeled the work legal instead of lobbying.
Mr. Fischbein said the law firm was scrupulous in disclosing all of its lobbying fees. And he pointed out that each company has to confirm the amount in lobbying fees that the firm registers with the City Clerk. If a client disagreed with the firm's accounting, he said, it should have told the firm.

HEADLINE: ALLIES WELCOMING U.S. HINT AT PAUSE IN DOLLAR'S SURGE

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: BERLIN, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Partly shell-shocked and partly delighted by the dollar's extraordinary surge in value in recent months, finance ministers and central bankers from the world's seven largest capitalist countries voiced relief today after signals from the United States that a pause was in order.
One day after Treasury Secretary Robert H. Rubin issued a broad hint that the United States had dropped its two-year effort to boost the dollar's value, finance ministers here for a meeting of the Group of Seven industrialized nations quickly nodded their full agreement. 
 "The dollar's correction process ought to end about now," said Hans Tietmeyer, president of Germany's central bank, at a meeting with reporters today. In recent weeks, Mr. Tietmeyer has characterized the dollar's rise as a necessary and healthy "normalization" to correct what the central bank viewed as serious overvaluation of the German mark.
Those views were echoed by France's Minister of Finance, Jean Arthuis, who expressed considerable satisfaction with where things stand now. "The recent appreciation in the dollar was logical and necessary," he said. "I would like the new configuration of exchange rates to be stable and lasting."
Mr. Rubin's cryptic message on Friday -- "We have had a strong dollar for some time now" -- was fairly close to what his counterparts wanted to hear. The comment was quickly interpreted here as a statement that the United States now favors keeping the dollar around its current level, but not pushing it higher. And that message was welcomed.
But Mr. Rubin and American officials have stopped short of suggesting that they would intervene in the markets -- selling dollars and buying the yen and the mark -- if the dollar continued to climb higher. The only hint of such action today came from Japan, which has been concerned that continued weakness of the yen would cause investors to flee from its already battered stock market.
Questioned today about the possibility of the dollar gaining further ground against the yen despite the change of signals, Japan's Finance Minister, Hiroshi Mitsuzuka said: "G-7 nations have agreed to take appropriate action if it appears to be necessary. No more, and no less." The other members are Britain, Italy and Canada.
Mr. Rubin, the most seasoned market player among the finance ministers because of his long career at Goldman, Sachs & Company, was clearly trying on Friday to sow fear in the markets that a surprise intervention in the markets by the United States and its trading partners is possible. That fear alone could keep the dollar from rising further, because it opens the possibility that speculators could lose billions of dollars on a bet that the dollar would keep surging forward.
Even with today's meeting, though, no amount of public cordiality or tinkering with exchange rates could dispel the sour taste of economic anxiety that is plaguing Japan and much of Europe.
It is one measure of that anxiety that America's biggest trading partners have in recent months been alarmed by both a very weak dollar and a considerably stronger one. There is no magical exchange rate that insures prosperity, and indeed there are dangers whether the dollar moves sharply up or sharply down.
Against that backdrop, most countries were grateful for the chance of a rest. The dollar has soared against most currencies since last year -- by 38 percent against the yen and nearly 20 percent against the mark.
Though Europe and Japan were initially thrilled by the dollar's rise because it boosted their exports by making them cheaper in dollar terms, several were beginning to worry that their currencies might start declining too far and too fast.
Indeed, at a time when German unemployment has been surging to its highest level since 1933 -- 12.2 percent -- exports have been that country's only economic bright spot. Similar patterns have been apparent in Japan, where automobile manufacturers have seen their share of the American market climb by 3.3 percent since May. In Europe and Japan, domestic demand for goods and services remains buried in a slump of pessimism and doubt.
Just three days ago, in fact, the German Government issued data showing that unemployment had soared by 500,000 workers in January alone -- a huge increase that was far worse than expected.
"I think the world economy is relatively healthy, but unfortunately I cannot say the same thing for continental Europe," Mr. Tietmeyer said as he prepared to greet ministers here. "There is a need for structural reform and more flexibility."
Though the countries decided not to issue a formal communique after today's meeting, many officials said that reflected a sense that little more needed to be said on the subject.
But the ministers did issue a statement reflecting their agreement.
"We believe that the problems outlined in our communique of April 1995 in the currency markets have been corrected," the statement said.
"We reaffirm our views that exchange rates should reflect economic fundamentals and that excessive volatility is undesirable."
American officials, speaking on condition of anonymity after the meeting, said their decision had been driven almost entirely by an evaluation of American interests. They said they had not been influenced by pressure from American automobile manufacturers, which have been hit hard by the strong dollar, nor by complaints from other countries.
Most analysts agree that the dollar's current value in relationship to the mark and the yen is about right.

HEADLINE: 'Round and 'Round On Bus-Fuel Issue

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your article about New Jersey Transit's bus purchase policies ("Will the Diesel-Bus Fleet Survive Trenton's Eco-Politics?" Jan. 12) failed to explain why readers should care about the outcome of an otherwise obscure political standoff involving N.J. Transit, the New Jersey Legislature and Governor Whitman. 
 At the heart of the debate is whether N.J. Transit should join the growing list of transit operators around the nation who recognize that they have a responsibility to move people in buses that are as clean as possible. N.J. Transit's current diesel bus fleet fails in this regard.
Diesel buses are among the region's largest local source of fine particulate matter, or soot. Recognizing that at least 60,000 premature deaths annually in the United States can be linked to fine soot, the Environmental Protection Agency recently proposed a stringent new health standard for this pollutant. At least 1,500 of these avoidable deaths are among New Jersey residents.
N.J. Transit's fleet contributes the lion's share of locally produced diesel particulate matter, yet cleaner alternatives like natural gas buses exist. Natural-gas buses are providing safe and reliable transit service in more than 70 fleets around the nation. Among the larger fleets, economies of scale are being reached to make natural-gas buses more cost-effective than diesel over the long haul. With only five natural-gas buses in its fleet and no plans to buy more, New Jersey Transit is woefully behind this industry trend.
Working with a growing roster of political leaders throughout the state, a diverse coalition of environmental, public health, religious, civic and business leaders have been urging N.J. Transit to hasten the switch to cleaner fuels like natural gas. The time is ripe for Governor Whitman and the New Jersey legislature to push New Jersey Transit in the right direction.
 
RICHARD KASSEL
Senior Attorney
Natural Resources Defense Council

HEADLINE: Stamford's Clout In Hartford

BYLINE: By BILL SLOCUM 

 BODY:
MOIRA K. LYONS was a duly-elected State Representative when she first set foot in the Capitol in January 1981, but she felt like an outsider. The issue was geography. Mrs. Lyons was from Stamford, and the goings-on in Hartford seemed parochial to her.
"Being in Hartford was almost as if the state government was just the government for that area," she said. "It was unusual to find leadership from outside that portion of the state." 
 She has reason to feel differently now. Last month Mrs. Lyons began her third term as the House majority leader. And George C. Jepsen, also from Stamford, was installed as the State Senate's majority leader. It is the first time anyone can recall two such highly-placed legislators being from Stamford.
Mrs. Lyons and Mr. Jepsen are also both Democrats. Yet it is the differences many speak of when comparing the two.
She is a process person, who excels at detail rather than speeches. He is a crusader who credits some of his most notable successes to working outside the legislative system. He is committed to tackling social issues like abortion rights and assisted suicide. She is better known for her keen interest in highways.
"They are very different personalities," said Representative Michael P. Lawlor, a Democrat from New Haven. "George puts a lot of emphasis in going out, marketing ideas, and then selling them to the legislature. I think Moira is more focused on making sure that outcomes in the legislature are reasonable and balanced."
Mr. Jepsen was elected to the House in 1986. Unlike Mrs. Lyons, he said he never felt like an outsider, perhaps because of his background of involvement in state Democratic politics, including the first United States Senate campaign of Christopher Dodd in 1980. But he agreed that Stamford and lower Fairfield County have been "estranged" from the rest of the state.
"Stamford specifically and southern Connecticut generally, until recently, never had a seat at the table," he said. "There's been a shift, not simply because of the emerging power base, but also because of the emerging economic base."
While the rest of the state struggles to shake off the effects of the recession of the early 90's, Stamford is going through a boom period. Employment is up. New construction, including a stocktrading center complex and a downtown branch of the University of Connecticut, promises more good times ahead.
"I joked with George when I visited his office" -- at Landmark Square in Stamford -- "and saw the construction projects downtown, asking what those long metal things were," said Senator Kevin B. Sullivan, a West Hartford Democrat who became Senate president pro tempore this term. "We long for the vision of a construction crane."
Stamford bills itself these days as "The City That Works," and Mayor Dannel P. Malloy said having Mrs. Lyons and Mr. Jepsen in such positions of power is heartening.
"If not a zenith, this is clearly a high point in Stamford's influence in the state," Mr. Malloy said.
Two other State Representatives from the city, Anne McDonald and John Wayne Fox, head committees on public health and general law, respectively. Across the aisle, Republican Senator William H. Nickerson of Greenwich, whose district includes the portion of Stamford not served by Mr. Jepsen, is ranking member of the Finance Committee, while Senator Robert L. Genuario of nearby Norwalk holds the same post in Appropriations.
"It's not just two leaders, but a delegation all playing at the top of their game," Mr. Jepsen said.
Mr. Jepsen and Mrs. Lyons both deny pursuing a "Stamford-first" agenda. But there are issues of importance to the lower Fairfield County region in which they are expected to wield critical influence.
"I don't think there's anything more vital to our area's economic future than transportation," Mayor Malloy said.
There is major congestion along southwestern Connecticut's main traffic artery, Interstate 95. Mrs. Lyons, a former chairwoman of the House Transportation Committee, continues to be an advocate of mass transit. Mr. Jepsen is likewise committed. "The transportation issue is not just a question of I-95 and trains, but the interplay between the two," he said.
Shuttle bus service and additional parking lots near railroad stations throughout the county are proposed by both parties as well as a regional lobbying group, the Southwest Area Commerce and Industry Association (Sacia).
Mrs. Lyons said better transportation is critical if the rest of the state is to reap some benefit from lower Fairfield County's robust economy.
One issue said to be of less concern in recent years is taxes. In years past, a dominant feeling was that the rest of the state leaned too heavily on lower Fairfield County for revenue. When Sacia did a tax flow study of transportation spending in 1987, it reported a differential of around 20 percent favoring the Hartford region over southwestern Connecticut.
But Joe McGee, a Sacia official, said that the last 10 years have brought healthy change. He credits the emergence of figures like Mrs. Lyons and Mr. Jepsen, as well as a "very good working relationship" between Democrats and Republicans from Fairfield County. "There's a lot more collaboration," Mr. McGee said. "It has strengthened Fairfield County's hand."
Mrs. Lyons said that Fairfield County continues to provide more state revenue than any other county, while receiving less than troubled urban areas like Hartford and Bridgeport.
"We probably shouldn't get as much grant money outright as a city in distress," she said. But she added the mind-set in Hartford of seeing lower Fairfield County as a cash cow for spending elsewhere has diminished. "And yes, being a majority leader helps diminish it, no doubt about it," she added.
The region still has image problems. When he and other lower Fairfield County legislators strenuously opposed Gov. John G. Rowland's support for a casino in Bridgeport, Mr. Jepsen said he had the feeling "people up in Hartford thought we were just unhappy because it would take us an extra half-hour to get to our vacation homes on the Cape and Block Island."
Both Mr. Jepsen and Mrs. Lyons say the problem is two-sided, with too many Fairfield County residents more focused on New York City than on events in the state. Cable television, which has given Fairfield County access to Hartford-area channels, and the election of Lowell P. Weicker Jr., of Greenwich, as Governor in 1990 have helped improve matters, but much has to be done.
At least one legislator -- Mr. Lawlor -- says he is concerned about having two such highly placed people from the same city. "A fundamental part of politics is geography," he said. "The fact that the two legislative managers are from Stamford is a concern."
Others are more sanguine. "Anybody in leadership gets there on their merits," said the House Speaker Thomas Ritter, a Democrat of Hartford.
There is no shortage of admirers on either side of the aisle when it comes to Mrs. Lyons. Mr. Ritter, her senior partner on the House leadership team, calls her a "real technician."
"When things go smoothly in the House, it's because of her," he said. "Beyond that, she gives me the best political advice I can get."
Among Republicans, Pamela Z. Sawyer, of Bolton, said Mrs. Lyons "set a standard for consensus" in the last term, when the state budget was passed on time.
Mrs. Lyons said there was a conscious decision to avoid partisan brickbats last term, despite the fact that the Democrat-dominated House was dealing with a budget proposal from a Republican governor.
"People were taking bets on how long we'd stay in session, that we'd never adjourn in June," she said. "I think we showed them that we really take our job seriously. We believe we are elected to give people good legislation, not sit around and be political animals."
The term "political animal" comes up a good deal when talk turns to Mr. Jepsen. For his part, Mr. Jepsen ticks off a succession of issues he has pushed for, saying the state now has "the strongest living will law in the nation, the strongest pro-choice law in the nation, and the strongest domestic violence laws in the nation."
"I may not have been the only person pushing for them, but in all cases I was the most active, aggressive leader,," he said.
Sometimes, Mr. Jepsen recalled, some Democratic leaders urged him to slow down, as with the 1990 abortion rights bill. He may not have gone along with them, but he insisted that his advocacy has never gotten in the way of being a team player.
"George spends a great deal of time staying in touch with colleagues," Mr. Sullivan said. "He's unafraid to take on tough issues or even the Governor from time to time. His colleagues see that as a strength."
Republicans are more divided on Mr. Jepsen. Mr. Genuario of Norwalk called Mr. Jepsen "a substantive, hard-working legislator."
But the party's State Chairman, Chris DePino, a State Representative from New Haven, said Mr. Jepsen has been "a strident partisan" on several issues, and a chief instigator of friction in last year's Senate session. If Mr. Jepsen is to be an effective majority leader, Mr. DePino said, he will have to make himself over. "His view has got to be much broader," Mr. DePino said.
Mr. Jepsen said he proved he can lead effectively and in bipartisan style when he headed the Judiciary Committee in 1993 and in 1994. While its passage of an assault weapons bill proved contentious, the committee also dealt with a variety of nuts-and-bolts issues like probate law and adoption, and with minimum fuss.
"I tackle tough issues, but not as a firebrand," Mr. Jepsen said. He paraphrased Kenny Rogers: "I know when to hold 'em, know when to fold 'em.' "
One example of the latter was his decision not to push forward a bill last year that would have legalized assisted suicide; the votes for passage simply weren't there. He said its passage would soon arrive: "The public believes in the right to control our own bodies in terms of the right to die. The politicians will catch up."
Mrs. Lyons keeps a lower public profile, but the State Democratic Chairman, Edward L. Marcus, said that "doesn't mean she's not equally as effective."
"She has the votes," he said, noting the Democrats' overwhelming majority in the House. "If you have the votes, you vote. If you don't, you talk."
She is viewed as a moderate by some, a conservative by others. "I don't really see myself as a political individual," she said.
Others say she does speak out from time to time. Last year she took an influential stand against managed care policies for women given birth that became known as "drive-by deliveries." A minimum 48-hour post-natal hospitalization period is now mandatory.

HEADLINE: Despite Critics, New U.N. Chief Keeps His Style

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Kofi Annan captivated Capitol Hill. He dazzled financiers and political leaders at Davos.
The United Nations' new Secretary General impresses nearly everyone he meets as ever so nice, but now they are discovering that he is also ever so cautious. And although Washington and other capitals are reluctant to pass judgment so early on the man the Clinton Administration promoted as the organization's savior, some of his first moves -- or lack thereof -- have disappointed. 
 By Mr. Annan's own admission, the job he assumed last month makes him "the man in the middle," the chief administrative officer -- with very limited authority -- over only part of an unwieldy, decentralized, global system that takes orders from the 185 countries of the world that make up its membership.
"I'm trying to move the organization to go through with reform at a time when lots of people think that the United States is imposing reform and that the member states are not ready," he said in an interview on Friday in his office overlooking the East River. "You can come with the best blueprint, but if you impose reform, you're never going to go anywhere."
Asked whether he had an impossible job before him, he replied, "A friend of mine described it as a job from hell."
A career international civil servant from Ghana who is said to have never raised his voice with colleagues, Mr. Annan, 58, whose name is pronounced to rhyme with cannon, has survived and thrived in the labyrinthian United Nations bureaucracy for more than three decades because he prefers quiet, slow-moving consensus-building to dramatic, bold action.
But it is precisely that quality that may make it hard for him to press the United Nations to change -- the only way the United States will pay more than $1 billion in back dues.
In its 1998 budget proposal released on Thursday, the Administration proposed spending $100 million next year and $912 million in 1999 to pay its debt. However, the payments are contingent on a level of reform that the Administration and the Congress have yet to define.
"It's not ideal, but given the history and circumstances it's probably the best we could get," Mr. Annan said, acknowledging that he has no choice but to accept the proposal even though the payments are not at all certain and even though the United Nations says the United States owes $300 million more.
Mr. Annan disagrees that his studied, low-key style is a liability. "There seems to be a sense out there that unless you are confrontational and get into contentious situations you are not tough, you are not a leader, you are not free," he said. "I've never shared that view in my life and I'm not going to change now. I often tell my colleagues you can even win without fighting so why do I have to go and pick unnecessary fights."
Much to the dismay of the United States and some of the other big donors, Mr. Annan has announced that he will not have a comprehensive reform plan ready until late July at the earliest, after the entire United Nations membership has had an opportunity to weigh in.
"A good leader must also be a good follower," he said of his decision to wait until all the other countries have their say.
But the delay misses the opportunity to capitalize on the extraordinary goodwill surrounding Mr. Annan in succeeding Boutros Boutros-Ghali, the Egyptian whose ouster was spearheaded by the United States.
It also gives conservative Republicans in Congress time to preempt Mr. Annan with their own legislation.
"I was a little surprised," said Princeton Lyman, the Assistant Secretary of State for International Organizations, of Mr. Annan's decision to take so much time. "There are a number of steps we have all been waiting for, and frankly, we hope he takes them before July."
One change the United States and the world's six other largest industrial countries say they want is the merging of the United Nations' three economic departments under a single head, a proposal they formally presented last year.
Even the departments' titles suggest duplication: the Department for Policy Coordination and Sustainable Development, the Department for Economic and Social Information and Policy Analysis, and the Department for Development Support and Management Services.
But when Edward W. Gnehm Jr., the acting chief American representative, and Ambassador Alain Dejamet of France met with Mr. Annan on Tuesday to press him for a decision on behalf of the group, he said he was not ready to make a decision, according to diplomats familiar with the meeting.
In fact, they said, he changed the subject. And when the two envoys tried again, Mr. Annan refused to be pinned down.
"This is an idea that has been around for a long time," said one diplomat. "Even the Chinese seem to be in favor. It's all, well, a bit disappointing."
Mr. Annan's reappointment of most of the senior bureaucracy at the United Nations -- many on contracts of three to five years -- instead of cleaning house has also dismayed the United States, some of the other members and even some officials inside the bureaucracy. He has even given plum assignments to several senior officials who openly lobbied against him for Mr. Boutros-Ghali.
"Uninspired," is how one senior Administration official described the appointments.
To that charge, Mr. Annan replied that the right time to make personnel changes is not in the midst of a far-reaching reform process. "Change is a process; it's not an event," he said.
Still, the way Mr. Annan has decided to organize his reform team is already causing confusion about who will do what.
Mr. Annan appointed Maurice Strong, a former businessman from Canada who has undertaken a number of United Nations missions, to a newly created post of "executive coordinator for reform" at a symbolic salary of $1 a year. But Mr. Strong reports directly to Mr. Annan, not to Joseph E. Connor, the American Under Secretary General in charge of the United Nations' administration and management.
The two men are said to have a correct relationship at best.
The Administration has expressed concern that Mr. Strong may usurp or duplicate some of the functions now performed by Mr. Connor, a former chairman and chief executive of Price Waterhouse, whom the Administration hand-picked to lead the reform effort three years ago.
In addition, Mr. Strong openly campaigned for a second term for Mr. Boutros-Ghali, predicting that efforts by Madeleine K. Albright, then the chief American representative, to oust him would fail.
When Ms. Albright met with Mr. Annan before she left for Washington as Secretary of State, she had a two-word reaction to Mr. Strong's appointment, according to American officials: "Why Strong?"
Mr. Annan explained that Mr. Connor would continue to deal with making the United Nations more efficient, but that he needed Mr. Strong to reach out to the countries that belong to the United Nations and craft a plan reflecting their larger vision for change.
"Reform is a full-time activity," Mr. Annan said in defending Mr. Strong's appointment. "It is not something I can tag on to Mr. Connor's functions."
Meanwhile, there is still a third reform apparatus: a handful of committees made up of all the countries in the United Nations, headed by Ismael Rezali of Malaysia, the president of the General Assembly, many with their own specific ideas of what does and does not need to be changed.
As part of his conciliatory style and his determination to reach out to the United States Congress, Mr. Annan has invited a team from the staffs of several lawmakers, including that of Senator Jesse Helms, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and an outspoken critic of the United Nations, to discuss reform at the organization next week.
Mark Thiessen, Mr. Helms's spokesman, said the purpose of the meeting is to give Mr. Annan "some input" into the specific targets for the United Nations that Mr. Helms will include in legislation he intends to introduce before any taxpayers' money is spent on back dues.
Mr. Annan said he is "uncomfortable" with specific targets dictated by Washington, but his gesture to consult closely with Congress at all has sparked criticism from other delegations that he is America's man at the United Nations.
"I am a free man," he insisted.
He is a realist as well.
"Without Congress the payment cannot be made," he said. "To those who say, 'Aren't you setting a bad example and are you going to do the same for all the other 184 Parliaments in the world?' my answer is, 'I will devote the same attention to any country that pays 25 percent of the dues and owes $1.3 billion.' "

HEADLINE: College Finally Finds a Home in Downtown Bridgeport

BYLINE: By FRED MUSANTE

 BODY:
STUDENTS sitting on upholstered benches in the atrium that is the main entrance of the new Housatonic Community-Technical College in Bridgeport might find it difficult to imagine that the building had once been a shopping mall.
David Council, beginning his first semester as an accounting major, said he didn't recognize much of the old Hi Ho Mall at all, but Ana Sharp, who was browsing through a course catalogue for introductory computer offerings, was able to recall the mall. "There was an escalator here," she said, pointing to a space where no escalator remained, "and there was a Chinese restaurant." 
 All around them were pieces of the college's 4,500-piece art collection, giving the space a serene eloquence the shopping mall never had.
In January the college moved from its rented home of 26 years in an old sewing machine factory on the East Side of Bridgeport into its new $27 million home in downtown Bridgeport. The move pleased the college community as well as the municipal government and downtown merchants, who see the college as an important component of the city's rebirth. Lots of people were talking about what might be next in downtown Bridgeport's revitalization. "It's like getting new clothes or a new hairdo," said Janis Wertz, the president of Housatonic Community-Technical College. "'It just makes you feel different."
What was equally remarkable was how successful the college project was. The building's architecture manages to be understated but not boring. Moreover, it was a sizeable government construction project completed within budget and on time.
That was in sharp contrast to the decades of delays and disputes over where the 31-year-old college's permanent home should be. "It's been a very long and tortured history," said Esther Watstein, of the college's public relations office. "It was the only state college in Connecticut that didn't have its own property." Housatonic was created in 1966 as a branch of Norwalk Community college. Its classes met in Bunnell High School and Wooster Junior High School in Stratford. It was formally established as an independent state junior college the following year. Over the next few years, its classroom sites spread into church halls, a library and a Masonic temple, while state officials searched for a permanent site.
Studies in 1970 and 1971 recommended more than a dozen places in Bridgeport, Stratford and Trumbull, but no action was taken. In 1971, Housatonic signed a 10-year lease for the former factory of Singer Sewing Machines on Barnum Avenue in Bridgeport.
As the lease approached expiration, another study recommended moving Housatonic to shared space on the campus of the University of Bridgeport (which had lost much of its enrollment and had empty buildings). But that was rejected by Housatonic's trustees, who chose instead to negotiate an extension of the college's lease. Quarreling between interest groups within the college and in the city government over where the school should go, and a steadily shrinking number of acceptable sites, stymied efforts throughout the 1980's to find a permanent home for Housatonic.
But as the state's economy slipped into recession, city leaders, the college trustees and state officials selected the Hi Ho Mall, which was bankrupt and millions of dollars behind on its property taxes by 1994 when the state took possession of it.
The state -- rather than advertise bid specifications and select the low bidder -- asked contractors and architects to submit design ideas and chose the one thought to be in the best interest of the college and the city. The winning proposal was swiftly completed without add-ons or revisions. "We knew what they wanted and they knew what they were getting," said Louis Cappucci, vice president of operations of the Fusco Corporation, the general contractor.
Its intended use, its urban setting and the college's determination to be able to display its extensive art collection guided the final design. The original structure was completely gutted, keeping only the columns, beams and floor slabs. About a third of it was completely torn down to create a courtyard between the college itself and the parking garage. Part of the garage was also removed so that the main entrance would be exposed to the street.
Petina Killiany, an architect with the S/L/A/M Collaborative, the design contractor, said the twin themes of an urban campus and an Ivy League atmosphere went into the architecture. The exterior is defined by the use of vertical lines and curves. The courtyard is intended to draw in the buildings much as a traditional university quadrangle does, and will be the site of a sculpture garden.
Inside and out, Ms. Killiany said, the design is urban minimalist, thought best to display the art collection. Two art galleries off the main entry atrium will be used for shows, but pieces from the collection are hung on walls in hallways and offices throughout the building.
The college and its art collection are considered to be major assets for Bridgeport's efforts to revitalize its downtown business district. Chris Duby, a spokesman for Mayor Joseph P. Ganim, said the college would help restore the downtown area as "the cultural and economic development center for the city." Just having Housatonic's 2,600 students there will help the downtown economy, he said.
"We are now getting a renewed interest in retail in the downtown," said Michael Freimuth, the city's director of economic development. The Days Inn hotel, which went into bankruptcy and closed several years ago, will soon be torn down and redeveloped as retail stores, he said.
Mr. Freimuth said the college is the second of a three-part state government development program aimed at aiding the city's downtown economy. The first was to move State Police Barracks Troop G to a building there, and the third will be the redevelopment of the former Sears department store, the last piece of the mall site, into a state office building. He added that the college and its art collection also support two economic development themes: arts and entertainment, and educational and cultural development.
Housatonic Community-Technical College also now has many amenities: four computer labs filled with new hardware, all linked in networks and offering access to the Internet. Most classrooms are equipped with video monitors and VCR's.
The school also has a day care center with two classrooms. The center be available for the children of the college's students, and one classroom has a one-way mirror through which students in early childhood development courses will be able to observe the children at play.
The new college also has a student lounge that looks out into the courtyard. The old lounge was too small and occasionally had to serve as a lecture hall.
Frambiel Rodriquez, sitting in the lounge waiting for his criminal justice course class to start, said he remembered the Hi Ho Mall, but noted there was little left of it. "You can recognize the shopping mall when you first come in, the second-floor balcony, but that's the only thing," he said.
