HEADLINE: A Vacant Tower in Philadelphia Casts a Shadow

BYLINE: By DAVID J. WALLACE 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
WRANGLING over repairs to a fire-scarred office tower in this city's commercial heart has become a major obstacle to downtown revitalization. Vacant and barricaded for more than six years because of a dispute between its owner and an insurance company, it has become such an eyesore that neighboring property owners say their own plans for redevelopment are in jeopardy.
The building is One Meridian Plaza, a 38-story, 756,000-square-foot office tower where a fire in 1991 killed three firefighters and heavily damaged 11 floors. While the owner and Aetna Corporation, the fire insurer, prepare for litigation over how to proceed on repairs, and at what cost and under whose control, neighboring property owners have been waiting for a decision on the building before making their own plans. 
 Behind the tower, on Chestnut Street, a smaller office building and several three-story shops damaged by falling debris from the fire sit with gray cinderblocks in windowframes and doorways. "You can't do anything until you have the disposition of the Meridian building," said Warren Dunlap, a sales agent for Edward M. Paul & Company, which represents several retail and office properties behind the Meridian Plaza.
Meridian Plaza is on 15th Street between Market and Chestnut Streets, diagonally across Penn Square from City Hall. The century-old City Hall is at Broad and Market Streets, which form the north-south and east-west axes of the city's downtown.
Just east of City Hall is the new Criminal Justice Center and the new Pennsylvania Convention Center. The Wilma Theater opened late last year south of City Hall along South Broad Street, a portion of which the city has dubbed the Avenue of the Arts.
J. Ward Larkin, a local real estate broker, called the Meridian Plaza fire "the best thing and worst thing to happen to Broad Street."
"It forced people to make some decisions and created a blank slate for an entrance to the Avenue of the Arts," he said. "That area had died anyway and the fire created an opportunity for a gateway."
Until 1987, no building was permitted to rise higher than City Hall, which with the statue of William Penn atop it stands 548 feet high. Since then, five office towers, ranging in height from 700 to 945 feet, mainly west of City Hall along Market Street, have been built. These have provided the major competition for postwar buildings of an earlier vintage such as One Meridian Plaza, which was completed in 1972.
THE fire on Feb. 11, 1991, started when a workman's chemicals and rags were ignited accidentally. The blaze, which burned for 19 hours, raged from the 22d floor to the 30th floor, raining down glass panels and debris to the street below, before a sprinkler system installed by a tenant on the 30th floor extinguished the flames.
(The Meridian Plaza, which included partial asbestos insulation, rose before the building code required sprinkler systems. The requirement went into effect in December 1991, but the building had been grandfathered under the old code.)
The building is owned by E/R Partners, a joint venture of the Rubin Organization, a Philadelphia real estate company; Equitable Life Assurance Company of America and a Dutch pension fund. Consulting engineers for the owner say structural steel elements were bent into an hour-glass shape by the fire's intense heat, according to Jeffrey Rotwitt, the owner's spokesman and a lawyer with Obermeyer Rebmann Maxwell & Hippel of Philadelphia. He added that fire-damaged walls, floors and granite slabs had been contaminated with chemicals that require hazardous-waste disposal.
The engineers have proposed stripping the building to structural steel to just below the 19th floor and reconstructing it at a cost of $250 million, Mr. Rotwitt said.
But Aetna maintains that undamaged, existing girders above that level can be used, cutting repair costs to $115 million. Aetna also has proposed taking over the reconstruction, as permitted in the language of its insurance policy, and returning it after completion to the owners.
The owner has rejected the proposal, saying Aetna is delaying a settlement and trying to force a lower cash settlement on the owners. To that Aetna's lawyer, Henry Daar, of the Chicago firm of Kostauer & Daar, says that it is the owner who is delaying.
"If they were so motivated to get back in business why haven't they done anything with this building," Mr. Daar said. "The Dutch pension fund has $250 billion in assets; it's the second largest fund in the world. If they wanted to repair it, they could afford it. But if they could get the loss of rents for years and years, what's the impetus to do anything with this building?"
Meanwhile. ongoing maintenance continues at the building with monthly expenses totaling $500,000 for security guards, utilities and ongoing inspections by engineers, Mr. Rotwitt said, adding that the owners say they have spent $50 million to secure and safeguard the tower.
E/R Partners has $90 million in escrow, to be used for the redevelopment. The money was amassed from suits against 45 companies, ranging from the metal cleaning company that caused the fire to the fire department's supplier of nozzles that were ineffective in combatting the fire, Mr. Rotwitt said.
Mr. Rotwitt said the claim against Aetna included $250 million for the cost of restoring the building to its original condition; $60 million in rent lost during the last six years and $50 million in interim expenses plus interest lost by the partners since the fire.
Adjacent to the damaged tower, Craig Spencer, a local developer who has bought and renovated several downtown office and retail properties, acquired an old office building in 1993 with plans to restore it to office use. As the office market weakened, he decided instead to convert the building into a 350-room Westin hotel.
CONSTRUCTION of the $62-million project, which acquired its financing last December, could spur action at the Meridian Plaza and a vacant property across from Mr. Spencer's building, where offices could be converted into apartments.
While the burned-out Meridian Plaza has had a major effect on holding up development in the area, Mr. Spencer said, other factors also contributed to it. He cited the recession, the abundance of available office space and the shift in the office market to the western edge of downtown. "I hope that our project will be a catalyst to get the block going again," Mr. Spencer said. "It's an eyesore, you can't get away from that. I don't think I can help it. I know I can't hurt it. But it's tough for me to say if that building hurt my project."
Instead of restoring the Meridian Plaza to its previous condition, a more economically viable project might include a mixed-use office, hotel and retail center, said Forrest Huffman, associate professor of legal/real estate studies at Temple University. But such a major change would only complicate negotiations, he added.
Professor Huffman, however, is not too perturbed by the status quo. "It's an excellent location for office space but there's just too much office space and if you're putting money into this, you're not going to get much out of it," he said. "In some ways it makes sense to let it sit rather than bringing it back online in a time of oversupply."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 16, 1997, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about a dispute over fire insurance coverage of the Meridian Plaza office building in Philadelphia included an outdated reference to the insurance company involved. The company has been known as Travelers/Aetna Property Casualty Corporation since Aetna Inc.'s sale of its property and casualty portfolio last year to Travelers Group.

HEADLINE: Treasury Sets Debt Refunding For This Week

 BODY:
The Treasury undertakes its quarterly refunding this week with auctions of 3- and 10-year notes and 30-year bonds. The schedule of financing also includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills.
The quarterly refunding will begin tomorrow with the sale of $17.75 billion of 3-year notes, followed by $12 billion of 10-year notes on Wednesday and $10 billion of 30-year bonds on Thursday. 
 At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.98 percent and on the six-month issue, 5.04 percent. In when-issued trading, the 3-year note was offered at a price to yield 5.98 percent; the 10-year at a price to yield 6.36 percent, and the 30-year bond, 6.64 percent.

HEADLINE: A Wider Public for Noncommercial Radio

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

 BODY:
For the first time, public radio stations are being asked to demonstrate their relevance to their own communities or risk having their Federal funds cut off. The demand for accountability is forcing a new discipline on smaller broadcasters, who are struggling to broaden their appeal without crossing the line into commercial radio.
In the Los Angeles area, three of the six noncommercial radio stations, which all occupy the lower end of the FM dial, received notice that they currently failed to meet the new financing criteria set by the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, the Federal-financed entity that will provide 620 public stations with $260 million in support this year. On average, stations rely on Federal money for 16 percent of their budgets. 
 Los Angeles has 80 or so commercial stations, nearly all owned by groups that have bid up station prices in recent years and rely on mass appeal to generate enough cash to service their debts. It is the noncommercial stations that provide room for long discussions on issues and for idiosyncratic programming.
The Corporation for Public Broadcasting's criteria, developed in the face of fewer Federal dollars and prodding from Republicans in Congress, who question taxpayer support for public broadcasting, is based on a complex set of standards. A station must demonstrate a minimum audience size and a certain level of local financial support, depending on the number of people in its market and the geographic reach of its broadcast signal.
In a reflection of the fractious, fragmented character of noncommercial radio, each of the small Los Angeles stations under threat is using different strategies to satisfy the new qualifications. About a dozen other stations elsewhere in the country -- including KDHX in St. Louis, WYSO in Yellow Springs, Ohio, and KBOO in Portland, Ore. -- have also been warned that their Federal funds might be cut off this year because their audiences and local financial support fell short of the eligibility threshold.
Even operators of strong public radio stations, with bigger budgets and audiences, are heeding the self-help message. Some are adopting the business practices of their commercial cousins, although under different guises, by consolidating operations and allying with others to jointly raise funds.
Critics of this new approach say it squelches distinctive programming by pushing stations to adopt more successful, uniform formats. Because only 10 percent of listeners contribute to noncommercial radio, the new rules also force more reliance on corporate support, which some critics believe jeopardizes the independence of broadcasts.
But Robert T. Coonrod, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting's chief operating officer, said: "These standards are reasonable. Mature institutions ought to periodically assess their impact on the community. We're not suggesting they have to become rock-and-roll stations to get reasonable support."
In fact, the music itself was removed from the programming at KPCC in Pasadena, Calif., which became the region's first all-talk alternative radio station.
Rating figures show that KPCC's audience is climbing, but is still short of the mark, said Rod Foster, the station's manager. KPCC, which operates from Pasadena City College, faces the loss of $175,000 in Federal funds from its $1.5 million budget.
"We hope we will make the C.P.B. number by the fourth quarter," Mr. Foster said. "If not, we hope it's enough to convince them to stick with us."
At KPFK in Los Angeles, one of five stations operated by the Pacifica Foundation, which include WBAI in New York, the new guidelines came as management was imposing more structure on a chaotic programming schedule that catered to ethnic and interest groups.
KPFK, a standard-bearer for leftist ideology, eliminated programs devoted to medicinal hemp, atheists and Central America. Others were shifted to different times, like the one featuring former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California. As a result, some defiant volunteer programmers revolted, briefly seizing control of the station in February 1996. They accused KPFK of going mainstream.
"Our independence speaks for itself," said Mark Schubb, the general manager, who after a few frantic minutes threw the switch and took the dissidents off the air. The Pacifica stations are among the few that reject corporate sponsorships. About 80 percent of Pacifica's $8.5 million budget comes from listener donations, while the rest -- which KPFK says is crucial -- comes from the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.
Along with program changes, the station's pleas for money moved listeners to increase donations 37 percent last year, to $1.3 million. Mr. Schubb says KPFK now meets the new financial-support standards.
At KCSN, a classical-music station on the Northridge campus of California State University in the San Fernando Valley, taxpayer funds of $115,000 make up 30 percent of the budget. "Were assuming the worst -- that we'll lose it," said William Toutant, the station's acting general manager and associate dean of the college of arts, media and communications. "We have not been aggressive enough in tapping corporate underwriting. The classical music audience is not a mass audience."
Lynn Chadwick, president of the National Federation of Community Broadcasters and a member of a task force that established the financing criteria, said, "The intent of this redesign was not to kick stations out, but to help them focus on getting listeners and listener support."
"It is a threat," she added. "It has helped some stations move in a direction they needed to."
In Seattle, for example, the two public radio stations, KUOW and KPLU, have begun offering joint underwriting, giving corporate sponsors a simpler way to reach their combined audiences and for the stations to save money.
In New York, WFUV at Fordham University has focused its format on music, dropping several specialty programs aimed at ethnic groups, and news from The Christian Science Monitor. Its audience has grown.
"Today, we have a much healthier station in terms of economic support," said Ralph Jennings, WFUV's general manager. But the station's audience is still insufficient to meet the new financing standards. "They don't believe public broadcasters should serve fragmented tastes," Mr. Jennings said.
A harsher critic of the standards is Mr. Schubb of KPFK. He says a loss of Federal support will make noncommercial radio too reliant on corporate support and chill independent programming. "The national news brought to you by Archer Daniels Midland," he said, paraphrasing a sponsorship tag line on National Public Radio. "These things seriously compromise democratic debate."

HEADLINE: At Home Abroad;
Reaons For Optimism

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG

 BODY:
Bobby Godsell is a top executive in the Anglo-American Corporation, the dominant force in South African business. I asked him how he thought the country was doing two and one-half years after its democratic transformation.
"All things considered I think we're doing extraordinarily well," he said. "On the economy I am very optimistic -- robustly optimistic. The reason is that I think the fundamental diseases of the economy are at long last being tackled." 
 The "diseases" that afflicted the country in the last decades of the apartheid Government included high budget deficits and inflation, sapping investment. President Nelson Mandela's Government is reducing both, and Mr. Godsell said "there is every indication that they'll keep to the target they have set."
President Mandela and his colleagues have made it their prime goal to attract new capital investment to modernize South African industry. To that end they are following a conservative fiscal policy and plan to privatize Government-owned companies such as South African Airways in whole or part.
Mr. Godsell's optimism was not based only on economic considerations. He spoke also of social change.
In the past, he said, labor relations were crippled by the politicized divisions of race. "Blacks and whites had different pubs, different sports heroes, different politics. It was Nadine Gordimer's world. That cannot make for productive human relationships at work.
"That has changed enormously," Mr. Godsell said. For example, large numbers of black children are now in Government schools with whites in the once-segregated suburbs of Johannesburg.
"It is one of the most successful pieces of racial integration that I know about in the world," he said. "It is one area in which the two worlds have begun to overlap."
He also mentioned sports. Soccer, which was an almost exclusively black sport, now has 10 or 15 percent whites in the stands at matches. And there are blacks in the crowd at rugby and cricket.
The upbeat appraisal ends, for Bobby Godsell and everyone else, when it comes to one subject: violent crime. Concern about that crosses lines of race and class. Among those who raised it with me as a profound problem was Walter Sisulu, Nelson Mandela's life-long comrade in the African National Congress.
Carjacking, as it is called, is a menace in the Johannesburg area. People are stopped at gunpoint as they leave their homes, told to get out -- and sometimes killed. Crime syndicates fill orders for particular makes and models.
Another common practice, less terrible but still frightening, is for a criminal to smash the front passenger window when a car is stopped at a traffic light, reach in and grab a cellular telephone or a woman's purse. That has happened twice to Mr. Mandela's secretary at A.N.C. headquarters in Johannesburg, Beryl Baker.
The police are less than effective for several reasons. In the apartheid years their resources were devoted overwhelmingly to suppressing dissent instead of fighting crime. Corruption has been rampant. There has been little visible patrolling.
The Government is prosecuting policemen in large numbers; 400 have been arrested in the Johannesburg area on corruption charges in two years. In his speech at the opening of Parliament last week Mr. Mandela said, "We will make criminals' lives difficult this year." But meanwhile the fear of crime has pushed up the white emigration rate.
Some think high unemployment is a factor in crime. The economic growth rate, 3 percent, is better than it has been but just about keeps up with the population increase.
The truth is that while racial divisions have eased dramatically, the lines of class are still there. Millions of black South Africans subsist outside the formal economy, without decent homes. In the election campaign in 1994 the A.N.C. promised a mass housing program, but only now is the Government beginning to make progress on housing.
There are shortcomings in the Government's performance, but there are also pluses. It has brought electricity and clean water to millions for the first time. It has set out to restore land to blacks from whom it was seized. And more broadly, everyone knows it is a government that looks to the interests of the majority: the first in South Africa's history.

HEADLINE: Special Winter Games Warm Hearts in Toronto

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Feb. 9

 BODY:
It was the same kind of tiered stage used for award ceremonies at the Olympics. Gold, silver and bronze medals were standard here too. Even the triumphal music was similar.
But when athletes like Thabelang Gumbi of South Africa or Liu Yanpeng of China stepped forward on shaky knees to receive medals for skating in the 111-meter dash at the Sixth Special Olympics World Winter Games that ended here on Saturday, the national anthems of their countries were not sung nor were their nation's flags unfurled. 
 Organizers of the Games say that is because at the Special Olympics, the handicapped athletes and 2,000 others like them from 75 countries are expected to represent more than their homelands.
"We don't count medals, we don't use flags," said Timothy P. Shriver, president and chief executive of the Special Olympics. He said the games are an attempt to show the world that what counts is not being better, or stronger, but recognizing the best in people no matter where they came from, what they look like, or how their minds work.
When the Special Olympics was started 29 years ago by Mr. Shriver's mother, Eunice Kennedy Shriver, it was not much of an international event. Canada was the only country besides the United States to take part in the first games, held on a blustery day at Soldiers Field in Chicago.
Now, nearly three decades later, this year's winter games were billed as the largest international sporting event of 1997. Through the years the basic goal has remained the same: to help the athletes see themselves in a new light.
It is hard to say just how much taking part in the Special Olympics may change the lives of the athletes when they return home. But while they are here, they have the chance to visit a dentist or have their eyes checked. Some get to be television sports commentators, or newspaper reporters. And as they listen to the announcer read off their names and call them to receive their medals, their faces indicate that life has grown sweeter, at least for a while.
Mr. Gumbi, 18, who lives just outside Johannesburg, could not express what he felt as he raced haltingly around the slick ice at Veteran's Arena. But in the stands, the volunteers who traveled with the team's 16 members were on their feet shouting "Thabelang, Thabelang."
"It just proves that something could be done for these children," said Doreen Selekane, one of the volunteers. She has been fighting for the rights of the mentally handicapped in South Africa since 1982, and against apartheid all her life. At one time, she said, someone like Mr. Gumbi, whether black or white, would have been locked up at home and never let out.
Another volunteer, Angela Braun, said the rink where her handicapped daughter Lorna trains in Johannesburg has now been desegregated, and the "Whites Only" signs have been removed. But much still has to change in South Africa, both concerning race and prejudice toward the mentally retarded, she said.
People still fear Lorna because they do not understand her. And economic inequality remains.
"None of the black athletes' parents could afford to come over here because of the financial conditions of the country," Mrs. Braun said, "and that's sad."
As another heat of the 111 meters (the distance was one lap around a hockey rink) was almost ready to be run the other day, a burly man from Inner Mongolia named Daxidorji, the head of the Chinese delegation, leaned over from the stands and urged Mr. Liu, 18, who only started skating a year ago, to do his best.
Mr. Liu skated hard, but when he crossed out of bounds on one of the turns, he was disqualified. He received a medal anyway, as all athletes here do.
Mr. Daxidorji could not explain why all 14 athletes on the Chinese national team this year are from Inner Mongolia, nor how handicapped children get the special care they need when they return home.
But he said that while Mr. Liu and the other athletes in the orange and gold ski suits of China were competing in this year's World Games, "they feel terribly happy to enjoy the sports with everyone, black and white, boys and girls, young and old."
That much, at least, was clear.

HEADLINE: In America;
Bad Air Day

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Here we go again.
Hoping to prevent 40,000 premature deaths per year while easing the health problems of children with asthma and other respiratory illnesses, the Clinton Administration is proposing tough new anti-pollution standards that would lower the current levels of smog and soot in the air. 
 Industrial leaders do not think this is a good idea. They have already launched a multimillion-dollar assault on the new proposals, complaining that they will cost too much money, will slow down the economy, will raise the price of consumer goods, will force people to car pool and -- perhaps most ominously -- will threaten the weekend barbecue.
If this were a sporting event, I might ask for whom you were rooting -- the kids with asthma who have a tough time breathing whenever there's a bad air day or the powerful representatives of the oil industry, the mining industry, the Association of International Automobile Manufacturers, the American Bus Association, the Chemical Manufacturers Association, etc.
The problem with the industry groups is that they lack credibility. They always claim that taking steps to improve air quality will lead to economic catastrophe. U.S. News and World Report, in January 1976, noted that E. B. Speer, chairman of the board of U.S. Steel, had declared that "the lifeblood of America's economic strength" was being undermined by the Clean Air Act of 1970.
Mr. Speer wanted the law weakened. Luckily, a more sensible approach prevailed. In 1977 the law was expanded and strengthened.
An article last month in the National Journal had an item that showed just how wrong industry can be on these matters. The article pointed out that during the 1990 Clean Air Act debates "electric utility industry officials asserted that curbing sulfur dioxide emissions would cost $10,000 per ton. Today reductions are being made for as little as $100 per ton."
The new standards proposed by the Environmental Protection Agency would lower the permissible levels of ground-level ozone (commonly known as smog) and the airborne microscopic particles that typically result from the burning of coal, gasoline, oil and diesel fuel. These particles are technically known as particulate matter and are commonly referred to as soot.
A series of well-documented scientific and medical studies have linked ozone and particulate matter to decreases in lung function and other forms of respiratory distress in children and adults, to increases in emergency-room visits and hospital admissions and to increases in mortality.
According to the American Lung Association, children playing outdoors in ozone levels 33 percent below the current standard have experienced as much as a 20 percent loss of lung function. The problem is worsened by the fact that ozone levels tend to be highest on warm, sunny days -- the very days on which kids are most likely to be playing outside.
Mortality studies, according to the association, have shown that "the average life span shortening resulting from exposure to particulates is on the order of two years." That implies, association officials said, "that many individuals in the population have lives shortened by many years."
Big business contends that it would cost too much to do much about these problems. Overall air quality is improving, so why bother to do more? If the kids are gagging, if the old folks are wheezing and gasping for breath, if some of our lives are somewhat shortened -- well, that's the price of prosperity.
The Environmental Protection Agency, in its cost-benefit analysis of the proposed regulations, estimated the costs at $8.5 billion and the benefits, including saved lives and reduced medical expenses, at $120 billion.
But industry strategists are focused on other matters. A radio spot that was prepared to run in Chicago but was eventually pulled said that barbecue grills and even lawn mowers might be banned by the new regulations. A voice in the ad expressed fear that Americans might be forced "to change the way we live."
You might have thought that something equivalent to the Communist threat had arrived, and that the evils associated with clean air must be resisted at any and all costs.
Except that we've heard this hysteria before. The proponents of bad air need a new approach.

HEADLINE: Wall Street Journal on Line: Readers Pay but Profits Remain Elusive

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

 BODY:
From the moment that newspapers moved onto the Internet, some media futurists have been predicting that Americans will some day read their daily papers the way John P. Trebnik reads The Wall Street Journal: He points his Web browser at http://wsj.com, scans the articles he is interested in, downloads a few to be read or printed later, and logs off.
"In about 20 minutes or less, I'm finished with what I need," said Mr. Trebnik, an assistant professor of business and economics at Marian College in Indianapolis. "Frankly, I don't need the paper version hanging around -- too many other paper things to read." 
 Yet, although about 700 newspapers now have sites on the World Wide Web, only The Wall Street Journal, which is published by Dow Jones & Company, has so far managed to close the circle by charging subscriptions for access to any part of its on-line daily, a distinction that was underscored by the recent decision by Slate, the Microsoft Corporation's on-line magazine, to abandon its plans to charge an admission price. Slate learned what other on-line publications assumed: most people expect the Internet to be free.
Many on-line papers require visitors to register for access or charge them for premium services like archival searches. The Web site of The San Jose Mercury News, owned by Knight-Ridder Inc., provides free admission to some features but charges a modest subscription for access to archival searches and daily news reports beyond a brief summary. The New York Times charges about 2,000 overseas businesses $35 a month for access to its Web site, although the site is free to registered readers in North America.
The Wall Street Journal Interactive Edition alone charges for all access. Mr. Trebnik and other subscribers said The Journal's specialized business coverage makes the on-line version worth the price.
"A year ago, everybody thought no one would be able to charge for content, and that there would be a huge backlash from the Web community because everything is supposed to be free," said Thomas Baker, business director of The Journal's Interactive Edition. "Sure, we lost a lot of readers, but we kept a lot, too."
The Journal's breakthrough has not answered all the questions surrounding on-line journalism. For one thing, nearly 90 percent of the Interactive Edition's readership had vanished by the time the last free trial subscriptions had expired at the end of the year. Moreover, Interactive Edition subscribers gave anecdotal support for a deep worry of newspaper publishers: that on-line services, free or not, will cannibalize their profitable newspaper sales when readers like Mr. Trebnik, decide they do not need "the paper version."
Meanwhile, on-line advertisers, who pay to have links to their Web sites embedded in on-line journals, are still trying to decide if reaching a relatively small number of paying subscribers is as good as reaching 10 times as many freeloaders.
And The Journal's subscription program is still too new to answer perhaps the key question: Whether subscribers will be loyal enough to resubscribe year after year?
Martin Nisenholtz, president of The New York Times Electronic Media Company, said on-line publishers were watching the progress of The Journal's Interactive Edition for clues to a still-emerging Internet news business. Although The Times's Web site -- www.nytimes.com -- may before long begin offering fee-based archival searches and other premium services, he said, few on-line publishers, including The Times, are willing to accept the decline in readership that comes with subscription charges.
"We are perfectly willing to start charging," Mr. Nisenholtz said, "once we see an acceptably large and loyal audience emerging."
Mr. Baker said he was not dismayed by the plunge in readership that followed the imposition of a $49 annual subscription fee -- $29 to current subscribers of The Wall Street Journal -- that became final on Jan. 1. The Interactive Edition had 653,000 registered users, some of them probably duplicates, before the subscription fees were imposed, he said; now there are 70,000.
Mr. Baker contends that the number of subscribers will rise as Internet users begin to accept the idea of paying for on-line services. "People will realize that if you want something interesting and deep, you are going to have to pay for it," he said.
Mr. Baker would not discuss his division's finances, beyond conceding that the Interactive Edition has not yet begun to pay for itself. Bill Bass, an electronic media consultant with Forrester Research Inc. of Cambridge, Mass., said most sites covered about 30 percent of their costs from advertising, a figure he estimated held true for The Journal's Interactive Edition.
"Seventy thousand is a pretty respectable start," Mr. Bass said. "I would think that puts them right in the middle of where they expected to be, but they're still not going to be making any money."
What subscribers to The Journal's Interactive Edition get is access to the main articles and features of the daily paper plus frequent updates from the Dow Jones News Service and The Associated Press..
"Now newspapers can be more up to date than radio and television," said John F. Dowd, a T.W.A. pilot who reads the Interactive Edition from his home in Kittery Point, Me.
Mr. Baker, the Interactive Edition's business director, is confident The Journal's Web site is not cutting into sales of the paper version. Interactive Edition readers were younger and less likely to be print version readers, Mr. Baker said, noting that fewer than 40 percent of on-line subscribers also had print subscriptions.
But a sampling of eight subscribers showed that only one, a woman in central Texas who would speak only on the condition that she not be identified, said she would continue to buy both the print and interactive edition. One, Chance Harris of Austin, said he might renew his print subscription once it expired, and six -- George Scriban of Ontario; Tab Turner of North Little Rock, Ark.; Mike Cline of Big Bear, Calif.; Mike Hollander of Redondo Beach, Calif; Mr. Dowd and Professor Trebnik -- said they stopped buying the printed Wall Street Journal once the on-line version became available.
"The Marketplace section is the most important part of the paper to me, and I can get that on line and not have to throw away big chunks of the paper that I never read anyway," Mr. Hollander said.
Interactive Edition advertisers pay a few pennies each time a page with one of their ads, which are linked to their own Web sites, is called up. Some are not concerned about losing the greater exposure that a free on-line publication offers.
"We thought the demographics of The Wall Street Journal would be right," said Cyndy Ainsworth, marketing director for Virtual Vineyards, an on-line food and wine retailer. "Because we paid by the impression it did not really matter to us if they charged their readers. In fact, we thought it might even be good."
Virtual Vineyards paid The Wall Street Journal 4 cents for each "impression," with a guaranteed 50,000 impressions before the charge kicked in -- a hurdle the Interactive Edition easily cleared, Ms. Ainsworth said. But the company dropped its account after it failed to produce enough "click throughs" to Virtual Vineyard's own Web site, let alone hard sales. In the future, she said, her company would try to negotiate ad rates based on sales or at least on click-throughs.
Advertisers mainly interested in attracting Journal readers to their own advertiser-supported Web sites said they were happy with the Interactive Edition, however.
"We think it makes them a better, more select audience because they are paying to get the service," said Laura Henry, a spokeswoman for Lucent Technologies, which produces a free mapping service on the Web called Maps On Us.

HEADLINE: MEDIA: BROADCASTING;
To fulfill a children's educational TV quota, everything old becomes new again.

BYLINE: By Lawrie Mifflin 

 BODY:
WHEN the Federal Communications Commission voted in August to require television stations to broadcast three hours of educational programs for children, the F.C.C. chairman, Reed E. Hundt, envisioned a new world of production, one in which "the creative community can invent a whole new art form: the art of teaching children with television."
Last week, the first glimpses of that world appeared, when the broadcast networks began presenting their fall 1997 children's program schedules to advertisers. 
 The schedules included the requisite three hours of educational or informational programs. But no new art form was on view.
In fact, some very old shows have been trotted out to meet the Federal mandate -- a sign of either cynicism or economic desperation.
Fox has filled two and a half hours of its three-hour educational commitment with five weekday half-hours of "Bobby's World," a cartoon about a 4-year-old boy that has been around for seven years. Mostly reruns with 10 new episodes thrown in, it is scheduled to run in most markets five days a week at 7 A.M. (In New York, where the Fox station has a morning news program, "Bobby's World" will be seen at 2 P.M.)
Similarly, Kids WB, the children's portion of the WB network, has filled two and a half of its three hours with weekday reruns at 7:30 A.M. of "The Adventures of Captain Planet," an environmentally minded cartoon that is still shown on the Cartoon Network, on TBS and in syndication.
NBC is sticking to the same Saturday morning format, three hours for adolescents, led by the eight-year sitcom "Saved by the Bell," and the seven-year-old "N.B.A. Inside Stuff," a show produced by the National Basketball Association's entertainment division. "I've never understood where the educational value is on that one," Jon Mandel, a senior vice president of Grey Advertising, said. "But I'm not an educational consultant, nor am I a child."
An educational consultant reads all the scripts for the NBC shows and suggests revisions that add or strengthen "pro-social" messages.
Mr. Mandel argues that children spot such overlaid messages, and that if a show is "90 percent as good as it was originally" in entertainment terms, "and it's up against a cable show that's 100 percent, kids will go for the 100 percent."
But Fox, known for its superheroes and karate choppers, has a program that disproves the notion that education and entertainment are incompatible. Its remaining half-hour of educational programming, "Life With Louie," is a Saturday morning cartoon about the comedian Louie Anderson's forlorn childhood; it is currently the highest-rated animated children's program.
Still, children can find pure entertainment all day on the Nickelodeon and Cartoon networks on cable, and cable networks are not required to meet educational requirements.
While Fox has children's programs every weekday afternoon, and WB plans to follow that next season, the three other broadcast networks have only Saturday mornings available for children's programs. Now three hours of that time must go to education or information.
CBS, which has been at the bottom of the ratings barrel with children for several years, decided to cut back to three hours from five, and make them all educational or informational. Under its new programming chief, Lucy Johnson, CBS also seems to be the only network that took risks in developing programs for the fall -- perhaps not surprisingly, since it had so little to lose. The only show returning to CBS from this season is "Beakman's World."
The new lineup includes a game show, "Wheel of Fortune 2000," adapted from the adult version; "The Sports Illustrated for Kids Show," based on the magazine, and a mixed-media comic variety show starring Weird Al Yankovic, whom many children know from MTV for his parodies of popular songs.
"People will trash it as silly, but 'Wheel of Fortune' may be the sleeper of the season," Mr. Mandel of Grey Advertising said. "And I'll argue that it absolutely is educational. One of the classic children's games is hangman, and this is just hangman with a wheel."
CBS is also recycling a program from ABC, "Fudge," based on the Judy Blume children's novels, and a public television show, "Ghostwriter," in which junior high school students and a ghost friend decipher word messages to solve crimes.
There are high expectations at ABC, now owned by the Walt Disney Company. Not all ABC's shows have been announced yet. One will be a cartoon version of the Disney movie "101 Dalmations." The network is excited, too, about "Pepper Ann," an animated show created by Sue Rose, about a seventh-grade girl "who thinks the coolest thing in the world is her brain," said Geraldine Laybourne, the former head of Nickelodeon, who is overseeing the retooling of ABC's children's lineup.
Whatever the educational value of Pepper Ann and other such characters, it will only seep through if the shows are entertaining enough to draw children away from Nickelodeon and Cartoon.
"If the F.C.C. rule just drives kids away from broadcast to cable," Mr. Mandel said, "then you're wasting three hours of public airwaves each week, and you haven't educated anyone, either."

HEADLINE: John Perry Miller, 85, Professor And Yale Graduate School Dean

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
Dr. John Perry Miller, an economics professor for more than 40 years at Yale University who was the dean of the university's graduate school in the 1960's, died yesterday morning at his home in Hamden, Conn. He was 85.
He joined the economics department at Yale in 1939 after teaching briefly at Harvard and Princeton. He became an authority on industrial organization and public policy and was on a committee of seven economists who advised President Harry S. Truman on stabilizing and rebuilding the New England economy after a recession in the late 1940's. 
 Dr. Miller was appointed director of Yale's social sciences division, one of the three major faculty divisions, in 1959. He became the dean of the graduate school in 1961, holding the post until 1969.
As dean, he presided over several major changes in the university's approach to graduate education, including establishment of a Master of Philosophy degree, the first of its kind in the nation.
The degree, awarded to students who have satisfied all of the requirements for a doctorate except the writing of a dissertation, was intended to alleviate a shortage of college instructors. The move was seen as a challenge to the Ph.D. as the only valid mark of achievement for those seeking to join college faculties.
Following a trend started by Columbia University, Dr. Miller also instituted Yale's first combined degree program, allowing students to receive a bachelor's and master's degree in the same course of study. He called the combined degree program a forebear of "radical readjustments of the relationships between our secondary schools, colleges and graduate and professional schools." Combined degree programs are common today.
As dean, he also served on the faculty committee that in 1962 recommended admitting women as undergraduates.
John Perry Miller was born in 1911 in Lynn, Mass. He graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Harvard in 1932. He received a Master of Arts degree in 1934 and a Doctor of Philosophy degree in 1937, also from Harvard. He worked as a principal economist for the Office of Price Administration in Washington before being assigned to the Navy's Office of Procurement during World War II. He was released from the Navy in 1945 as a lieutenant commander.
Besides teaching, he also worked as a consultant on industrial economics, military procurement and higher education. He was director of Yale's Institution for Social and Policy Studies from 1969 to 1974 and also led the Campaign for Yale, a capital fund-raising drive that collected more than $370 million for the university in the early 1970's. He retired in 1981.
At the time of his death, he was the Elizabeth S. and A. Varick Stout Emeritus Professor of Social Science.
He is survived by a daughter, Ann M. Finicane, a lawyer in Brimfield, Mass.; a son, Dr. Perry Lowell Miller, a professor at Yale Medical School, and six grandchildren.

HEADLINE: OFFICIALS SAY MOB IS SHIFTING CRIMES TO NEW INDUSTRIES

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB 

 BODY:
With their longtime control of extortion and bid-rigging rackets in New York City and New Jersey weakened by years of relentless prosecutions and by regulatory crackdowns, the region's Mafia crime families are switching increasingly to white-collar crimes as ripe sources of plunder, law enforcement officials say.
The new Mafia focus is primarily on multimillion-dollar frauds in three lucrative businesses: health insurance, prepaid telephone cards and small Wall Street brokerage houses, according to law enforcement experts on organized crime. 
 The experts say that mobsters and their associates, especially younger ones, have searched for new criminal opportunities in recent years as many of the most powerful Mafia bosses have been sent to prison and the flow of loot from traditional rackets has dwindled.
Those old enterprises, investigators said, included shakedowns for labor peace in the construction industry, garbage-hauling cartels, extortions of merchants in the city's wholesale food and produce markets, the milking of union pension and welfare funds, payoffs for obtaining jobs and contracts at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center and control of the garment district's trucking companies.
With a tinge of irony, law enforcement officials said that their successes in eliminating long-established rackets had caused the crime families to mine new fields for booty.
"They are analogous to companies in Chapter 11 bankruptcy," Lewis D. Schiliro, a top Federal Bureau of Investigation official, said of the region's five largest Mafia gangs -- the Genovese, Gambino, Lucchese, Colombo and Bonanno families. "They are still in business but many of their old moneymaking bases have dried up and they are moving into new industries to fill the cash void."
Most information about the Mafia's moves into white-collar areas, law enforcement officials said, has come from informers, wiretaps and electronic bugs. They said that despite a handful of arrests in a medical-fraud investigation in New Jersey last year, no major mob figures had been seized so far. But they added that white-collar investigations required long and complex paper trails before indictments could be obtained.
"In destroying their old rackets, we have given them on-the-job training about how we infiltrate families, turn witnesses and use electronic surveillance," said Mr. Schiliro, the chief of the F.B.I.'s criminal division in New York. "They are not as overt as they once were, and we may have to change our techniques."
Mr. Schiliro and Peter G. Verniero, the Attorney General of New Jersey, said their agencies were giving high priority to thwarting mob attempts to turn medical insurance into an underworld treasure trove.
Infiltration of the health care industry, Mr. Verniero said in a recent interview, "is now our most serious organized crime problem."
The authorities in New Jersey said they uncovered what might be the prototype of the mob's medical care strategy in August, when they arrested 12 men accused of being members of a Genovese crew, or unit. The crew's leaders were charged with siphoning payments from Tri-Con Associates, a New Jersey company that arranged medical, dental and optical care for more than one million patients in group plans throughout the country.
Investigators said that the mobsters set up Tri-Con, investing their own money and using employees as managers, and intimidated some health plan administrators into approving excessive payments to the company. New Jersey authorities said Tri-Con in effect became a broker, linking networks of health-care providers, including physicians, hospitals and dentists, with group plans for companies and unions.
The authorities said that this area of health care service generally was not tightly regulated and that a grand jury was trying to determine the extent of any frauds manipulated through Tri-Con.
All Tri-Con defendants have pleaded not guilty to the fraud charges and denied that they intimidated health-plan administrators to approve excessive fees.
A relatively new industry -- prepaid phone cards -- that grosses about $1 billion a year is another Mafia target, Federal agents said. The cards, sold at neighborhood stores, are especially popular with immigrants as a convenient way to call overseas from public telephones.
The companies that make and distribute the cards program their magnetic strips with a fixed amount of credit for calling time, typically $20. They pay stores a small commission for each card sold and reimburse long-distance carriers for calls made with the cards, pocketing whatever money is left.
Agents say that the Gambino family set up a calling-card company that stole more than $50 million from callers and phone companies from fraudulent sales in the New York area and in other big cities.
An agent, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because the matter was still under investigation, said that each card supplied by the Gambinos was typically sold for $20 in calls, but that most cards became worthless after $2 or $3 in calls because they had not been programmed for the listed amounts.
The agent said that Gambino gangsters "ripped off millions in small amounts from thousands of customers who bought semi-worthless cards." The telephone carriers that handled the calls also lost money, he said, "because they made the deal almost entirely on credit to the phony distribution company, which never passed along the money for the calls that were actually made with the cards."
The stock market boom is also attracting the mob. Federal and city law enforcement officials said they were investigating efforts by the Genovese, Gambino and Colombo crime families to coordinate frauds through initial public offerings of stock in the over-the-counter markets handled by small brokerage firms. The officials, citing ongoing inquiries, refused to give details of the suspected stock-tampering schemes. But a Long Island businessman who admitted participating in recent stock swindles involving Gambino and Colombo members agreed to discuss the deals on the condition of anonymity. The businessman, who served a prison sentence for grand larceny, said in an interview that his life might be endangered if he were identified.
Recounting what he said was the Mafia's most common ploy, he explained that mobsters or their associates offer loans to brokers who are in debt or need capital to expand their businesses. Then, the mobsters force the brokers, using confederates as front men, to sell them most of the low-priced shares in a company before its stock is available to investors through initial public offerings.
The mobsters, with the brokers' help, quickly inflate the value of the shares by trading among themselves in paper or fake transactions. The brokers are then coerced into further inflating the prices of the new shares by recommending them to unsuspecting investors. The gangsters then sell out with huge profits before the overvalued stocks plunge, the businessman explained.
"It is a new wrinkle on loan sharking," he said. "The brokers are in debt to these wise guys and the only way they can pay off and not get hurt physically or ruined financially is by pumping up the stocks that the mob is interested in."
Daniel J. Castleman, the head of the investigation division in the Manhattan District Attorney's office, said the Mafia's move into Wall Street and white-collar activities created unseen dangers for the public. "When you borrow from loan sharks, at least you know what you're getting into," he said. "But when you are unaware that you are dealing with mobsters, there is a tremendous potential for substantial financial losses."
The Mafia's entry into white-collar crime has followed a recent string of serious financial setbacks, law enforcement officials say. Investigators assert that the Mafia was hit with probably its largest loss -- about $500 million a year in illicit profits -- when its garbage-hauling cartels in the city and on Long Island were dissolved in the last two years. Leaders of the Gambino, Genovese and Lucchese families and their allies have been convicted or are awaiting trials on accusations of reaping enormous profits through rigged bids and inflated bills.
Another $50 million a year evaporated from the mob's treasury, organized crime experts said, when the city, using stricter licensing powers, evicted from the Fulton Fish Market more than 20 companies linked to the Genovese family. A proposed licensing law aimed at removing mob figures and corrupt practices from two other big markets, the Hunts Point produce market in the Bronx and the Gansevoort meat market in Manhattan, is before the City Council.
At the Javits Center, the state now supervises hiring and construction contracts controlled until the mid-1990's by carpenters' and teamsters' union officials who have been removed on charges of corruption and ties to the Gambino and Genovese families. In the garment district, a group of Gambino-run trucking companies that prosecutors said had a stranglehold for decades over the delivery of clothing have been replaced through a court order by untainted, independent companies.
Other Mafia economic bastions, known as the windows, concrete, drywall and paint clubs, that extorted millions of dollars a year for labor peace in the region's construction industry were dismantled by the convictions of top mobsters and union officials.
But the authorities concede that the Mafia's network of illegal sports bookmaking and loansharking rings still flourish. Investigators say that bookmaking and loansharking enterprises are hard to eradicate because they can be easily re-established and because gambling convictions usually result in light sentences.
In 1994, a New York City Police Department report estimated that mob gambling operations reaped $2 billion a year in illegal profits. Salvatore Gravano, the turncoat Gambino underboss who was arrested in 1990, testified later that he had routinely funneled more than $1 million a year in cash to John Gotti, the imprisoned Gambino boss, as his share from just one Gambino gambling ring.
"Gambling feeds the Cosa Nostra army for its true mission -- infiltrating legitimate business," said Robert T. Buccino, the deputy chief of the Organized Crime and Racketeering Division in the New Jersey Attorney General's office.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Vincent Gigante; John Gotti, and Joesph C. Massino. (pg. B4)
 
Chart: "UPDATE: Hard Times for the Mob"
Despite recent forays into white-collar crime, the Mafia has seen its power in the New York region slipping under the weight of arrests, prosecutions, infighting and other problems, the authorities say. Citing information gleaned from informers, surveillance and electronic eavesdropping, they cite these recent significant developments for four of the five big Mafia "families," or gangs:
 
GENOVESE -- The Genovese family remains the nation's largest and most influential Mafia faction, but it faces organizational difficulties because its reputed boss, Vincent Gigante, known as Chin, and his entire hierarchy will soon be tried on Federal racketeering and murder charges. Last year, a judge found that Mr. Gigante, who for years has behaved erratically in public, had been feigning mental illness to block his trial. "Chin is still the No. 1 boss in America," said Lewis D. Schiliro, criminal investigations chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in New York.
 
GAMBINO -- Two recent racketeering indictments of Nicholas Corozzo, who prosecutors say is a Gambino captain, have blocked his efforts to succeed John Gotti as Gambino boss, the authorities say. Mr. Corozzo's arrest, they say, may have revived the prospects of Mr. Gotti's son, John Gotti Jr., a reputed Gambino captain, to replace his father, who is serving a sentence of life without parole. Mr. Corozzo was designated last fall by other Mafia leaders to assume control of the family. But since he has been denied bail and is facing long prison sentences if convicted in New York and in Florida, he is unable to run the troubled family, agents said.
 
BONANNO and LUCCHESE -- In December, the New Jersey wings of the Bonanno and Lucchese families merged their gambling activities with the Bruno-Scarfo family, which operates in Philadelphia and New Jersey. Robert T. Buccino, the deputy chief of the Organized Crime and Racketeering Division in the New Jersey Attorney General's office, said that the three groups consolidated because their ranks in New Jersey had been cut by arrests and internal wars. The Bonanno family, the only Mafia group whose leaders are neither in prison nor under indictment, has emerged as the most stable mob group in the New York region. The authorities say that Joseph C. Massino revived the family's fortunes after becoming the Bonanno boss in 1992. (pg. B4)

HEADLINE: Machine Tool Orders Jumped in December

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9

 BODY:
American orders for machine tools rebounded in December, posting the first rise in two months, industry figures show.
Orders for domestic and foreign-made machine tools rose 29.7 percent during the month to an estimated $839 million, the Association for Manufacturing Technology and the American Machine Tool Distributors' Association said today. For all of 1996, estimated consumption totaled $8.5 billion. In November, machine tool orders totaled an estimated $647 million. All regions had gains in orders during December. 
 Exports of machine tools, which are counted separately from domestic orders, jumped 118.4 percent to $108.39 million in December from $49.63 million in November.
Actual machine tool orders rose 25.9 percent in December, to $554.58 million from a revised $440.57 million in November, the industry groups said. Total units ordered increased 12.3 percent, to 3,543 during the month from 3,155 in November.
The machine tool figures cannot be compared with those last year because the organizations changed their method of counting orders in August.
The Northeast region posted the largest gain in the latest report with a 45.3 percent increase in December, to $98.63 million. Orders in the Midwest jumped 22.4 percent, to $249.41 million in December. demand increased 15.2 percent, to $81.84 million in the Central region, 7.0 percent to $58.88 million in the West and 5.6 percent to $65.83 million in the South.

HEADLINE: AN ARMY ACCUSED -- A special report;
Sex Abuse Cases Sting Pentagon, But the Problem Has Deep Roots

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: ABERDEEN, Md.

 BODY:
It is hard to spot any signs of the behavior behind accusations that the Army post here had become the libidinous playground for a captain and about 20 or 30 sergeants. With strict enforcement of a new buddy system, even female recruits, alleged to be the men's prey, complain of having to walk in pairs just to cross a yard to breakfast.
But the immense Aberdeen Proving Ground, on the northern banks of the Chesapeake Bay, is reeling from charges by a growing number of young women. Nineteen in the first official report in November -- 50 at last count -- allege that 10 male superiors at the mechanics training school here sexually abused them. The charges include at least 26 rapes, forced oral sodomy, battery, buttocks grabbing, hair pulling and threats for reporting such misconduct. Seven men face courts-martial beginning in March, and more are being investigated. 
 No American institution has ever confronted such charges of sexual misconduct, including the Navy, which struggled five years ago with charges that drunken male aviators had groped or stripped 26 women at the Tailhook convention in Las Vegas.
But in the weeks since the stories of sexual misconduct began to surface, the Pentagon has discovered that the reports from Aberdeen are no aberration. Initially attributed to a "few bad apples," the accusations of sexual misconduct are reverberating throughout the Army.
Among all big American institutions, the Army, women's advocates say, stands out as the most abusive of women, stunning a top command that had prided itself on bringing women aboard with the same success it had achieved in integrating blacks.
Interviews with Army officials and female recruits, a review of the Pentagon's own surveys on harassment and an examination of the cases so far show that the Army failed to heed signs of widespread sexual misconduct dating back as far as two decades, when women began moving from hospitals and offices into fatigues and formations.
Seventeen years ago, for example, half the 300 women attached to the 3d Infantry Division in Germany said in a survey that they had been subjected to unwanted physical advances. Two Pentagon inquiries then found systemic misconduct in all the services, including instructor-trainee abuses at Fort Meade, Md., much like those reported here.
Nine years ago and again last year in polls conducted in all the services for the Pentagon, a majority of the women responding, particularly in the Army, said they had encountered some form of sexual harassment. In the latest poll, many said their complaints had been met with ridicule, retaliation or indifference, a charge repeated in interviews with women at Aberdeen and elsewhere.
In all the services, few of the women who report harassment behind the anonymity of surveys file formal complaints. Since 1991, the Army has received about 1,200 complaints from women each year, proportionately about the same as the other services. But the Army throws out almost two-thirds of the complaints as unsustainable, far more than the other services.
Disclosures of sexual misconduct are erupting week by week at posts across the nation. At Fort Leonard Wood in Missouri, 28 instructors are under investigation for sexual misconduct; in November, two drill sergeants were discharged and given prison terms for illegal sex with nine female recruits.
At Fort Jackson, near Columbia, S.C., 64 people have been punished for sexual misconduct, including three rapes, occurring in the last two years. At Fort Sam Houston in San Antonio in December, two sergeants were jailed and five were disciplined for sexual transgressions with trainees on trips to Mexico to celebrate the completion of training.
Summoned before the Senate Armed Services Committee to testify about the scandal at the training grounds, Army Secretary Togo D. West Jr. assured the committee that the Army was pursuing a "zero tolerance" policy against sexual harassment.
But critics fault the Army's culture and structure for the scope of the problem. Harassment cases under an officer's command can hinder chances of advancement, and Army officials appear to be particularly hostile to complaints of abuse.
"At some posts, they are not reporting the rapes," said Susan Barnes, a military law attorney in Denver. Post commanders "don't want those statistics," she said.
Another problem, critics say, is that the Army chaplains to whom soldiers can take complaints have become hard to find because their numbers have shrunk with budget cuts. At Aberdeen, the sole chaplain had been reassigned to a teaching job.
Women's groups also say the Army has made only perfunctory efforts to tackle the problem. They note that Secretary West's anti harassment task force, like those of his predecessors, is made up almost entirely of senior and retired Army men and women who rose through the ranks of the institution they managed and are now investigating. On Feb. 3, Gene C. McKinney, the Sergeant Major of the Army, which makes him the service's top noncommissioned officer, resigned from the task force in the face of charges by a senior aide that he had sexually assaulted her in a Hawaii hotel room.
What is reported to have occurred at Aberdeen, while apparently extreme, illustrates the difficulty the Army has long had in dealing with allegations of sexual misconduct.
Prosecutors here have accused one sergeant of a striking number of abuses: Over the last two years, they say, Staff Sgt. Delmar G. Simpson raped 10 women, 5 of them more than once, until just before he was suspended, on Sept. 6. Sergeant Simpson, whose court-martial begins in April, has not entered a plea.
One reason the women did not complain, post attorneys say, is that Sergeant Simpson's company commander, Capt. Derrick Robertson, was also preying on the trainees. The captain, who has also not entered a plea, is to be tried on rape charges in March.
Representative Jane Harman, a California Democrat who is a member of a House subcommittee investigating sexual misconduct in the armed forces, said the Aberdeen cases suggested that Army anti-harassment programs "may not have accomplished much of anything at all."
Evidently, they accomplished little in Aberdeen, where officers say the surge of assaults was news to them.
"How come we're just finding out?" asked Capt. Craig A. Minnick, a lawyer at the post. "Why did not someone report it? There is a disconnect somewhere. The Army is trying to figure out where that disconnect is."

The Army
Women Play A Bigger Role
The Army is shrinking, but women are playing a much larger role. Six years ago, women made up 10 percent of a total uniformed force of 706,000. Today, woman represent 14 percent of a force of 495,000. And their numbers are likely to keep rising: they make up 20 percent of the Army's youngest soldiers, the trainees.
As women have spread through the service, the Army has maintained that sexual assault, though real enough, is no worse than in civilian life.
So far through the 1990's, the Army's public affairs office reports, soldiers have been submitting an average of 500 formal charges of sexual misconduct a year, representing well under 1 percent of the women in uniform each year.
But after the first report from Aberdeen, the Army's Criminal Investigation Command opened a hot line to let women to buck the chain of command and make their complaints directly. After only 12 weeks, the command recorded almost 7,000 calls, including 1,074 allegations of sexual abuse that it deemed legitimate enough to pursue.
The Defense Department also had ample signs of trouble in surveys of service members in 1988 and 1995. In July, when it announced its findings from the more recent survey, the top command seemed cheered. Though 64 percent of 20,000 women surveyed in 1988 had said they had received unwanted sexual attention in the previous year, that number dropped to 55 percent of the 90,000 surveyed in 1995. "Sexual harassment in the active-duty military is declining," the press releases began.
But an analysis of the survey results, compiled in December by the Pentagon's Defense Manpower Data Center and George Washington University, struck more somber notes.
Among other things, it found that most women kept their complaints to themselves, in many cases because they thought nothing would be done. Of those who did report harassment, 56 percent said that they had been urged to drop the complaint or had not been taken seriously, that their supervisor had received the report with hostility or that no action had been taken.
Just 27 percent said the person harassing them had been counseled to stop or had been transferred. One-fifth of the women said they believed that they had received a lower performance rating as a result of complaining.
The analysis showed entrenched and systemic harassment in the other services, too. But Army women had the lowest expectations that the leadership would intervene.
Army women also reported the smallest decline in abuse.

The Accusers
Two Careers End In Abuse Claims
Stephanie Calender, 41, who spent a long career on active duty and in the reserves and the Michigan National Guard, said her last skirmish happened in the guard, where she was a full-time technician and a specialist fourth class.
One day four years ago, she said, she was standing in a formation in the at-ease position, with her hands clasped behind her.
"The sergeant behind me pulled my hands onto his crotch area," she said. "He was very drunk. I walked out of the formation very quickly because he was coming after me. The platoon officer, a second lieutenant, ordered me back. They were all laughing."
Incensed, Ms. Calender went to her commanding officer, a woman. "She told me to drop it," Ms. Calender said. The top command in Lansing " 'will retaliate against you,' " Ms. Calender quoted the officer as saying. Ms. Calender has quit the guard and moved to California.
Jessica Bleckley, 18, is solidly built, 5 feet 3 inches tall and 134 pounds, with a firm jaw, dark blond hair and blue eyes. She joined the Army straight out of high school in Belton, S.C., and did basic training at Fort Leonard Wood. She was sent to Aberdeen last spring and assigned to Charlie Company in the 143d Ordnance Battalion.
In interviews here before she was granted an honorable discharge at the end of January, Ms. Bleckley said that on or about May 18, a drill sergeant in her company, Nathaneal Beach, had been spending the night in the barracks.
"My roommate was asleep," she said. "He said I had to go down to his office." She said Sergeant Beach had induced her to have illegal sexual intercourse in his office -- not actual rape, she said, but she said she had thought she had to acquiesce. It is against military rules for superior officers to fraternize with their charges.
After a month, she found someone in whom she could confide -- Staff Sgt. Ophelia Webb, one of the school's seven women among 39 drill sergeants. Sergeant Webb helped drive the complaint up the chain of command.
Then one day, Ms. Bleckley was sent to Alpha Company to copy some papers and ran into Sergeant Simpson. She said he had ordered her into an office latrine and had told her to have sex with him on the floor. "When he got through," she said, "he was like: 'Get out. Don't get in my face.' "
The harassment took a twist in November, after the Army reported the first allegations of abuses at Aberdeen and Ms. Bleckley was the only accuser to come forward publicly.
"Most people don't talk to me," she said. "They can't believe I said something because it draws negative attention to the Army. They say I asked for it. I wanted it. I didn't say no."
In classes on subjects like stress management and family abuse, she said, the discussion always turned to her. "We could be talking about inflation," she said. "But every meeting we have turns into a conversation about me." In one class, she said, someone asked, " 'How many of you joined the Army to talk to Diane Sawyer?' I hate it."
On Jan. 24, Ms. Bleckley was taken to Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington, after what she describes as a suicide attempt. She was granted an honorable discharge.

The Accused
A Training Officer Awaits Trial
Sgt. Delmar G. Simpson, 31, sits in the Marine Corps jail in Quantico, Va., awaiting a court-martial starting April 8. He grew up in Richburg, S.C., the fourth of five children brought up by his mother, Edna Simpson, after her husband's death, when Sergeant Simpson was 7.
Townspeople describe a tall, thin, well-mannered youth and a hard-striving student and athlete.
Douglas Harrison, his science teacher and basketball coach, said, "He didn't have a whole lot of ability, but he worked hard."
Mrs. Simpson, 60, a retired cook, said her son was disciplined and neither smoked nor drank. She is bringing up a son of Sergeant Simpson's who is 14. He also has a daughter in Texas, friends say, and is married to a woman who lives in Virginia.
Mrs. Simpson said she was confident about his innocence. In a recent telephone chat with her son, she said, "He said he didn't do it, and he ain't worrying about it."
Sergeant Simpson spent six years at Fort Hood in Texas before going to Fort Jackson for drill-instructor training and then, in January 1995, to Aberdeen. At Fort Hood, "he always stayed sharp," said Staff Sgt. Randolph Stevens. Of the sexual abuse allegations, he said, "I never saw any evidence of anything like that here."
But in Aberdeen, post officials say Sergeant Simpson was reprimanded and transferred to another company after poking and berating a woman in training. Now he faces a long list of charges. Of 26 women who have submitted formal allegations against Sergeant Simpson, 10 allege rape. One accuses him of "grabbing the hair on the back of her head and jerking her head back" and of threatening to "knock your teeth out." Among other charges are larceny -- the theft of one recruit's gold necklace and another's watch.
Sergeant Simpson declined to be interviewed. His Army lawyer, Capt. Edward W. Brady, suggested that the accusations were false or overdrawn. "When the facts and the evidence are presented in a court of law and not the court of public opinion," he said, "they will speak for themselves."
Whatever the outcome for Sergeant Simpson, it will be some time before the Aberdeen Proving Ground can settle down.
"There's a high probability," said Lieut. Col. Gabriel Riesco, the school's chief of staff, "there will be more people charged."

HEADLINE: The Dollar Declines, Then Recovers, in Tokyo

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 10

 BODY:
The dollar rebounded from a sharp selloff at the opening of Asian trading today as traders looked beyond the weekend decision of the Group of Seven industrialized nations to end their two-year campaign to strengthen the American currency.
Traders said that the dollar continued to draw buyers because interest rates in the United States are much higher than in Japan and Germany, making the returns on dollar-denominated deposits and fixed-income assets more attractive to investors. 
 "The major reason for a strong dollar and a weak yen is the rate gap," Makoto Sato, foreign-exchange manager at Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, said. "If currencies were to stabilize, the best strategy is to buy one of the highest-yielding currencies."
In Tokyo in late afternoon trading, the dollar was quoted at 122.81 Japanese yen, after falling as low as 120.35 yen. In New York late Friday, the dollar ended at 122.60 yen after a selloff that followed comments by Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin's that were taken to suggest that the United States had finished its effort to raise the currency's value.
The dollar also pared its losses today against the German mark. In late afternoon trading in Tokyo, it was quoted at 1.6495 marks, up from the 1.6345 marks it touched earlier this morning but down from 1.6568 marks in New York on Friday.
Japanese stocks, meanwhile, rose sharply during the afternoon trading session. At the end of the day, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 314.13 points, or 1.76 percent, to 18,181.17. Analysts attributed the surge to investor hopes for strong Japanese corporate earnings.
The dollar slipped at the opening of Asian trading after finance ministers and central bank governors in the Group of Seven, meeting in Berlin over the weekend, issued a statement saying that "major misalignments" in foreign exchange markets that the group noted in April 1995 "have been corrected."
When Group of Seven members -- the United States, Germany, Japan, Britain, France, Italy and Canada -- met in the spring of 1995, they called for an "orderly reversal" of the dollar's decline to a postwar low of 79.75 yen set in April 1995 and a record low of 1.3455 marks in March 1995.
A day before the Group of Seven's latest meeting, the dollar reached a 32-month high of 1.6751 marks and a four-year high of 124.75 yen. That was a gain of more than 7 percent against the yen and the mark since the beginning of this year. Group members suggested that they did not want the dollar to keep rising at such a rapid pace.
"We reaffirmed our views that exchange rates should reflect economic fundamentals and that excessive volatility is undesirable," the Group of Seven said in a release Saturday.
Traders said economic fundamentals still suggested the dollar should not fall much. Though the Group of Seven statement "slows the speed of the dollar's rise," said Yukihiko Hashimoto, foreign-exchange manager at Sanwa Bank, "people will continue to park their money in the U.S."
