HEADLINE: From the Wings, a Prayer: A Black Troupe Improvises

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

 BODY:
It was the first day of rehearsals for a new production, and that meant there was a ritual to adhere to, a tradition to uphold. So administrators and employees of the Crossroads Theater Company in New Brunswick, N.J., and the cast of "Wedding Dance" fanned out, held hands and bowed heads.
"This space belongs to you," the company's artistic director and co-founder, Ricardo Khan, said as he gazed at the 30 other people in the loop, all but 4 of whom were, like him, black. "This place is ours." 
 Then, in a grave voice, he intoned the company's mission, beginning with the vow "to provide a professional environment for artists in black theater to develop, explore and practice their craft."
A 264-seat auditorium decorated with kente cloth and other iconography of African-American culture and history, Crossroads is the name and place singled out by the black playwright August Wilson over the last eight months as a model of what black theater can and should be.
In remarks that have kindled a vigorous debate among intellectuals and artists, Mr. Wilson said that attempts to diversify American theater through such practices as color-blind casting were in fact harmful and condescending to African-Americans. What African-Americans in nonprofit theater need most, he argued, is not more participation in predominantly white theater companies, but stages of their own, run by black directors, showcasing black writers and actors, catering to black audiences, sustained by black support.
And Crossroads, he pointed out, is the only such arena in the country's elite League of Resident Theaters, an association of 67 nonprofit companies. "We need to have six or seven more just like Crossroads," Mr. Wilson said in a telephone conversation this week.
To visit Crossroads and to talk with its administrators and patrons is to understand immediately why it has emerged as an ideal. The characters in the original works that it showcases are black Africans rattling the chains of apartheid and black Americans battling the ills of the inner city.
Last season, it produced a revival of Mr. Wilson's "Piano Lesson," and this season it will produce another, "Jitney." The black playwrights and directors it has helped nurture include George C. Wolfe, the producer of the Joseph Papp Public Theater in Manhattan. And the audience includes black people who travel more than two hours in buses chartered by churches and community colleges and professional societies to observe and honor a caliber of black theater they say is hard to find.
Yet Crossroads is neither an unqualified success nor an exact realization of Mr. Wilson's vision. It is, in fact, an example of how slippery it can be to define black theater, of how hard it is to keep a black resident company solvent and of the forces -- in addition to the artists' passion and initiative -- that are necessary.
"People come to this space and see how beautiful it is, and they don't realize we're hurting for money," Mr. Khan said of the $4 million auditorium -- complete with gift shop, bookstore and even a small exercise space -- that a consortium of public and private benefactors built for Crossroads in 1991.
To get off the ground 19 years ago, Crossroads benefited from a level of government munificence no longer available. To grow, it has relied on a degree of benevolence from private foundations that is increasingly uncertain. And to survive, it recognizes the importance of building not only its black audience, but also its white one, which fills about 25 percent of the seats.
Indeed, while Mr. Wilson's argument was tinged with separatism in the eyes of some critics, the atmosphere at Crossroads is decidedly not. Mr. Khan wants a diversity of racial groups to see dignified images of African-Americans and nuanced explorations of their lives, to foster understanding between them. But integration at Crossroads also seems to be a matter of economic necessity. White membership on its board of trustees, which functions in part as a link to the many corporations with headquarters in New Jersey, has at times approached 40 percent. (It is about 20 percent now.)
And while the company's administrators are dedicated foremost to work that satisfies its core audience of African-Americans, its managing director, Steven Warnick, who is white, said that the limited black audience for noncommercial theater in and around New Brunswick compelled Crossroads to find ways to attract more whites.
Crossroads has had enough money only since 1991 to pay the union-scale wages required for membership in the national league, and it is among the smallest members in terms of its seats and operating budget of $2.2 million. That pays for a September to May season of five productions and a new-play festival for staged readings of developing works. While average nonprofit theaters earn more than 60 percent of their income, Crossroads earns just 50 percent. Over a season, about 25 percent of the seats go unfilled.
To be sure, most regional theaters struggle just as Crossroads does to draw theatergoers to plays without big stars, gimmicky effects and lauded playwrights. But to those challenges, Crossroads adds another: developing and marketing work that speaks to one ethnic group in particular.
"It's difficult for all not-for-profit theaters, but it's lethal when you add black to that," said Douglas Turner Ward, a founder and former artistic director of the Negro Ensemble Company in New York. There are, of course, worlds of black theater beyond the league. One embraces the low-brow melodramas that travel through a chain of inner-city theaters, described recently by Henry Louis Gates Jr. in a New Yorker article titled "The Chitlin Circuit." Another is the more high-minded productions by respected black companies like Penumbra in St. Paul that perhaps cannot afford the union-scale pay required for league membership. But the league's membership list is nonetheless a yardstick, and Crossroads' singular status reflects limited opportunities for black theatrical artists.
Scarce opportunities are precisely what led Mr. Khan to start Crossroads in 1978, the year after he graduated from Rutgers University with a master's degree in fine arts and dual ambitions to act and direct. When he surveyed the landscape for black artists, he said, he saw desolate terrain.
"The only roles available for black men were pimps or drug dealers or drug addicts or ex-convicts or convicts," Mr. Khan said. "I don't believe in separatism, but I do believe in righting the wrongs, especially when it comes to the images of black people in this society."
With a Rutgers classmate who has since left Crossroads, Mr. Khan began the company with a $225,000 grant not from a Government arts program, but from a Government jobs program, the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act.
Mr. Khan used that money to convert a former sewing factory in New Brunswick into a makeshift auditorium with only 130 seats. A bulky Y-shaped beam bisected the stage.
"It was a tree in one play, a room divider in another," Mr. Khan said.
Although Mr. Khan strived to provide opportunities for black playwrights, he did not take the hard line recently advocated by Mr. Wilson against black directors and actors mounting plays by white authors. He does not take that line now, either.
Over the years, Crossroads put on productions of "American Buffalo," by David Mamet, "Zoo Story," by Edward Albee, "Agnes of God," by John Pielmeier.
It also attracted, or successfully solicited, grants from the New Jersey State Council of the Arts, the National Endowment for the Arts and an array of foundations.
Mr. Wilson says that foundations are a major impediment to quality black theater because their members satisfy their liberal impulses by giving money to white companies that make stabs at ethnic diversity. But Mr. Khan says he has not felt shortchanged by foundations. Crossroads' smallest source of contributions is from individuals, perhaps, its directors say, because blacks as a group do not have the same wealth as whites.
Crossroads has benefited from the good fortune of time and place. In the 1980's, New Brunswick, with the artistic aspirations of a university town, formed a group of civic officials and philanthropists under the banner of the New Brunswick Cultural Center Inc. and that organization built the auditorium that Crossroads inhabits.
The company pays a reasonable rent of $55,000 a year. Even so, Crossroads has struggled to make ends meet, leaning heavily on benefactors. In 1991, Bill Cosby gave five benefit performances, raising more than $200,000 for the company. Since then, the company has gradually but decisively pulled back from an economic precipice, whittling its debt from $1.7 million just two years ago to about $600,000 now.
There is constant tension, the directors and trustees say, between promoting the challenging original work by black playwrights that few other resident companies sponsor and staging the established plays and musicals that increase ticket sales.
The mission of Crossroads, it turns out, is one thing; ticket sales are quite another. While about three dozen theatergoers at Friday's performance of "The Meeting" lingered after the show for a salon-style discussion of its themes, the majority of middle-class and upper-middle-class African-Americans in the audience, who had paid $20 to $25 for their seats, headed home for Somerset, Plainfield, Montclair or Princeton.
For some, coming to Crossroads was neither a statement nor an act of ethnic pride. It was simply a night at the theater more convenient than Broadway or Off Broadway.
"There's no Holland Tunnel, no Lincoln Tunnel," said Norward Harris of Westfield, N.J. "And when you walk out, your car hasn't been towed."

HEADLINE: Bear Stearns Is Negotiating For Space in Proposed Tower

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Bear Stearns & Company, the investment bank that has crisscrossed Manhattan for the last three years looking for a new home, is considering moving to a proposed 55-story tower on Seventh Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets.
The building, Rockefeller Plaza West, was first approved by the city in 1990 for the site, which is currently a parking lot. But the tower, which would stretch Rockefeller Center's presence a half-block west, might have to go through the city's seven-month review process again because of the design changes required by Bear Stearns. 
 If a deal can be struck with the current landowner, the Rockefeller Center Development Corporation, the tower would include up to 10 cavernous floors at the base for the bank's trading operations.
Bear Stearns, which wants to be a co-owner of the building, is the largest of many tenants scouring a resurgent midtown market, where rents are inching upward and developers are itching to build. But for now, the investment bank appears to be the most likely tenant for the Rock West tower, as it is called, according to real estate experts.
"We're in the market for space," said William J. Montgoris, chief operating officer at Bear Stearns who is leading the search for new quarters. "We've got several alternatives. Rock West is one of them. Hopefully we'll get everything resolved by the end of the year."
To build a 55-story tower, Rockefeller Center Development would also have to buy 466,000 square feet of unused development rights, or air rights, from the new owners of Rockefeller Center itself, Tishman Speyer Properties, Goldman Sachs & Company and David Rockefeller.
Jonathan D. Green, president of Rockefeller Center Development, a subsidiary of the Rockefeller Group, confirmed that he has held discussions with Bear Stearns, adding that his company also is considering building a smaller tower for other tenants currently in the market for space, like Reuters. "We've been working on what we'd do if a tenant like Bear Stearns wanted more and larger floors at the base," he said.
Bear Stearns's current lease at 245 Park Avenue, between 46th and 47th Streets, expires in 2002, and the building is in need of extensive renovations. Last year, Bear Stearns struck a deal with CS First Boston to buy an entire block at 383 Madison Avenue, at 46th Street, for a new tower. But First Boston's partner, the al-Babtain family of Saudi Arabia, bought it instead.
Bear Stearns then began talks with Mr. Green. The bank is also negotiating with its current landlord, and is being wooed by several of the developers who hope to build a commercial and residential complex on the site of the Coliseum at the southwest corner of Central Park, a project that is 5 to 10 years away.
"Rock West is the most likely site," said a director of Bear Stearns who spoke on condition of anonymity.
"It's too disruptive to have to move around the Park Avenue building" as floors are renovated, he said, "and I don't think we can wait for delivery of the Coliseum site."
The Rock West site has served as something of a barometer of the real estate market. Mr. Green began assembling the property in 1980, as the real estate boom began. But by the time Mr. Green bought the land, demolished the buildings and obtained city approval in 1990, the recession had cut property values in half and pushed the vacancy rate for midtown office buildings to a devastating 17.6 percent. Now, with rents rising and the vacancy rate at 10 percent, Rock West is one of only four major sites for a new development in midtown.

HEADLINE: Caldor, in 700-Job Trim, Says It Will Close 2 Stores

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
In a setback to neighborhood redevelopment efforts, Caldor Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest discount department store, announced yesterday that it was closing one store in Brooklyn and one in the Bronx as part of its continuing effort to climb out of bankruptcy proceedings.
The stores, on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn and Fordham Road in the Bronx, are expected to be closed in May, with a loss of more than 700 jobs. Two other Caldor stores, in Westfield, Mass., and Woonsocket, R.I., were also scheduled to be closed because of poor results, the company said. 
 From a business perspective, the closings were not surprising. Caldor, based in Norwark, Conn., filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in September 1995 and has been steadily shedding stores. And Caldor is just the latest regional discount chain -- Jamesway and Bradlees are others -- that has fallen on hard times in recent years, crippled by the growing dominance of national big-box retailers like Wal-Mart and Kmart.
But from the local perspective, the closings are a blow to efforts to revitalize neighborhoods.
"When Caldor came in a few years, it was a big boost to what was happening then to rebuild the area," said City Councilman Jose Rivera, whose offices are across the street from the Caldor on Fordham Road. "So the fact that they're closing is not only a blow to the Bronx; it's a blow to the entire city."
In 1995, Caldor operated 172 stores in the 10 northeast states, and it ranked as the nation's fourth-largest discount chain, trailing Wal-Mart, Kmart and the Dayton Hudson Corporation's Target Stores division.
But in the face of competition, Caldor's sales declined. In the third quarter of 1996, the company reported a loss of $47.96 million on revenues of $2.7 billion, compared with a loss of $32.6 million for the same period in 1995.
The company, which will be reduced to 157 stores, has tried to turn things around recently, submitting a five-year business plan in December that is now being reviewed by creditors.
"These locations have not met our targets for some time, and are unlikely to do so in the foreseeable future," Warren Feldberg, chairman and chief executive officer of Caldor said in a statement. Caldor's stock closed yesterday at $2 a share, down 25 cents.
In New York City, the number of Caldor stores will drop to six; still remaining are three in Queens and one each in Brooklyn, Staten Island and the Bronx.
The Flatbush store opened in July 1995 on a site that had been occupied by Macy's for decades. Some residents said Caldor could not quite find a niche among the neighborhood's mom-and-pop discount stores, but most said it filled a void because it offered low prices and a variety of items.
Alvin M. Berk, chairman of Brooklyn Community Board 14, said the closing would delay plans to build a parking lot linking the site to a nearby Sears store.
The story was similar in the Bronx: Caldor took over in October 1993 the former site of an Alexander's that had been vacant for several years. As with Brooklyn, the store seemed popular to many, but the numbers were not enough.
One customer, Maria Hernandez, 65, said she and her friend Anna Rivera had visited the food court in the store for many years, going back to when it was run by Alexander's.
"First, we had Alexander's, and that closed. Then this opened, and we like it, and now it'll be gone," she said. "The neighborhood will be empty without it. It's lonely to think of it as gone."

HEADLINE: U.S. Admiral Says Iraq, Aided by Iran, Is Smuggling Oil in Gulf

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: MANAMA, Bahrain, Feb. 11

 BODY:
With help from Iran, tankers are smuggling oil out of Iraq in violation of United Nations sanctions, an American admiral said today.
The Iraqis and their Iranian protectors have had two confrontations with Navy warships in the last two weeks, ramming a United States frigate in one showdown. 
 While the amount being smuggled is modest, "our indications are that this is a rather sophisticated effort, centrally controlled within Iran," said Vice Adm. Thomas B. Fargo, commander of the Fifth Fleet.
The smuggling is one sign of the cooperation between the two former Persian Gulf enemies in trying to evade efforts to enforce the United Nations trade sanctions on Iraq.
But the main motive is money. Iraq, desperate to circumvent the embargo, is willing to sell the oil cheap, and a 2,000-ton shipment of oil can net $50,000, Admiral Fargo estimated. All together, the tankers are smuggling tens of thousands of tons of fuel oil every month, he said.
But the amount is small compared with the restricted sales of $2 billion of oil over six months that the United Nations has allowed. And that amount is about one-fifth of what Iraq exported before the gulf war.
Another Navy official in the gulf area, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that Iraq also has other ways of smuggling oil. This official said that more contraband oil was being smuggled through other countries in the region, especially Jordan.
According to American investigators, crews of intercepted vessels have said that Iranian authorities take a cut of the profits. "A protection fee is paid to the Iranians that guarantees them safe passage through territorial waters," Admiral Fargo said.
The admiral said some smuggled oil is unloaded in the United Arab Emirates in the southern Persian Gulf.
The sanctions were imposed in 1990 by the United Nations to punish Iraq for its invasion of Kuwait. Since December, however, an exception has been made to allow the sale of limited amounts of Iraqi oil under United Nations supervision to allow Iraq to buy food and medicine.
But as legitimate shipments have begun to leave Iraqi ports, the smugglers have stepped up their work as well. "Through our reconnaissance capabilities, we can image these guys as they're loading up," Admiral Fargo said. The smuggling "has increased to 60,000 metric tons per month, due to the fact that there's a significant profit to be made," he said.
After picking up the fuel at ports on the Shatt al-Arab waterway, the ships -- not only small tankers, but also other vessels that flood their ballast tanks and compartments with the cargo -- hug the Iranian coast as they steam southward.
Admiral Fargo said some 30 vessels have been identified on this run, one having traversed the route at least nine times.
Both international law and treacherous shoals keep the deep-hulled American destroyers on patrol out of Iran's 15-mile-wide territorial waters. A watch officer aboard the American destroyer Cushing said crew members can detect the boats but cannot go after them.
Last week, the American detroyer Nicholson cut off and boarded a smuggler in international waters. An Iranian patrol boat, armed with missiles, suddenly arrived on the scene just as the Cushing steamed in to back up the Nicholson.
As the Iranian ship began to circle the American destroyers, the crews took up defensive positions on deck.
"It was hairy," a young officer aboard the Cushing recounted, speaking on the condition that he not be identified. "One little Iranian gunboat had two $800 million destroyers totally tied up."

HEADLINE: After Night in Jail, Jesse Jackson Appears Weary but Retains Old Zeal

BYLINE: By DON TERRY 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Feb. 11

 BODY:
Looking weary in wrinkled corduroys, the Rev. Jesse Jackson flashed a thumbs-up sign this morning as he walked into a courtroom filled with sheriff's deputies, Mr. Jackson's supporters and the fading ghosts of 1960's street demonstrations.
Mr. Jackson had spent the night in the Cook County Jail, after being arrested on Monday afternoon at a protest over the treatment of black truckers at a construction site on the city's South Side. 
 The general contractor on the project, Paul H. Schwendener Inc., which was honored in 1992 by the Chicago Urban League for its minority hiring practices, "categorically" denied that its dismissal of a black subcontractor was racially motivated.
In the old days, when he was marching with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., spending a night in jail went with the job of being a civil rights worker. But Mr. Jackson is in his 50's now and is more likely to spend a night in the White House. He has a hard time remembering the last time he slept in a cell.
"I think it was in D.C. during a Free South Africa demonstration," he said. "It's been a while."
He may be out of practice at getting some sleep in jail, but Mr. Jackson always knows how to turn any event into a one-man show. Today was no different. He used his brief court appearance to address what he calls the new civil rights movement: the struggle for economic opportunity. "We want fairness," Mr. Jackson told the judge. "We want to open these markets up to everyone. These patterns of racist, sexist discrimination must end or I'll be back."
The judge shook Mr. Jackson's hand for the second time in 10 minutes and released him on a $5,000 bond.
Mr. Jackson, along with two other men, was arrested for blocking workers entering the site, a $43.7 million underground parking garage project at the Museum of Science and Industry. Mr. Jackson twice refused to be released on a signature bond, which would have spared him his night in jail.
The Monday afternoon protest had been brewing for months as Mr. Jackson and his Rainbow Coalition negotiated on behalf of the black subcontractor, Willie Carter, owner of Carter's Excavating & Grading. Schwendener said in a statement today that Mr. Carter had been dismissed because he Mr. Carter had failed to perform such obligations as paying vendors and keeping proper records.
Mr. Jackson said that the accusations against Mr. Carter were not true and that his dismissal was a blow to black economic development. "There's been a lot of focus on deadbeat dads who don't pay to support their children," Mr. Jackson said at a news conference shortly after he was released from jail. "But what about deadbeat corporations that don't honor the law, that don't hire?"
The company offered to rehire black truckers who had been hired by Mr. Carter. The truckers, however, have joined Mr. Jackson's protest and this morning they circled the construction site in a fleet of 20 horn-blowing dump trucks. At the urging of Mayor Richard M. Daley's office, the museum construction site was shut down today and the two sides are scheduled to resume negotiations on Friday.

HEADLINE: Memo From Prague;
Of Czechs and Jews and the Blinding of Memory

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: PRAGUE, Feb. 8

 BODY:
In the cemetery of the small Bohemian town of Letohrad, which was home to Madeleine K. Albright's forebears, there is a simple marble slab tucked away in a corner where the snow is untrodden. Dated 1930, it reads simply: "1914-1918: We gave our lives. You give love to your homeland."
The theme of one generation's sacrifice for the next has been a constant one in this waning century, not least in the bloodstained center of Europe from which the new Secretary of State's family came. 
 Josef Korbel, Ms. Albright's father, took the exhortation to heart, loving and serving the Czechoslovak state born out of World War I.
He later described the state as rising "phoenix-like from the ashes of the Austro-Hungarian empire," rich in its "heritage of freedom." An assimilated Jew, he seems to have seen in Czechoslovakia's democratic gathering-in of diverse ethnic and religious groups -- Czechs, Germans, Slovaks, Ruthenians, Magyars and Jews -- a moving symbol of the progress and emancipation his own merchant family had enjoyed.
Then, within a decade of each other, the twin totalitarian forces of this century -- Nazi Fascism and Soviet Communism -- engulfed Czechoslovakia. The former annihilated his Jewish family, the latter the interwar democratic state he loved.
Mr. Korbel, having fled to America in 1948, chose to recall for his daughter Madeleine, and to write about, "the total perfidy of the Communist mind." What Nazism did to the Jewish Korbels was suppressed.
In his book, "The Communist Subversion of Czechoslovakia (1938-1948)" -- dedicated "to the Memory of my Parents" -- Mr. Korbel repeatedly assails "the long night of Communist totalitarianism."
He also deplores the killing of "patriotic leaders," the Germanization of Czech culture, the closing of universities and the pillaging of the economy under Nazi occupation.
But he does not mention the fate of the more than 100,000 Jews in his homeland, most of whom, like his mother and father, were killed by the Nazis during the period covered by the work.
This, it seems, is a selective kind of history, one that left his daughter unaware of the fate of her grandparents. Certainly, it appears to shun the solemn admonition of Vaclav Havel, the Czech President, who has written that the "special union" between ancestors and descendants "is one of the foundations of the existence of every sound human community aware of its identity."
But the extent to which such generational links were severed or distorted in this century by waves of violence and ideological warfare is becoming gradually clearer.
The cold war was also a war on history, on both sides of the divide. Somewhere in this struggle, Ms. Albright's past was buried. So, too, was the history of Nazi gold and plundered paintings in French museums.
This was, of course, particularly true behind the Iron Curtain. Communist morality, Lenin once said, is "the morality that serves the struggle." The same was true of Communist history.
One example is Terezin, known in German as Theresienstadt, the small fortress town 50 miles north of Prague where Ms. Albright's grandparents were persecuted as Jews and where her grandfather, Arnost Korbel, died.
For decades after the war, Czechoslovakia's Communist authorities distorted its history. A memorial recalled the suffering of Czech resistance fighters, particularly Communists, imprisoned there but scarcely mentioned the Jews. Lists of Jewish deportees were kept secret. The history of Terezin, as the place where Czechoslovakia's Jewish community was annihilated, was subordinated to the dictates of "anti-imperialism" and "anti-Zionism."
Today, a monumental cross towering over a field of graves -- dwarfing a Star of David -- suggests a certain ambiguity. But much has now been clarified. Within two years of Communism's fall in 1989, a new museum recalling the Jewish ghetto was opened. In 1995 a list was published of the more than 70,000 Jews who perished in Terezin, or after deportation from the town.
The names of Ms. Albright's paternal grandparents -- Arnost and Olga Korbel -- are in the 1,559-page list. Of the 999 Jews who arrived in Terezin with them on July 30, 1942, only 66 survived the war. Arnost Korbel perished in Terezin; several of Ms. Albright's relatives died at Auschwitz.
In the Czech Republic, which separated from Slovakia in 1993, the repeated oppression of this century has bred a deep understanding of the forces that lead to personal decisions like that of Josef and Mandula Korbel to convert their family to Catholicism and hide their Jewish descent.
The conversion took place in 1939 in London, when Madeleine Albright was 2, her cousin Dagmar Sima said. Mrs. Sima lived with the Korbel family in London during the war.
Lenka Matusikova, an archivist at the Central Archive in Prague, is not surprised by the Korbels' silence. "After the war," she said, "people were afraid to talk about their Jewish origin. Many Czechs only found out about their Jewish roots after the democratic changes. Now my desk is full of applications for genealogical research."
Shortly after the war, when Mr. Korbel was the Czechoslovak Ambassador in Belgrade, Josef Marek attended the baptism in the embassy of Ms. Albright's younger brother, Jan. Mr. Marek, chosen as godfather to Jan, had long known the Korbel family as Jews before the war. "But I found nothing strange in the ceremony," he said. "After all, they were completely assimilated Czechs. Madeleine's mother told me to be Jewish was always to risk persecution."
Even Dagmar Sima said the death of her parents at the hands of the Nazis "did not make me feel Jewish." Reared, like the Korbels, in an assimilated family, and baptized during the war in the quest for survival, she remained a secular Czech. But unlike Ms. Albright, she knew the family history and passed it on to her children.
She said: "My parents, my grandparents, Madeleine's family -- they all belonged to me in some way. My heart grew bigger for all of them. It is this, I think, that should be passed down the generations -- not the Jewish feeling necessarily, but the remembrance of the dead. I never for a moment suspected that she did not know."
In Terezin, as at Letohrad, the generations speak to each other across a gulf of suffering. A sign engraved on marble in the midst of the graves says: "The blood we lost flows again. We died so that our relatives could live."
Now, by a strange twist of fate, one of those relatives, Ms. Albright, appears likely to have the task of steering the Czech Republic into NATO, the Western alliance born out of the battle against Nazism to fight the battle against Communism.
Of such union with Western nations her father dreamed. Like much history these days, her own appears to have come full circle.

Josef and Jan, born Czech Jews, survived World War II. Arnost, like Mrs. Sima's parents and other Albright kin, died at the hands of the Nazis. (Dagmar Sima)

HEADLINE: Six Figures Of Fun;
It's Bonus Season On Wall Street

BYLINE: By TRIP GABRIEL 

 BODY:
There they are again, the brash young men with slicked-back hair, prowling among the exotic sports cars in Steven Kessler's East 34th Street showroom. They finger the buttery leather seats of an $84,900 1993 Ferrari Mondial, or dicker over the $179,000 price of a 1994 Lamborghini Diablo.
From late December through March, Wall Street's bonus-paying season, when executives receive as much as five or six times their base pay in a lump sum, Mr. Kessler says he makes 80 percent of his sales to stock and bond traders with money burning holes in their pockets. 
 "They are young, aggressive people who are able to make decisions spontaneously," Mr. Kessler said. "They come to see what's in inventory, and when they receive their bonus checks -- bingo."
Unlike most businesses, Wall Street rewards its workers strictly according to the previous year's results, and 1996 was spectacular. The securities industry's 150,000 workers in New York City are expected to pull down bonuses of more than $8.1 billion, 30 percent higher than the previous high of $6.2 billion in 1995, according to the State Comptroller, H. Carl McCall. (That's an average of $54,000 a person, with bonuses ranging from $10 million or more for the biggest winners to a few thousand for the lowliest clerks.)
Although Wall Street employs only about 5 percent of the city's private work force, the big year-end paychecks have a disproportionate effect on the local and regional economy, buoying everything from apartment prices to windfall tax revenues that can be sprinkled like stardust by City Hall in an election year.
Big bonuses also have an effect on the cultural climate of the city. In stores and restaurants there are numerous signs of a return to luxe. New York magazine recently published a buying guide to custom goods, which included "basic" dress shirts for $190 and shoes made on hand-carved lasts of Canadian maple for $1,350.
There is much discussion on Wall Street of how the prosperity of the late 1990's differs from that of the often vulgar 80's, the era of "greed is good," when many thought the party would last forever. Now many Wall Streeters say they are spending bonuses less flamboyantly, investing for the long term in the knowledge that what goes up also comes down.
But in the full flush of bonus season, when 25-year-old Masters of the Universe roam the city, ordering $12 martinis made with Ketel One vodka at the Four Seasons Hotel bar and $125 tasting dinners at Nobu in TriBeCa, self-restraint can be hard to find.
Dan Rubin, who had parked his Acura NSX-T sports car outside Steven Kessler Motor Cars on East 34th Street in Manhattan recently, entered the showroom of bright red Ferraris and sleek Lotuses with his fiancee and said, "We're looking for something more fun."
Mr. Rubin dropped out of Princeton in 1994 to start Rubin Investors Group, a private company that had a banner year, he said, thanks in part to betting on the Internet. "I trade big positions in small companies and terrorize the chairman," he said with a supreme air of assurance.
Besides shopping for a new car, he had just bought a ski house at Stratton Mountain, Vt.
Many on Wall Street, of course, are not making extravagant sums. Only about 1,500 in the top tier of traders, analysts and investment bankers take home more than $1 million in total pay, according to compensation experts.
At the very top, the nearly 200 partners of Goldman, Sachs & Company made between $4 million and $8 million apiece, according to people at the firm, although much of it is reinvested in the firm until they leave. Alan C. Greenberg, the chairman of Bear Stearns & Company, which had a record year for profits, made $18.8 million in 1996, according to the company.
The bonus system is deeply ingrained on Wall Street.
"In a five-minute meeting, they give you a piece of paper with a number on it," said an analyst at a major investment bank, who spoke on condition that neither he nor his firm be identified. "It's awesome. In some cases it's five, six or seven times your salary, your whole year in one payment. Since many people on Wall Street derive psychic pleasure chiefly from their earnings, it's a lot more significant than, say, a schoolteacher finding out she got a 3.5 percent raise. It is the score."
Most investment banks promote a culture of extreme discretion, playing down any flashy displays of wealth. Even in a champagne-popping year like the most recent one, when Wall Street's total profits were a record $12.5 billion, bonuses are discussed only tersely, in a kind of code. "Are you happy?" one Wall Streeter will say to another. "Yes, I'm happy," the colleague will reply.
Many Wall Streeters declined to speak publicly about bonuses. In part that is a measure of the industry's traditional conservatism. But it is also a reaction to the late-1980's, when Wall Street was scorched by recession, as well as by public opinion, which tagged its players as money-hungry Gekkos after the character popularized by Michael Douglas in the movie "Wall Street."
"You still don't have the ugly behavior of the 80's," said an equity trader at a major house who spoke on condition of anonymity. "People have all been sobered by the layoffs and entrenchment in the business. Everybody knows we made a lot of money, but it's 'When is it going to end?' rather than 'This could go on forever.' "
Economists said that Wall Street's good times have been a bonus for the city in general, but the rising tide has not lifted all boats equally.
The city expects a windfall of $450 million in additional personal income and corporate taxes from the securities industry. Aides to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani have said the money would be spent on everything from new schoolbooks to closing the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island.
"When Wall Street's having a good year," said Lawrence J. White, a professor of economics at New York University, "more people are employed, and they buy more takeout meals, they buy more Brooks Brothers suits, they buy more one- and two-bedroom apartments.
"But it can't undo basic trends -- we've lost manufacturing jobs and the economy that goes along with it, and that's never coming back."
The spending of individual Wall Streeters depends to a great extent on age, according to interviews with securities workers. Young associates recently out of business school, who in very good years can receive total compensation of up to $250,000, are the ones most likely to seek instant gratification, spending on fast cars, Charvet ties, Hamptons summer rentals.
"You have a young couple in their 20's who both have significant income and they just bought a city co-op and they'll come out and rent a house for $60,000, $70,000 for the summer," said Diane Saatchi, president of the Dayton-Halstead real estate agency in East Hampton, L.I. The traditional bonus-season hunt for a summer property fashionably south of the Montauk Highway has gotten off to a very fast start this year, she said.
Real estate brokers say that the inventory of super-luxury properties in the city has not been so low in memory.
"Last January there was a lot of money, but this January there's euphoria," said Dolly Lenz, Sotheby International Real Estate's top salesperson, who says she has made more than a dozen bonus-driven deals for luxury apartments since late last year.
She said she sold a 33-year-old single investment banker two side-by-side condominiums, for $1.9 million and $1.2 million, in the Trump International Hotel and Tower on Columbus Circle, Donald Trump's latest gold-hued edifice. Another client, a single young woman, bought a two-bedroom apartment on East 76th Street for $700,000, an all-cash deal paid for mainly with a $1 million-plus bonus.
"A lot of these people have also just bought high-end luxury cars: 740i's, Jeeps," Ms. Lenz said. "In one instance a guy just bought an apartment, a Jeep and a BMW."
Merchants House in TriBeCa, two former industrial buildings on North Moore Street that were converted to 23 large condominiums last year, have nearly sold out, many to Wall Streeters, at asking prices from $750,000 to $2 million.
"There is much more disposable income around," said David Teolis, one of the buyers, who is a 30-year-old co-manager of a high-risk hedge fund. He described his spending as "pretty modest," although he plans to fly to Vail, Colo., for the weekend this month and in the last year has visited Europe five times to see a girlfriend.
Not everyone applauds rising property values, which benefit owners but can price middle-class residents out of the city. Michael McKee, an official of the New York State Tenants and Neighborhood Coalition, recalled that many renters were forced to move by the wave of co-op conversions of the 80's. "It hasn't heated up to that stage yet," he said. "But it will."'
As Wall Streeters enter their 30's, winning promotions to vice president, many move to wealthy suburbs in Fairfield and Westchester Counties. Their base salaries range from about $80,000 to $150,000, and in good years, bonuses based on the income they generate for their firms can boost their total pay to $1 million or more. Their wealth is often invested for the long haul: in securities, a second home, trust funds for their children.
"What I see is many of my friends are now in their mid- to late-30's, as well as early 40's, and you see nesters doing what wealthy nesters do," said Jeffrey T. Leeds, the founder and president of Advance Capital, a private investment fund. "You see them with the round-the-clock live-in nanny, the second house well appointed. I'm getting a lot of change-of-address cards in the mail."
Last year was a very good one for Mr. Leeds, who is 40 and unmarried. He helped broker the sale of the Hard Rock Cafe chain for $410 million and in the same month moved into a seven-room co-op on Park Avenue.
Eli Halperin, 48, vice president of information technology at Goldman, Sachs, said: "I know people who paid off their mortgages with their bonuses so if something happened they won't be dependent. Ten years ago, they used to go to Hawaii for a month or two. People want to be sure if they lose their job they don't go bankrupt."
Still, some Wall Streeters said that the only real difference from the 80's is that the lavish spending is better hidden from the censorious and envious gaze of outsiders. Mr. Leeds, a former law clerk to Justice William J. Brennan Jr. of the Supreme Court, is one of the very few on Wall Street who openly questions the extraordinary sums received. "It's obscene," he said. "Of course it is.
Will there be a backlash against this wave of fat and happy bonus babies? So far, there are no signs of one. After the city's long recession, too many people in all walks of life seem to be benefiting from the fruits of Wall Street's roll.

HEADLINE: Clinton and Republican Leaders Agree on Five Goals

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11

 BODY:
President Clinton and Congressional leaders agreed today on a five-item list of issues, from the quite specific to the very general, where they hope to work out agreements.
The list comprised a tax credit for employers who hire people off welfare, education, tax cuts for individuals, juvenile crime and justice and using the District of Columbia as a laboratory to test new ideas for education, employment and economic growth. 
 But just as pointedly, it did not include three issues where the participants were far apart.
The Republicans paid little attention to Mr. Clinton's suggestion that they include legislation to revise the way campaigns are financed.
Vice President Al Gore poked holes in the suggestion of Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, that legislation dealing with the Superfund program to clean up toxic waste disposal be given a priority.
And Republicans did not agree to include measures to expand health insurance for children, the suggestion of Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader.
After the meeting, leaders from both parties said it had been a resounding success, at least atmospherically.
"The tone was really uniformly excellent," Mr. Gore said. And Senator Lott said, "It was an overall good session, and the atmosphere was the best I've seen it in quite some time."
The comparison was plainly to the time, barely more than a year ago, when Mr. Clinton and Republican leaders met again and again at the White House, arguing about shutdowns of the Government and how to balance the budget. Today's meeting, which took as a given the idea that all sides wanted a balanced budget, was never contentious.
But for all their approval of the tone of the meeting, held among the Turkish-style drapes of the President's Room, just off the Senate chamber, they were cautious about predicting the results to be achieved on an undetermined schedule by task forces whose composition they have not yet figured out.
Speaker Newt Gingrich said at a news conference, "There is a possibility here that we could actually begin a bipartisan process that would be helpful to the national capital, that would be helpful to helping people get off welfare and go to work, that would help young people get educated better, that would be useful in small business being able to hire more people."
Mr. Gingrich added: "That's not a small step, but that's the most we want to say for today. And if we go beyond that, we could end up starting an argument over how we're cooperating. So I think we're better off just to sort of relax. This is a nice step for one day, and we'll come back another day."
Senator Daschle said, "This is a very productive beginning. But it's only that; it's the beginning. It's an opportunity for us to compare priorities, to address those areas of common ground and to find a way with which to resolve the differences and those problem areas that will exist in each of our goals."
Mr. Lott said, "We're going to begin to get groups sitting down together, House and Senate with the Administration, and begin to see where we have the commonality rather than where the differences are."
But education is an item where the commonality is mostly rhetorical and the partisan differences quite specific.
"We all agree that 8-year-olds ought to be able to read," Mr. Gingrich said later, praising the President for raising the issue and saying he "began to give us a measurable way of focusing."
But Mr. Clinton's call for national standards in education has been resisted by Republicans on the ground that they would lead to Federal control of local schools. And they have scoffed at his plan for attacking in-school illiteracy with an army of one million literacy volunteers.
Indeed, Mr. Gingrich quoted one scoffer, Representative Bill Goodling of Pennsylvania, the chairman of the Committee on Economic and Educational Opportunities, as noting that "there are at least 32 Federal literacy programs that already exist."
Republicans, for their part, have urged support for vouchers that would help poor children escape bad public schools, an idea that Mr. Clinton and other Democrats have condemned as a threat to public education.
At the other end of the scale of difficulty is the tax credit for employers who hire welfare recipients. When Democrats propose tax breaks for business, Republicans rarely disagree.
Mr. Gingrich said that at today's meeting, the President made a "very, very helpful point on his part to emphasize that we need to reach out, particularly to small business, which is the primary employer of people who are entering the work force, and find ways to dramatically enhance the opportunity for people currently getting welfare to go to work and get their first job and to begin to rise."
It was much less clear what the leaders meant when they talked about juvenile crime and juvenile justice, which Senator Lott persuaded them to put on the list.
Reviewing the ideas all parties have for tax cuts is clear enough, but where it leads is not, especially since the participants emphasized that all the goals on today's list must be pursued within the overall framework of balancing the budget by the year 2002.
Participants said Mr. Gingrich's suggestion of focusing on the District of Columbia drew widespread support, from the President and from Congressional Democrats and Republicans.
Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader, said he told Mr. Clinton during the meeting that for this process to succeed, both sides have to be wary of being goaded by their core supporters. He said, "I pointed out to the President that I am already picking up signs from my base that since they don't hear my thunder, they are not sure I am here, and I expect he is having the same experience himself."
The discussion, which lasted about an hour, was preceded by a description of the President's room by Donald A. Ritchie, associate historian of the Senate. He said Presidents had used the room chiefly for signing bills when the end of a Congressional session coincided with the end of a President's term in office. He also recounted the occasion in 1921 when President Woodrow Wilson, furious at Senator Henry Cabot Lodge, a Massachusetts Republican who was the majority leader, for defeating the League of Nations treaty, refused to look at him when the Senator came to the room to advise him that Congress was ready to adjourn.
The Senate's chaplain, Dr. Lloyd J. Ogilvie, offered a prayer asking a blessing for the assembled leaders and for the unity they sought.
After that, the atmosphere was so cordial that Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the minority whip and for two years Speaker Gingrich's most insistent antagonist, praised one of the suggestions offered by Mr. Gingrich. The Speaker, for his part, accepted some water Mr. Bonior passed him and drank it.

HEADLINE: News Summary

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL A3-11
 
30 Palestinian Women Are Released by Israel
 
After more than a year of delays and a day of last-minute legal challenges, Israel freed 30 Palestinian women from prison, carrying out part of its agreement with the Palestine Liberation Organization. To pacify Israeli hard-liners, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said he would seek pardons for Jews who killed Arabs. A3
 
Iraq Said to Smuggle Oil
United States Navy officials said Iraq had been exporting oil, with Iranian help, in violation of United Nations sanctions. They said the Iraqis and their Iranian protectors had had two confrontations with Navy warships in the past two weeks, ramming a United States frigate in one showdown. But the officials said the smugglers often avoid American warships by hugging Iran's shallow, treacherous coast. A7
 
Ecuador Gets Newest President
The President of Ecuador's Congress, Fabian Alarcon, was named President of the country for the second time in under a week. His first promotion came the night that the elected President, Abdala Bucaram, was ousted, but was eventually set aside in favor of the Vice President, Rosalia Arteaga. After the vote, Mrs. Arteaga returned, angrily, to the Vice Presidency and called for a plebiscite on who should run the country. A9
 
Peru Talks With Rebels
A Peruvian Government negotiator met face to face with rebels holding 72 hostages in the Japanese Ambassador's compound in Lima. The talks, the first of their kind in over six weeks, took place in a house across the street from the compound. Representatives of the Red Cross, the Vatican, Japan and Canada took part. A8
 
Croats Force Out Muslims
Croats in the divided Bosnian town of Mostar evicted some 100 Muslims from their homes, hours after firing on 200 Muslims who were visiting a cemetery at the end of the holy month of Ramadan. NATO-led forces and United Nations police began patrolling the streets to prevent more violence. The Mayor of Croat Mostar said the Muslims were disguised soldiers. A11
 
Charges for Honduran Ex-Chief
Prosecutors in Honduras said they would charge a former President, Jose Azcona Hoyo, with illegally extraditing a drug trafficker to the United States. The case grew out of the kidnapping, torture and murder of a United States Drug Enforcement Administration agent in Mexico in 1985. The Honduran Constitution says no citizen can be turned over to a foreign country. (AP)
 
China Seals Off Muslim Town
China sealed off the northwestern town where at least 10 people were killed in a Muslim separatist riot. An exiled leader said the troubles were set off by the public execution of 30 ethnic Uighurs. (Reuters)
 
NATIONAL A12-22
 
Clinton and Congress Seek Agreements on 5 Issues
President Clinton and Congressional leaders agreed to try to agree on five issues: a tax credit for employers who hire people off welfare; education; tax cuts for individuals; juvenile crime and juvenile justice, and using the District of Columbia as a laboratory to test new ideas for education, employment and economic growth. They did not agree on changing campaign finance laws, health insurance for children or toxic waste disposal. A1
 
Campaign finance reformers faced other difficulties on Capitol Hill. Democratic and Republican leaders clashed on the terms of an investigation into the alleged abuses that occurred during the 1996 campaign. And supporters of a bill to revise the laws worried that it seemed to be losing momentum. A1
 
Hearings for Nominee Delayed
The chairman of a Senate committee postponed hearings on the nomination of Anthony Lake to lead the Central Intelligence Agency until March 11. He said there were many "unanswered, perplexing questions" about Mr. Lake's conduct as national security adviser during President Clinton's first term. A19
 
A Losing Cosmological Bet
Dr. Stephen W. Hawking, the cosmologist, conceded defeat in a famous bet he made six years ago with two professors at the California Institute of Technology. He bet that naked singularities -- places other than the centers of black holes where space and time are infinitely distorted and matter is infinitely dense -- could not exist. A scholar in Texas showed that, in theory, they could. A1
 
Hubble Repairmen Blast Off
Seven astronauts aboard the shuttle Discovery blasted into space, heading for the Hubble Space Telescope. They are scheduled to replace two aging scientific instruments with more up-to-date ones and give the telescope a tuneup. A12
 
Trial Opens in Racial Killing
North Carolina prosecutors began presenting their case against a white former Army private. They said he teamed up with a compatriot to kill a couple in Fayetteville in December 1995 because the couple was black.
 A12
 
Pooch Wins a Reprieve
Portsmouth, N.H., pardoned Prince, a black Labrador mix who had been on death row since August for killing a rooster. But the agreement requires that a home be found for him outside Portsmouth. A15
Knife Brings a Suspension
 
A high school honor student in Gobles, Mich., was suspended for 10 days for bringing a knife to school. She said it was a kitchen knife that she planned to use to cut a friend's birthday brownies. School board members said the action showed they were serious about weapons in schools, even though the student, Amber Nash, did not plan to use the knife as a weapon. (AP)
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-8
 
City Women's Shelter Replaces Its Entire Staff
The entire staff of the only shelter for battered women run directly by New York City was replaced. Investigators said the shelter's workers had forced women to have sex, used drugs and alcohol on the job and allowed abusive husbands and boyfriends into the shelter at night. A1
 
Dinkins Decides Against Race
Former Mayor David N. Dinkins told associates he would not run for Mayor this year. Some of the associates said he would probably endorse the Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, instead. B1
 
Battle to Control Adelphi U.
The trustees of Adelphi University won a court order blocking their removal by the State Board of Regents. The board, which put new trustees in power on Monday, said it would appeal. Each side said its trustees were in charge in the meantime. B1
 
Workfare Chief to Go Private

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
China Reported Ready to End Some Barriers

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11

 BODY:
China has quietly told American officials that it is willing to abandon many of its largest trade barriers, including some of the laws that protect state-run and military-run industries from foreign competition, in return for membership in the World Trade Organization, according to senior Administration officials.
The offer, conveyed to an American negotiating team over the last two weeks and repeated to European and Japanese officials, marks the first time that China has discussed eliminating specific laws that have long been the subject of complaints by foreign investors. These include a requirement that the investors export the great majority of the goods they produce, rules that have contributed to China's rising trade surplus with the United States. 
 But the Chinese have yet to indicate any willingness to tackle the most politically explosive problem in opening China's market: ending the big subsidies Beijing gives state-run industries, which employ a significant portion of the country's workers.
Officials on several continents warn that the offers have so far only been conveyed in conversations between Chinese and American officials, and that they are wary of the Chinese officials' willingness to follow through on the changes they have discussed. "There always has been a dysfunction between what they say and what they put in writing," Charlene Barshefsky, the acting United States trade representative, said today. "And for W.T.O. accession, what they put in writing is what counts."
Nonetheless, Ms. Barshefsky said: "Obviously China's rhetoric has improved significantly, and its willingness to begin to discuss issues of importance has increased." Others in the Administration say they believe that China -- in part to engage the United States on a subject other than human rights and arms sales --- may have decided to put entry into the club of trading nations atop its agenda.
The United States can effectively block the entry of any country into the trade organization by arguing that its plans to open markets do not meet the group's requirements.
"They didn't think we were serious about it last year because of the election," a senior Administration official said. "I think they now believe that we will not stand in the way of their entry to the W.T.O. on political grounds if their offer is sufficient."
Indeed, many in the Administration hope a deal to open China's economy will be the centerpiece of the President's first trip to China, late this year or early in 1998.
But there are many obstacles ahead, officials say. The United States believes China's leadership is deeply divided on whether joining the World Trade Organization, which China has demanded for several years, is worth the high price. The leaders are especially worried that any deal that weakens the already noncompetitive state-run industries could result in widespread unemployment and political instability.
For China, membership in the trade organization is partly a matter of prestige and partly a matter of economic good sense. It can benefit from low or zero tariffs, but membership also subjects it a judicial process to settle trade disputes.
The United States, Japan and the European Union are also doing a delicate pirouette around the rules of entry, each worried that the other could gain some kind of political advantage in dealing with the world's biggest emerging market.
According to negotiators, here is what Chinese officials said they would agree to do during the recent round of talks, which were intended to preview more formal negotiations in Geneva starting on March 4:
*They have agreed to eliminate, over time, the requirement that foreign companies building factories in China export the majority of their output. Companies like Fruit of the Loom, the underwear maker, are required to export 70 percent or more of their output; electronics companies are often required to export even more. It is unclear how quickly China would phase out such requirements or whether individual contracts with companies might still require such exports.
*They have agreed to phase out rules requiring foreign companies to bring big amounts of foreign currency into China and keep it there and that require them to "balance" their foreign trade -- that is, to export more goods than they import -- and that require high levels of "local content" for goods made in China.
*They have agreed to scrap laws that bar many foreign companies from freely trading in China. For example, American food producers like Cargill Inc. are required to buy their wheat through China's state-run trading agencies, rather than importing it directly.
In each of these areas, the scope of the concessions China is offering cannot be measured until it has filed proposed wording for an "accession agreement" in Geneva. That is expected to begin next month, and it will touch off a worldwide negotiation in which Europe, Japan and the United States all have somewhat differing agendas.
China has not yet submitted data to the trade organization that would quantify its subsidies to state-run industries, which range from manufacturers of heavy industrial equipment to computer makers to a manufacturer of tofu that is run by the military. And even when those data are submitted, they would be difficult to verify, especially because the ownership of many enterprises in China is murky.
One complexity in this negotiation is that American officials and their allies are uncertain how much power the chief negotiator -- Wu Yi, China's Trade Minister -- actually holds. She has managed to push through smaller agreements, including one last year that led to a continuing crackdown on the piracy of foreign-produced software, music and videos. But accession to the World Trade Organization is a far bigger and politically sensitive undertaking.
"The mystery," one senior American official said, "is at what point does the top political leadership get involved to make the hard decisions." The hardest of those will be the World Trade Organization's rules against many types of subsidies for domestic industries, including state-owned enterprises.
The Administration's position on China's membership in the trade organization has been that Beijing should become a member on "commercially acceptable terms," a position President Clinton repeated to President Jiang Zemin when they met in Manila in November. The two leaders engaged in their lengthiest conversation yet about China's membership, and that appears to have sparked the talks that American negotiators began two weeks ago in Beijing.
But Mr. Clinton is not operating with an entirely free hand. Many in Congress have expressed deep reservations about China's entry into the trade organization. Of the 18 written questions Ms. Barshefsky received from senators during her confirmation hearings as the permanent trade representative last week, all but one concerned concessions China must make. Senators from agricultural states were particularly insistent that the Chinese lift obstacles to importing American beef and other agricultural products.
The other potential obstacle lies in China's political behavior in coming months. "If Hong Kong becomes a problem or if there is a new arms scandal, you could kiss this goodbye," one senior American official said. "But if there is anyplace where we can get the Sino-American relationship back on track, this is it."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Surging Dollar? In U.S., Most Companies Shrug It Off

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 11

 BODY:
When the American dollar was soaring a dozen years ago, many American manufacturers warned that their businesses would be severely injured by an influx of cheap Japanese tractors, cars and other imports.
The dollar has been soaring again this winter, but this time, the number of American companies expressing alarm has been surprisingly small. In recent days, officials at the Boeing Company, the General Electric Company and the Intel Corporation have dismissed worries about the dollar. Even Caterpillar, which led the complaints in the mid-1980's, has said almost nothing lately about the dollar's surge, although its chairman, Donald V. Fites, indicated some concern last summer. 
 The dollar continued to climb today even after Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin declared that it "has now corrected itself" after hitting a record low against the yen nearly two years ago. His comments came three days after global finance officials meeting in Berlin suggested that the dollar's rally was over.
While the dollar's rise still threatens grave harm to some industries, notably auto makers here, many other American companies are insulated from the dollar's effects by their expanded production overseas, a decade of aggressive cost-cutting and active hedging of currencies.
American machine-tool makers, many of which were nearly driven out of business in the mid-1980's by low-priced Japanese imports, have been remarkably quiet about the latest rise in the dollar. "We can export our machines to Japan and Europe with a landed cost that is competitive," even at current exchange rates, said James S. Gleason, the chairman of the Gleason Corporation, a big machine-tool manufacturer based in Rochester.
Mr. Gleason gave several reasons, echoed by executives at other companies, for the failure of the rising dollar to inflict much harm so far. The Gleason Corporation has sharply reduced its costs over the last decade and has abstained from making significant price increases, he said. Japanese machine-tool producers have had little room to cut prices lately with a strong dollar because they never raised them much when the dollar was weak. And Gleason has significantly expanded its production overseas.
Low-cost foreign production allows companies to sell competitively priced goods and hold on to market share even when the dollar is rising, although the profits from foreign operations may be worth less when converted into dollars.
Some economists also note that while the dollar has risen 54 percent against the Japanese yen since its low in April 1995, it has appreciated only 17 percent in trade-weighted terms. The American dollar is nearly unchanged against the Canadian dollar, for example. And the dollar's recent rise against the yen has not yet put the dollar at the vertiginous levels reached in the mid-1980's.
So while some companies, notably auto makers, are very worried now by the dollar's strength, others are not, particularly those that have moved part or all of their manufacturing operations offshore. "I wouldn't characterize my phone as ringing off the hook," with manufacturers worried about the dollar, said Marino P. Marcich, the director for international investment and finance at the National Association of Manufacturers. "Perhaps the rhetoric concerning globalization is a bit closer to reality than it seemed."
Yet it remains possible that American companies are simply slow to recognize the dangers, as they were in the 1980's. Higher inflation in the United States and Japan means that the dollar should be falling by 2 or 3 percent a year just to keep price levels in the two countries comparable. Adjusted for differences in inflation, the dollar-yen exchange rate is near a six-year high.
The rising dollar is clearly harming some sectors of the economy already. And some economists argue that it hurts American workers even if it does not hurt multinationals based in the United States.
The businesses that are suffering from the strong dollar now fall into three sometimes overlapping categories. Commodity producers that operate on small margins are finding their profits eroded by foreign competitors. Businesses without international operations that export or compete with imports suffer many of the disadvantages of a strong dollar without the ability to expand production in countries with weak currencies. And some companies that compete mainly with imports from Japan are also struggling.
The loudest complaints lately have come from Detroit's Big Three auto makers because they fall into all three categories of vulnerability. They mainly compete with Japanese imports in the American market, and have been steadily losing market share to them recently. While the Big Three have extensive operations in Europe, they have minimal sales in Japan and do not directly own any assembly plants there, so they are not insulated against the yen's decline. And there are some signs that cars are becoming commodities, sold as basic transportation at razor-thin margins that can evaporate when exchange rates change.
The Big Three have also not been shy about raising prices to raise profits now, sometimes at the expense of market share. A study released on Monday by Automotive News showed that the Big Three raised their vehicle prices by an average of $39 since Jan. 1 while Japanese auto makers have left their prices unchanged. The Big Three also raised their prices by an average of $386 at the beginning of the current model year on Oct. 1, while their Japanese rivals did so by an average of just $8.
Not surprisingly, the Big Three's inventory of unsold cars has ballooned, to 85 days of sales at the end of January, up from a more typical 60 days at the end of September.
American auto executives have begun hinting at stepping up their cost-cutting efforts if the dollar continues to rise, although they have not yet mentioned the possibility of layoffs. When the dollar was trading at 114 yen early last month, John F. Smith Jr., the chairman and chief executive of the General Motors Corporation, said, "If the yen continues to weaken, we'll have to take a relook at accelerating that process."
If layoffs do come, they would be one sign that American workers may be bearing the brunt of a rising dollar, even if big corporations with global operations are not. Jobs in export industries and manufacturing jobs also tend to pay considerably more than the national average.
To the extent that these jobs are eliminated now because of the rising dollar, "You actually hurt the average wage level of the median family," said C. Fred Bergsten, the director of the Institute for International Economics, a Washington-based research group.
Yet a rising dollar does help a few industries. Cheaper imports tend to mean less inflation. That means lenders are willing to accept lower interest rates, because they have fewer worries that their principal will be repaid in dollars devalued by inflation. And many industries whose customers borrow a lot of money benefit from low interest rates, notably home builders.
Trucking companies have also been pleased because they tend to haul a lot of building materials and imported products, like videocassette recorders and cars. Even if the strong dollar produces an offsetting fall in exports, truckers may not be hurt much because exports tend to move by air freight.
And in a few industries that seem at first glance like clear victims of a strong dollar, the effect has actually been the reverse. California wine producers now face competition from slightly cheaper French wines. Yet several winery executives said that they were delighted by the dollar's rise because it would lower the cost of imported French oak barrels and other wine equipment. Any loss of sales to foreign competition, they predicted, would be minimal.
"We are just high-fiving each other; this is great," said Tom Rinaldi, a wine maker at Duckhorn Vineyards in St. Helena, Calif.

HEADLINE: Family Planning and Foreign Policy Are Linked, Albright Tells House Panel

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11

 BODY:
In her first public appearance on Capitol Hill as Secretary of State, Madeleine K. Albright today asserted that family planning was an important component of the United States' foreign policy and urged Congress to support an Administration-backed measure that would speed the release of money for family-planning programs overseas.
The House is to vote on Thursday on such a measure, as well as on an alternative that would bar aid from the United States to groups that perform abortions, even if they use private money for that purpose. 
 Ms. Albright, making the Administration's strongest statement yet on family planning, called it an important tool by which the United States could demonstrate world leadership.
"One of the most important ways we contribute to sustainable development is through our support for international family planning," Ms. Albright told a packed hearing of the House International Relations Committee as she sought an increase in the State Department's budget.
"By stabilizing population growth rates, developing nations can devote more of their scarce resources to meet the basic needs of their citizens," she said. "Moreover, our voluntary family-planning programs serve our broader interests by elevating the status of women, reducing the flow of refugees, protecting the environment and promoting economic growth."
The family-planning programs have come under fire from anti-abortion forces, who contend that they are actually conduits for what many of them call President Clinton's worldwide "abortion crusade."
In addition, some opponents of the Administration's measure, like Steven W. Mosher of the Population Research Institute, which opposes contraception, accuse the United States of a "contraceptive imperialism." At a news conference on Monday that featured Representative Christopher Smith, Republican of New Jersey, and Senator Tim Hutchinson, Republican of Arkansas, Mr. Mosher said that overpopulation of the world was a "myth" and that money from the United States was used disproportionately for family planning at the expense of basic health and hygiene.
The Administration-backed resolution would speed the release of money allocated last year but withheld until July 1997. If released on March 1, as the Administration wants, the money available between then and Sept. 30, the end of the 1997 fiscal year, would amount to $215 million. If delayed until July, the sum would amount to $92 million, a loss of $123 million.
An alternative measure, offered by Mr. Smith, would provide $385 million for family planning, but only on the condition that none of the money go to any organization that performs abortions, even if it finances them with money from other sources.
While both measures could conceivably pass the House, the Smith bill would face a tougher time in the Senate and would be vetoed by President Clinton.
At today's hearing, Mr. Smith pointedly questioned Ms. Albright as he asserted that the Administration was bent on undermining anti-abortion laws in many of the countries where the United States sends family-planning money through the Agency for International Development.
"I believe the real consensus is with providing family planning funds," Mr. Smith said, "but not, however unwittingly, empowering the pro-abortion movement overseas to bring down the right-to-life laws as they exist in approximately 100 countries of the world."
Ms. Albright responded: "The U.S. does not fund the performance or promotion of abortion anywhere in the world. And what we are concerned about is that the restrictions that are envisioned in your language would preclude U.S.A.I.D. from working with organizations that provide effective, voluntary family planning and women's health services in countries where abortion is legal."
She added, "I think the issue here, sir, is that we desperately need the money in order to try to get women out of the terrible poverty that has existed."
Planned Parenthood took two Russian pediatricians to Congress on Monday to brief legisators on what they described as the benefits of the United States-backed family-planning efforts. The Russians said that since contraceptives had become more available, abortions in Russia had dropped to 2.7 million in 1995, from 4.4 million in 1989.
One of the doctors, Inga I. Grebesheva, director general of the Russian Association of Family Planning in Moscow, said Russia's birth rate had dwindled as a result of post-abortion complications that had left women infertile. Unlike in other countries, where family planning was intended partly to check overpopulation, she said Russia hoped that family planning would help rebuild the population by preventing the spread of sexually transmitted diseases and curbing the need for abortions, which are often performed in unsanitary conditions.
Mr. Smith and his supporters have characterized Thursday's vote as the first abortion-related vote of the new Congress, a characterization that may help pressure some abortion opponents in the House into voting with them.
For that same reason, supporters of family planning strongly reject such a characterization. If the vote is cast in terms of abortion instead of family planning, they would probably lose votes in the House, where a majority of members oppose abortion. As a matter of policy and law, the Federal money cannot be used for abortions, even though Mr. Smith argues that because money is interchangeable, the Federal money frees up other money to be used for this purpose.
Kate Bunting, a spokeswoman for CARE, one of the international relief and development organizations that receives Federal money for family planning overseas, said, "We do not pay for abortions with our private money; we don't even have an organizational position on abortion."
Ms. Bunting said approval of the Administration's resolution on Thursday would depend on "pro-life members' making the distinction and understanding that providing family-planning services will in fact reduce abortion."
