HEADLINE: White House Memo;
Clinton Seems to Keep Running Though the Race Is Run and Won

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11

 BODY:
Last year, President Clinton waged a campaign that looked like government, announcing initiatives at his political rallies and virtually never mentioning his opponent. Now, with his last election behind him, Mr. Clinton is running the White House in a manner that looks like a campaign.
Some of the President's recent national appearances to highlight his education proposals have been indistinguishable from the re-election rallies of 1996. When he traveled to the northern suburbs of Chicago last month to call for testing to assess education standards, Mr. Clinton dropped into a classroom briefly, just as he did before campaign rallies, then delivered a speech in a gymnasium bedecked with a giant American flag. 
 Even the music is sometimes the same. When Mr. Clinton made a similar appearance at a college in Georgia last week, the school band struck up one of his campaign theme songs, Fleetwood Mac's, "Don't Stop (Thinking About Tomorrow)."
Although Mr. Clinton will not run for office again, he is still using his campaign polling firm of Penn & Schoen Associates to gauge public opinion and help him test and craft language for his speeches. On Monday, in fact, officials of the Democratic National Committee met with Mark Penn to discuss payment terms and a plan for polling in 1997 for both the White House and the Democratic Party.
The weekly evening meeting in the White House residence, where Mr. Clinton once gathered his aides and strategists to plot his campaign, is run by Erskine B. Bowles, the White House chief of staff. Along with other White House officials, the pollsters and the campaign media team of Robert Squier and Bill Knapp, of Squier Knapp Ochs Communications, still attend, officials say.
White House officials say that while they are now trying to promote Mr. Clinton's policies instead of winning his re-election, they still need to use forms of public persuasion similar to those used in a campaign -- with attention to everything from television images and mobilizing support, to using language that resonates well with the public.
"In the campaign year, campaigns are about framing a choice for the American people -- why me and not the other guy," said Michael D. McCurry, Mr. Clinton's press secretary. "When you are responsible for governing you have to use the same tools of public persuasion to advance your program, to build public support for the direction you are attempting to lead."
Mr. Clinton is not the first President to use these techniques; Ronald Reagan's master stage manager, Michael K. Deaver, elevated the theme of the day and the telegenic backdrop to a political art form.
But Mr. Clinton not only has hewed to the same path, he has made such tools more important. That is because so much of the success of his current program, designed for the era of deficit reduction, depends not on traditional legislative and executive action but on his success in urging groups like state legislatures or individual school districts or citizen volunteers to take action.
For this effort to work, some officials argue, the President must be perceived as riding a wave of public support. "Clinton has come to believe that if he keeps his approval ratings up and sells his message as he did during the campaign, there will be greater acceptability for his program," said one aide to the President. "The idea is that you have to sell it as if in a campaign."
Dick Morris, the political strategist who helped Mr. Clinton develop the technique of the permanent campaign -- using polling and paid commercials as tools of governance -- during Mr. Clinton's years as Governor of Arkansas and then in the 1996 campaign, put it this way: "A President doesn't just need a majority on Election Day. The President needs a majority every day of the week behind every bill that he has."
It is that notion which explains one curious fact about the way Mr. Clinton has been promoting his education ideas. In his three stops around the country, Mr. Clinton has spoken not to those who doubt the efficacy of the programs he is supporting but to the already converted. He has gone to a school consortium that has already embraced testing standards; to Georgia, the state that was the model for his proposal to give tax credits for higher education; and to the Maryland State Legislature, which already supports his education goals.
The education appearances, at least at this early stage, are not designed to confront and convince doubting state legislatures or school districts to adopt national education standards. Rather they are conceived as events that mobilize Mr. Clinton's supporters and give his ideas an aura of inevitability and public support.
They also usually generate large doses of favorable coverage in local television markets, causing a regional surge of support.
To measure how he is interacting with the nation, Mr. Clinton has long favored public opinion polling to gauge the shifts and turns of the public pysche. And polling is continuing in the White House.
White House officials argue that the President uses polls not to set his positions, but to figure out how best to sell them. Before Mr. Clinton delivered his State of the Union Message, Mr. McCurry said the White House was polling on speech themes to make the President's arguments "as crisp and as sharp and as persuasive as possible."
Such polling has helped the White House discover, for example, that the President had a better chance of marshaling public opinion for an assault-rifle ban if he portrayed it as an anti-crime measure, as opposed to a gun-control measure. During the campaign, Mr. Clinton learned that he drew more support by speaking about the strength of the economy under his stewardship than by highlighting the concerns of those left behind in the information age economy.
Mr. Clinton's aides say polling will be conducted with far less frequency now than in 1996. Amy Weiss Tobe, the spokeswoman for the Democratic National Committee, declined to discuss the exact amount Penn & Schoen will be paid by the party, and both Mr. Penn and his partner Douglas Schoen refused to comment. But Democrats familiar with the pollsters' billings in the campaign said a one-year total was likely to run from $750,000 to $1.25 million and that the pollsters were not being given a retainer or a firm contract.
Mr. Clinton, of course, has not eschewed the traditional forms of Presidential persuasion. In fact, he has made a concerted effort since he began his second term to have better relations with members of Congress. He invited a small group of Republicans and Democrats to watch Super Bowl XXXI with him in the White House and he has been holding a series of one-on-one meetings with lawmakers to hear their concerns.
The President has also made an effort to patch up his prickly relations with the press. He has been inviting reporters and columnists to off-the-record discussions inside the White House and he has been holding a news conference a month since Election Day.
What remains to be seen is whether Mr. Clinton will include paid television commercials as the final weapon in his arsenal of persuasion techniques. Mr. Morris, who left the Clinton campaign last August in the wake of a tabloid report that he had had dealings with a prostitute, said that he had advised the President that he should continue to run ads about issues during his second term. "I don't think he has to dominate the airwaves," Mr. Morris said. "I do think he should do some advertising at crucial junctures."
White House officials said they would not rule out such a move.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Time Warner Reports Profit And Seeks to Cut Debt Load
Time Warner reported a 79 percent rise in profit, and said it was determined to improve cash flow in an effort to pay off its $18 billion in debt. The company posted net income of $59 million, or a loss of 3 cents a share after the payment of preferred dividends for the quarter ending Dec. 31, compared with a profit of $33 million, or 1 cent a share, a year earlier.
Perhaps the news that heartened Wall Street most was the appointment of several prominent new board members. [Page D6.] 

Stocks Rise on Late Buying
Stock prices rebounded, despite an early selloff in some technology issues. The Dow Jones industrial average found its momentum in the last hour of trading to close up 51.57 points, at 6,858.11, 25 points shy of the closing high set on Jan. 21. The Nasdaq composite index finished modestly lower. [D8.]
 
Treasury prices ended little changed, as a sale of new three-year notes largely matched expectations. The yield on the 30-year bond was unchanged at 6.70 percent. [D18.]
 
An Air Strike's Effects Feared
A strike by the pilots' union of American Airlines would not only shut down the carrier but would also severely inconvenience tens of thousands of passengers throughout the nation's crowded air-transportation system. The airlines are already filling a higher percentage of seats than they have in years, and with the Washington's Birthday weekend at hand, several carriers expect to be crowded even without an American Airlines strike. Edwin McDowell: Business Travel. [D7.]
 
New Goal on Air Safety
Two years after the Transportation Secretary proclaimed a goal of eliminating airline accidents, a White House commission will set a revised target that experts consider more realistic: cutting the rate 80 percent. [A16.]
 
U.S. Productivity Grew Significantly
Worker productivity grew at the fastest rate in three years at the end of 1996, the Government said, reinforcing a picture of a healthy economy with little inflation. Productivity outside of agriculture rose 2.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 1996, a sharp improvement from the third quarter, when productivity was flat. [D2.]
 
Westinghouse Posts Loss
Westinghouse said that its fourth-quarter profit from continuing operations declined 17 percent, as an operating loss at CBS offset stronger results at the company's local television and radio stations. [D6.]
 
Chief Ousted at Computer Company
Centennial Technologies, a maker of personal computer equipment, whose stock soared last year, said it had dismissed its chairman and chief executive, Emanuel Pinez, and had begun an investigation into the accuracy of its financial statements. [D4.]
 
Auto Makers Sue on Electric Cars
A group representing the Big Three auto makers has sued New York State over rules requiring the car makers to include some electric vehicles in their fleets beginning next year. It contends that the rules violate the Federal Clean Air Act. [B5.]
 
Jeans Maker Plans To Combine Businesses
The VF Corporation, the maker of Lee and Wrangler jeans, said it would combine its 17 businesses into 5 as part of a streamlining expected to cut costs $150 million a year. The company also said it would increase spending on marketing and research 25 percent. The moves are not expected to result in charges against earnings. [D4.]
 
A New Take on the 3 Musketeers
Until now all three musketeers who represented the 3 Musketeers candy brand have been white. Now, though, one of the three actors who portray the characters in television commercials and print advertisements is black. The campaign was created by a company that specializes in work aimed at black consumers. The 3 Musketeers ads, however, are for the general market -- that is, aimed at all consumers. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D6.]

HEADLINE: Bulgaria's Socialists Block Change for Better

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Bulgaria Party Blocks Action on Economy" (news article, Feb. 7) doesn't make clear the desperate straits of the Bulgarian people. The statement that "the average salary is $10" doesn't indicate that this is not a daily or even weekly wage but a monthly income. Heat and electricity for a small apartment costs more than $13 a month. My wife's 70-year-old mother must live on a stipend of $3 a month. 
 The Bulgarians are hungry and cold, but the Socialist Party fights to remain in office. Its agenda makes it unwilling to accept the changes necessary to conserve the country's meager resources and attract investments. Can it be that the Socialists fear that when they no longer carry the cloak of office they will be brought to justice?
 
S. ALAN LOWE
Englewood, N.J., Feb. 8, 1997

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Yawn. A global-warming alert. But this one has solutions.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
STERNLY worded petitions and ringing screeds of principle are as much a part of campus life as grade inflation -- which is why Washington rarely takes them seriously. But the nation's movers and shakers would do well to pay attention to a statement on global warming by some 2,000 mostly academic economists.
For one thing, the signatures collected by Redefining Progress, a group of policy-minded social scientists based in San Francisco, range from the newish left (Duncan Foley of Barnard College) to the skeptical center (James Heckman of the University of Chicago) to the libertarian right (Gordon Tullock of the University of Arizona). "Market-based approaches to coping with climate change generate as much consensus among economists as free trade," explains Paul Krugman of M.I.T., one of the organizers of the statement. 
 More important, the statement focuses on what is now regarded by insiders as a make-it-or-break-it issue in slowing atmospheric warming: designing an international system that permits rich economies to contribute cash in lieu of emissions reductions. "Allowing some to pay others to reduce greenhouse emissions could reduce the total cost by 80 to 90 percent," estimates William Nordhaus, an economist at Yale and another organizer of the statement.
Like any committee looking for consensus, the drafters of the climate statement cast their net widely. "We believe that global climate change carries with it significant environmental, economic, social and geopolitical risks, and that preventive steps are justified," the unshocking introduction reads.
Those who read on, however, will discover there is meat on these bones: "Sound economic analysis," the authors argue, "shows that there are policy options that would slow climate change without harming American living standards."
And what might these policy options be? Here, the drafters stake out a position that seems almost obvious to economists, but has barely entered the consciousness of environmental policy makers. "A cooperative approach among nations is required -- such as an international emissions trading agreement," the statement asserts.
To understand where the economists really want the diplomats to go, consider where we are now. Current rates of deforestation and combustion of carbon-based fuels -- coal, oil, gas -- are adding carbon dioxide into the atmosphere faster than the oceans can absorb it. The higher carbon dioxide concentrations trap solar energy. Rising temperatures will likely change weather patterns radically and raise the level of the oceans.
Governments of all the major economies are vaguely committed to containing greenhouse gas emissions before once-a-century hurricanes become an annual event in the Caribbean, Kansas turns into a dust bowl and the Bay of Bengal doubles in size at the expense of Bangladesh. But the emphasis is on the vague: the process of setting emissions targets or creating political institutions to enforce the targets is in the talking stage.
That's where the economists' statement fits in. "We wanted to be there early," said Stephen DeCanio of the University of California at Santa Barbara, "before governments and politicians were locked into positions." Specifically, the statement is intended to give the Clinton Administration some help in pressing the idea of creating an international market in emissions permits at the next global meeting on climate change, set for Kyoto, Japan, in December.
The idea is simple. If and when world leaders start to deal with the practical issues, they are apt to set national targets for containing emissions that will be very expensive to meet in the rich industrial economies, and probably won't be honored in the large emerging economies like China, Russia, India and Indonesia.
Creating an emissions trading system that allows already rich economies to pay the emerging economies to use less energy and less carbon-intensive fuels as they develop offers a double dividend. It reduces the cost for developed countries, in turn reducing the chances their legislatures will balk. And it creates a pool of capital to be used as an incentive to push emerging economies toward environmentally benign growth.
Translation: Getting, say, China or India to switch from coal to natural gas, or to encourage energy conservation by charging world market prices at home would be a lot easier if they were paid billions of dollars each year to do it.
Not every economist who favors emissions trading signed the statement. "I'm worried it will be used at Kyoto to commit America to useless, expensive unilateral actions in reducing emissions," says Robert Hahn, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute.
But Mr. Nordhaus has very different worries. "Economists haven't been important players in environmental policy over the last 30 years," he said. "This time we could make a difference."

HEADLINE: Lott Says He Sees Chance for Broad Cut in Capital Gains Taxes

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12

 BODY:
One day after agreeing to accelerate negotiations with the Clinton Administration over taxes, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, said today that he saw cracks in the Democrats' long-standing opposition to a broad cut in capital gains taxes.
Republicans have long sought such a cut. Senator Lott, alluding to several recent proposals by Congressional Democrats, said there might be enough bipartisan support to overcome the opposition of Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin. 
 Mr. Rubin supports only a narrow capital gains measure, offered by the Administration in its latest budget proposal, that would benefit some people who sell their homes.
"The Democrats have also been tiptoeing into the capital gains area," Mr. Lott said after a meeting of the Senate Finance Committee, adding that any compromise would ultimately depend on President Clinton's flexibility. "If we can get the staff and the Secretary out of the way, I think maybe we have something to agree about here."
But in an appearance before the committee, Secretary Rubin did not budge from the Administration's official line that it sees few economic benefits -- and potentially huge costs -- from a sweeping reduction in the tax on profits from the sale of stocks, bonds, real estate and other assets.
While Mr. Rubin continued to leave the door open to a compromise, the conflicting statements suggested the difficulty that the Republican leadership and the White House face in trying to reach agreement on the issue, a primary impediment to any deal to balance the budget by 2002.
Tax policy was one of five issues -- along with education, juvenile crime and justice, aiding the District of Columbia and efforts to encourage employers to hire welfare recipients -- listed on Tuesday by Mr. Clinton and Congressional leaders as issues on which they would seek quick agreement as a start toward bipartisan cooperation on the budget. The talks are tentatively scheduled to begin after Congress returns from a one-week recess next week.
The Administration has proposed $98 billion in tax cuts over the next five years, paid for in large part by $76 billion in new or extended taxes or closed loopholes.
The latest Republican proposal, backed by Senator Lott, calls for $193 billion in tax reductions over the same period, including a $33 billion cut in the capital gains tax. The Republicans have not said how they would pay for their plan.
The Administration's plan would exempt from capital gains taxes the profits on sales of homes up to $500,000, but would not cut the top 28 percent capital gains rate on the sale of other assets. The Republican plan calls for the top rate on all capital gains to decline to 19.8 percent.
A possible compromise was offered today by Senator Wendell H. Ford, Democrat of Kentucky. Senator Ford's plan would reduce the capital gains tax based on how long a taxpayer had owned an asset before selling it.
The plan would be most appealing to long-term investors and to farmers and small-business owners. It would be of little benefit to short-term investors in the stock market.
"I believe the impact will be to provide the greatest benefit to middle-class families and not Wall Street," Senator Ford said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Lower As Auction Disappoints

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended lower yesterday, following poor results at a Treasury auction of new 10-year notes.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 3/32, to 97 11/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, edged up to 6.71 percent from 6.70 percent, where it had stayed the previous three session. 
 The $12 billion sale of 10-year notes yesterday afternoon was met with weak demand. The bid-to-cover ratio, or the amount of bids compared with the amount of securities available, was just 1.90 to 1, down from 2.41 to 1 at the last auction of 10-year notes and the smallest since May 1995, when it was 1.67 to 1. Noncompetitive demand was considered decent and amounted to about $424 million. The average yield at auction was 6.374 percent, a little higher than expected, as some selling in the cash market pushed yields a bit higher.
Investors seized on the auction's poor results as an excuse to sell Treasury securities before today's retail sales report for January and the final auction in the Treasury's quarterly refunding. Today, the Treasury sells $10 billion of 30-year bonds. In when-issued trading ahead of today's sale the 30-year bond was priced to yield 6.64 percent.
Traders note that the 37 primary securities dealers who are required to bid at the auctions often try to punch yields higher before the sale to make Treasury securities more attractive to investors and insure demand for the issue. But with a number of important economic reports coming out this week, few investors were willing to buy actively.
Today the Government will report on retail sales in January, and tomorrow on producer prices and industrial production. Recent signs of economic growth have not driven prices higher. The market received more indications of economic strength early in the session yesterday, when the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta released its survey of business conditions within its region. The index had a strong reading of 11.1 for January, compared to a negative 18.7 reading for December.
Gerald A. Guild, senior vice president of the taxable-fixed-income department at Advest Inc. said the trading so far this week was typical of a three-part quarterly refunding. "The 3-year is successful, the 10-year maturity is disappointing and the balance of whether it will be a successful refunding or not hangs on the 30-year issue," he said. "The short-term benchmark of success is whether or not the three issues sell above their average auction prices on settlement day, which is Feb. 18."
The generally mediocre results of the Treasury refunding so far -- an auction on Tuesday of three-year notes came largely within expectations -- have left investors concerned that demand from foreign investors may be diminishing. Such fears have weighed on bond prices. Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new 10-year notes:

HEADLINE: The Ebbing Hudson River Park

 BODY:
The edge of Manhattan along the Hudson River may be one of the most precious strips of land in the nation. Ever since the Manhattan waterfront became moribund, New Yorkers have dreamed about its potential for open parkland and recreational use. But that promise is slipping away.
The riverside between Battery Park and 59th Street is owned by the state and the city. For years it has contained a depressing mixture of ruined piers and unlovely facilities like a cement plant and a parking lot for sanitation trucks. The city and state agreed long ago that when a new highway was built along the West Side, the waterfront would be recaptured for a mixture of open space and ball fields. The new park would be maintained with income from a modest amount of recreation-based business development. 
 Now the road is being built, but the park is floating in a vacuum. Gov. George Pataki says he supports the project, but he has neither publicly endorsed the park plan nor included any money for it in his budget. The Governor says there will be time for that once an environmental impact statement is completed.
A $200 million project that is moving forward bureaucratically but without strong political backing is a project in trouble. Pieces of the intended park have already been nibbled off for development. The city recently took over several piers from the Port Authority, which had been running a money-losing passenger ship terminal. It intends to lease part of the space for a new film studio. The Chelsea Piers recreational facility wants to use a slice of the intended parkland for a traffic rotary. Restaurants are being given temporary leases along the water in lower Manhattan.
Unlike the state, New York City has made a clear economic commitment to the park, including its share of the construction cost in its long-term budget. But in the absence of strong state leadership, it has not been acting as though it believes the project will really happen.
The initiative should come from Mr. Pataki. Skeptics have a right to be dubious about his commitment since he has never publicly endorsed the park plan. A press conference about the waterfront would take care of that problem. The Governor should also include the state's $100 million share of the construction price in his long-term budget.
The future Hudson River Park's promise is too great to be frittered away. Every city resident or tourist who has visited Battery Park in Lower Manhattan realizes what a resource the Manhattan waterfront can be, and how little use New York has ever made of this precious asset. Saving the park will reinforce Mr. Pataki's reputation as an environmentalist and boost Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's efforts to improve the city's quality of life.
Mr. Pataki is right when he says that the state cannot begin building a park along the river until an environmental impact statement is completed and expected legal challenges are overcome. But there is a great deal he can do to make sure that when the time is right, all the pieces are still there.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Congressional Panel Hears Options for Delayed Space Station

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12

 BODY:
If Russia further delays or fails to produce a major component of the planned international space station, the United States is considering several steps to minimize the impact, including possibly delaying the launching of the first elements of the project by several months, officials said today.
Clinton Administration officials told skeptical members of Congress attending a hearing of the House Science Committee that they received solid assurances from Russian officials last week that $100 million would be provided, starting at the end of the month, for work on a service module that is running behind schedule. 
 If it appears that the launching of the service module, initially set for April 1998 and now eight months behind schedule, will be further delayed, the United States will decide in March on pursuing one of two contingency options for interim modules, Dr. John H. Gibbons, director of the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy, told the hearing.
Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin of Russia promised Vice President Al Gore at meetings in Washington last week that money to continue work on the Russian module would be provided by the cash-strapped Russian Government by the end of February, Dr. Gibbons said.
"We will be looking very closely at whether the Russian space agency receives the promised funding by the end of the month," he added.
"If it does, we will adjust our contingency plans accordingly," Dr. Gibbons said. "If it does not, we expect to be in a position to decide on the two options."
The Russian-made service module, the third component of the space station to be lifted into orbit, is designed to maneuver and control the multipart station as it is being built and to provide temporary crew quarters during the building phase.
One option for an interim control module is adapting a military satellite maneuvering unit developed by the Naval Research Laboratory to control the station. The other option, officials said, would be to contract with a Russian group, the Khrunichev Design Bureau, to build a version of its FGB space module to serve as a maneuvering unit.
The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has paid Khrunichev more than $200 million to make an FGB to serve as the first station element to be launched, and NASA said the component is on schedule and within its budget. Agency officials said they believed an FGB-2 unit could be built for substantially less money to serve as an interim control unit until the service module is ready.
Representative F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., the Wisconsin Republican who is chairman of the Science Committee, said Russia's inability to finance its part of the space station adequately was threatening the entire project. The Russians have given repeated assurances in the past that they would make up deficits for the station, he said, but have not kept their promises.
Mr. Sensenbrenner and several members of the committee plan to go to Russia next week on a fact-finding mission concerning the space station and other issues.
"I support building the international space station, with or without the Russians," Mr. Sensenbrenner said. "I would prefer to have the Russians in as a full partner, but we must ask whether we can wait any longer for them to decide whether to fund their part of the program."
Daniel S. Goldin, the Administrator of NASA, said he had also been frustrated by past assurances from Russian officials that the lack of funds would be resolved. Last week, he said, the Russians made very specific commitments about what amounts of money would be paid on certain dates, and the United States made arrangements to monitor the flow of money to contractors to insure that they were paid and work on the service module restarted.
"While I remain cautiously optimistic that, this time, the commitment will result in funding," Mr. Goldin said, "we will take action based only on observed performance, not on mere statements of intent."
In addition to looking at interim modules to control the space station, Mr. Goldin said, NASA is also considering other options to keep construction close to its original schedule and cost. One option, he said, is the possibility of delaying launching of the first elements of the space station, now scheduled for this fall.
The current schedule calls for beginning construction of the orbital laboratory in November, with a Russian rocket launching the FGB module in November and an American shuttle flying the first American component, a docking module, in December. If the Russian service module slips further, Mr. Goldin said, station officials might consider delaying the flights of the first elements until the spring of 1988.
A delay of these launchings would require storing and maintaining the completed segments, which adds cost to the project, and rearranging a tight schedule of space shuttle launchings for 1998 and beyond, he said. But it would still be possible to complete construction of the station, now scheduled for the year 2002, on time, and not disrupt space science planned in the interim, he said.
"We will not prematurely launch, even if we are ready," Mr. Goldin said after the hearing. "We have many options to consider."
Mr. Goldin reminded lawmakers at the hearing that Russia attaches great pride to its space program, even in hard economic times, and gave up plans to build a follow-up to its 10-year-old Mir space station to take part in the international project. There are indications that Russia would resist suggestions to downgrade its role in the project from that of a full partner to one of merely being a contractor providing parts for other nations who can afford to pay for them, he said.

HEADLINE: Clinton Clears U.S. Media To Set Up Cuba Bureaus

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration announced today that it would allow American news organizations to open bureaus in Cuba for the first time in nearly 30 years, hoping that the presence of a foreign corps of journalists will increase diplomatic and political pressure on the Communist Government of Fidel Castro.
The White House signaled the change in policy as the Treasury Department granted special licenses to 10 organizations to open what are essentially commercial enterprises in Cuba, despite the economic embargo that prohibits Americans from spending money on the island. 
 The announcement did not clear the way for a new flood of news reports on conditions in Cuba after 38 years of Communist rule. Although 10 news organizations have applied to the United States for permission, Cuba has so far agreed to allow only one -- Cable News Network -- to open an office and begin reporting.
The decision nonetheless represented a significant break in the longstanding American effort to isolate Mr. Castro and his Communist Government. The Administration, supported by prominent Republicans on Capitol Hill, argued that the benefits of exposing Cuba to more regular scrutiny by American journalists outweighed the drawbacks of letting Mr. Castro's Government receive the hard cash that news organizations would spend to rent offices or buy supplies.
The President's spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, said: "The Administration believes that news gathering and reporting by U.S. news organizations will keep international attention focused on the situation in Cuba and on the realities of economic and political conditions there and will bring greater public exposure to those who are advocating a democratic change in Cuba."
Assuming Mr. Castro keeps a promise he made about CNN last November, the television network would become the first American news organization formally granted permission to open a permanent bureau in Cuba since 1969, when Havana expelled the last correspondent from The Associated Press. The United States retaliated by barring Cuban news organizations from having bureaus in the United States.
Today's decision did not lift that restriction, which Administration officials said would remain in place until Cuba opened the door to "a representative sampling" of American news organizations, including Radio and TV Marti, the Federally financed anti-Castro network.
Eason Jordan, CNN's executive vice president for international news, applauded the Administration's decision and said the network planned to open a full-time bureau in Havana in March.
Until now, journalists have been allowed to enter Cuba temporarily with special visas granted by the United States on a case-by-case basis. The new licenses would allow their organizations to station them there permanently, but only if the organizations confine their spending to activities directly related to gathering news and insist on having "unconditioned and unrestricted" work conditions in Cuba. The licenses are valid for only a year, but Mr. McCurry said he did not foresee problems in renewing them.
The Treasury Department's Office of Foreign Assets Control, which enforces the embargo, granted licenses to every organization that had formally requested one. In addition to CNN, they are ABC News, CBS News, The Miami Herald, The Associated Press, Dow Jones & Company, The Chicago Tribune, The Sun Sentinel of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., Univision and Johns Hopkins University's School of Advanced International Studies, which publishes a newsletter called Cuba Info.
The New York Times has discussed opening a permanent bureau in Havana with the authorities in Cuba in recent years, but has not formally requested a license to do so from Washington, a spokeswoman said today. "Now that we know that approvals are being issued, we will be applying," she said.
The decision has won support from Republicans otherwise staunchly opposed to any easing of pressure on Mr. Castro. In a letter to Mr. Clinton last week, Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, the Republican chairman of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, strongly supported the opening of news bureaus.
"If Castro wants to open Cuba to the roving eye of the American news media, we should by all means give him the rope with which to hang himself," Mr. Helms wrote.
In lifting the prohibition on bureaus, the Administration had to weigh objections from news organizations other than CNN that the United States was essentially allowing Cuba to choose who reported on it. Acknowledging that Cuba would probably exclude some, officials said the Administration decided that letting some in would inevitably increase pressure on Mr. Castro to open the door to more.

HEADLINE: Tyson Set to Join Ameritech Board

 BODY:
The Ameritech Corporation plans to announce today that it expects its newest board member to be Laura D'Andrea Tyson, a former top White House economic adviser.
Ms. Tyson stepped down in December as head of the National Economic Policy Council and was previously chairwoman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers. 
 She will seek election to the board of Ameritech, a regional telephone operating company based in Chicago, at the company's annual meeting on April 16.
Ms. Tyson holds an endowed chair in economics at the Haas School of Business at the University of California at Berkeley. Ameritech's offer is the first she has accepted, although recruiters predicted that as a high-profile woman she would be widely courted.
Already on the board is Lynn M. Martin, a former Republican Congresswoman and the Labor Secretary under President George Bush.

HEADLINE: A Rental Tower Is Planned for West Side

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
A block of Broadway in the 50's that has frustrated developers for more than 30 years with failed plans for an office building, a Planet Hollywood restaurant and a luxury hotel would become a 45-story rental apartment tower under a plan by Related Companies.
Related, which won out in fierce bidding for the site amid an increasingly hot rental market in Manhattan, would build the tower on the site between 55th and 56th Streets on the west side of Broadway. The new building would sit above a five-story retail complex that would include a movie theater, a theme restaurant and large stores. Related has five other residential projects under way. 
 "I think the retail, entertainment and mixed-use combination will make the site successful," said Jeff Blau, a senior vice president of Related. "That's what enables us to make this economically feasible despite the high land prices."
Related's bid, which was not disclosed, topped those of more than a half-dozen other prospective buyers who have been scrambling from one rare development site to another in Manhattan hoping to cash in on the current boomlet in rental apartments, retailing and hotel rooms.
The Chase Manhattan Bank, which foreclosed on the property last year, put it on the auction block in January. Real estate executives familiar with the transaction say that the Jack Parker Corporation, Ian Bruce Eichner, Rose Associates and Donald Trump all expressed interest in the site but that only Related was willing to pay almost $18 million.
"We got a very strong investor response that clearly reflects growing confidence in Manhattan," said Hugh Balloch, a managing director at Chase Manhattan. "It certainly encouraged us."
Related had already formed a joint venture with the owners of the south end of the blockfront, a group led by Doug Oliver and Jon Hanson. That deal let Related propose a large structure for a site where low-slung buildings now squat amid residential and commercial towers. Mr. Blau said he hoped to come to terms with the owner of a small pizzeria in the middle of the block, although, he said, the tower could still go up around it.
Like other residential developers today, Related included a large commercial component because big retailers are willing to pay high rents to get into lucrative Manhattan neighborhoods, which offsets the construction of more costly residential space.
But with so little housing built in recent years, demand for apartments has driven rents up 38 percent on the West Side since 1993. The rent for the average two-bedroom apartment in a doorman building rose during that time to more than $2,900 from $2,100, according to Clark Halstead, managing director of the Halstead Property Company.
"The rental market is very strong and there's a shortage of apartments," Mr. Halstead said. "Rents have gone up to the point where it's very feasible to develop market-rate rental buildings. So developers who have sites are rushing to put up rentals."
For that reason, Mr. Blau of Related may have far more success than the developers who came before him. The late Seymour Durst, who purchased the land in the early 1960's, considered putting up an office building on the block. After those plans fell through, however, the Dursts entered lengthy negotiations with Planet Hollywood.
At the last moment, the theme restaurant opted to move onto West 57th Street. The Durst family sold the parcel in 1990 for about $30 million to William Zeckendorf, the developer, and the Swig real estate family, who planned to build the latest addition to the Swigs' Fairmont Hotel chain. But those plans went awry with the recession in 1991.
Related's proposed project on Broadway in many ways resembles the complex it is building in Union Square, on a block bounded by 13th Street, Broadway and Fourth Avenue. Union Square South, as it is known, will be a 21-story tower made up of 240 apartments, a Virgin music and entertainment store, a 14-screen theater and a large electronics store, Circuit City.
The company is also finishing up the Strathmore, a 43-story tower at 400 East 84th Street near First Avenue, and is starting work on an 18-story apartment house at 89th Street and Amsterdam Avenue and 400 apartments at Battery Park City.

HEADLINE: We Are Not the World

BYLINE: By Paul Krugman; Paul Krugman, a professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is the author of "Peddling Prosperity" and "Pop Internationalism."

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
It is a truth universally acknowledged that the growing international mobility of goods, capital and technology has completely changed the economic game. Nations, conventional wisdom tells us, no longer have the power to control their own destinies; governments are at the mercy of international markets.
Some celebrate this development, saying that both rich and poor nations benefit. At the same time, a growing number of journalists, union leaders, politicians of both parties and even businessmen deplore it, blaming globalization for instability, unemployment and declining wages. 
 But both sides have it wrong. They take the omnipotence of global markets for granted -- not realizing that reports of the death of national autonomy are greatly exaggerated.
A certain fascination with the march of globalization is understandable. For half a century, world trade has grown faster than world output, and international capital now moves more quickly than ever before. The rapidly expanding exports of newly industrializing economies have put pressure on less-skilled workers in advanced countries even as they offer unprecedented opportunities to tens of millions in the third world. (The wages of those workers are shockingly low but nonetheless represent a vast improvement on their previous, less visible rural poverty.)
But while global economic integration is increasing, its growth has been far outpaced by that of "global economy" rhetoric. Two recent books by economic journalists, William Greider's "One World, Ready or Not" and Robert Kuttner's "Everything for Sale," are jeremiads about the evils of unfettered economic globalism. Politicians like Patrick J. Buchanan and Ross Perot have made careers out of assailing open markets. Even the financier George Soros warns, in the current issue of The Atlantic Monthly, that global capitalism is now a greater threat than totalitarianism to "open society."
Such oratory has become so pervasive that many observers seem determined to blame global markets for a host of economic and social ills in their countries, even when the facts point unmistakably to mainly domestic -- and usually political -- causes.
For example, critics of globalization often cite France, whose Government has taken no serious action to reduce its double-digit unemployment rate, as the perfect example of how states have become powerless in the face of impersonal world markets. France cannot act, according to a recent New York Times article, because of the demands of "European economic integration -- itself partly a response to the competitive demands of the global marketplace."
French policy is indeed paralyzed -- not, however, by impersonal market forces but by the determination of its prestige-conscious politicians not to let the franc decline against the German mark. Britain, which has been willing to let the pound sink relative to the mark, has steadily reduced its unemployment rate with no visible adverse consequences.
The cause of France's paralysis, in other words, is political rather than economic. True, the country must meet the conditions laid down by the Maastricht treaty of 1991, which is supposed to lead to a unified European currency. But creating this currency is more a political than an economic project. Its main purpose is to serve as a symbol of European unity, and many economists think that the costs of the common currency will exceed its benefits. It would actually be more accurate to say that French politics has battered markets rather than the other way around.
And what about the United States, where the continuing power of the Government -- or at any rate that of the Federal Reserve -- to push the economy around can hardly be questioned? Critics of the global economy invariably reply that America may be creating lots of jobs but that they are tenuous because of the prevalence of downsizing, which is a reaction to international competition (a line of reasoning that also provides a good excuse for companies undertaking layoffs).
Come again? Newsweek ran a story last year, titled "The Hit Men," about executives responsible for massive layoffs. The chief executives of AT&T, Nynex, Sears, Philip Morris and Delta Air Lines were high on the list. Of course, international competition plays a role in some downsizings, but as Newsweek's list makes clear, it is hardly the most important cause of the phenomenon. To my knowledge there are no Japanese keiretsu competing to carry my long-distance calls or South Korean conglomerates offering me local service. Nor have many Americans started buying their home appliances at Mexican stores or smoking French cigarettes. I cannot fly Cathay Pacific from Boston to New York.
What explains this propensity to overstate the importance of global markets? In part, it sounds sophisticated. Pontificating about globalization is an easy way to get attention at events like the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, and Renaissance Weekends in Hilton Head, S.C.
But there is also a deeper cause -- an odd sort of tacit agreement between the left and the right to pretend that exotic global forces are at work even when the real action is prosaically domestic.
Many on the left dislike the global marketplace because it epitomizes what they dislike about markets in general: the fact that nobody is in charge. The truth is that the invisible hand rules most domestic markets, too, a reality that most Americans seem to accept as a fact of life. But those who would like to see us revert to a more managed society in all ways hope that popular unease over the economic influence of people who live in far-off places and have funny-sounding names can be used as the thin end of an ideological wedge.
Meanwhile, many on the right use the rhetoric of globalization to argue that business can no longer be expected to meet any social obligations. For example, it has become standard for opponents of environmental regulations to raise the banner of "competitiveness" and to warn that anything that raises costs for American businesses will price our goods out of world markets.
But even if the global economy matters less than the sweeping assertions would have us believe, does this "globaloney," as the cognoscenti call it, do any real harm? Yes, in part because the public, misguided into believing that international trade is the source of all our problems, might turn protectionist -- undermining the real good that globalization has done for most people here and abroad.
But the overheated oratory poses a more subtle risk. It encourages fatalism, a sense that we cannot come to grips with our problems because they are bigger than we are. Such fatalism is already well advanced in Western Europe, where the public speaks vaguely of the "economic horror" inflicted by world markets instead of turning a critical eye on the domestic leaders whose policies have failed.
None of the important constraints on American economic and social policy come from abroad. We have the resources to take far better care of our poor and unlucky than we do; if our policies have become increasingly mean-spirited, that is a political choice, not something imposed on us by anonymous forces. We cannot evade responsibility for our actions by claiming that global markets made us do it.

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
Hopeful Cities Explore Bidding for Games

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12

 BODY:
In the roomful of Billy Payne wannabes, men and women from eight American cities gathered today to learn how to become the host of the 2008 or 2012 Summer Olympics. It is a numbing process, one that is more precise, difficult, restrictive and professional than when Payne led an audacious campaign in the late 1980's to bring the 1996 Summer Games to Atlanta, beating Athens, the sentimental favorite.
"The prize here is so big, and the financial rewards of hosting the Olympics have gotten so much bigger," said Daniel Doctoroff, president of New York City 2008, which is conducting a 10-month study of a potential Olympic bid. "It's very attractive." He said his group's plan envisioned the construction of an Olympic stadium. 
 Doctoroff met last week in Colorado Springs with Dick Schultz, executive director of the United States Olympic Committee. "We were encouraged," he said.
Representatives of potential bidding groups from New York, Boston, Chicago, Cincinnati, Baltimore, Washington, Seattle and Houston attended the U.S.O.C. seminar. All of the groups are in the early stages of their quest. They cannot even begin the race for approval by the U.S.O.C., and then, by the International Olympic Committee, until after the I.O.C. selects the site of the 2004 Summer Olympics in September.
"But we're a year and a half behind other countries looking to bid for 2008," Schultz said. Still, the I.O.C. won't pick a host city for the 2008 Games until the fall of 2001.
For now, the process is entirely directed by the U.S.O.C., which administers the I.O.C.'s criteria. The heart of that criteria is a questionnaire covering more than 500 subjects, with the emphasis on answering all queries in the affirmative. "If you have a flaw," said Roger Jackson, a Canadian Olympic official, "the I.O.C. isn't looking to accept your bid."
One of the crucial challenges for any bidder seeking Payne-like glory will be the I.O.C.'s new requirement that the budgets for all host cities be guaranteed by their local and federal governments. It is unclear whether the I.O.C. expects direct public investment, unless an organizing committee cannot meet its financial commitments.
"The I.O.C. didn't like the risks" that came with the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games' raising $1.8 billion privately without a governmental guarantee, or an indemnification against any losses by the group, said Charlie Battle, the Atlanta committee's former executive vice president.
Several bid cities said they were awaiting word from various government officials.
"It would be helpful if the Federal Government would come forth and say what they would guarantee," said Jerry Pearlman, of Chicago 2008 Bid Review. "Our Governor and Mayor say we have their support, but they also said, 'No new taxes.' But if we can't live within the rules of the I.O.C. and the U.S.O.C., we won't bid."
John Moag, of the Baltimore Committee for the Olympics, and president of the Maryland Stadium Authority, said politicians who may be out of office or dead by 2008 or 2012 must be persuaded of the civic and economic glory of guaranteeing Olympic finances. "If it's 2012, they're going to have to wait 15 years," he said.
On Sunday, the U.S.O.C. board of directors is expected to pass a resolution that will essentially begin the 2008 bidding process.
"They tried to scare people off today," Moag said. "They're not doing their job if they don't cut this list in half."

HEADLINE: Economist's Survey Supports Theory That Inflation Is Overstated

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
In an effort to bolster his case that the Consumer Price Index overstates inflation, Michael J. Boskin, the head of a panel that examined the issue last year, is circulating the results of a survey of fellow economists that backed his conclusions.
The survey is the first formal effort to document whether there is a consensus among economists in support of the the Boskin Commission's estimate that the index overstates actual inflation by 1.1 percentage points each year. 
 The survey, which agreed with this number, is a step in the effort to sway the political debate over whether the Government should cut back cost-of-living increases for Social Security and other Federal benefits, saving the Government tens of billions of dollars a year.
The Senate Finance Committee appointed the commission, which submitted its report in December. But the Clinton Administration, and some members of Congress, have pressured the commission to line up support among other economists for its finding, before considering legislation that would end the indexing of Social Security benefits to the Consumer Price Index.
Mr. Boskin, a Stanford economist who was President George Bush's chief economic adviser, said, "It was an attempt by me to respond more carefully to a question that keeps coming up, that I keep getting asked in testimony."
Mr. Boskin sent the results of his survey to Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and members of Congress, among others. A spokesman for Mr. Rubin said the fax from Mr. Boskin arrived on Tuesday night, and that Mr. Rubin had not yet seen it. Mr. Rubin said in December that a broad-based agreement among experts would be needed to justify making an adjustment in Social Security benefits that better reflected actual inflation.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, put the survey's results into the Congressional record. An aide to the Senator said, "We all agree that we need a concensus among experts, and this is part of the consensus that is building up." Senator Moynihan, the ranking minority member of the Senate Finance Committee, has strongly endorsed the commission's report.
Mr. Boskins sent a questionnaire to 24 people he described as experts in the field. Eighteen responded, and their findings averaged 1.2 percentage point. The median finding was 1.1 percentage point, matching exactly the commission's. But the survey quickly drew criticism. Mr. Boskin did not release the names of those to whom he sent the survey, but the 24 included the four other commission members, at least two of whom declined to respond.
"That was an oversight to send a poll intended for other professional economists to members of the commission," said Robert Gordon of Northwestern University, one of the commission members who declined to answer the questionnaire.
In addition, at least three economists recognized as experts in the field but critical of the Boskin Commission's report, said they had not been sent the questionnaire.
One was Jack Triplett, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, who has done research on product quality. The commission held that more than half of the upward bias in the Consumer Price Index was because of the failure to subtract from price increases the value of quality improvements. "I would not have responded if I had been asked," Mr. Triplett said. "I don't think we know enough to come up with a number."
Mr. Boskin's survey asked for each person's "best judgment on the likely bias in using the change in the C.P.I. as a measure of the change in the cost of living."

HEADLINE: U.S. to Increase Funds for Anti-Milosevic Media and Unions

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12

 BODY:
The United States is significantly expanding its support of newspapers, radio stations and trade unions opposed to President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia, senior American officials said today.
While the money to be distributed in 1997 is small -- about $2 million -- it is five times the $400,000 provided last year. The officials said the increase was a direct result of the pro-democracy demonstrations in Belgrade and other cities against the authoritarian rule of Mr. Milosevic. 
 The aid is another indication of a shift in policy away from Mr. Milosevic, who was a crucial supporter of the Dayton peace accords of December 1995, which halted the war in Bosnia. American officials now say Mr. Milosevic is no longer critical to stability in Bosnia.
"His days are numbered," one official said. "Now it's a matter of when his era ends, not if, and how it does. Even if he survives, he won't be able to exercise the same unbridled rule. The rules have changed."
Some of the money can be delivered immediately through the American Embassy in Belgrade in small grants valued at $5,000 to $10,000, the officials said. The support is to be given not in cash but in goods, like computers or newspaper ink, and technical assistance.
Most of the aid, which has already been appropriated, is to be funneled through American groups like the National Endowment for Democracy, the National Democratic Institute and the International Foundation for Electoral Systems. These foundations can usually provide support faster than the Agency for International Development.
The groups, officials said, will organize programs to train journalists, union leaders and political parties in the ways of democracy. In other countries this has included teaching political parties how to use polling data and advertising, and to draw up party platforms.
While praising the program, some representatives of the groups criticized the Administration for being so late. In 1996, they point out, the Government aid of $400,000 was dwarfed by funds provided by the private Open Society Institute, led by the financier George Soros, and by European countries.
Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, has been prominent in urging more support for independent news media in Serbia.
The effort was hampered last year by American sanctions against Serbia and by the general atmosphere of suppression, American officials say. Efforts by the Embassy to find worthy recipients independent of the Government were made difficult by the "reticence" of Serbian organizations to seek or accept aid from Americans, a senior official said.
But after the demonstrators, who demanded the reinstatement of opposition victories in local elections in November, began to chip away at Mr. Milosevic's rule, Serbian organizations were more willing to come forward.
And American credibility with the opposition was helped by the decision in December to incorporate reports from the independent radio station B92 into transmissions of Radio Free Europe when Mr. Milosevic tried to shut it down.
"People have shed their fears about operating in public," one senior official said. "People are more approachable, and more willing to take risks in approaching American officials."
A successful program will still require the tolerance of the Serbian Government, which could withhold visas for American aid workers and experts working for the American groups, or prevent Serbs from traveling to the United States for training and study.
"If they do that, we have big problems," the official said. "But we're plunging ahead in expectation of approval of the Serbian Government to work in Belgrade."

HEADLINE: It's Not Real Big, but Texas Takes to It

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Feb. 12

 BODY:
New York has its official state muffin (apple), Arizona its official neckwear (bolo tie), and Massachusetts its official dog (Boston terrier).
Kansans are proud to call the ornate box turtle their official reptile, while Ohioans who drink tomato juice are downing the state beverage. 
 Now Texas is on the verge of getting an official state molecule: the buckyball.
The buckyball, a soccer-ball-shaped compound of 60 carbon atoms also known as the Buckminsterfullerene, is so named because its contour resembles those of R. Buckminster Fuller's geodesic domes. It was discovered by two Rice University professors, and, just months after they earned a Nobel Prize in Chemistry for that discovery, a State Representative from Houston is unveiling a proposal to designate the buckyball the molecule of Texas.
The legislator, Scott Hochberg, an alumnus of Rice, says he has broad support for the measure and expects it to sail through the Legislature.
It probably will, although a group of University of Texas alumni point out that the Texaphyrin, an engineered molecule invented by chemists at -- guess where -- the University of Texas, might make a worthy competitor, for its use in cancer treatment. "The buckyball is a wonderful molecule," said one of the inventors, Prof. Jonathan Sessler, "but our molecule is going to be better."
"I don't think so," Representative Hochberg said. "Nobody won the Nobel for discovering that," at least not yet.
Official designations can make for remarkably contentious battles.
In New York, it took a highly persistent group of fourth graders from Syracuse to prevail upon Mario M. Cuomo, then the Governor, to sign the apple-muffin bill in 1987.
New Jersey remains without an official anthem after years of legislative battles. "The Jersey Bounce," a 1940's swing hit, never made it. Bruce Springsteen's classic "Born to Run" was a strong contender a few years back, but a group of legislators offended by some of the lyrics ("Just wrap your legs 'round these velvet rims and strap your hands across my engines") blocked it.
And perhaps most famously, amid a debate that stretched back to the 19th century, the United States went without a national flower until the Reagan Administration. Lawmakers simply found the competition -- among the rose, the marigold, the corn tassel, the mountain laurel, the columbine, the dandelion and a host of other candidates -- too hot an issue to touch. Congress finally put an end to the matter in 1986, settling on the rose as the official "national floral emblem."
Mr. Hochberg said he believed that Texas would be the first state with an official molecule. (Indeed, none are listed in "Facts About the States," an exhaustive compendium of official designations.)
The buckyball, discovered in 1985 by the Rice chemists Dr. Richard E. Smalley and Dr. Robert F. Curl Jr., has a range of important possible applications, including the conducting of electricity and the delivery of medicines to precise locations within the body.
"Yes, it is a fun thing to do," Mr. Hochberg said of the designation, "but it also recognizes where the state is going in terms of economic development and our high-tech future."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Continued Rise In the Dollar May Compel Officials to Act

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and his allies in the Group of Seven industrial nations are trying to rein in the dollar, which has jumped 14 percent against the German mark and 16 percent against the Japanese yen in the last year.
But in the statement they issued in Berlin backing this goal, they included one sentence that may have unintentionally given currency traders a reason to push the dollar even higher -- particularly against the German mark and other European currencies. 
 The key words are these: "We reaffirmed our views that exchange rates should reflect economic fundamentals."
By yesterday, the fourth trading day since Mr. Rubin switched from strong dollar to strong enough, traders were looking at those 11 words, along with new indications of a weakening in the economic fundamentals that can support currencies -- higher interest rates and attractive economic growth.
"This highlights the thought that the dollar should be able to trade higher" against European currencies, said Audrey McNiff, vice president in foreign exchange sales at Goldman, Sachs & Company.
And yesterday the dollar did trade higher, moving well above where it was on Friday against the German mark and higher against the Japanese yen.
"The one thing that we took away from that statement was that the central banks are serious and that they think that fundamentals should drive the dollar," Ms. McNiff said. And, she added, "You made a lot of money last year by listening to the central banks."
She said that recent gains in unemployment in Germany and Switzerland and pessimistic reports from the business communities in both countries were being taken as signs "of a worsening of the economic situation in Europe." That means interest rates are more likely to fall or remain stable and growth could be sluggish, all factors that favor the dollar.
What this means for Secretary Rubin and the Clinton Administration is that they, together with their allies, could be forced sooner than they might like to follow their words with actions.
That effort could begin with clearer verbal jawboning from Mr. Rubin and other finance ministers and follow with intervention by the United States and other countries that would sell dollars to lower the value. But those actions are likely to have no more than a temporary effect, analysts say, if the economic fundamentals that move currencies -- interest rates, economic growth and global capital flows -- do not cease to favor the dollar, as they do now.
"As long as investors assume the outlook is for solid U.S. growth and lower inflation, disappointment about the outlook on European growth and pessimism about Japan's economy and policy outlook, there is no reason to see a turn in the dollar's climb," said John Lipsky, the chief economist at the Chase Manhattan Bank.
"The intriguing question is when the G-7 ministers think their credibility is at stake and they have to do something," he said.
"The notion that there might be some new policy action behind the new policy is highly inconceivable," Mr. Lipsky said, adding that he would not expect the Federal Reserve to undermine the dollar by lowering its target for short-term interest rates.
In trading yesterday, the dollar jumped as high as 1.6940 marks to the dollar, its highest level in almost three years, after a report suggested that the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, would not mind the dollar moving into the 1.70 range.
The dollar lost much of its gain after a spokesman for the Bundesbank denied the report. But the currency ended higher on the day, at 1.6846 marks, up from 1.6766 Tuesday and 2 percent higher than last Thursday, the day before Mr. Rubin made his policy switch. Against the yen, the dollar was at 124.17 in late New York trading, up from 123.15 Tuesday and half a percent higher than last Thursday.
Ms. McNiff said that the short-term outlook against the yen should be more stable than against the mark, unless there is new information showing that the Japanese economy is in worse shape or that policy initiatives are floundering. "Traders will give the benefit of the doubt in the short term," she said, because the current Japanese negatives versus the dollar -- a weak economy, lower interest rates and uncertain government policies -- all are well known.
"The next step we go," she said referring to the mark and the yen and the Group of Seven statement, "has to be on new fundamentals.
Analysts and traders noted that the statement issued by the Group of Seven, which includes Japan, Germany, France, Italy, Britain and Canada, was not very strong. Mr. Lipsky called it "indistinct." Carl B. Weinberg, the chief economist at High Frequency Economics, said all it had was "six verbs."
The key sentences about their concern about the dollar were these: "We believe that major misalignments in exchange markets noted in our April 1995 communique have been corrected." And, "We agreed to monitor developments in exchange markets and cooperate as appropriate."
In the April 25, 1995, statement, when the Group of Seven met as the dollar was falling to its lowest levels since World War II, their statement was more forceful. They said that the dollar had fallen "beyond the levels justified by underlying economic conditions in the major countries." And the Group of Seven "agreed that orderly reversal of those movements is desirable."
Nicholas P. Sargen, J. P. Morgan's market strategist for private clients, thinks the Group of Seven "is worried about the foreign exchange market overshooting" and is telling traders, "Let's not get the dollar too strong."
But he adds "that is their dilemma, because the fundamentals support a stronger dollar."

HEADLINE: Beach Clubs and Ski Slopes Would Lose Money, Too

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
As the strike deadline fixed by American Airlines' pilots draws nearer, travel agents have been besieged by worried clients at destinations where American dominates the air-travel market.
Officials at several popular vacation spots heavily served by American -- warm-weather areas like the Caribbean and cold-weather destinations like Colorado -- said the economies in their regions could be hit hard by a strike. 
 "Strikes like this always have a wide ripple effect," said Gordon Lambourne, a spokesman for Marriott Lodging, a unit of Marriott International, which has hotels in St. Thomas and Aruba, as well as in Florida and other resort destinations. "They don't just affect travelers; they affect hotels, rental-car companies, cruise ships, desinations, theme parks, restaurants -- you name it."
In Miami, American's most recently established hub, there were predictions that a strike at the AMR Corporation unit would result in $258 million in lost revenue, assuming that it lasted a month, because 234,000 fewer visitors would come to the city. Officials also forecast $33 million in lost pay from aviation-related jobs and $16 million in lost tax money. According to Merrett Stierheim, president of the Miami Convention and Visitors Bureau, American provides 50.3 percent of airline seats to Miami.
Jean Holder, secretary general of the Caribbean Tourism Organization, said a strike by American, which provides 70 percent of the airline seats to the region, "would be a disaster worse than any hurricane."
Colorado, the nation's biggest destination for skiers, is also likely to be hurt by a strike. "It couldn't have come at a worse time because this is our busiest weekend," said Lynn Bronikowski, a spokeswoman for Colorado Ski Country U.S.A., a trade group. The state gets 40 percent of its ski business between Washington's Birthday weekend and the end of March, she said, and American brings 2,000 skiers a day into four mountain airports.
"A lot of those people belong to groups," Ms. Bronikowski said, "and it's harder for groups to make alternate plans. So a strike won't just affect our industry; it could ruin a lot of vacations."
Though the economic effect of a strike would be great for vacation destinations, travelers and the other airlines would obviously feel its impact, as well -- particularly because this month has been one of the busiest Februaries in recent years for the airlines.
Adding to the crush of travelers is the popularity of Valentine's cruises, many of which depart from ports in Florida or Puerto Rico, this weekend, when the strike is to begin if no agreement is reached between the pilots and the airline. The cruise industry has been frantically rebooking thousands of passengers from American onto other airlines.
In anticipation of a strike, American has stopped offering special fares to computer users on the Internet.
Some of American's competitors have been taking steps to reduce overbooking in preparation. Delta Air Lines, for example, has extended through Feb. 21 the restrictions it imposed on some tickets last week. Initially imposed for just the Washington's Birthday holiday weekend, the tickets are nonrefundable and require that customers pay for them within 24 hours of making reservations.
Even higher ticket prices do not seem to be an impediment to people who are determined to get away despite the strike threat. "A lot of our members have booked the higher-priced tickets" on other airlines, said Steve Loucks, a spokesman for the American Society of Travel Agents, "because they would rather pay more to be sure of getting to their destination."
Partly for that reason, "air fares are going to shoot up like crazy, especially for leisure travelers, because there aren't going to be any cheap seats," said Ronald J. Nordheimer, president of the Delaware Travel Agency in Wilmington.
Leisure travelers with reservations on other carriers will not lose their seats despite the crush of fliers displaced by a strike, the airlines say.
But while the carriers will attempt to accommodate the extra traffic, travelers with several types of tickets on American are likely to encounter problems, they say. These include tickets obtained with American frequent-flier miles, discount tickets on American that were purchased from consolidators or tickets given to passengers bumped from earlier flights.

Take along reservations numbers of all other airlines that fly to of from your destination.
 
Show up at the airport at least two hours before flight time, carry a photo I.D., and be sure the ticket is in your name.

IF AMERICAN SHUTS DOWN
 
Ask your travel agent if the travel agency has a toll-free number to phone for strike updates.
 
Be prepared to fly at off-peak hours and via circuitous routes.
 
Travel as light as possible, rather than risk having to lug heavy suitcases long distances in the event gates are changed -- a definite possibility as carriers struggle to cope with the confusion and crowds that often accompany a strike.
 
Do not expect to fly on a an American frequent flier ticket, a discount ticket purchased from a consolidator or a ticket given for being bumped from a flight or for voluntarily giving up one's seat. Remember, paying passengers have priority American's reservations agents and employees at airport counters will at airport ticket counters for at least the first days of the strike to help passengers make other arrangements.
