HEADLINE: Dispute at American Airlines Draws Clinton Plea

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12

 BODY:
American Airlines canceled most of its Friday night overseas flights today in the face of a looming strike deadline, as President Clinton urged the nation's second-largest carrier and its pilots' union to use mediation to resolve a dispute that he said "has huge implications for our country."
With a strike deadline set for 12:01 A.M. on Saturday and widespread disruptions in travel plans already apparent, pressure intensified on the parties. Mr. Clinton said he was following the matter "very closely" and ordered his Administration to study the potential economic disruptions of a strike -- a first step toward any Presidential intervention. 
 But White House aides insisted that Mr. Clinton was loath to intercede in the standoff, preferring to keep pressure on the airline and union to avert a strike that would throw the nation's air travel system into turmoil at the height of the winter tourist season.
"The time has not expired and I want to encourage the parties to make maximum use of the mediation board process," Mr. Clinton said today, in his first public comments on the matter, at an unrelated White House ceremony on air safety. "That's what ought to be done today and that's all I have to say about it."
Airline and union negotiators continued to meet throughout the day here, after the pilots rejected management's latest pay offer. An American spokesman said that the airline had canceled its overseas flights for Friday night, except for flights to London, to assure that its planes would not be stranded abroad if the pilots walk out.
A strike would cancel 2,200 flights by American on Saturday, affecting as many as 220,000 passengers.
Ken Hipp, chairman of the National Mediation Board, which is conducting the talks, said that the process was "going slowly and with increasing difficulty," and that even the discussion of possible Presidential involvement "makes it much more difficult to get an agreement at the table."
Under the Railway Labor Act, Mr. Clinton could intervene to name a three-member Presidential emergency panel to recommend a nonbinding resolution of the dispute, if the mediation board found that the strike threatened a region's central transportation system and recommended intervention. Such a panel would have 30 days to devise recommendations and the parties would have another 30 days to consider them, with no work stoppage in the meantime.
Such boards are relatively common in rail strikes, but the White House said today that none had been convened in an airline strike since a machinists' strike against five carriers disrupted service for 40 days in 1966. President George Bush twice declined to appoint such a board during a machinists' strike against Eastern Airlines in 1989.
In recent years, a far more common practice has been jawboning and arm-twisting, such as Mr. Clinton informal intervention after a five-day flight attendants' strike against American on the eve of Thanksgiving in 1993, in which he persuaded the parties to submit to binding arbitration.
But Mr. Clinton's informal efforts to break a logjam in the Major League Baseball strike in 1995 failed, and White House aides said that there was little incentive to get involved in the current dispute unless absolutely necessary.
"There's no gain in this for us being involved," one senior aide said, "because you have every angry passenger whose flight gets screwed up blaming us. We want them to settle the damn dispute and do it before midnight Friday."
A strike against American would be particularly disruptive because of the major airlines' system of hub services, in which carriers concentrate routes through particular cities. For example, two-thirds of all flights at Dallas and Miami are American flights, while one-third of those at Chicago's O'Hare International are on American.
American Airlines carries roughly 20 percent of the nation's air travelers, or about 220,000 passengers a day. Though February is normally a slow month, the big airlines already expect to fill more than 70 percent of their seats.
Despite the prospect of such a disruption, the shares of the airline's parent company, the AMR Corporation, surged yesterday, rising $3.125, or 3.8 percent, to $82.875. Much of the gain came after the White House issued its statement.
One Administration official estimated the possibility of averting a strike by the American pilots as less than 50-50. And because the pilots earn an average salary of $120,000 a year, with resources to endure a strike, White House aides said that Mr. Clinton would have less leverage in persuading them that a settlement would be in their best interests, as he did with the less well-paid flight attendants in 1993.
A strike would put about 90,000 employees on unpaid furlough, ground the silver-skinned American fleet and roil the plans of Valentine's Day and Washington's Birthday travelers, especially in the Caribbean destinations heavily served by American and American Eagle.
The company and the Allied Pilots Association have been wrangling over the pact for more than two years. Today, the union president, Jim Sovich, said that the company's latest offer, which was made on Tuesday, was worth $43.1 million less over the life of the contract than a tentative agreement that the pilots voted down last month.
In that agreement, the company had offered to raise pilots' pay by 3 percent this Aug. 31 and another 2 percent by Aug. 31, 1999. Pilots would also get options to buy three million shares of stock at $10 less per share than the market price at the time the contract was signed and another 2.75 million shares at the Aug. 31, 1998 price.
The new offer would increase the 1999 raise to 3 percent, but drop the option to buy the 2.75 million shares, which the company said was an effort to meet the union's demands for more cash and less stock.
But a union spokesman, David Bates, told reporters, "We're very disappointed in this offer."
The union's negotiating committee is to take the proposal to its 18-member board, but has called it unacceptable.

American Airlines Cancels Some Overseas Flights
American Airlines canceled most of its Friday night overseas flights as a strike deadline set by the pilots' union loomed.
President Clinton urged the carrier and the pilots to resolve through mediation a dispute that he said "has huge implications for our country." [Page A1.]
 
The dispute seems to be over issues, like wage increases, that might be resolved relatively easily. But questions of respect, trust and the role of pilots in the company have added an emotional charge. News analysis. [A1.] 

ITT Board Rejects Hilton Bid
ITT said that, as expected, its board had rejected the $6.5 billion hostile takeover bid by Hilton Hotels, setting up what is looking like a protracted struggle for control of ITT. [D2.]
 
Stocks Surge to Records
Stock prices soared to record levels, bolstered by renewed strength in technology issues. The Dow Jones industrial average surged 103.52 points to close at 6,961.63. [D8.]
 
Treasury prices ended lower, following poor results at an auction of 10-year notes. [D18.]
 
Pay Raises Outpace Inflation
American workers' wage gains last year were the largest since 1990, keeping them ahead of inflation for only the second time in a decade. Modest though these raises were, many economists expect them to continue. [A1.]
 
Europe Delays Trade Challenge
Seeking to avoid a breach with the United States that could threaten the World Trade Organization's future, Europe postponed its legal challenge to American sanctions against companies doing business in Cuba. [A1.]
 
The White House said that it would let American news organizations open Cuban bureaus for the first time in decades. [A11.]
 
Survey Says Inflation Overstated
In an attempt to bolster his case that the Consumer Price Index overstates inflation, Michael J. Boskin, the head of a panel that examined the issue last year, is circulating the results of a survey of fellow economists that backed his conclusions. [A20.]
 
The New Look Of Campbell Soup
Campbell Soup is marking the 100th anniversary of its condensed soup in cans with ads pushing soup sold in glass jars. Advertising. [D19.].
 
GTE ended a review on its advertising account by dismissing the incumbent agency and hiring Ogilvy & Mather, which works for a competitor of GTE's, Nynex. [D19.]
 
Schwab Might Get Goldman Funds
Goldman, Sachs is negotiating to sell its mutual funds through Charles Schwab, the discount broker. [D8.]
 
Dangers Seen in Car Phones
Talking on a cellular telephone while driving poses as great a risk of an accident as driving while slightly drunk does, Canadian researchers have concluded. [A30.]
 
Russian Businessman Sues Forbes
One of Russia's richest businessmen and stormiest politicians filed a libel suit against Forbes magazine, saying it had defamed him by linking him to shady business deals and the murder of a journalist. [A4.]
 
Trial Advancing Despite Questions
The trial of three members of a Venezuelan family accused of fraud in the collapse of their financial empire is expected to go to a Manhattan jury tomorrow. The case is drawing attention because neither the family nor its banks were ever in New York. [B1.]
 
Nynex Ordered to Pay Rebates
Regulators ordered Nynex to pay $109.6 million to its customers in New York State for what they called shoddy service and improper business practices. [B1.]

HEADLINE: Question in New York Trial: How Long Is Arm of the Law?

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON 

 BODY:
For three months, a 13th-floor courtroom on Centre Street in Manhattan has been the scene of an emotional trial of three members of one family that has received far more attention in Venezuela than it has in New York.
The family is that of Orlando Castro Llanes, 71, an influential financier in Venezuela until a banking crisis there in 1994 led to a run on that country's financial institutions, the collapse of his empire and losses of more than $15 million to depositors in banks he controlled. 
 The Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, has charged Mr. Castro, his 47-year-old son, Orlando Castro Castro, and his 29-year-old grandson, Jorge Castro Barredo, with scheming to defraud Venezuelans of millions of dollars. The case is expected to go to the Manhattan jury tomorrow.
In Venezuela, a soap-opera aspect of the case has included hints of deep Venezuelan feuds and dark suggestions from the Castros that Mr. Morgenthau is carrying out a vendetta for unspecified powerful Venezuelans. But among lawyers in New York, the case is drawing attention for a less sensational reason: the Castros never did business in New York.
Some lawyers are criticizing Mr. Morgenthau for what they say is a bid for global influence that is excessive for a local prosecutor. But Mr. Morgenthau and his supporters say the case is nothing more than an adaptation of existing law that represents how prosecutors will have to respond to modern white-collar crime. In an age when computers can move money around the globe in a flash, they say, prosecutors who are inhibited by national borders -- let alone local ones -- risk being outrun by criminals.
Over the objections of the defense, the Manhattan prosecutors convinced Justice Edward J. McLaughlin of State Supreme Court in Manhattan that they had the power to bring the case here because many of the transactions involved checks drawn on banks in New York or electronic transfers of funds that passed through banks in New York.
In his office this week, Mr. Morgenthau argued that because of New York's role as a global banking center, he had a special duty to protect the integrity of the banking system. "If the banking system goes down, the place that's going to be most affected is Manhattan," he said. "If you let people use New York for one kind of crime -- banking crime -- they're going to use it for others."
Ronald K. Noble, who was Undersecretary of the Treasury for Enforcement until last year, sees the Castro case as little more than an application of existing law, which has long proclaimed that a prosecutor can file a case if a wire transfer of funds occurs in his territory. "What Morgenthau is saying is, 'If you want to commit fraud, stay out of the U.S. and, particularly, stay out of New York,' " Mr. Noble said.
Supporters of Mr. Morgenthau say he is a leader in establishing more aggressive policing of global finance, beginning in 1989 with his investigation of the multibillion-dollar international fraud case involving the Bank of Credit and Commerce International. That investigation ultimately led to the closing of the bank and the recovery of more than $1.6 billion for depositors.
But critics say Mr. Morgenthau's office established jurisdiction over B.C.C.I. partly because that bank had a New York office and other New York ties. The Castros had no New York office and their lawyers say none of them were ever in New York before they were arrested in Miami last spring and extradited to face Mr. Morgenthau's charges.
Some critics say Mr. Morgenthau is overreaching as he tries to recapture the attention he received after the B.C.C.I. case. And some financial experts question whether it is good policy for a state prosecutor from a single county to involve himself in foreign banking controversies.
Geoffrey P. Miller, a nationally known banking law expert at New York University Law School, said he thought Mr. Morgenthau was improperly trying to put New York in a position to regulate global financial practices. "I think he has a God complex to think he's the one who has to rescue the financial world," Mr. Miller said.
Mr. Morgenthau has alleged that the Castros stole millions from their depositors to prop up other businesses in Venezuela and misled depositors into believing their money was protected under American banking laws while they were actually losing millions in risky options trading. The prosecutors also say that Jorge Castro Barredo, the nephew of Orlando Castro Castro, used some of the depositors' money to buy such items as jet skis and a yacht.
In the courtroom, the defense lawyers have met such allegations with flat denials and differing explanations of what the complex financial records prove. But they also argue that it is unfair to force businessmen to answer for their conduct in a foreign land. And they have repeatedly appealed to jurors to send Mr. Morgenthau a message.
"If I was a New York taxpayer, I'd be ready to jump out of my skin knowing what went on here," Richard Sharpstein, the lawyer for the senior Mr. Castro said in his closing statement to the jurors on Monday.
Outside of the courtroom, there has been what amounts to a campaign by the defense to portray Mr. Morgenthau as a blunderer who was misled by a former Venezuelan official named Thor Halvorssen. Mr. Halvorssen was an anti-drug czar for the Venezuelan Government with the rank of ambassador from 1989 to 1994, and drew attention in Venezuela last fall when he told a Caracas magazine that the Castro family had arranged to have him beaten and imprisoned and that Orlando Castro Castro had come into his cell and urinated on his face.
As Venezuela's drug czar, Mr. Halvorssen knew Mr. Morgenthau from other investigations. It is also clear that old animosities exist between Mr. Halvorssen and the Castros. People who know them all say the bitterness may trace back to a takeover battle in Venezuela during the 1980's in which the Castros and Mr. Halvorsen were on opposite sides.
The senior Mr. Castro and Mr. Halvorssen have sued each other in Federal Court in Florida, with Mr. Castro contending that Mr. Halvorssen defamed him and Mr Halvorssen saying that Mr. Castro arranged to have him incarcerated and beaten.
Mr. Halvorssen has denied in previous interviews that he is carrying out a vendetta. He was not called to testify or even mentioned in the Manhattan case. He could not be reached, and his lawyers did not respond to repeated phone calls.
But in an interview this week, Mr. Castro's lawyer, Mr. Sharpstein, said the Manhattan criminal charges were based on "ridiculous allegations that began and ended with Thor Halvorssen," who, he said, falsely told Mr. Morgenthau that the Castros were money launderers for drug traffickers.
Mr. Sharpstein said Mr. Morgenthau had been misled by Mr. Halvorssen into filing the charges. "My guess is," Mr. Sharpstein said, "he was taken by the nose and led to believe this was some massive money-laundering scheme."
Mr. Morgenthau has said repeatedly that his office began studying Venezuelan banks because of an interest in pursuing money laundering operations in that country that might affect drug imports into New York. But he has been careful to say that there are no money-laundering allegations against the Castros by his office and he repeated this week that money laundering was not involved in the bank-fraud case.
Asked about Mr. Sharpstein's allegations that he had been misled by Mr. Halvorssen, Mr. Morgenthau denied that his investigation of the Castros had begun with information from Mr. Halvorssen. He said the investigation started when officials of the Federal Reserve Bank in New York expressed concerns about the New York transactions of the Castros' banking operations.
He said high officials of the Venezuelan Government had also asked him to bring charges against the Castros, who moved to Florida when their banks failed.
Mr. Morgenthau acknowledged that he had worked with Mr. Halvorssen in the past. But he said: "Halvorssen in no way played an important role in this investigation. Did he do a lot of talking about money laundering in Venezuelan banks? Yes. But did he play a key role in this investigation? No."
Prosecutors from Mr. Morgethau's office are scheduled to deliver closing statements today. Then, a jury that includes two New York nurses, an actor and an unemployed parking attendant are to begin trying to decide whether three Venezuelan bankers should be convicted of criminal charges in Manhattan.

HEADLINE: Prominent Welfare-to-Work Effort Is Off to Slow Start

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER 

 BODY:
In his State of the Union address last week, President Clinton hailed five giant corporations for their pioneering efforts to put welfare recipients to work. But the limited progress of those companies is evidence of the daunting scope of the project.
While the five companies together employ nearly 700,000 workers in the United States, they have hired only a few hundred welfare recipients through targeted efforts since the welfare bill was signed last summer. Most of those workers were put on the payroll by just one company, United Parcel Service of America Inc. 
 Officials of all the companies -- the others are Burger King, a unit of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C.; the Sprint Corporation; the Monsanto Company, and United Airlines, a unit of the UAL Corporation -- said they were making a long-term commitment to hire welfare recipients, though market forces would ultimately determine the number of jobs the companies provide.
"This thing is not based on getting 100 people or one million people off welfare," said Joseph Schneider, vice president of human resources for U.P.S. "It's based on our need for employees."
Since signing the landmark legislation in August that ended the Federal entitlement to welfare benefits and requiring most recipients to find work within two years, Mr. Clinton has looked to private business to create those jobs.
"I'd like to say to every employer in this country who has ever criticized the old welfare system, 'You cannot blame the old system anymore,' " the President said in his State of the Union address on Feb. 4. "We have torn it down. Now do your part. Give someone on welfare the chance to work."
The budget Mr. Clinton proposed two days later included an estimated $600 million in tax credits over the next four years intended to subsidize the hiring of 120,000 or more welfare beneficiaries by private businesses. Employers would get a tax credit of 50 percent of the first $10,000 paid to newly hired workers who had been on welfare at least 18 months.
Other companies than those cited by Mr. Clinton have more experience in hiring from the welfare rolls; indeed, with the exception of U.P.S., the five employers said they were either just devising programs or were having limited success finding job candidates who met their standards. But all expressed optimism that the new relationships they were forging with social agencies and community-based groups would bear fruit.
Officials of some business groups said, however, that more leadership was needed from government if the smaller companies that create most jobs are to enlist in Mr. Clinton's campaign.
"It's perfectly all right for the President to put the spotlight on every world-class corporation that wants to do something," said Jeffrey R. Joseph, vice president for domestic policy at the United States Chamber of Commerce, "but I don't think they really accomplish all that much on their own."
The chief executives of the companies mentioned in the State of the Union address were among the participants in a meeting with Mr. Clinton in January on welfare-to-work efforts. The public notice they received was not meant to denigrate other companies that might be doing as much, said Mary Ellen Glynn, the deputy White House press secretary.
Still, officials of one company that went unmentioned, Marriott International, were smarting.
"We were shocked and very disappointed," said Janet Tully, the hotel company's director of community employment and training programs. Long before the welfare bill gained bipartisan support, Marriott had programs to hire welfare recipients, Ms. Tully said.
Marriott's chairman, J. Willard Marriott Jr., was invited to the January meeting with Mr. Clinton but was unable to attend; Ms. Tully said a White House aide told her that was why the company was not mentioned in the President's speech.
At Marriott, the welfare-to-work program typically trains 12 to 18 participants over six weeks in classroom and occupational skills training. The program is financed by Pathways and government sources. After placement in full-time jobs, the trainees are given six months of follow-up support to help promote job retention.
So far, efforts by the five companies mentioned by Mr. Clinton are less well developed.
Sprint, the fast-growing provider of long-distance phone service, said it would hire 25 welfare recipients this year to add to its 47,000 workers. Monsanto, an international chemical and biotechnology company with 18,000 workers in the United States, has given full-time jobs to 5 former welfare recipients and helped 45 others obtain jobs with companies that supply Monsanto with contract services, officials said.
United Airlines and Burger King both said they were still developing programs.
Like other fast-food chains, Burger King, with 7,000 domestic outlets and nearly 300,000 employees, is faced with a huge turnover rate; officials said the company had to replace the equivalent of its entire hourly work force every year. United said it wanted to find ways to hire welfare recipients for entry-level jobs like handling baggage and cleaning airplane cabins, as well as jobs requiring higher levels of training, like reservation agents and sales clerks.
U.P.S., with 290,000 workers, signed up last August for a state program in Illinois to help create jobs for people on welfare, becoming the first employer to do so. The company, which is based in Atlanta, gave part-time jobs starting at $8 an hour for roughly 25 hours a week to 31 residents of the Chicago area who completed a training program.
Similar efforts led to the hiring of 80 workers at the company's Philadelphia hub, about 100 in New York City, and additional workers in other cities, Mr. Schneider of U.P.S. said.
In many parts of the country, he noted, economic growth has created a demand for entry-level manpower. But companies will not hire welfare recipients unless the applicants exhibit personal discipline and meet minimum qualifications for work, Mr. Schneider said.
Indeed, at one of its four pilot job-training sites, Monsanto rejected 11 of every 12 applicants screened by local or state agencies, said Cyndy Rosenbloom, the director of human resources at the company, which is based in St. Louis.
"One of the things we quickly discovered," Ms. Rosenbloom said, "was that a state's standards for employment were not the marketplace's standards. We were being sent people certified by state job training programs who could not do simple math equations, had little sense of grammar and were below standards in performing functions."
Sprint, along with AT&T and Gateway 2000, has agreed to hire graduates from a program recently started at Metropolitan Community Colleges in Kansas City, Mo., close to its headquarters in Westwood, Kan.
The six-week program trains welfare recipients for customer service and telemarketing positions -- skills in great demand in the Kansas City area, where the unemployment rate is less than 3 percent.
"Demand is such we could place 300 graduates a month," said Jackie Snyder, the institution's vice chancellor.
But in Kansas City, too, finding welfare recipients with suitable skills has been difficult. The first class has only 6 participants, and the second, due to start next Monday, will have 12, Ms. Snyder said.
"We don't want to put people through the program who would not be hired because they don't have the basic speaking or reading skills needed for success in a call-center environment," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: United Parcel Service has led the way in hiring workers off welfare rolls. Santa Cruz, a former welfare recipient, inspected packages yesterday in Manhattan. U.P.S. has hired about 100 such workers in New York. (Philip Greenberg for The New York Times)

INTERNATIONAL A3-13
 
Europeans Postpone Case Against Helms-Burton Law
Europe decided, reluctantly, to postpone its legal challenge to American sanctions against companies doing business in Cuba. Washington had warned that the United States would declare Cuba a threat to its security, which would invoke an exemption to the World Trade Organization's jurisdiction. The Europeans fear that such a use of the national security exemption would damage the organization's authority. A1
 
The Clinton Administration agreed to allow 10 news organizations to open offices in Cuba, but will continue barring Cuban news bureaus from the United States. Cuba thus far has approved only one American news organization, CNN, to open a bureau there. A11
 
A Cuban court sentenced six people to prison terms ranging from 8 to 20 years for hijacking a tugboat and trying to flee to Florida last year. The United States Coast Guard intercepted them and handed them over to the Cuban authorities. A10
 
North Korean Said to Defect
South Korea reported that a top North Korean leader was in its consulate in Beijing and had asked for asylum. If confirmed, the defection of Hwang Jang Yop would be a spectacular coup for Western intelligence services. North Korea suggested that Mr. Hwang, the top theoretician of its ideology of self-reliance and the former tutor of its leader, Kim Jong Il, had been kidnapped. A3
U.S. to Aid Serbian Opposition
American officials said the United States would quintuple its financial aid to the Serbian opposition. The officials said the increase was directly due to the daily pro-democracy demonstrations that began in November in Belgrade and other cities. The program will require the tolerance of the Government of President Slobodan Milosevic. A3
 
Russian Tycoon Files Libel Suit
One of Russia's richest businessmen and most controversial politicians filed a libel suit in London against Forbes magazine. Forbes had published an article suggesting that the official, Boris A. Berezovsky, had built his career on corruption and links to organized crime. Forbes vigorously defended its article. A4
 
U.N. Criticizes Rwanda Tribunal
The United Nations issued a scathing report on the international criminal tribunal it set up to investigate the 1994 genocide of over half a million Tutsi and moderate Hutu in Rwanda. The report called for "substantial" changes, alleging that not a single area functioned effectively. Secretary General Kofi Annan promised further action. A13
 
Interim Government in Bulgaria
Bulgaria's president swore in a caretaker prime minister and called elections for April 19, ending two years of economically ruinous Socialist rule. Stefan Sofiyanski, the new Prime Minister, must now try to mend the nation's hyperinflation and sharp drop in living standards. (AP)
 
NATIONAL A14-30, B9-10
 
11 Term-Limit Proposals Are Debated, but All Lose
House members debated 11 different versions of a constitutional amendment to limit their terms, but didn't pass any of them. The most popular one garnered 217 votes, 69 short of the two-thirds majority it needed and 10 fewer than it received two years ago. A1
 
4 Balk at Fund-Raising Inquiry
A congressional committee chairman said three former members of the Clinton Administration and a fund-raiser had refused to cooperate with a House investigation into improper money-raising for the Democratic Party. The chairman, Dan Burton, an Indiana Republican, said subpoenas would be served on all four. B9
 
Gifts Campaign Goes Public
An advocacy group that wants to force Congress to change the campaign finance system said it would take its case to the public by trying to collect 1,776,000 signatures by the Fourth of July. Efforts at campaign finance reform in Congress have stalled in recent days. B9 
 
Hazards of Car Phones
Talking on a cellular telephone while driving increases the risk of an accident fourfold, the same increased risk faced by someone who drives drunk, Canadian researchers said. But 39 percent of the drivers studied used their phones to call for help after they crashed. A30
 
Cohen Defends Military Budget
Defense Secretary William S. Cohen defended President Clinton's military budget from attacks by his former Republican colleagues in the House and Senate. He said he did agree with them that too much was being spent on peacekeeping missions and not enough on modernization. B10
 
Opening Seen for Gains-Tax Cut
Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, said there might be enough bipartisan support for a cut in the capital gains tax to overcome the opposition of the Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin. His view was based on recent statements by some Congressional Democrats. A21
 
Abortion Pill Dispute Is Settled
A nonprofit group holding the right to sell the French abortion pill in the United States agreed to settle a lawsuit about control of the drug. The settlement will give control of the drug to a new company, Advances for Choice. By July, the company is to submit the material needed to win Food and Drug Administration approval to sell it. A28
 
Panel Acts on Airports Measure
The House Ways and Means Committee approved a bill to reinstate a package of expired aviation taxes, including the 10 percent tax on domestic tickets that lapsed last month. The taxes pay for airport improvement projects, and without an extension, the Government has said, the money could run out by about March 1. A Senate committee has already acted to extend the taxes. (AP)
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-8
 
Giuliani Promises Changes At Shelter for Women
Mayor Giuliani said he assumed full responsibility for the failings at a city-run shelter for abused women, and promised to order major changes in how it is run. The shelter's staff was removed Monday after city investigators said they had uncovered improper sexual contact between staff and residents and the failure to report child abuse allegations, among other things. A1
 
Nynex Ordered to Pay Refunds
The New York State Public Service Commission ordered Nynex to pay $109.6 million to its customers in the state -- at least $8.70 per customer. The refund is for what the commission called shoddy service and improper business practices between 1984 and last year. B1
 
Judicial Panel Is Attacked
A judicial screening panel established by Governor Pataki gives the appearance that political influence affects the selection of many judges, the city bar association charged. Four of the panel's seven members are from Mr. Pataki's administration. When Mr. Pataki set up the panel two years ago, he said it would be only temporary. B3
 
Fire Under Boardwalk Kills 3
A makeshift shack under the Brighton Beach boardwalk in Brooklyn caught fire, killing three occupants. The authorities were unable immediately to say what caused this fire, but neighborhood residents said homeless people often set fires under the boardwalk to keep warm. B3
 
Apartment Tower Is Planned
A developer, Related Companies, announced plans for a 45-story rental apartment building on Broadway between 55th and 56th Streets. There was a fierce bidding battle for the block, which has seen failed plans for an office building, a Planet Hollywood restaurant and a luxury hotel over the last 30 years. B8

Yankees Sign Williams
The Yankees agreed to a one-year contract with Bernie Williams, their star center fielder. He will earn $5.25 million for the 1997 season. B13

HEADLINE: Failings in Quality

 BODY:
To The Home Section:
 "When What You See Is All You Get" is an accurate description of failings in quality in a large part of today's design/build industry.
One source asserts that the current lack of standards can be attributed to the lack of skilled labor, which he calls "the industry's largest problem." Because of this, he says, "builders are always looking for ways to decrease the amount of labor necessary." 
 Quality craftsmen have always been scarce. It is the architect who is mandated by law and tradition to find such craftsmen. Yes, they still exist. Yet, architects are often denied a central role in construction. It is a misguided economy, as your article demonstrates.
 
BARRY E. MILOWITZ
Tarrytown, N.Y.
 
President
Society of American
Registered Architects

HEADLINE: EUROPE POSTPONES CHALLENGE TO U.S. ON HAVANA TRADE

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12

 BODY:
In a last-minute effort to avoid a major breach with the United States that could threaten the future of the World Trade Organization, Europe postponed today its legal challenge to American sanctions against companies doing business in Cuba.
European officials said that in the hope of reaching a compromise, they reluctantly asked the organization, the two-year-old arbiter of trade disputes, to delay for a week the naming of a panel to rule on the validity of the Helms-Burton Act, which imposes sanctions on non-American companies doing business with the Castro Government. Europe calls the act an illegal attempt to force Europe, Canada and Mexico to join the American effort to isolate Castro. 
 The postponement follows a week of frenzied and sometimes bitter negotiations between Washington and European officials in Brussels.
After failing repeatedly to get Europe to drop its case, the Administration warned officials this week that it would invoke a "national security exemption," based on an assertion that Cuba poses a security threat to the United States, saying that the organization, which is empowered to rule only on trade disputes, is thus not qualified to judge the case.
But the strategy carries considerable long-term risks for the United States. This is the first major case to come before the new Geneva-based organization, which the United States strenuously supported, and American officials have argued that it must have broad powers to rule on economic disputes.
But many European officials, and some in the Clinton Administration, have argued that the United States would forever damage the agency's authority by invoking the national security exemption because other countries often cite national security grounds to justify keeping their markets closed.
Japan, for example, has long asserted that keeping out imported rice is rooted in Japan's "food security." South Korea, China and other nations have made similar security arguments about maintaining an industrial base to produce cars and computer chips.
Today the European Union's senior trade official, Sir Leon Brittan, accused Washington of seeking "to be judge and jury in its own cause." "It is not acceptable to say this issue is too sensitive for the W.T.O. to handle," he said. "It is even less acceptable to imply than an adverse finding against any particular country would weaken the acceptability of the W.T.O. in that country."
Sir Leon was referring to arguments made by American officials that a ruling against the United States would only fuel Congressional opposition to the trade organization.
During the Presidential campaign, Patrick J. Buchanan vowed to oppose any effort to allow American laws to be reviewed by "faceless bureaucrats," and the Republican nominee, Bob Dole, periodically used similar language.
Nonetheless, European officials were insisting as recently as a few weeks ago that if the trade agency ruled against the United States, Congress would be obligated to rewrite the law, or American companies could face countersanctions.
Last week, frustrated by American unwillingness to agree on a panel of judges, Europe asked the director general of the trade organization, Renato Ruggiero, to appoint one. He was obligated to act by Thursday.
But the seven-day delay may not be sufficient to work out a compromise that would avoid a ruling on the issue. This evening a senior American official said "it's too early to tell, but there is more than a slim chance" to settle out of court. The European Union's Ambassador to Washington, Hugo Paemen, said, "On both sides there is a desire to come to some kind of arrangement."
"Will it be enough time?" he said. "That's not sure."
The Helms-Burton law has been a source of conflict between the United States and its traditional allies for nearly a year. They have objected to one provision that allows Americans to sue in United States courts any foreign firm that profits from the use of American property expropriated by Mr. Castro four decades ago. Canada and Europe have since passed laws that would retaliate against American companies that won judgments in American courts.
Another provision bars from the United States senior executives of companies that do extensive business in Cuba. The State Department has already informed executives of Sherritt International of Canada that they and their families are barred. The company responded by holding a board meeting in Havana.
At the core of the European, Canadian and Mexican complaints is the argument that the United States has no right to use its economic power to force other countries to come into line with American foreign policy. The Europeans say about Cuba what Washington says about China, that the best way to change the Government is to flood the country with investment and drown the Government in the forces of a global economy.
Although many Administration advisers made no secret of their distaste for the law, Mr. Clinton apparently felt that he had no choice after Cuba shot down two small aircraft flown by an anti-Castro group near the Cuban coast last year.
Experts disagree on whether Europe would win its case if it went before the three-judge panel in Geneva. But there is a considerable likelihood that at least part of the law would be struck down -- the part that reaches beyond American borders to punish foreign companies.
The European officials say, though, that it is the United States that has caused the problem.
"My American friends," Sir Leon said, "seem to have a hard time understanding that if they had not enacted this law, we wouldn't be discussing it."

LENGTH: 286 words

HEADLINE: French Are Right to Question Changing World

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"For France, Sagging Self-Image and Esprit" (front page, Feb. 11) suggests that France has committed the unpardonable error of ignoring marketing lessons learned at Stanford University by a new generation of French. And France compounds the error by a less than enthusiastic embrace of the Internet. 
 Moreover, Paris is "flat" compared with the sizzling German and English capitals. Even France's position as the fourth-largest industrial economy in the world is characterized as the tired claim of an outmoded bureaucracy.
Such attitudes undercut the concerns your article raises. The political and social conflict arising from immigration challenges France's view of itself as a humanistic society, but immigration is a flash point in nearly every industrialized society, including our own.
Unemployment is a Continental European problem: the German unemployment rate is nearly that of France. There are many who argue that the United States' 10 million new jobs were created at the expense of the decent wages, job security and benefits that France has tried to institutionalize. And it is simplistic to suggest that France must choose between either Jean-Marie Le Pen's National Front or European integration and obeisance to global market forces.
France's ills cannot be attributed to its resistance to unregulated free-market globalization. Indeed, many of us are relieved that in spite of the problems besetting their country, the French are at least questioning whether the role of government is to protect the global robber-baron capitalism practiced by some industrialized nations or to protect the welfare of its citizens.
 
ANNE POIRIER
Berkeley, Calif., Feb. 11, 1997

HEADLINE: In Era of Belt-Tightening, Modest Gains for Workers

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: RALEIGH, N.C.

 BODY:
American workersdownsized, re-engineered and shoved into salary ruts -- are slowly beginning to climb back up.
Last year, they won wage gains that were the largest since 1990, keeping them ahead of inflation for only the second time in a decade. Modest though these raises were, many economists expect them to continue. Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said recently that the era might be drawing to a close when workers were so worried about losing their jobs that they were afraid to demand raises. 
 For many people in Raleigh and other rapidly growing areas, it already has. As a sushi bar waiter at the Kanki Japanese House of Steaks here for three years, James E. Woodward Jr. became more like an affable host, building a steady clientele. His requests for raises from the standard dinner rate of $2.13 an hour plus tips, though, were repeatedly denied.
About a month ago, he gave his boss one last chance. "Waiters don't get raises," he was told again. Yes, they do, Mr. Woodward decided. In a strong economy like Raleigh's, he won about a 15 percent increase, with potential for more, by agreeing to join a departing sushi chef who was opening a rival establishment.
In his confidence, Mr. Woodward is hardly alone. In January of last year, 26 percent of those surveyed by the Conference Board said that jobs were tough to get, with 21 percent saying they were plentiful. The rest were in between. By December, the balance of opinions had reversed, with 29 percent seeing plenty of jobs and only 21 percent seeing scarcity.
Not that salaries are off to the races. Nationwide, hourly wages, in current dollars, are rising at an annual rate of 3.8 percent -- about five-tenths of 1 percent above the inflation rate -- to an average of $11.98.
That's nothing like the big gains of the 1960's and 1970's. Still, it is a lot better than the 2.1 percent increase for 1992, when the nation was just coming out of recession, and up solidly from the 3.2 percent gain in 1995.
Even in the tight labor markets of the South and West like Raleigh -- with unemployment of less than 2.5 percent, compared with 5.4 percent nationally -- there are no indications yet that the raises are proving inflationary.
A lot of companies, under pressure from competitors, are finding it difficult to pass cost increases on to their customers for fear of losing market share. Many have improved their efficiency so much that productivity gains are outpacing the still modest rise in pay levels.
Moreover, to keep costs under control, companies here and elsewhere have developed a variety of strategies to help restrain wages. They send recruiters onto college campuses, military bases, even into beauty parlors and barber shops. They tap immigrant labor. They stress job security. They use more temporary workers, whose pay is lower even though their wages are rising quickly. They even hand out bonuses to employees who recruit friends.
But even a gentle breeze of rising real wages, after inflation, could heat up the nation's economic climate. Involuntary worker sacrifice and unusually low inflation have been pillars of this economic expansion, now the third longest since World War II. Stagnant wages have helped corporations multiply their earnings and share prices. In the 1990's, a worker asking for a raise often seemed as hapless as Oliver Twist asking for more gruel.
Some of these trends may begin to unwind. "The predominant risk is, we're going to see higher wage growth, higher inflation and higher interest rates," said Mark Zandi, chief economist at Regional Financial Associates, a consulting firm in West Chester, Pa.
Whether these wage demands accelerate will depend heavily on the length and strength of any further expansion. Employers are likely to face some increased expenses simply because they can no longer count on shrinking benefit costs.
Overhauls of workers' compensation and unemployment insurance, plus a sharp drop in health care inflation, kept the growth in benefits costs to 2 percent last year, the lowest on record. But the overhaul is virtually complete and medical costs are expected to creep up again.
The best pay increases are concentrated in certain regions, mostly in the South and West, and industries like high technology and construction. Managers and executives are still the prime beneficiaries.
But wage gains are also popping up all over the place. Telemarketers and customer service providers are bidding up wages for practically anyone with a voice in cities like Omaha and Tulsa, Okla. Accountants are widely in demand. Despite reports of a national lawyer glut, Atlanta law firms are finding that they have to offer more than $60,000 to new associates, up from about $55,000 a few months ago. A Raleigh supermarket chain raised its starting wage to $8.50 from $7.50. Indeed, employers seem most willing to raise their rates for new workers, making job-jumping that much more profitable.
Trucking companies, with fewer laid-off factory workers to recruit, are also offering higher pay to lessen turnover. At J. B. Hunt Transport Inc., a big national trucker based in Lowell, Ark., the costs of training and insuring inexperienced replacements were soaring. "We were not compensating our drivers enough to make it worthwhile," said Stephen L. Palmer, the company's senior executive for personnel. As of Feb. 25, starting pay for those with one year's experience will rise 48 percent, to 37 cents a mile. Drivers with at least 10 years' experience will earn even more, 41 cents a mile. J. B. Hunt expects to recover the $54 million annual cost by having safer, more experienced drivers, reducing turnover by more than half.
With labor markets so tight, the raises these days often go to those -- construction workers, restaurant and retailing help, temporary labor -- who are most willing to auction their services and switch to the highest bidder.
No longer are migrating workers always there to grab the available jobs. Labor markets in California and the Northeast have strengthened enough to diminish the flow of economic refugees to places like Georgia, North Carolina, Texas and the Rocky Mountain states -- leaving the pools of available workers in the nation's boom towns that much shallower.
Mr. Zandi, who advises companies on locations, said that as the unemployment rate had fallen in Los Angeles and New York, "those two markets are not going to provide safety valves for the rest of the country any longer."
The signs of labor shortages are obvious here in the Research Triangle area of North Carolina, roughly bounded by Raleigh, Durham and Chapel Hill. Manufacturing wages rebounded earlier than elsewhere and are now rising at about a 4.7 percent annual rate, providing perhaps a glimpse of what is in store elsewhere.
At the Greater Raleigh Chamber of Commerce, a reception room is lined with framed magazine covers extolling the area as the best place to do business. Unions are seldom seen. Lately, however, the advantages have been tilting in favor of the workers.
At the Austin Quality Foods plant in the suburbs here, managers first blamed their agency, Monarch Temporary Services, for failing to recruit enough help at $6 an hour. "We went to barber shops, beauty parlors and churches," said Dolores Smith, a Monarch vice president. She left leaflets under windshield wipers. She checked with homeless shelters. With sales of its cheese-and-peanut-butter-cracker sandwiches growing, Austin tried another agency. The answer was the same.
Last month, Austin reluctantly raised the starting wage to $7. The higher pay and the promise of a permanent job if things work out have brought in new employees like Lara A. Nicklow. She had worked at a Hardee's for $5.30 an hour while waiting for an increase to $6.
For construction workers, the bidding is so fervent that the muddy site for a new 273-room Embassy Suites hotel near Raleigh seemed as fraught with financial calculations as a commodity pit. At their offices inside a trailer, superintendents said they were at the mercy of anyone who walked in. "A lot of people come in here and say they're carpenters," said John T. Long, the project superintendent, with a look that could saw wood. He mentioned a name. "Slow as molasses. Very limited in what he can do. I should get rid of the guy but right now I'd be a fool to."
Outside, over the rumble of drills and front-end loaders, Donald Benton, an electrician, reported that other offers were his most useful tool. He joined the project last May to win a modest raise -- electricians average about $17 an hour -- and escape a new manager he did not like. About two months ago, he and two friends announced they were ready to quit for a site that paid better still. "They made it worth it for us to stay," he chuckled. "I'll put it like that."
Count workers in the computer industry as among the most empowered. Demand for them, already strong, is accelerating. Cisco Systems, a leading maker of computer networking equipment, decided in 1992 to open an East Coast base in Research Triangle Park, in part to escape the high costs in Silicon Valley. Now Cisco finds itself competing for talent with scores of other companies that came to Silicon Hollow for similar reasons.
Clifford B. Meltzer, Cisco's general manager here, has a simple strategy to keep workers. "You pay them enough to get them to feel guilty," he said. Bill Fredenburg, a hardware engineer who joined Cisco last April, shrugged at how easy it was to win a big pay increase. He was just about to accept another job that would have increased his pay by 10 percent. Then a Cisco recruiter asked him, "What would it take?" He cited a figure more than 10 percent above his other offer. The recruiter laughed at his modesty. A few days later, he asked for thousands more, which the company topped. And that does not count the bonuses and stock options.
At North Carolina State University here, Walter B. Jones, the director of the career center, says the going rate for computer-friendly graduates is $42,000 and up, roughly 10 percent above last year. It's not just high-fliers like Cisco that are vigorously bidding, but also companies like I.B.M., which brought at least five recruiters to campus last fall. "Organizations went through a long time of downsizing and downsizing," Mr. Jones said. "Now they are looking up and saying, 'Hey, we have to get more people in the pipeline.' "
Even in unionized industries where retrenchment remains a threat, companies and union leaders sometimes misjudge workers' determination. At the Kelly-Springfield plant in Fayetteville, N.C., the largest tire factory in the nation, union members overwhelmingly rejected a proposed contract from Goodyear last month for the second time. Among the contract's irritants: the right to hire new workers at 62 percent of normal wages. "Goodyear is doing really great -- making money hand over fist," said Gary Schrump, cradling a beer at Pappy's Country Club and Sports Bar after his shift. "They don't want to give it up."
Some companies, desperate to fill their slots, find themselves signing paychecks for workers who would not have met their standards before.
John L. Moore, the director of operations at the two Kanki Japanese steak restaurants in Raleigh, said that he once insisted that teppanyaki tableside chefs -- the guys with the flashing knives -- be Japanese. Two or three years ago, he began turning to Filipinos and Vietnamese. "If they're Asian-looking, they'll pass," he said. He paid labor lawyers to help them obtain permanent residency. But now, he has exhausted his supply of Asians. So who is he hiring? "Puerto Ricans," he said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Mixed Amid Rumors Of Central Bank Intervention

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed yesterday and the German mark strengthened as rumors circulated that central banks might intervene to stop the American currency's ascent.
But traders said the underlying appetite for dollars remained strong because of the strength of the United States economy and the stock market. The Dow Jones industrial average passed 7,000 points yesterday for the first time. 
 "When you take half a step back from the market, you realize nothing has changed," said Kevin Raphael, manager of foreign exchange at Rabobank Nederland in New York. "The environment in the United States is better than it is in most of the industrialized world. We've got real nice rates of return here, low inflation, good employment; that's really not too bad."
In New York the dollar cost 1.6828 marks, down from 1.6846 Wednesday. The dollar fetched 124.35 yen, up from 124.17. The British pound slipped to $1.6239 from $1.6321.
The mark strengthened against the dollar in early trading after Johann Wilhelm Gaddum, vice president of Germany's central bank, said that the bank did not favor a stronger dollar and was concerned about the currency's rapid rise.
The mark also derived strength from broad weakness in the Swiss franc and British pound.
Nervousness over a possible sale of dollars by central banks also permeated currency trading. That nervousness has grown since the Group of Seven industrial nations -- Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States -- issued a statement last Saturday that the dollar's reversal from postwar lows was now complete.
Although there was no evidence of dollar selling by any of the Group of Seven central banks, many traders reasoned that it was only a matter of time before they would back up their words with actions.
But some said the central banks were likely to wait until the demand for the dollar had waned, and would try to surprise the market by selling dollars as the currency was falling.
"Stepping in front of speeding train doesn't make much sense," said Robert Katz, a currency trader at MTB Bank in New York. "At this point, they're content to jawbone it down."

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Sales Up for Small and Medium Condos

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
Spurred in part by the increasing cost of rental apartments, sales of small and mid-sized Manhattan condominiums rose significantly last year, while sales numbers for bigger condos -- with a more limited supply -- remained relatively flat.
The statistics were contained in a series of year-end market reports being issued by brokerage and real estate consulting firms, which assessed the more than 2,500 condo sales for 1996 in slightly different ways. Unlike the sales of co-operative apartments, condo sales are publicly recorded. 
 The increase in the number of lower-priced apartments sold was a large factor in the overall sunny picture most companies reported for the condominiums: Yale-Robbins's reported volume was up 12.5 percent; Douglas Elliman's report, due in the next two weeks, will show 21 percent more sales than last year, according to its authors. The Corcoran Group reported that sales were up 17 percent.
According to Douglas Elliman's statistics for Manhattan condominium sales, the number of studios sold rose 29 percent; the number of one-bedrooms was up 22 percent and the number of two-bedrooms rose 21 percent. In prices, the only major upswing was in studio apartments, which the Douglas Elliman report found jumped almost 15 percent from 1995 to 1996, from $235 a square foot to $270 a square foot. Prices for one- and two-bedrooms increased only about 2 percent, while prices for three-bedrooms and up were virtually unchanged from 1995.
The reasons that smaller condominium apartments have finally begun to move include such factors as a growing economy, reasonable mortgage rates and a feeling of confidence among Manhattanites that "the job market is growing again" said Samuel E. Solie, executive vice-president of Miller Samuel Inc., the real estate appraisal and consulting firm that is compiling the Douglas Elliman report.
Other reasons, according to real-estate agents, include these apartments' poor performance during the real estate recession -- they had, in the words of one, "nowhere else to go but up" -- and the skyrocketing cost of renting an apartment, which made buying more appealing.
Meanwhile, the number of three- and four-bedroom condominiums sold remained about the same from last year -- or decreased a couple of percentage points -- which agents universally attribute to the dearth of such apartments. (The dearth, real or perceived, may not last. A number of developers, especially Donald Trump, have announced plans to build more, or to create more in rehabilitated spaces -- including old hotels and warehouses.)
Although the volume of large apartments sold did not change, the prices did -- at least in the most desirable buildings in the most desirable locations. According to a report issued by the Halstead Property Company, "selected prime neighborhoods, each with a handful of super-luxury condominiums, fared well." In the stretch Fifth to Park Avenue, 42d to 59th Street, prices rose from $530 to $684 a square foot, according to Halstead, which said prices in the same corridor from 79th to 96th rose from $476 to $591.
Yet for the stretch between 59th and 79th -- the city's "Gold Coast" -- prices fell precipitously, from $508 to $386, according to Halstead, which attributed the fall to a lack of excellent high-priced apartments on the market last year.
"For the most part, your condominium buyer is totally different than your co-op buyer," said Frederick W. Peters, president of Ashforth Warburg Real Estate. "Your condominium buyer wants new, new, new, glitz, glitz, glitz."
And the newest and glitziest is Trump International Hotel and Tower at One Central Park West at Columbus Circle.
"When Trump started getting over $1,000 a square foot in that building -- and I had to double-check the numbers, they seemed so high," said Ms. Corcoran, "that really set off prices in the upper-upper-end condo market."
But the selling price of condominiums, perhaps even more than co-ops, varies tremendously from building to building, making average price comparisons between this year and last year lose some meaning.
While Mr. Solie said that prices for all condominium sales rose only 2 percent on average, he cautioned that the figure should be interpreted cautiously. Others agreed.
"My perception is that the condo market is very uneven, that certain areas are very strong and certain areas are not very strong at all," said Mr. Peters, whose firm does not produce a report.
"New construction has done very well," said Mr. Peters "The Trump Building has done incredibly well; the Siena, the new building on 76th Street has done incredibly well." But some of the older, most expensive condominiums -- Mr. Peters named Trump Tower, Metropolitan Tower and Museum Tower -- "are not moving as quickly," he said. "The market is about the same as last year."

HEADLINE: Defense Spending Boon

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Michael Dorsey (letter, Feb. 7) says that we lavish too much money on the military. He postulates that it would be better to increase spending on foreign aid. This is a common but dangerous misconception.
Maintaining an overseas presence provides the United States the opportunity to wield political and economic influence around the world. In addition to preventing armed conflicts in many of the world's hot spots, we also insure prosperity for our own economy. 
 However, these political and economic benefits come at a price, under the auspices of military spending. The military budget must be looked at in its comprehensive whole, not simply in terms of tanks, guns and bullets.
 
(Capt.) DANIEL L. DAVIS
Stuttgart, Germany, Feb. 7, 1997
 
The writer is commandant, Joint Task Force Readiness Training Center, U.S.-European Command Center.

HEADLINE: Farm Workers Hit by a Freeze and Hard Times

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: HOMESTEAD, Fla., Feb. 10

 BODY:
Dressed in jeans and muddied sneakers, and packing a lunch bag in case they found jobs today, Tereso Reyes and Evangelina Alvarez got into the car of another couple in the fog of the early morning to drop in on the farms of South Florida's agricultural fields. Car pooling saved on gas and rejection -- at each stop the two men jointly asked for work for themselves and their wives. Each time the answer was no.
Normally this time of year, the two couples would have been busy picking squash, tomatoes and pole beans. But since a freeze last month destroyed winter vegetable crops in this area, only a lucky few migrant and seasonal workers are working full-time or at all, picking or working in nurseries and packing houses. 
 The Governor's Council on Farmworker Affairs estimates that 100,000 farm workers have been affected by the freeze statewide. Most of them saw their last paycheck nearly a month ago and have begun to hurt for cash to pay rent and electric bills.
Local churches here, in the heart of Dade County's farm country, say they are getting desperate calls for basic needs, like shoes for a boy who was missing school because he lacked them. Others are pleading for intervention with landlords to avoid evictions.
"People are getting by with half what they usually make, which is next to nothing," said Jorge Lara, a counselor at Centro Campesino Farmworker Center in Florida City.
Hard times like these expose the vulnerability of migrant workers like Mr. Reyes, 47, and Ms. Alvarez, 33, Mexicans who have picked crops in Florida and Texas for the last 20 years and who have five children. From November to May, Florida is home for workers who travel on three paths the rest of the year, up the East Coast to Maine, north to Michigan or west to Texas. But with no significant work available yet elsewhere and no money made here to even finance a search elsewhere, the couple say they are stuck.
"We were told there were oranges in the north of Florida, but we need money for gas and to take all the children with us," Ms. Alvarez said.
The freeze last Jan. 18 and 19, with temperatures as low as 19 degrees, caused more than $270 million in losses in 20 Florida counties. Gov. Lawton Chiles has asked the Federal Department of Agriculture to designate the counties disaster areas in order to provide low-interest loans and other aid to farmers. But so far, no Federal aid has been forthcoming.
State officials say that in order to release Federal or state aid for the workers, they first need to gather information on the impact of the freeze on the workers, a task they say is difficult because so many are reluctant to come forward.
But while many farmers can recover losses through insurance or because of price increases at the supermarket -- prices have risen to up to 100 percent for some vegetables -- farm workers, particularly the more than a quarter estimated to be illegal immigrants, have been left largely to fend for themselves or rely on churches and local charities for sustenance.
About 20 migrant service organizations here are pooling resources to open a center next week to offer whatever aid they can muster. But much of what they have gathered so far consists of food, clothes and other goods, not the estimated $325,000 in cash assistance the organizations say they need to cover rent and utilities for affected families, most of whom are Mexicans but also Salvadorans, Guatemalans and Haitians.
"Farm workers live from paycheck to paycheck," said Sister Iliana Valdes, director of social ministry at Sacred Heart Church. "Let's face it. They're paid 50 cents for a bucket of tomatoes."
The couple teaming up with Mr. Reyes and Ms. Alvarez on job-hunting trips, a 29-year-old man and 24- year-old woman who are here illegally, are living on the $220 a month in food stamps they receive because their two young sons are American-born citizens. The couple, who said they have migrated between Mexico and Florida for the last four years, received food stamps even before the freeze -- the average farm worker makes $7,000 to $8,000 a year, state officials say. But now, the couple said they have been forced to borrow from a few relatives and friends to pay the $63 weekly rent for their trailer and are close to losing power and water because of unpaid bills. Prodded to comment on their predicament, the man pulled out a pay stub. Of $280.25 he made the first week of January, $17.38 was withheld for Social Security, $4.06 for Medicare and $8 as "Federal withholding."
"Even though one is illegal one pays taxes," he said. "But when we are in need it is as if we don't exist." As legal residents, Ms. Alvarez and Mr. Reyes are better off. In addition to food stamps, they receive unemployment benefits. But the new welfare rules that restrict aid to noncitizens have reduced their food stamps by $150 a month. In all, they and their children, ages 3 to 15, are surviving on $650 a month, down from a monthly income of about $1,600 when both parents have work. This month they had to borrow $300 from their crew leader to pay the $281 rent in their subsidized house. Meat and corn flakes are beyond their budget. "We vary," he says, "Tortillas with eggs one day, eggs with tortillas the next."
At times like these Ms. Alvarez renews her resolve to become an American citizen, a feat that she and her husband have yet to accomplish because it requires two things they are short of: money and English. Ms. Alvarez says she also yearns to go to school to become a beautician, but the family could not survive on Mr. Reyes' salary alone.
Ms. Alvarez blamed the workers' current situation partly on their failure to organize.
"You see the Cubans, if something happens, all getting together," she said. "We should do the same and go to the employment center to ask for help." In the meantime, the two couples scavenge for work in the morning and for food, and other donated goods in the afternoon. At one stop, while the men talked to a crew leader, Ms. Alvarez picked yellow squash to take home for dinner.
With no work in sight until new plants are ready for harvesting in about a month, Mr. Reyes and Ms. Alvarez are letting their 15-year-old daughter, Vanessa, look for part-time work in grocery stores that so far have not hired her because she is not yet 16. The 10th grade student at Homestead Senior High, who has helped her parents out in the fields on weekends, said she eventually would like to join the Air Force or the Marines and become an engineer.
"Picking is very hard," she said of her parents' occupation. "You work your back all day long and you get tired."

HEADLINE: Pataki Amends Budget Proposals For Medicaid Cuts and Tax Relief

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 13

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki today modified his proposed budget to soften his Medicaid cuts somewhat and include co-op owners in a program he is pushing to hold down local property taxes across the state.
Mr. Pataki lessened by $100 million the cut he had sought in state Medicaid spending, but it remains the area where he would make by far the deepest cuts in his $66.2 billion budget for the fiscal year that will begin April 1. 
 When matching Federal and local Medicaid contributions and the inflation of medical costs are calculated, the Governor's budget still means almost $2 billion less for doctors, nurses, hospitals and nursing homes.
"We'd hoped for substantially more than $100 million, but it is a small first step toward what we'd like to see," said David Rich, vice president of the Greater New York Hospital Association.
New York City legislators had criticized Mr. Pataki's property tax relief program for leaving out most city residents, who either rent or own cooperative apartments. The Governor proposed including co-op owners, though he took no action to spread the benefit to renters, and his office said that New York City residents' share of the total benefits from the tax relief program would climb only from 9 percent to 12 percent. Democrats have said that New York City, which has more than 40 percent of the state's residents, should get a similar share of the tax benefits.
"It's a step toward equity, but there needs to be more," said the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat and Mr. Pataki's chief rival in state government.
The Governor's office also pledged faster implementation of the $1.75 billion environmental bond act approved by voters, saying that spending in the next fiscal year would increase about 60 percent over his original budget proposal, and would roughly double in the first five years, to about $1 billion.
Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a Westchester County Democrat, noted that the amount of bond act money included in the budget had not changed, and accused the Governor's office of deceit. But officials in Mr. Pataki's budget office insisted that the point was moot, because the state could increase bond act spending without changing the text of the budget. Mr. Pataki plans to use the real estate transfer tax, which generates $117 million a year, to repay the bonds.

HEADLINE: January Retail Sales Rose 0.6%, Slightly Less Than Expected

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13

 BODY:
Retail sales rose modestly in January, following a holiday shopping season that was much weaker than retailers had hoped, Government figures showed today.
A separate report today, however, provided evidence of greater strength in the economy. The number of people visiting unemployment offices for the first time tumbled last week to the lowest point since mid-summer, another of several recent signs that the labor market continues to tighten. 
 "The economy's doing just fine," said William C. Dudley, chief domestic economist with Goldman, Sachs, pointing to swelling payrolls that in turn have raised consumer confidence and kept people spending, albeit at a more subdued recent pace.
The Commerce Department said retail sales rose six-tenths of 1 percent in January, slightly less than expected, with all sectors other than apparel and grocery stores posting sizable gains. But the monthly comparison would have been weaker had it not been for a downward revision that held December's gain to three-tenths of 1 percent, half what the department initially estimated a month ago. And when the automotive sector is excluded, December shows no sales increase at all.
Analysts said that today's report put the Government closer to the disappointing seasonal results that merchants themselves had reported.
"It sure looks as if consumers have suddenly 'got religion' and tempered their buying proclivities," Kenneth Mayland, chief economist for Keycorp in Cleveland, said. "This should help keep inflation pressures from boiling over and stretch out this already-long business expansion."
The restrained retail sales number helped offset the strength seen in the weekly jobless claims number, and bond prices surged today, pushing interest rates down to their lowest yield in six weeks. The drop in interest rates bolstered the stock market's recent rally, which pushed the Dow Jones industrial average above 7,000 for the first time.
Bond and stock market investors have been encouraged by an economy that has been growing for nearly six years now without a significant acceleration of prices.
Still, policy makers and private economists watch the labor market closely for signs of wage pressure and the marked downtrend in first-time jobless claims since early in the year has caused some uneasiness.
The surprising drop of 15,000, to 309,000, in the number of claims for the week that ended last Saturday "could signal troubling further tightening in labor market conditions," Joseph Liro and Anita Ash of CIBC Wood Gundy Securities in New York advised clients. They said the Federal Reserve would be forced to raise short-term interest rates by one-quarter point without saying when.
On a four-week average, which makes the Labor Department's claims data less erratic, the decline has been to 327,750 now from 358,250 on Jan. 4.
The retail sales report showed that consumers spent $209.1 billion last month, six-tenths of 1 percent more than in December and 4.9 percent, with no adjustment for inflation, above the January 1996 level. Sales of durable goods, those designed to last at least three years, rose seven-tenths of 1 percent, while nondurables rose five-tenths of 1 percent.
Department stores and others selling general merchandise had a 1.3 percent sales increase followed by gasoline service stations, up nine-tenths of 1 percent, and drugstores, up seven-tenths of 1 percent.
Stores selling apparel and accessories, however, saw receipts fall nine-tenths of 1 percent, apparently reflecting heavy discounting, while sales at food stores were unchanged for the month, the department found.

HEADLINE: Sears to Open 110 Stores in New York by End of 1999

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Sears Roebuck & Company will open 110 stores across New York State by the end of 1999, with the largest share of the expansion -- 2 large department stores and 33 smaller specialty stores -- in New York City, the senior economic adviser to Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday.
Sears, which said a month ago that it hoped to open a large department store as part of the redevelopment of the New York Coliseum, will open the first of the new stores in Brooklyn's Kings Plaza shopping mall, where it is to begin renovating the former Alexander's department store for its own use this month. 
 Sears' expansion was described as an important milestone at a time when major national retail chains have been making fresh investments in urban neighborhoods, ranging from Manhattan's East Village to downtown Buffalo. Its plan has particularly rich symbolic value for Manhattan, where Sears has never before operated a store.
"It sends a very strong signal when a company like this -- I think it is synonymous with America -- wants to make a big commitment to New York," said Charles A. Gargano, the economic adviser to Mr. Pataki and chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation. "It means we are in a period of renewal."
He said Sears would receive no special tax breaks or other financial incentives from the city or state.
The expansion plan is to be described today by Arthur C. Martinez, the chairman of Sears, at a Manhattan news conference to be attended by Mr. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Sears has reported strong earnings growth in the last year and sharp increases in clothing sales.
According to state officials, the new Sears stores will employ 5,000 people and generate $300 million in sales tax and property revenues to the city and state. Part of a broad expansion of its store network across the nation, the New York plan will be weighted most heavily toward increasing the number of Sears specialty stores, which are far smaller than its department stores and limit their merchandise to more narrow categories like hardware, automotive goods or housewares.
With 33 of the specialty stores to be opened in New York City, Sears is expected to locate a majority of them in neighborhoods that it considers as underserved retail markets, mainly poor and middle-class sections above 96th Street in Manhattan and in the other four boroughs.
Although Sears executives declined to comment yesterday, Mr. Martinez, a native of the Park Slope section of Brooklyn -- where he was a childhood acquaintance of Mr. Gargano -- said in a recent interview that he had long hoped to open a large department store at a prominent location in Manhattan.
That interest has culminated in the company's effort to become part of the huge coliseum redevelopment project on Columbus Circle, where it has teamed up with Bruce Ratner, a major developer on Times Square and downtown Brooklyn, in submitting 1 of 9 development proposals.
If Mr. Ratner's proposal is selected by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the owner of the coliseum, his project would provide Sears with the site of its Manhattan store. State officials said yesterday that Sears was exploring other Manhattan alternatives, but declined to say where. Mr. Ratner, a developer who has invested heavily in retail projects in inner city neighborhoods, is renovating the Kings Plaza department store for Sears.
The expansion would greatly increase Sears' presence across New York State, where it now operates 130 stores, 17 in the New York City metropolitan area, which includes Westchester and Long Island.
State officials said Sears would open two of its department stores on Long Island, in Yaphank and Bay Shore, but had not yet disclosed the location of its other new stores.
