HEADLINE: Germans Wonder: Twilight for Kohl?

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: BONN, Feb. 14

 BODY:
A tantalizing question has burst forth from Bonn's placid politics: is Helmut Kohl politically mortal?
Only last October, when the 66-year-old Mr. Kohl overtook Konrad Adenauer as Germany's longest-serving Chancellor since Bismarck, even his critics acknowledged the durability of what one adversary begrudgingly called "the eternal Chancellor." 
 Still basking in the afterglow as the architect of Germany's reunification in 1990, Mr. Kohl appeared unassailable, an emblem of confidence in an uncertain world, a political fixture who would see the country through the rigors of European integration and the triumphant return of its capital to Berlin at the start of a new millennium.
But the pendulum has swung rapidly. With unemployment topping 4.6 million -- at 12 percent its highest rate since in 1933, the year Hitler took power -- the talk is of what Joschka Fischer, leader of the Green Party, termed "the twilight of the Chancellor."
Now the issue is whether Mr. Kohl will run for a fifth term when Germany holds national elections next year. And with that comes a much broader question: if Mr. Kohl withdraws from the fray, can Europe's striving for unity survive without its dominant champion?
The mood changed in early January, when Wolfgang Schauble, Mr. Kohl's senior lieutenant in the governing Christian Democratic Union, deliberately let slip that he might "not be able to resist the temptation" to assume Germany's political leadership.
To outsiders, Mr. Schauble's aside might have seemed innocuous. But in the regimented world of Mr. Kohl's close advisers, the remark took on Delphic proportions. Mr. Schauble was raising a question that the Chancellor himself refuses to address in public. A debate, once taboo, was opened.
With some embarrassed squirming, Bonn's pundits addressed the sensitive question of whether Mr. Schauble -- a 54-year-old paraplegic who has used a wheelchair since a gunman shot him in 1990 -- was physically capable of running Europe's economic and political powerhouse. "A cripple as Chancellor?" Mr. Schauble himself said, unabashed. "That's a good question."
The remarks inspired younger members of the Christian Democratic Union to openly challenge their party leader's policies. Whisperers filled the salons here with suggestions that after 14 years in office, Mr. Kohl was tired and looking for a way to bow out.
The weekly newsmagazine Der Spiegel broke another taboo, speculating openly that contrary to adamant official denials, Mr. Kohl may be hiding his doctors' suspicions that he is suffering from cancer -- just as the late President Francois Mitterrand of France did.
Alongside Mr. Schauble, who is widely considered Mr. Kohl's favorite, the names most frequently mentioned as likely successors are Edmund Stoiber, 55, the Governor of Bavaria, and Defense Minister Volker Ruhe, 54. Neither has announced an open challenge to Mr. Kohl.
Mr. Kohl himself is not saying much. Last week, when he journeyed to Berlin for the groundbreaking of a new Chancellery building, he was asked who would turn the key in the front door when the Government moved from Bonn in 1999. "We can leave that safely to the good Lord," he replied.
In any other political system, the omens might look bad. The latest opinion surveys say 55 percent of respondents do not want Mr. Kohl to run for chancellor again. And, despite his party's triumphs in important local elections last fall, opinion polls now show the opposition Social Democrats running even with the Christian Democrats.
But Mr. Kohl's allies argue that he has been here before. "Midterm blues are nothing new to Helmut Kohl," said a confidant who spoke in return for anonymity, referring to earlier challenges to Mr. Kohl's tenure. "He's been through this kind of thing and lived to tell the tale."
In 1989, for instance, Mr. Kohl was at a political ebb when the fall of the Berlin wall offered him a chance to carve a place in history and revive his fortunes through the enormous popularity of the prospect of reunification.
This time, though, the issues are nitty-gritty economics that promise no such political credits with voters long used to Europe's highest standard of living.
After years of complacency, Germany has been brought up short against hard realities. Its economy, says Hans Tietmeyer, the president of the Bundesbank, the central bank, is inflexible, uncompetitive in global terms and burdened by social welfare programs that it can no longer afford.
The population of 80 million is aging, the reunification of 1990 continues to soak up more tax money than Mr. Kohl ever publicly projected and the stringent economic qualifications for the creation of a single European currency -- a process due to start next year -- have further strained the Government's ability to pay for social programs.
The criteria for a single currency include severe limits on deficit spending, so Germany has been pressed toward what many economists view as a long-overdue reform of its interlinked taxation, pension and welfare systems.
At the same time, though, Germany's unemployment -- driven, Mr. Tietmeyer and others say, by the same structural inflexibilities and high costs that underpin its social systems -- has soared to record levels. And that, in turn, means there is less tax revenue to pay for social costs, including the increased demand for unemployment benefits.
The combination of uncertainties over Germany's and Mr. Kohl's future, thus, have much wider consequences, raising the possibility that Europe's putative political integration will falter.
"If Kohl is not available for a further term, then it becomes much more difficult to push through monetary union," said Werner Becker, senior economist at Deutsche Bank in Frankfurt.
But at this junction, Mr. Kohl's coalition Government seems paralyzed, caught in internal feuds over what it calls the economic "reforms of the century."
Others liken Mr. Kohl's plight after 14 years in power to that of Mr. Adenauer in his final days -- a symbol of his land abroad, yet undermined within his own party.
In Parliament last month, Mr. Kohl called out to Oskar Lafontaine, the leader of the Social Democrats: "You'd like me to go, wouldn't you?"
"Mr. Chancellor," Mr. Lafontaine replied, "it's true we would like you to go. But your problem is that there are even more people on the Government side who would like that too."

HEADLINE: U.S. Aide Assails Colombia as New Drug Sanctions Are Studied

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14

 BODY:
A senior State Department official lashed out at the Colombian Government today for "cooperating" with drug traffickers and stopped just short of predicting that the Clinton Administration would impose economic sanctions on Colombia for the second year in a row.
In testimony before a House subcommittee, Assistant Secretary of State Robert S. Gelbard painted a picture of a Government that he said puts obstacles in the way of its police and prosecutors and allows drug kingpins to run their operations out of comfortable jail cells. The charges were not entirely new, but they came only two weeks before President Clinton is scheduled to decide whether Colombia should be "certified" as a trustworthy ally in the international fight on drugs. 
 "The Government of Colombia has failed," Mr. Gelbard said, "to follow through on promised counternarcotics action or to confront fully the drug interests that contributed millions of dollars to President Ernesto Samper's campaign."
Mr. Gelbard is receiving and reviewing reports from various law enforcement agencies as he prepares his recommendation on certification to the President. A State Department official who monitors Colombian affairs said Mr. Gelbard, who is well respected in the White House, is virtually certain to recommend decertification.
Last year, Mr. Clinton decertified Colombia, putting the traditional United States ally in the company of Afghanistan, Burma, Iran, Nigeria and Syria. Some economic sanctions were applied, delaying American assistance for many months and making it more difficult for Colombia to attract international loans.
Should Mr. Clinton decide to decertify Colombia a second time, he could apply more stringent sanctions like cutting off landing rights for Colombian planes, putting Colombian travelers through onerous searches when they enter the United States and rescinding tariff preferences on coffee and other Colombian products.
An estimated 80 percent of the cocaine used in the United States is processed in Colombia, mostly from coca leaves produced in Peru and Bolivia. As eradication and interdiction efforts in Peru and Bolivia have increased in the last three years, Colombia has grown an increasing amount of coca.
And with the cocaine market in the United States peaking in recent years, Colombian cartels have stepped up shipments of heroin to the United States, undercutting traditional Asian traffickers with lower prices and purer product. An estimated 60 percent of the heroin now seized in the United States can be traced to Colombia, and that figure appears to be increasing quickly.
"There is as much cocaine coming into the United States or being produced in Colombia as ever before," said Mr. Gelbard, who heads the State Department's international narcotics and law enforcement affairs bureau. "There is more heroin being produced in Colombia than ever before. That's the bottom line."
Mr. Gelbard had kind words for Colombian officials, including the nation's top narcotics prosecutor and the head of the national police. But he made no effort to hide his disdain for President Samper, who was accused of receiving $6 million in donations from the Cali cartel during his campaign two years ago but has been absolved by the Colombian Congress.
He characterized Mr. Samper as "a truly corrupt President who has had a clear history of cooperating with drug dealers and receiving drug money back to 1982."
In recent weeks, Colombia has made a concerted effort to avert decertification. In December the Colombian Congress passed an asset-forfeiture law to take wealth away from convicted drug dealers. In the last two weeks, the Colombian police have shut down two huge cocaine-refining laboratories in the Andean jungles.
In a radio interview in Colombia today, Foreign Minister Maria Emma Mejia said, "Colombia has demonstrated that it's making serious progress." Ms. Mejia had just returned from a trip to Washington, where she tried to persuade Mr. Gelbard to certify Colombia this year.
A senior Administration official acknowledged that "some of the recent developments have been helpful" and added that no firm decision on decertification had been made.
Colombian and United States officials are now negotiating a maritime interdiction treaty that would allow American law enforcement agents to board and search Colombian-flagged ships in Colombian waters.
Speaking after Mr. Gelbard at a hearing of a House Government Reform and Oversight Subcommittee, Gen. Harold Bedoya, the commander of the Colombian armed forces, said decertification would demoralize his troops and deny them needed resources to fight traffickers.
"We are not the enemy," he said. "The enemy is international narcotics."

HEADLINE: Amrom H. Katz, 81, Early Expert on Space Reconnaissance

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Amrom H. Katz, whose studies prepared the way for space reconnaissance -- the use of space satellites to collect intelligence by photography and other means -- died on Monday in St. John's Hospital in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 81 and lived in Los Angeles.
The cause was complications from Parkinson's disease, said his son, Michael, of Santa Monica. 
 Mr. Katz was also an authority on the detection of weapons systems and other military capabilities of cold-war opponents.
From 1941 to 1954 he played a central role in improving photographic reconnaissance equipment and systems at Wright Field, now Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, near Dayton, Ohio, becoming the chief civilian physicist of an aerial reconnaissance laboratory there.
In 1954 Mr. Katz joined the staff of the Rand Corporation, a research organization based in Santa Monica, and specialized in reconnaissance systems for airplanes and spacecraft; he was a senior scientist at Rand until 1970. Later he worked for Rand as a consultant.
He went on to become an assistant director of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, and was its ranking expert on determining how fully arms control treaties were carried out. He served with the agency from 1973 until he resigned in 1976.
John Pike, an authority on space policy who is the director of the space policy project at the Federation of American Scientists, an organization that is based in Washington, said on Thursday that Mr. Katz's "early studies made possible the reconnaissance satellites that were a mainstay of intelligence collection and treaty verification during the cold war."
Most of those studies were done at Rand in the 1950's. Mr. Pike said they were important because they "identified how one would do photographic intelligence from space."
William R. Harris, a Rand consultant who is an expert on arms control treaties, said of Mr. Katz: "In the 1950's and early 1960's, he was really the world's pre-eminent expert on the use of photographic systems in piercing cold-war secrecy. His expertise helped others in the West to construct reconnaissance systems that enabled successive Western political leaders to manage cold-war crises more effectively in the nuclear age."
Mr. Katz was born in Chicago, grew up in Milwaukee, received a bachelor's degree in 1939 from the University of Wisconsin and did graduate work at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
In 1946 he supervised the Army Air Forces' photography of the atomic bomb tests at Bikini atoll in the Marshall Islands in the western Pacific.
During the Korean War, in preparation for the successful amphibious landing of American troops at Inchon, South Korea, Mr. Katz devised a plan to measure the height of a sea wall at the harbor without alerting enemy forces of the impending attack. He did it by having airplanes take photographs of Inchon at carefully timed intervals, and then using trigonometry to calculate the height of the wall and to show that it would not be a major obstacle to the Marine Corps landing on Sept. 15, 1950.
In 1957, Mr. Katz and a Rand teammate, Merton E. Davies, advocated the use of cameras and film-recovery systems in space reconnaissance to gather intelligence about the Soviet Union from places where intelligence-gathering had not been possible before. Rand's recommendations were promptly accepted by the Air Force.
Mr. Harris said Mr. Katz "was among the earliest champions of the use of reconnaissance by spacecraft to take the place of inspectors on the ground as the main means of monitoring the implementation of proposed arms control treaties."
Mr. Katz was sometimes a critic of American reconnaissance techniques in the cold war, too. Mr. Harris said that in 1964, Mr. Katz "did a study for Walt Rostow, then the special assistant to President Lyndon Johnson for national security," in which Mr. Katz "assessed and summarized Soviet knowledge of U.S. reconnaissance, and he argued that much of what we learned, the Russians wanted us to know; and much of what we didn't learn, they wanted us not to know."
Over the years, Mr. Katz was also quick to discern possible civilian applications of reconnaissance technology -- notably in conserving water, forests and other natural resources and in helping victims of natural disasters.
Besides his son, Mr. Katz is survived by his wife of 56 years, the former Louise Klibanow; two daughters, Barbara Katz of Santa Monica and Deborah Kovar of Canoga Park, Calif.; two brothers, Yale, of Bellingham, Wash., and Matty, of Milwaukee, and six grandchildren.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Amrom H. Katz. (1993)

HEADLINE: Gov. Wilson Backs Bay Bridge Project

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 14

 BODY:
Gov. Pete Wilson announced his support of a $1.5 billion plan on Thursday to rebuild part of the 61-year-old San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge, rather than strengthen it to withstand earthquakes.
Mr. Wilson accepted the California Department of Transportation's recommendation to replace the eastern half of the bridge, a crucial commuter route that carries an average of 280,000 vehicles a day and was damaged when a 50-foot section collapsed in the 1989 earthquake. 
 "It is my belief that in order to best insure the safety of motorists and the economic integrity of the Bay Area and the state, we should proceed with the construction of a new high-tech bridge to replace the aging Bay Bridge," Mr. Wilson said.
He said he had ordered state officials to begin an environmental review for replacing the bridge's eastern span. The new section will link Yerba Buena Island, in the middle of San Francisco Bay, to Oakland. The existing western half of the bridge will remain in place and be strengthened to withstand earthquakes.

INTERNATIONAL 3-8
 
Japan Unlikely to Join U.S. In Anti-Missile System
Japan has all but decided against joining the United States in the development of an anti-missile defense project, Clinton Administration officials said. Senior officials said Japan was worried about the costs and about angering its Asian neighbors. The United States will press ahead with its own plan, they added. 3
 
Russia's Army a Catastrophe
On the heels of an appeal by Russia's defense chief for more money for the country's armed forces, a private research group in Moscow warned that the army needs urgent reform if it is not to collapse entirely. The group proposed several immediate options, including reducing the number of soldiers from 1.5 million to under 300,000. 3
 
Health Concerns in Peru
Concerns about the physical and psychological health of the 72 hostages held by Tupac Amaru rebels in Lima led to renewed calls for the Peruvian Government and the rebels to speed up talks. Aid workers laid cables to restore electricity, which had been cut off by the Government in December, so heart-monitoring equipment could be used. 6
 
Prisoner Exchange in Tajikistan
Rebels in Tajikistan began releasing hostages on Friday, easing tension a day after they announced that they had killed a prisoner. Russia's Deputy Prime Minister said he had been told that the reported killing was a bluff and that all the hostages were alive. The Tajik rebels have been holding 14 hostages, including United Nations employees and Russian journalists, and have been seeking the release of about 40 rebel fighters from Afghanistan. 3
 
Harsh Criticisms of Colombia
Stopping just short of predicting that the Clinton Administration would impose sanctions on Colombia for the second year in a row, a senior State Department official criticized the Colombian Government for "cooperating" with drug traffickers. President Clinton is to decide in two weeks whether Colombia should be "certified" as a trustworthy ally in the international fight on drugs. 6
 
Kohl's Future Uncertain
The senior lieutenant of Germany's governing Christian Democratic Union has broken the taboo over discussing whether Chancellor Helmut Kohl would run for a fifth term in national elections next year, inspiring younger members of the party to challenge their leader's policies. With unemployment at its highest rate since 1933 and polls showing the opposition Social Democrats running even with Mr. Kohl's party, the debate seemed likely to grow. 8
 
A Pittance for French Farmer
A farmer lost his three-year fight with the French Government over land surrounding the country's most spectacular prehistoric cave drawings, the state radio France Info said. A court ordered the Government to pay only about $1,750 to the farmer for land owned by his family for six generations in Pont d'Arc, in the Ardeche, a dry, rugged region in south-central France. (AP)
 
NATIONAL 9-12
 
Clinton Received Warnings On Dealings With Donors
Advisers to President Clinton and Vice President Gore warned them against maintaining ties and granting access to a group of Asian-American fundraisers and donors who sought to influence American policy, according to National Security Council documents. 1
 
Vice President Gore ignored a warning from the the National Security Council that a fund-raising luncheon at a Buddhist temple should be approached with "great, great caution." His own national security adviser raised no objections, a spokeswoman said. 10
 
Questions for Labor Nominee
A Senate committee is examining why Alexis Herman, President Clinton's nominee for Secretary of Labor, received an ownership interest in a real estate development in Washington without investing any money. The interest is now worth as much as $500,000. 1
 
Unions Offer to Return
The unions that have been on strike against The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press for 20 months made an unconditional offer to send 2,000 strikers back to work. The unions said the move was made in the hope that a National Labor Relations Board ruling would eventually require the papers to pay back wages for every day they refuse to take the workers back. 9
 
More Sex Allegations for Army
Already in turmoil because of allegations of sexual harassment of female soldiers, the Army said the problem had spread to Germany. Three male training instructors were suspended after 11 women in the service complained of sexual assault or abuse. 11
 
Adoption Efforts Endorsed
Citing concern for children who languish in foster care, President Clinton began a campaign to speed adoptions for such children. He endorsed bonus payments for states that improve their adoption rates and technical assistance to help find ways to recruit parents and place children. 12
 
A Bigger, Older Universe
Measurements of the positions of 120,000 stars by a European satellite suggest that the universe may be bigger and perhaps a billion years older than had previously been thought. The finding may solve the paradox that the universe seemed to be younger than the oldest stars. 11
 
Astronauts Upgrade Hubble
Walking in space as they worked on the Hubble Space Telescope, a pair of astronauts from the space shuttle Discovery installed two new instruments to expand its view of the cosmos. 9
 
Bulk of Tobacco Suit Dismissed
A state judge has dismissed most of the lawsuit West Virginia brought against tobacco companies to recover damages for treatment of smoking-related illnesses. The judge dismissed similar claims by the state in 1995. (AP)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

American Pilots Walk Out; Clinton Orders Them Back
President Clinton intervened moments after midnight to halt a strike by American Airlines pilots that had threatened to disrupt air travel nationwide. The action -- the first such move by a President in an airline strike in 31 years -- will keep American's planes flying for at most 60 days while negotiations continue. Mr. Clinton took the steps after refusing to tip his hand yesterday on whether he would intervene, hoping that the pressure would force the parties to agree. [Page 1.]
 
In an era of weakened labor unions, the pilots are one segment of the American work force that may be stronger than ever. The pilots' dispute represents a rare instance in which a union in the United States holds not only extraordinary power over its employer, but also over much of the country. Pilots at American and other airlines have tried to flex their muscles before, but they have much more in their favor now.
News Analysis. [1.]
 
In the hours before the strike deadline thousands of prospective passengers at Kennedy, La Guardia and Newark airports -- as well as at airports around the country -- struggled to make last-minute changes in plans ahead of a holiday weekend. [37.]
 
Canada Seeks Banking Competition
Canada plans to bolster competition in its tightly controlled banking industry by loosening restrictions on foreign banks from the United States and other countries, officials in Ottawa announced. Legislation to be introduced later this year would enable foreign banks to compete more aggressively against Canada's six large national banks in making loans, doing corporate business and offering consumer services like credit cards. [38.]
 
Shift in Detroit Newspaper Strike
Striking unions at Detroit's two newspapers -- The Detroit Free Press and The Detroit News -- planned to make an unconditional offer to send 2,000 striking employees back to work after 20 months on strike. The union said it made the move in the hope of getting back pay for the workers. The newspapers said the offer constituted an end to the strike. [9.]
 
Huge Paper Company Merger
Abitibi-Price and the Stone-Consolidated Corporation said that they would merge in a transaction valued at about $1.7 billion, creating the world's largest maker of newsprint. Paper companies have been consolidating as they struggle to overcome lower prices, overcapacity and a limited number of newsprint buyers. Combined, the two Canadian companies would have annual sales of $3.6 billion, and about 8 percent of the global newsprint market. [49.]
 
Stocks End Week With a Whimper
The euphoria that swept Wall Street into a new millennium this week ended not in a bang, but with a whimper. After gaining 574 points, or 8.9 percent, in just seven weeks, and reaching the 7,000 milestone on Thursday, the Dow Jones industrial average slumped, closing down 33.48 points, to 6,988.96. For the week, the Dow rose 133.16. [36.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities forged ahead on good economic news, but further gains were stymied by profit taking in a shortened trading session ahead of the long Washington's Birthday weekend. The yield on the newly issued 30-year bond fell to 6.53 percent, down from 6.62 percent on Thursday and down 17 basis points from the week before. [36.]
 
Dollar Closes Mixed
The dollar was mixed, touching a four-year high against the yen and 34-month high vs. the mark on benign inflation news, the ebullient stock market in the United States and more economic weakness in Germany. [48.]
 
Coffee Prices Retreat
Coffee futures prices retreated for the first time in a week on concern that production in Brazil, the world's biggest producer, would be higher than has been expected. [48.]

HEADLINE: School Budget Is Attacked As Inadequate

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Feb. 14

 BODY:
Many governors and President Clinton have pushed ambitious new education programs recently, but Gov. John G. Rowland took a different tack in the budget he presented on Thursday. He did not raise spending on state schools, he trimmed the budget for higher education and he offered a small spending increase for one of the most pressing educational issues facing the state.
Faced with an order from the State Supreme Court to desegregate and improve state schools, Mr. Rowland, a Republican, responded with $37 million in new spending. It was one of the few increases in his two-year, $20.5 billion budget proposal. 
 Today, educators, legislators and representatives of the families who brought the initial case, Sheff v. O'Neill, criticized the proposal, saying that it was too little to accomplish the monumental task at hand.
"This is rhetoric without any action," said John Brittain, a civil rights lawyer who represented the 17 families from the Hartford area that had sued the state in the Sheff case. "This is like a hamburger without any meat."
Mr. Rowland and his supporters defend his budget proposal on this issue as an important first step, but it reveals differences between him and his fellow Republican Governors in New York and New Jersey.
While Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and Gov. George E. Pataki highlighted increases in education spending in their budget proposals, as did Mr. Clinton, Mr. Rowland's budget has drawn attention for the absence of such initiatives.
Among the proposals drawing fire are these:
*State aid to public schools remained the same, even though enrollment is increasing by about 2 percent a year.
*Higher education would receive a 10 percent across-the-board spending cut.
*State aid for special education would be reduced to $30.4 million next year, about $2 million less than what is projected this year.
In contrast, Governor Whitman, also at the behest of a court order, recently approved a $286 million school financing plan, in addition to a $5 billion education budget.
Last month, Governor Pataki proposed a $309 million increase in state school aid, now $10.2 billion a year.
President Clinton's budget address included items like a large increase in school construction aid, universal access to community college education and an expansion in early childhood education.
At a news conference this afternoon, the President pro tem of the State Senate, Kevin B. Sullivan, a Democrat, said Mr. Pataki and Mrs. Whitman had taken "dramatic new steps" on education.
"We just don't see the same vision," Mr. Sullivan said. "We just don't see the same direction."
But Dean Pagani, Mr. Rowland's spokesman, disagreed.
"The economic situation in Connecticut isn't the same as in New York and New Jersey," he said.
The State Education Commissioner, Theodore S. Sergi, also defended Mr. Rowland's proposal to deal with the Sheff decision, saying it represented a promising start.
Mr. Rowland's proposal features $6 million next year to expand access to early childhood education in Hartford, Bridgeport and New Haven; $1 million to support reading instruction in urban school districts; $5 million to support a voluntary busing program, and $3 million more for summer and weekend programs that draw children from a variety of school districts.

HEADLINE: New Questions On Investments For a Nominee

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER DREW 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14

 BODY:
In a new set of questions about the nomination of Alexis Herman as Secretary of Labor, a Senate committee is examining why she received an ownership interest now worth as much as $500,000 in a real-estate development here without investing any money, Government officials said today.
Ms. Herman was given an interest in the $200 million project on Pennsylvania Avenue in the mid-1980's when she ran a consulting business that worked to insure minority participation in that project and in other such ventures. 
 People involved in the deal said Ms. Herman, who is now a White House aide, was one of three minority business owners who received small interests in the project in what they described as a fairly typical effort to meet Federal affirmative-action goals.
Ms. Herman was not a Government official then, and it was legal for her to accept part ownership in the project. But Senate Republicans are looking broadly at whether Ms. Herman, who was involved in the Democratic Party for a long time, ever blended her political activities with either her business dealings or her role at the White House, where she has directed the Office of Public Liaison since 1993. The office typically directs efforts to build grass-roots support for President Clinton's social and economic policies.
The questions about the real-estate deal have added to the troubles facing Ms. Herman's nomination, which has become caught in the furor over fund-raising practices in Mr. Clinton's re-election campaign.
In another development, the White House acknowledged today that one of Ms. Herman's deputies, Doris O. Matsui, went too far in sharing an official Government list of more than 350 Asian-American leaders with Democratic Party strategists and fund-raisers early last year.
"We would say that this probably shouldn't have been done," said the White House special counsel, Lanny J. Davis.
Mr. Davis and other White House officials insist that Ms. Herman, who was a political appointee at the Labor Department in President Jimmy Carter's Administration and the chief of staff of the Democratic National Committee from 1989 to 1991, has done nothing improper in either her business dealings or her work at the White House. White House officials said they still expect her to win confirmation to succeed Robert Reich as Labor Secretary.
The Senate Labor Committee has held off scheduling hearings on the nomination, however. The Office of Special Counsel, an independent Federal agency, also is examining whether Ms. Herman or her White House assistants engaged in improper political activities in helping the Democratic Party reach out to ethnic voters last year.
White House officials said the Senate Committee recently asked for information about Ms. Herman's involvement in the Pennsylvania Avenue redevelopment project, a huge office, retail and residential complex known as Market Square. The main developer, Herbert S. Miller, had close ties to the District of Columbia Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., and one of the minority partners ran a public relations company that employed Effi Barry, the Mayor's wife then.
One question on Capitol Hill is whether Ms. Herman was included in the project to take advantage of any ties she had to local or Federal Democratic officials.
Ms. Herman has declined to grant interviews while her nomination is pending. But a White House spokesman, Joseph Lockhart, said Ms. Herman did no lobbying on the Market Square project. Henry A. Berliner Jr., an appointee of President Ronald Reagan who was chairman of a Federal corporation that oversaw the choice of the developer, also said she played no role in that decision.
Inviting members of minority groups to join such projects at little or no cost to meet affirmative-action goals "was pretty common in any program at that time that involved the Federal Government," Mr. Berliner said. Mr. Lockhart said Ms. Herman got involved in the Market Square project in 1984 through a friend, Robert Mendelsohn, who was working with Mr. Miller.
Mr. Mendelsohn helped Ms. Herman's consulting firm, A. M. Herman & Associates, win a $205,000 contract to oversee the hiring of minority workers and contractors at Market Square, Mr. Lockhart said.
She and the two other minority partners later were each given a 3 1/3 percent interest in a limited partnership involved in the deal. Several other people also received interests in that partnership without putting up cash, Mr. Lockhart said, but there were two significant differences. Most of the others had either invested money in the project in other ways or were employees of Mr. Miller who took the interests as part of their compensation. And the minority partners were not subject to any calls to put up cash if it was needed, as the other limited partners were.
One result was that the minority partners initially were not eligible to share fully in any income from the project. When Mr. Miller decided to sell 70 percent of the project in 1987, Ms. Herman and the other minority partners each received $50,000, or one-fifth of what others holding the same interest earned.
Since then, the restrictions have been eased, Mr. Lockhart said. And although Ms. Herman has never had to invest any money in the project, the value of her remaining holding of about 1 percent has risen to possibly as much as $500,000.
Ms. Herman has listed her interest in the project on Government financial-disclosure forms since 1993 and estimated it was worth at least that much. But she was not required on the forms to give details of how she acquired the interest.
Mr. Lockhart said this was the only such project in which Ms. Herman ever received part ownership. But Ms. Herman's consulting firm also won a $500,000 contract in 1989 to create and monitor affirmative-action plans for the construction at the Government's new $1 billion Ronald Reagan Building here.
The financial-disclosure records show that in the early 1990's, Ms. Herman's company did consulting work on diversity issues for Burger King, Procter & Gamble and Levi Strauss. She sold the company after she took the White House job in 1993.
Ms. Herman's nomination ran into problems last month, when the White House disclosed that one of her assistants had invited a top banking regulator to meet with Mr. Clinton and some of the nation's most powerful bankers at a coffee sponsored by the Democratic Party. White House officials have said Ms. Herman's office was involved in setting up the coffee because of a miscommunication about the nature of the event.
Mr. Miller, the developer who put together the Market Square project and still holds an interest in it, also attended one of the White House coffees last year, and he donated $50,000 to the D.N.C. three weeks later. Mr. Lockhart said Ms. Herman did not know that Mr. Miller was at the coffee. Mr. Miller, who has long contributed to Democratic candidates, was unavailable for comment.
White House officials said that Ms. Matsui, a deputy to Ms. Herman at the White House Liaison Office, and others, including John Huang, the former Democratic fund-raiser who is under Federal investigation, used the list of Asian-Americans compiled by the office in providing Mr. Clinton's campaign with names of people who might want to help it court Asian-American voters.
The 20-page document contained the names of Asian-American civic, political and business leaders in 12 cities, and it was included in the files of Mr. Huang released by the Democratic National Committee. But Mr. Huang does not appear to have used it in his fund-raising.

HEADLINE: DISPUTE AT AMERICAN AIRLINES: THE UNION;
A Showdown Forced by the Power of a Union

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Saturday, Feb. 15

 BODY:
The pilots' dispute at American Airlines represents a rare instance in which a union in the United States holds not only extraordinary power over its employer, but also over much of the country.
So much so, in fact, that President Clinton intervened immediately after the pilots called their strike to keep the airline flying and avoid the turmoil that would have been caused by a grounding of the nation's second-largest airline. 
 In an era of weakened labor unions, the pilots are one segment of the work force that may be stronger than ever.
Pilots at American and other airlines have tried to flex their muscles before, but they have much more in their favor now. Airlines are generating record profits, meaning greater job security for pilots. That is a sharp contrast to many previous airline pilot disputes in which the threat of bankruptcy or layoffs tipped power in favor of the airlines.
Now, the balance of power is tipped against the airlines. Because pilots cannot be readily replaced, they can instantly shut down the airline, costing the company millions of dollars a day. Although American's healthy profits of late have helped fortify the carrier's war chest to survive a strike -- it has $3 billion in cash and credit available -- the company also faced the prospect of running up losses quickly.
"This dispute has been about raw leverage, and pilots are probably in a stronger position than any pilot group has been since deregulation of the industry," said Daniel M. Kasper, an aviation consultant and member of a 1993 Presidential commission to study the industry.
The pilots have also gained more leverage as a result of broad shifts in the way airlines divide up the country. Since deregulation of the industry in 1978, airlines have set up hub operations in major cities, helping the carriers gain advantages over competitors in key markets and enabling them to exercise greater control over their prices.
Increasingly, airlines like American have come to dominate major airports, controlling as much as 90 percent of the flights through key cities. American's strongholds include Dallas and Miami, where it controls about two-thirds of the flights, and to a lesser degree Chicago, where it competes against United Airlines for most of the air traffic. So when pilots threaten a strike, tourism and other industries in some cities are severely affected. That can build pressure on the airline to make concessions to the pilots.
The Transportation Department, for example, has estimated that a strike would have cost the country $200 million a day and leave 40,000 passengers stranded over the Washington's Birthday holiday weekend.
But the pilots' immense leverage has worked against them, too. With so many people affected, pressure built on governors, members of Congress and the Clinton Administration to step in to avert a strike. Such intervention did not help the pilots' cause of getting raises and other concessions, which are best extracted during a strike or just before one.
During a news conference yesterday, James G. Sovich, president of the pilots' union, said he did not want President Clinton to intervene. The reason was perhaps best detailed in a letter Mr. Sovich mailed to pilots' union members on Monday. "As I have told you before," the letter read, "plan on at least a 30-day strike. Only the absolute belief by management that such a devastating threat is not only present, but also that it will be utilized, may make AMR come to reason."
The two sides, which still have to settle their differences, represent opposing views on questions being posed by employees at many companies now benefiting from a healthy economy: How much should employees share in the profits? And should employees be viewed strictly as a cost of doing business or rather as equal partners with management?
According to the most recently publicized proposals from the two sides before the strike was announced, the pilots said they wanted an 11 percent raise over the next four years while the airline offered a 5 percent raise over the next three years. They have also been quarreling over how much in stock options the pilots should receive.
Donald J. Carty, American's president, said in a news conference shortly after Mr. Clinton averted a strike that the dispute centered on economic issues, rather than issues of job security.
With their average salary of $120,000, pilots at American, and other major airlines, are on an economic par with many managers at the company. And because pilots cannot transfer their skills to other professions -- or transfer to other airlines without losing seniority -- they have long been intensely interested in company affairs.
In the current dispute, the union has sought to sway the airline on a key strategic issue of whether the main airline or its commuter subsidiary, American Eagle, should fly smaller jets that American wants to acquire. The Allied Pilots Association, which represents pilots only at American, says its members should fly the jets. They worry that their jobs will be threatened if the jets are flown by the pilots at American Eagle, who have a different union.
The dispute between American and its pilots has been governed by strong emotions as much as debates over strategy. Although there is widespread dissension within the ranks and within leadership of the Allied Pilots Association, the union has tried to build unity by portraying Robert L. Crandall, the chairman of American and its parent company, the AMR Corporation, as a boss who is greedy.
In the pilots' union magazine, Mr. Crandall has been caricatured in a cartoon as running a staff meeting in which he urges his lieutenants to get concessions from the pilots so that he can enrich himself.
Mr. Crandall has stayed clear of direct negotiations with the pilots, clearly recognizing that his public image would be of no help. He sent the airline's president, Donald J. Carty, to Washington last fall to reach a tentative agreement with the union's leadership. Mr. Carty was successful, but members of the union voted against the agreement. Mr. Carty has also led negotiations for American this week in Washington.
Although Mr. Crandall was in Washington Thursday, and publicly asked President Clinton to intervene to avoid the strike, a spokesman for American said that Mr. Crandall remained at company headquarters in Dallas on Friday.

HEADLINE: DISPUTE AT AMERICAN AIRLINES: THE OVERVIEW;
AMERICAN AIRLINE PILOTS STRIKE BUT CLINTON ORDERS THEM BACK

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Saturday, Feb. 15

 BODY:
Invoking seldom-used emergency powers, President Clinton intervened today minutes after midnight to halt a strike by American Airlines pilots that had threatened to disrupt air travel nationwide.
The action -- the first such move by a President in an airline strike in 31 years -- will keep American's planes flying for up to 60 days, while a specially convened board develops a proposed agreement and the two parties consider it. In taking the action, Mr. Clinton said he hoped to avert "severe disruption to both domestic and international air transportation." 
 "I was also particularly concerned that a strike would be especially disruptive over a holiday weekend, when hundreds of thousands of citizens rely on our air transit system," Mr. Clinton said.
He called on the two parties to "redouble their efforts to reach an agreement; they owe that to each other and to the traveling public."
Just after midnight, James Sovich, the president of the Allied Pilots Association, addressed his members and their families via a satellite system, informing them: "We have no alternative but to exercise our right to call a strike."
Mr. Sovich said: "We have no other method of demonstrating to management that we are resolute in our commitment to receiving a fair and equitable contract agreement."
The pilots called the strike after their board rejected a last proposal from Federal mediators.
But the White House reacted almost instantly. Bruce Lindsey, the deputy counsel, rushed to the residence to obtain the President's signature on orders invoking powers Mr. Clinton has under the 1926 Railway Labor Act.
The President named a three-member panel to recommend a non-binding resolution of the dispute. The panel has 30 days to devise recommendations and the parties have another 30 days to consider them, with no work stoppage in the meantime.
By intervening, President Clinton ignored objections from the 9,000-member pilots union, which wascounting on the leverage of a strike to secure a better contract. But, had he not intervened, the tens of thousands of travelers who would have been stranded or at least inconvenienced by the strike may well have wondered why not.
Mr. Clinton took the steps after a day spent hanging back, refusing to tip his hand on Friday on whether he would intervene in hopes that the pressure of the deadline would force the parties to agree. But the airline and representatives of its pilots were unable to resolve differences over wages and whether lesser-paid pilots should be permitted to fly American's smaller, commuter jets.
Mr. Clinton named Robert O. Harris to be chairman of the three-member mediation panel. Mr. Harris, a former chairman of the National Mediation Board, previously served as chairman of a board convened by Congress to resolve the railroad labor dispute of 1981. The President also appointed Anthony V. Sinicropi, a professor emeritus of the University of Iowa and a former president of the National Academy of Arbitrators. The third member is Helen Witt, a former member of the Federal Mediation and Consultation Service.
The union emphasized that the President's action may only postpone a strike. "We may have to do this one more time," Mr. Sovich said early this morning.
Since American carries roughly 20 percent of the nation's air travelers -- and is a dominant airline in cities like Miami, Dallas, and Chicago -- a strike would have stranded travelers nationwide. While American's other unions are opposed to the pilots' efforts, the company said would not operate if its 9,000 pilots struck.
The Transpotation Department had estimated that 40,000 travelers would be stranded by a strike this weekend, and that it would ripple through the economy, costing as much as $200 million a day.
The airline was clearly delighted with the President's action. "If there's any silvery lining to the cloud," said Donald Carty, the president of American Airlines, after Mr. Clinton intervened, "the airline is operating. And we're delighted that it's operating."
But there was less enthusiasm among the pilots.
At Kennedy International Airport in Queens, Chet Smith, a 41-year-old captain, said he was "less than thrilled by the President's action."
Even before the pilots' union called their strike, the threat of such action disrupted air travel on Friday. In Miami, many grumbling passengers had given up on finding flights to Latin America and the Caribbean. With some American flights canceled and others filled, and no other airlines flying along some routes, some passengers threw up their hands and went home.
In other airports, travelers groaned about flights canceled, or they shifted to roundabout connections in places they never wanted to visit. Some wondered whether they would be able to get back from where they were going, while others scrambled for more expensive seats on other airlines.
Al Light, a 44-year-old logistics inspector, found himself stuck in Chicago Friday night without a flight home to Harrisburg, Pa. "They announced on the loudspeaker that the pilot had walked off the plane," he said. "Now I'm going to miss my plane, which means I'll miss seeing my wife on Valentine's Day."
Mr. Sovich, the union president, said on Friday that the union would comply and keep flying if Mr. Clinton chose to invoke his authority under the Railway Labor Act. But he urged that the President not do so.
"We prefer that the President not interject himself in this dispute," Mr. Sovich said.
In publicly describing -- and simultaneously trying to influence -- the state of the negotiations, both sides sounded pessimistic late Friday.
Calling the negotiations "slow and difficult," Mr. Sovich said, "We have made significant progress on insignificant issues." He did not elaborate.
Christopher Chiames, a spokesman for the airline, said: "Progress is coming, but it's coming slowly. But this is part of the give and take of negotiations. We have nothing to report as far as agreements."
The two sides have been far apart on issues of wages and staffing. AMR, the parent of American, is hoping to use small 50-seat jets in its American Eagle subsidiary to carry commuters. But the pilots' union fears that the company wants to use those jets, with lower-paid pilots, to take routes away from them. The union submitted a new, detailed eight-page proposal Thursday night for having its members also pilot those smaller planes.
With the prospect of thousands of stranded, angry passengers looking for someone to blame, the White House was at pains on Friday to try to deflect attention and pressure to the negotiators themselves. Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman, peppered with questions about Mr. Clinton's intentions at his daily briefing, finally said he would not rule Presidential action out or in.
"I'm putting the focus where it properly should be, on the negotiation itself," he said. "It should not be here."
A senior White House official said Friday night that the Administration had discovered that its slightest word affected the talks. Even a simple remark from Mr. Clinton at midday on Friday -- "I'm going to have a meeting on this later this afternoon to get an update, and then I think I should make myself available for questions after I see where we are in a couple hours" -- had an impact when the Cable News Network reported it.
"That instantly got misread and mistranslated inside the room, and basically froze things" until the White House could clear up its intentions to do nothing this afternoon, the official said. He said the White House felt "a reluctance to intervene in the labor market until you absolutely have to."
That is consistent with Mr. Clinton's past practice, although he has sometimes indulged in more jawboning and arm-twisting than he has employed in this dispute. On the eve of Thanksgiving in 1993, Mr. Clinton informally intervened in a five-day-old strike by flight attendants against American, persuading the parties to submit to binding arbitration.
This dispute seemed to sneak up not only on the White House, but also on the airline industry, where profits have been high and the labor force stable, and on American itself. Until last month, the pilots' grumbling over the commuter flights' issue was seen as source of minor, background tension.
In November, the leaders of the pilots' union reached an agreement that called for a 5 percent wage increase over four years and that options to acquire 5.75 million shares of the airline be distributed to the pilots. On average, American's pilots make $120,000 a year -- a pay scale that may equip them to survive a strike but has not encouraged lesser-paid colleagues at American to rally to their cause.
That agreement fell apart after the union rank and file voted it down in January. Last week, the pilots requested an 11 percent raise over four years and options for 7.25 million shares. They also insisted that members of their union fly all of American's jets.
The airline responded that such an agreement would raise its costs so high that it could not compete.
In addition to grappling with management, leaders of the pilots' union have had to face grumbling in their own ranks, with some pilots openly wishing for a second chance to vote on the first contract proposal and threatening to sue those who had helped torpedo it.
"I don't think it's unusual, as we approach the unknown, that there's fear," Mr. Sovich said on Friday.

HEADLINE: Detroit Newspaper Unions Offer to Go Back to Work

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

 BODY:
The striking Detroit newspaper unions announced yesterday that they would make an unconditional offer to send 2,000 employees of The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press back to work after 20 months off the job.
The move was taken, the unions said, in hopes that a National Labor Relations Board complaint against the newspapers would eventually require the papers to pay back wages for every day from this point that they refuse to take the workers back. 
 Although the offer suggests an end to the strike -- and although the papers' management considers it so -- the president of the Detroit Metropolitan Council of Newspaper Unions insisted that the strike was still on. The official, Al Derey, a Detroit teamsters leader, said that picketing would continue and that the unions would expand their efforts to discourage advertisers in publications owned by the Knight-Ridder Corporation, which owns The Free Press, and the Gannett Corporation, which owns The News.
"This is a bold new strategy to take our jobs back," Mr. Derey said. "If they do not accept this offer, then we will be going to court."
One of the six unions on strike still has to vote on the offer. A return to work by the Newspaper Guild members will require a binding vote, which has been scheduled for Sunday.
Detroit Newspapers Inc., the business and management agency for the two papers, said the unions' offer constituted the end of the strike, and management officials urged the unions to drop any ideas of continuing to bring economic pressure on the papers.
"We have heard from three of the unions who have indicated to us that they are sending us unconditional offers, and at that point, our position is that the strike is over," said Tim Kelleher, senior vice president for labor relations at Detroit Newspapers.
Mr. Kelleher repeated management's long-held view that some 1,300 replacement workers who had crossed picket lines to keep the papers publishing would not be fired to make room for returning strikers. Former strikers, he said, would be taken on as jobs opened up.
"People who are interested in coming back to work should get their names on a preferential hiring list, and we'll get them their jobs back as they become available," Mr. Kelleher said. "The idea of continuing advertising boycotts and everything else is counterproductive. The way to get people back to work is to improve sales and improve the business."
Whatever new pressure yesterday's decision by the unions puts on the employers, it also represents an acknowledgment by the unions that the country's longest active newspaper strike had failed to stop publishers' efforts at newspapers across the country to trim jobs made redundant by new technology and to streamline work rules.
Mr. Derey conceded as much yesterday when, in a statement, he said a new strategy was needed "because the current strategy has not achieved our final goal."
The six unions, including the typographers local, teamsters and Newspaper Guild, called 2,500 employees of the two papers onto the streets on July 13, 1995, after Detroit Newspapers refused to yield on plans to buy out several hundred union jobs and to reorganize the papers' distribution system.
The strikers published a successful weekly paper, The Detroit Sunday Journal, that drew advertisers away from the big dailies, discouraged readers from buying the struck papers and forced losses totaling more than $100 million last year alone. Combined daily circulation at the two papers fell to 600,000 from 900,000 before the strike.
Operating with a streamlined non-union work force, the papers reduced their losses month by month, however, and management has predicted that they would begin to turn a profit in the spring.
Throughout the strike, the unions had appealed to the stirring history of militant labor in Detroit, where, years ago, auto workers fought pitched battles to win recognition. But times and technology have changed, allowing newspapers to publish even during a strike, said Ben Burns, a professor of journalism at Wayne State University in Detroit and a former executive editor of The News.
"The issues here were the same at a lot of papers, where management was trying to get rid of featherbedding and a lot of people working at jobs that weren't really jobs," Mr. Burns said. "I think the strikers got whipped up in the romance of Detroit and trade unionism, and thought that what was true decades ago was still true today."
The strikers' best hopes now appear to lie with Thomas Wilks, an administrative law judge with the labor board in Washington. Last month he concluded hearings on a charge from the Detroit office of the labor board that Detroit Newspapers had engaged in unfair labor practices during negotiations leading up to the strike.
If Judge Wilks affirms the charge, and the unions continue to win on appeal, then the strikers will be entitled to back pay for each day the companies deny them their old jobs back -- jobs that management has said no longer exist in any large numbers.
"If the employers stick to that, they in a sense act at their peril," said Stephen M. Glasser, assistant to the regional director of the Detroit office of the labor board. "The judge's decision is appealable and it can go through the courts, and if ultimately some authority holds that this was an unfair labor strike, then that cash register has been ringing all along for the employers."
Mr. Derey estimated that Detroit Newspapers would be liable for $250,000 for every day it was found to have denied the strikers their old jobs.
About half of the reporters and editors who walked off the job eventually returned to work at the struck papers, and many others have found work at publications elsewhere. Less fortunate have been the blue-collar drivers, bundlers and laborers who had depended on the jobs eliminated by the changes in the distribution process. Some of those workers attended a rally at The Detroit Sunday Journal yesterday, condemning the back-to-work decision and calling for the strike to continue.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 20, 1997, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Saturday about a union offer to end the Detroit newspaper strike misstated the papers' financial condition. The management says that they have been profitable since the fourth quarter of 1996, not that they are expected to be profitable beginning in the spring.

HEADLINE: Where Wildlife Meets Wild Surf

BYLINE: By WARREN HOGE; WARREN HOGE is chief of the London bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
FACED with the multitudinous life choices that confront a child growing up in New York City, my son on turning 13 settled on his. He wanted to be a surfer.
My wife and I found ourselves living in the only apartment on our mid-Manhattan block where the wave heights at Pipeline and Waikiki were tracked (800 numbers to Honolulu surf shops) and where the morning greeting was "barrel and tube," the mantra of surfers describing the dreamed-of shape of a breaker. The challenge was how to accommodate this obsession of my son's along with my hope of devoting the family summer vacation to rain-forest exploration. We found a harmonious solution on the Pacific coast of Costa Rica. 
 The country has some of the largest untouched primary forests in the world and a government and population with a commitment to protecting them unequaled in Latin America. Costa Rica also figures in globe-trotting films modeled after "The Endless Summer" -- we had a large collection in our East Side apartment -- as one of the far-flung places on the planet where surf pilgrims go in pursuit of the perfect wave.
We decided on two spots, one at the tip of the remote Osa Peninsula in the south and the other on the busier coast of Guanacaste Province in the north. I had last seen the northern part of Costa Rica in 1979 where, as a correspondent, I had covered the bloody ending of the war between the forces of Anastasio Somoza and the Sandinista rebels across the border in southern Nicaragua. I pledged back then to return someday to focus on the peaceful beauty of Guanacaste's savannahs and seashore, its spreadtrees and grazing white brahma cattle.
Fought over in the 19th century by Nicaragua and Costa Rica, Guanacaste has been a conflicted part of the country in recent times. It served as a staging area for the Sandinista rebels in the 1970's, and in the 1980's it became the site of secret airstrips and supply centers for the contras who sought to oust the victorious Sandinistas from Managua.
Osa, on the other hand, had always been cut off from the world and even from the rest of Costa Rica. A dirt road linking the peninsula to the mainland was completed only in 1986.
Our group was my wife, Olivia; my son, Nicholas, the soi-disant surfer; his schoolmate Wyndham Boylan-Garnett; Wyndham's mother, Nuala Boylan, and myself. We flew to San Jose in August, where we overnighted at the Gran Hotel Costa Rica, a raffish downtown hotel with an open colonnaded restaurant looking out on the city's busiest square, where we reporters had put up in 1979.
Bordered by the Teatro Nacional, a tropical knockoff of the Paris Opera House, the square is called the Plaza de la Cultura. But not all of its denizens are opera buffs. One of them that Saturday night stole a bag with all of my family's passports, travel vouchers and credit cards.
After some hurried phone calls to start the process of getting passports replaced, credit cards canceled and copies of travel documents faxed, we set out the next day on a five-hour drive to Tamarindo, a beach community in Guanacaste famous for its waves. Our car was a rented Hyundai Galloper Exceed V6 Wagon, the kind of sturdy, four-wheel-drive vehicle recommended for the unmarked, muddy and often deeply rutted roads along the coast. The radio brought in hearty salsa, good traveling music.
If you need writing paper in Tamarindo, all you'll find is a notepad of sheets made from banana-leaf fibers. The shampoo on sale is biodegradable and carries a label, itself made of recycled paper, that assures that no animals were mistreated in the manufacture of the contents. The shorefront Hotel Las Tortugas was built with no ocean views to the south because light can distract giant leatherback turtles that use the beach there to lay their eggs.
The same hotel is headquarters to surfers who consider the beach there, Playa Grande, the finest venue in the area and many of whom also share the concern for nature. It was there that I had to abandon my East Coast notion of surfers as sun-addled, tattooed, monosyllabic layabouts. We had almost as much fun learning about their customs as we did finding out about the habits of rain-forest creatures.
Surfers are up early in the morning, and from some source somewhere the word goes out that a particular shore site is "going off" or "firing." It may be a "right" or a "left," a beach break, a point break or a reef break, the ideal time can be high tide or low tide or some point in between, the waves can be shoulder-high, head-high, overhead, double-overhead or Hawaiian-sized, the wind may be off-shore ("epic") or on-shore ("bummer") -- regardless, it's where the Jeeps with boards on their roofs and men and women in bathing suits at the wheel head as they rattle expectantly out of town, kicking up clouds of dust.
Once there, the surfers gather on the sand in motionless groups of statuary composition, silently studying the swell, the winds and the sets of large waves that come rolling in every five minutes or so. Another unuttered signal goes out, and the surfers grab their boards and plunge in.
At Playa Grande, around the bay from Tamarindo, Nick and Wyndham saw what they had been missing on Long Island. Long waves began on one side of the widely curved beach and peeled across the horizon, curling cleanly and showing nothing but a shimmering smooth surface to the morning sun until disappearing into frenzies of foam on the other side.
The boys were intimidated by the wave heights at first, but enchantment and exhilaration overcame their initial fear, and they soon were riding across the glassy wave faces. The boards they used -- known as body boards or boogie boards -- are ridden in a prone position. You are supposed to grasp the front with one hand and the side with the other, raise your chest and stare off into space uninterestedly, like a dog ornament on the hood of a pricey limousine. It's a look of arrogance and defiance, and the boys, both New Yorkers, got that part just right.
We adults, used to East Coast beaches, found the surf to be challenging but manageable. Because the waves break in expected patterns with little whitewater commotion, I found them ideal for body surfing. And there was the keen pleasure of looking back and seeing only mangrove forests, palms and banyans bursting explosively from their midst, and distant gray-green mountains with clouds lounging in the valleys.
Every time we wandered off into those forests, we got a lesson in the abundance of life that inhabits tropical shorelines. The microscopic organisms that the ocean washes over its reefs, rock and beaches feed a voluminous array of tiny creatures that in concert with plants support a vast community of crabs, snails, shrimps, iguanas, squirrels, egrets, herons and other creatures.
We were particularly intrigued by hermit crabs and the delicate orange-legged, purple-shelled crabs who make the land itself seem animate as they skitter by the thousands into their forest burrows at the approach of an intruder. Each April, these crabs make spectacular migrations to the sea to breed, with each female releasing tens of thousands of eggs, which become larvae drifting in the waves until six weeks later, when they all march inland and begin the cycle again.
WE stayed in the Tamarindo Diria, an unassuming beachfront hotel with carefully tended grounds and bungalow rooms looking out onto the Pacific. In the evening, we dined at the seaside restaurants and bars in the village, eating coriander-laced ceviche and grilled lobsters, grouper, snapper, sea bass and mahi-mahi, accompanied by rice and beans and washed down with local beer or Concha y Toro, the old reliable Chilean white. The boys drank banana con leche and rumless pina coladas. The owner of La Fiesta del Mar delighted us one night by rushing back to our table after we had ordered fish to say that a fresh supply of shrimp had just been delivered. They arrived at our table still kicking.
For high-end pleasure, we loved the food and atmosphere at the stylish Capitan Suizo. For low-end, we liked the funky Noguis Bar. Each evening we strolled back along the dirt road leading to our hotel past a pond that came alive in darkness with frogs, producing a symphony of guttural sounds with a numbing repetitiveness that would shame the most obdurate minimalist composer.
At week's end we drove back to San Jose, gave up our vehicle and caught our flight to Puerto Jimenez, the only town on the Osa Peninsula. Waiting for us by the gravel airstrip was Jonathan Seidman, a 27-year-old forestry and conservation graduate of Kent State University who has worked there as guide for five years, with whom we had made arrangements five months earlier.
He drove us into town, a laid-back frontier outpost with a soccer field, a boat dock and the only block of paved road on the entire peninsula. We bought flashlights and simple knee-high rubber boots for the rain-forest treks, then drove out along the coast of the Golfo Dulce and up muddy roads to our lodge, Bosque del Cabo.
Bosque sits in a privileged location, 500 forested feet above the Pacific. Its seven thatched-roof bungalows have porches that look out over the ocean. The beds are covered in mosquito netting, but it's a largely decorative touch. At that height, the nights are breezy and bug-free. Once a cattle pasture, the land has been gracefully landscaped with profusions of brightly colored gingers and heliconias lining the pathways from the individual lodgings to the one communal space, a dining area open to the sides.
The only contact with the outside world is by radio phone, and there is electricity only in the kitchen. Night falls early in Costa Rica in the summer, usually about 6 P.M., and from that hour on, Bosque lives by candlelight. The hiking during the day is very physical. You are apt to feel total bone fatigue and find yourself nodding off by 8 P.M. I loved the idea of reading by the light of a flickering flame in the midst of a forest, but each night I was good for only a couple of pages.
Our purpose in going to Bosque was to live in, feel and try to understand some of the complexities of the tropical rain forest, and Jon wasted no time getting us on the trail. Many times it wasn't a trail at all, but a slurry of leaves and mud and rocks, and the inclines and descents were steep. Within minutes of leaving Bosque our first afternoon, Jon announced that we were in primary forest, undeveloped, undisturbed, its reproductive cycles intact and humming.
We found ourselves at the base of immense trees, some rising 180 feet above the forest floor, closing out all but about 10 percent of the light shining down on the canopy. The sight induced a feeling of wonder and reverence. The great cathedral-like space captured the forest's mists and held them in the shards of sunlight, like fine particles of dust that hang suspended in the streaks of light shining through stained-glass windows in great naves.
The profound silence was a quietness that throbbed with activity as Jon pointed out all the life going on around us -- hummingbirds pollinating the voluptuous orange and red heliconia plants, cowtrees (so called because when cut with a knife they secrete a digestive latex), larvae of frogs and tadpoles in tightly joined leaf bases where water had collected, earnest parades of leaf-cutting ants carrying their immense burdens from trees to anthills, golden silk orb-weavers spinning perfectly symmetrical lace patterns, mimosa leaves that fold in on themselves protectively on being touched, strangler-fig vines reducing the tree they have encircled to a home for ants, moths and bats, Indian desnudio trees that continually shed their bark so that parasitic plants can't take up lodging, woodpeckers tapping away in pursuit of termites.
During our treks, giant frigate birds with their wingspans of more than six feet wheeled into view overhead. Lovely little immaculate antbirds called out to one another in sweet bell tones, laughing falcons guffawed and, in the forest counterpart to hoisting the cocktail flag, parrots, the most social of birds, gathered in flocks at day's end and raised a happy ruckus.
There are four kinds of monkeys in this part of the rain forest -- squirrel, spider, white-faced capuchin and howler -- and we saw them all. The howlers put up a sonorous groan, using their formidable sound equipment and then amplifying it with a bellows-like movement of their jowls. The spiders chatter excitedly and perform spectacular acrobatics in the trees. All of them get irritated at the presence of someone else. They shake their fist at you. They also shake tree limbs and have been known to throw things at people, ranging from fruit pits to their own feces.
We swam in waterfalls and splashed in pools in reef formations on the beach that emerge as the tide ebbs, producing a whirlpool-bath effect. We walked on beaches where the only signs of human life were our own footprints, and we hiked the forest paths in the midst of thunderstorms and marveled at how little rain fell on us.
ONE morning we were accompanied by a dazzling blue morpho butterfly that sashayed with the studied insouciance of a boulevardier showing off his chic. These were not the only popinjays out that day. Toucans and fiery-billed aracaris posed on three limbs proudly showing their golden-beaked profiles, and scarlet macaws flew by, shrieking and flashing their red plumage.
One afternoon Jon spotted a hugely feathered brown and black bird on a low tree limb. It was a giant curassow, a sight so rare that Jon demanded we take his picture with it so that his friends would believe he had really seen one.
Detached from the world, deep into the mysteries of nature in the raw, we grew to feel the kind of out-of-office sensation the best vacations deliver. But the real test of that phenomenon came when we were joined in the lodge by a Hollywood producer, Brian Grazer, whose film, "The Nutty Professor," had recently been released. He hiked and surfed and watched rosy sunsets behind thunderheads on the Pacific horizon from his porch hammock like the rest of us. Three days passed. But on the fourth day he sent someone to town to fax his studio and get the grosses.
 
Finding a perfect wave or a pristine rain forest
 
Getting There
Our four-wheel-drive sport-utility vehicle from Avis had seven seats and cost $780 a week, including mandatory insurance. Smaller vehicles, at $300 to $400 a week, do not have four-wheel-drive, which is worth considering if driving off main roads. In rainy months (September and October), roads to Tamarindo and Puerto Jimenez can be impassable. The drive to Tamarindo takes five hours, to Puerto Jimenez eight hours. Travelair has 45-minute flights to both towns from the Tobias Bolanos airport in the San Jose suburb of Pavas. The fare to each town is about $80 one way. The 45-minute trip from the Puerto Jimenez airport to Bosque del Cabo costs $25 in a taxi, usually a flatbed truck with benches.
 
Guides
Jon Seidman and a partner operate Escondido Trex in Puerto Jimenez, telephone and fax 735-5210. (The country code for Costa Rica is 506.) He charges $125 a day for groups up to four plus expenses.
 
Where to Stay
In Tamarindo, the Tamarindo Diria, telephone (506) 290-4340, fax (506) 290-4367, has double rooms with beach view that range from $99 to $133 , with breakfast.
At Bosque del Cabo, telephone and fax (506) 735-5206, there are four standard bungalows with two double beds, bathroom and outdoor cold shower for $100 single, $75 a person as a double, $65 a person as a triple and $60 a person as a quad. There are two deluxe cabins with a single king-size bed, tiled bath and more spacious balcony that cost $110 single, $85 a person double. Rates include all meals. There is also a house with solar power, refrigerator and stove that accommodates four, at $700 a week with no meals.
 
A warning to visitors on street crime
"The alarming growth in street crime reflects growing economic difficulties combined with an increasing influx of dollar-toting tourists who think they're visiting a nonviolent, democratic nirvana only to find that they are easy marks for thieves who are not interested in maintaining the country's pacific image."
This unattributed quote is posted in a part of the United States Embassy in San Jose that handles reports of thefts of passports and travel documents. That office is filled these days with everyone from doe-eyed backpackers to seasoned world travelers.
A consular information sheet published by the State Department on Dec. 3 warned travelers to buy locally valid theft insurance when renting vehicles in Costa Rica. Two Americans have been killed in robberies in the last three years, the sheet says, and there have been several other incidents directed at tourists, who are advised not to wear jewelry, to travel in groups during daylight and to carry only photocopies of their passports with them while leaving originals in their hotel's safe.
When I was a reporter in Central America in the late 1970's and early 1980's, San Jose was the "safe" city, capital of a country with no army, no desperate poverty and little history of civil strife, a pleasant escape from the more menacing places like Guatemala City, Managua and San Salvador.
We found out that things had changed when we pulled up to the Gran Hotel Costa Rica on our arrival in the country on a Saturday night to drop off the baggage in the crowded square the hotel fronts. Several men in white shirts and dark trousers busied themselves putting the bags onto a trolley, and I assumed they all worked for the hotel. Evidently one of them didn't. By the time we got to the front desk, the bag with all our passports, credit cards and travel vouchers was gone.
In the hours to follow, I was able to find out just how unremarkable the episode was in San Jose. Everyone knew the going price for an American passport ($30) and the name of the coffee shop two blocks away where the petty thieves plying this trade hang out. No one from the hotel or the police department expressed surprise or regret.
I put out the word that I was interested in paying to get our things back; after two meetings on nearby corners and the payment of $170 I managed to retrieve a notebook of no value to the burglar and to learn that the passports had probably been sold already.
