And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
BECAUSE THEY WANTED TO: Stories, by Mary Gaitskill. (Simon & Schuster, $22.) The enviable wealth of emotion and perception in these stories' characters makes them large enough for the author's inspection of women's sexual relations.
 
CHANGING ENEMIES: The Defeat and Regeneration of Germany, by Noel Annan. (Norton, $27.50.) Lord Annan's gift for anecdote, portraiture and aphorism is well displayed in this memoir of his service in British intelligence in World War II and in a conquered Germany.
 
CLOUD CHAMBER, by Michael Dorris. (Scribner, $24.) A bold novel, tracing five generations of a fictional American family that grows more multicultural with time, suggesting that the ugliness of history can be transcended.
 
COLOR-BLIND: Seeing Beyond Race in a Race-Obsessed World, by Ellis Cose. (HarperCollins, $24.) Mr. Cose, who is black, reasons that since race relations have improved, they could get still better; he offers a number of thoughtful proposals.
 
DEWEY DEFEATS TRUMAN, by Thomas Mallon. (Pantheon, $24.) Amorous configurations and public events are tightly linked in this novel, persuasively located in Dewey's Michigan hometown as the election of 1948 draws near.
 
LE DIVORCE, by Diane Johnson. (William Abrahams/Dutton, $23.95.) A wise, humane comic novel in which a freewheeling Californienne collides with French social and cultural values.
 
EVERYTHING FOR SALE: The Virtues and Limits of Markets, by Robert Kuttner. (20th Century Fund/Knopf, $27.50.) An economics journalist attacks the opinion that government can do nothing right and markets nothing wrong.
 
GLASS, PAPER, BEANS: Revelations on the Nature and Value of Ordinary Things, by Leah Hager Cohen. (Currency/Doubleday, $22.95.) Informed, meticulous historical and economic reflections on a tumbler, a newspaper and a cup of coffee, and the evocative power of each.
 
IMAGINING ROBERT. My Brother, Madness, and Survival: A Memoir, by Jay Neugeboren. (Morrow, $24.) A novelist's liberating development of two real-life themes: his brother's illness and his own struggle to manage it.
 
THE REICHMANNS: Family, Faith, Fortune, and the Empire of Olympia & York, by Anthony Bianco. (Times Books/Random House, $30.) A nicely balanced study, by a Business Week writer, of an ultra-Orthodox and ultra-rich Jewish family.
 
WILLIAM FAULKNER AND THE TANGIBLE PAST: The Architecture of Yoknapatawpha, by Thomas S. Hines. (University of California, $35.) Splendidly illustrated, this deft survey by an architect and historian enhances Faulkner's own use of the resonance of particular time and place.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 28; Column 2; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 961 words

HEADLINE: Crime

BYLINE: By Marilyn Stasio 

 BODY:
Like those ubiquitous bottle caps clustered around bus stops, Lawrence Block's crime novels are embedded in the streets of New York City. It takes more than an eye for local color or an ear for the vulgate to capture that feeling of ground-in grit that surfaces in EVEN THE WICKED (Morrow, $23), Mr. Block's 13th Matt Scudder mystery. It takes a certain sensibility to appreciate the animal comforts of a gin mill like Jimmy Armstrong's and to hear the music in two guys talking the same language:
" 'We have to talk,' he said. 
 " 'I was on my way over.'
" 'Don't come here. There's that coffee shop I met you once, Greek place, Eighth between 44th and 45th. I forget the name, they changed it when they redecorated, but it's the same place.'
" 'I know the one you mean. The east side of Eighth.'
" 'Right.' "
To put it another way, it takes a writer like Lawrence Block to find the humor, the horror and the only-in-New-York absurdity of a vigilante serial killer who calls himself "the Will of the People" and who includes a drama critic on his hit list of mobsters and child molesters. (David Letterman, of course, comes up with his own Top 10 list for this "urban folk hero.") The story has some sharp angles and the usual fancy footwork from our intrepid private eye. If anything feels a bit off, it's the class of New Yorker claiming Mr. Block's attention and wit: too many talky lawyers, reformed drunks, self-important journalists -- the sort of people who would step right over a bottle cap.
Who are you? Anyone who can't give an honest answer to that basic question might well get the wind up and disappear -- "like a spider, gone without a trace, leaving a perfect web behind." But when such a disappearance occurs in a rigid society like Japan's, as is the case in Miyuki Miyabe's deep and moody mystery ALL SHE WAS WORTH (Kodansha International, $22), the loss of face can be devastating.
Not even Shunsuke Honma, a senior police inspector idling at home after an injury, can fully grasp the significance of the crimes of desperation that he uncovers when he begins a search for his nephew's missing fiancee. After establishing that the lovely and elusive Shoko Sekine once declared "consumer bankruptcy" (incurred by imprudent credit card use), Honma does more digging and discovers that she has stolen another woman's identity and history, maybe even her life. The spare style and measured pace of Alfred Birnbaum's translation suit Honma's painstaking investigative methods and the somber tone of Ms. Miyabe's searching theme -- the value of the individual in a consumer-mad economy that punishes debt with ruin and disgrace, even death.
Stephanie Plum is having a job crisis. In THREE TO GET DEADLY (Scribner, $24), another rollicking chapter in the madcap career of Janet Evanovich's sassy bounty hunter, top pros like Ranger, Stephanie's mentor, get to bring back the "howling-dog" lunatics who skip out on $500,000 bail. Left with the chump change, our favorite Jersey girl (big hair, great bod, fresh mouth) is stuck with the unpopular assignment of tracking down Uncle Mo, a beloved candy-store owner who was nabbed for packing a gun. (The neighbors don't deny that Uncle Mo broke the law by "carrying concealed," but as Stephanie's grandmother sagely notes, "it wasn't one of those laws we care much about.") A pariah around town, Stephanie teams up with a savvy ex-hooker named Lula for a manhunt that turns nasty when a local drug dealer is shot dead in Uncle Mo's shop. As more dealers with connections to Uncle Mo are knocked off, Stephanie becomes so rattled that she dyes her hair orange. But even this fashion blunder looks good on the adorable klutz, whose manic excesses are an indelible part of her charm.
When Bill Moody writes about dead jazz musicians, you can hear the blue notes bouncing off the walls. THE SOUND OF THE TRUMPET (Walker, $21.95) pays homage to the real-life trumpet player Clifford Brown, whose shooting-star career ended when he was killed in a car crash on the Pennsylvania Turnpike in 1956. When lost tapes of Brownie surface in Las Vegas, it's not exactly the Holy Grail for jazz buffs (that would be a cylinder recording of the fabled New Orleans cornet player Buddy Bolden), but it's enough to get one collector killed. Evan Horne, the jazz pianist who plays sleuth in this cool series, is less concerned with finding the killer than with determining the authenticity of the tapes, so he spends his quality time hunting down old sidemen with long memories, whose voices, raspy and real, conjure ghostly musicians and sounds from the grave. In this context, the murder mystery becomes an afterthought, like some improvisational theme behind the melody.
Greg Iles's suspense thriller MORTAL FEAR (Dutton, $24.95) swells the lists in the growing subgenre of cyber-crime fiction, and like many of these machine-driven novels, it's a lot more complicated than it needs to be. Besides being a computer genius, the monster surfing the Internet for victims in this gory story also has formidable knowledge of microsurgery, psychology, Eastern religions and apocalyptic literature. Harper Cole, the hacker-hero who cuts him down, is no less self-absorbed. This digital wizard, who works from a farmhouse in the Mississippi Delta, is alerted that something sinister is afoot when several female clients drop off EROS, the erotic on-line service for which he is a systems operator. When the cyber-stalker proves too slippery for the F.B.I., Cole logs on to EROS in the guise of a woman and pursues the killer himself. Despite the artifice of the characters operating it, the technology involved in their ingenious computer chase -- which gives new meaning to the term "network" -- is fascinating.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 4; Column 5; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 272 words

HEADLINE: 'Everything for Sale'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The central argument in Robert Kuttner's book "Everything for Sale" (review, Jan. 26), that free markets often fail, is correct only if one asks, "At what?" The purest free market in economics, that which existed prior to civilization, had no economic imperfections but myriad political imperfections. It operated with optimum efficiency according to the law of the jungle. The political market came into existence as a mechanism to improve upon the law of the jungle. The history of civilization has been a history of the intersection of political markets and economic markets. 
 Government should be at a minimum when there is minimum need for government, usually in periods of extended peace and prosperity. Government should be at a maximum when there is maximum need for government, in periods of war and depression. Because wars and economic contractions cannot be predicted with very high degrees of certainty, government cannot be downsized below certain minimum levels of national security and social security -- a safety net.
Mr. Kuttner's work is useful in reminding us of the many successes of government. It would be more useful if he would simply recognize there is a law of diminishing returns on tax policy, on spending policy and on regulatory policy. The political marketplace should produce leaders who are able to tell when we are taxing too much, when we are spending too much on national or social security and when regulation creates more problems than it solves. It is when that marketplace fails us that the economy most often gets into trouble.
 
Jude Wanniski
Morristown, N.J.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 22; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 2924 words

HEADLINE: UNDER A BARE BULB

BYLINE: By Frank Bruni; Frank Bruni is a reporter for the Metro section of The Times. His most recent article for the Magazine was a profile of Andrew Wylie.

 BODY:
The evening's performance of Henrik Ibsen's "John Gabriel Borkman" has ended, and audience members have begun to disperse into the chill London air when a gray-haired woman in an awkward black dress materializes in the lobby of the Royal National Theater. She holds a blue bucket trimmed with silver tinsel, and the way she tilts it forward, combined with the beseeching look in her eyes, signals that she is collecting alms for something -- maybe the poor, maybe even herself. It seems a safe bet that she has wandered in from the windswept banks of the Thames on this night shortly before Christmas to seek out holiday-season good will.
But a closer inspection corrects that impression, bringing a gasp of surprise. It's Vanessa Redgrave, fresh off the stage, still in her turn-of-the-century costume, still enveloped by her character's aura of loneliness and desperation. Plastic snowflakes from the play's final scene fall from her wig as she nods to the people who draw near, encouraging their approach. What they want is an autograph or a better look, but they clearly feel obliged in the bargain to pony up a few pence for the refugee organization identified on her bucket. The actress is offering them a trade: a brush with theatrical greatness for a recognition, if only fleeting, of suffering in the world. 
 It is a deal she has been making almost her entire professional life, and it has exacted its costs. Although Redgrave has long been regarded as one of the world's most accomplished, fascinating actresses, her insistence on exploiting that renown for political purposes has often alienated peers and audiences; there were long periods during which the roles offered Redgrave did not reflect her stature or talent. This is not a subject she enjoys discussing, but it is broached during a late dinner, just a few ticks before midnight, as she savors a glass of red wine and the remains of a wearying day.
"It bothered me," she says of the years she found herself ostracized for her activism, mostly on behalf of Palestinians. Her smoky voice, coarsened by Silk Cut cigarettes, has dropped to a whisper, her hint that the conversation is getting too personal, too close. "It bothered me a lot."
Redgrave turned 60 last month. This week, previews begin at the Joseph Papp Public Theater in Manhattan for a new production of Shakespeare's "Antony and Cleopatra," directed by Redgrave and starring her as the legendary heroine who realizes too late, clutching an asp to her breast, that she has misspent her passions. But what of Redgrave's passions, and of the price she has paid for them? Does she have any regrets?
I went to see her in London with these questions in mind. For four days I trailed after her, cadging conversations in dressing rooms and taxicabs and wherever else she was likely to halt the perpetual motion that defines her jumbled careers as thespian, humanitarian and provocateur.
And I listened to her talk: about the stamina of fascism in the world, the confusion at the close of a millennium, the social utility of theater and the transcendent importance of art. As she droned on, I despaired that she would ever tell me what I really wanted to know. Then, finally, I realized that she had, not directly but indirectly, in the digressions and diatribes of a woman so caught up in the history and struggles of others that she seems almost indifferent to her own.
 EDGRAVE ENTERS HER SEVENTH decade with a burst of theatrical and cinematic activity. In addition to "Antony and Cleopatra," she has roles in three movies scheduled for release this year. The first, due later this month, is "Smilla's Sense of Snow," based on the best-selling Danish mystery by Peter Hoeg, to be followed by "Mrs. Dalloway," an adaptation of the novel by Virginia Woolf, and "Wilde," a biography of Oscar Wilde.
This lineup seems infinitely more worthy of Redgrave than some of her projects in recent years, when she popped up in such unexpected places as a cheesy thriller titled "Mother's Boys," featuring Jamie Lee Curtis as a would-be soccer mom gone round the bend, and a pro-forma TV docudrama titled "Two Mothers for Zachary," with Valerie Bertinelli as a lesbian.
Redgrave offers high-minded rationales for this work, pronouncing the social issues instructive or the characters unique, but some peers submit a less ennobling explanation. Redgrave needs the money, they say, because she earned little during her exile, insists on doing low-paying theatrical productions like "Borkman" and "Antony and Cleopatra" whenever possible and continues to pump much of her income into causes.
"She hasn't got a penny to her name," says Katharina Wolpe, an English pianist who is a close friend. "She hasn't got a bean." Her two-bedroom walk-up in London is unremarkable, with a bare bulb on a cord serving as the fixture in the foyer, and she shivered through one of the mornings I spent with her rather than let the drizzle dirty her one good winter coat, just back from the cleaners. The best way to barter for more time with Redgrave, I learned, was to offer to pay for a taxi or meal.
Friends say that her three children -- the actresses Natasha and Joely Richardson, and Carlo Nero, an aspiring movie maker -- badger her about her finances, with slightly more success in the last few years. Proof of that, they say, is her surprising appearance last year in "Mission: Impossible," a film with dubious social value. "She really knows that she needs money at the moment," says Eileen Atkins, her co-star in "Borkman." "At 60, you begin to get worried about whether you have anything in the bank."
Redgrave has softened in other ways as well. When her own children were growing up, she was often absent, dashing off to demonstrations. Her 1994 autobiography, "Vanessa Redgrave," includes a passage in which she tells a young, tearful Natasha that Mommy must go because "many children could not live a happy life with their parents because of the injustice and cruelty of our society." But, friends say, Redgrave dotes on her four grandchildren. Atkins recalls the time Redgrave took Joely's daughter, Daisy, 4, to the Royal National Theater and let her dance giddily amid the fake snowflakes used in the production of "Borkman." "She's enchanting with her grandchildren," Atkins says. "She must be the best grandmother in the world."
But in her energy and enthusiasms, Redgrave seems to defy age. Linked in the past with Tony Richardson, Franco Nero, Warren Beatty and Timothy Dalton, she is currently rumored to to be involved with David Harewood, the 31-year-old black actor who plays Antony to her Cleopatra. (Redgrave refuses to speak of romances, while Harewood says merely, "Sometimes, I'll be watching in the wings and get so transfixed by her I miss my cue.") And if Redgrave is now making fewer waves, it is not because she has surrendered her political zeal. She just happens to be channeling it, for the moment, in less controversial directions.
She travels frequently to the former Yugoslavia as a special envoy for Unicef; she presides over the International Artists Against Racism, a group that pressures European Governments to relax laws against third-world refugees seeking asylum. While it has been many years since Redgrave ran for Parliament on a Trotskyist ticket, she does not rule out the possibility of doing so again. There is certainly reason enough in the miseries she sees everywhere she looks.
 "THEY COME FROM CHINA," REDGRAVE IS saying over her shoulder as I hustle to keep pace with her. She is guiding me through a former Baptist church in London now being used as a refugee shelter, her broad-shouldered, six-foot frame lunging forward, a severe figure with a mannish haircut colored a vaguely punk orange. "From Russia," she says. "From Africa, especially Nigeria, because of the regime."
This recitation does not come in response to any particular question. Redgrave is simply playing teacher to a captive student. "From Algeria," she continues. "From Afghanistan. From everywhere, everywhere." It is nearly 11 P.M., and most of the young men are visibly baffled by who she is and why she is there. But one of them, a 37-year-old man from Zanzibar named Islam, seems to recognize her and says, "Thank you." Redgrave clutches his hand for a few seconds, then releases it to hold her fist up in a gesture of solidarity.
The next day, she whisks me to another shelter and again unfurls a litany of deprivations: about the 850 refugees that she says are being kept in prison for no reason, about the two pounds a day with which refugees are expected to feed themselves. Redgrave has clearly decided that if she is going to let a journalist hang around, she is going to make it matter. It is my first clue to her refusal to see anything, even an interview, as exclusively personal or professional.
She has never been content to define herself only, or even primarily, as an actress, a craft she gravitated toward naturally. Her parents, the late Michael Redgrave and Rachel Kempson, were luminaries on the English stage, and all three of their children -- Corin, Vanessa and Lynn -- followed in their footsteps. But Michael Redgrave passed on to his children a legacy of social activism as well -- and it made a particularly strong impression on Corin and Vanessa. No sooner was Vanessa making a name for herself as a performer than she was earning a reputation as a rabble-rouser. In between racking up awards and nominations in the 1960's for such movies as "Morgan!" and "The Loves of Isadora," she grabbed headlines for protesting the war in Vietnam and sounding calls for nuclear disarmament.
There are myriad theories about what propelled Redgrave in this direction, beyond the example of her father and an innate concern of her own for people in danger or need. Maybe the revelation of her father's furtive homosexuality made her acutely sensitive to the pain of oppression. Maybe class guilt fueled her embrace of Marxism. Maybe intellectual insecurity about emphasizing the arts over academics at an early age forced her to overcompensate, turning to radical politics to assert her seriousness.
Whatever the cause, Redgrave's crusades began to get her into real trouble when she backed the quest of Palestinians to wrest territory from Israel for a homeland. She financed a documentary, "The Palestinians," in which she danced with a Kalashnikov rifle. Then, accepting an Academy Award for her performance in the 1977 movie "Julia," she denounced the "Zionist hoodlums" demonstrating outside the auditorium. Jewish leaders in particular voiced outrage, and Redgrave felt the sting of it in dwindling career opportunities. Although she possessed the versatility and beauty that would later give Meryl Streep first crack at almost all the best female leads in movies, Redgrave virtually vanished from centerpiece roles in popular cinema and saw several Broadway engagements canceled.
"It was most difficult for her at what should have been the height of her career, in her late 30's and early 40's, and that was the tragic loss," says James Ivory, who cast her in "The Bostonians," a 1984 film. Still, Redgrave hardly made it easy for him. Ivory recalls that during a meeting to discuss the role he wanted her to play, she abruptly changed the topic to the Workers Revolutionary Party, hitting him up for a donation.
"Her voice got deep and remote," Ivory says. "It was like an oracle coming out of a cave. I found myself in this grotesque position of writing out a check for $50 for a political party whose whole mission was to overthrow practically every institution in Western civilization. But there was no way around it."
 HERE IS IS STILL NO WAY AROUND it. My first night with Redgrave, the talk turns to her peculiar status in movies in the 1990's as the queen of the walk-through so subtly breathtaking it both exalts and eclipses everything around it. In "Howards End," her meandering survey of a garden becomes a wordless meditation on the warring currents of satisfaction and sorrow in a life almost over. In "Smilla's Sense of Snow," the way she clutches a Bible portrays religious conviction as an amalgam of idealism, escapism and pure madness. What Redgrave does, less through technique than an ineffable gravity of spirit, is communicate a character's entire history in an evanescent moment.
Redgrave remarks that she commands no more money for movies today than she did in the 1960's, but reasons that this is the inescapable fate of so many people her age. I assume she is speaking of actors, but she defiantly corrects me. "You name it: taxi drivers, shopkeepers, whatever," she says. "They're earning exactly the same in real value terms as they did in the 1960's."
The comparison strikes me as delusional: the money struggles of the average worker are not volitional, while Redgrave could solve her own by making two movies like "Mission: Impossible" a year and cutting back on charity. That she doesn't do this is admirable, perhaps even noble, but a choice nonetheless, and that distinction often seems lost on Redgrave as she perfects her posture, equal parts studied and sincere, as a woman of the people.
When I comment that her West London neighborhood seems charming, she launches into a soliloquy about the way rising rents and convoluted parking regulations are driving store owners away. When the subject of music comes up, she says that John Lennon's "Imagine" is her favorite song "because of what it says: 'Imagine there's no countries.' " Redgrave is like a broken record, forever spinning lyrics of injustice and insurrection.
She has been in that groove for a long time. Her autobiography depicts an ideologue for whom circumstances change but the song remains the same. Her account of the birth of Natasha Richardson, her first child, becomes a rant against unnecessary painkillers and Caesarean sections in capitalist societies intent on profit. More than two decades later, when Redgrave accompanies a pregnant Joely Richardson for a uterine scan, simple joy over the imminence of a grandchild surrenders to moral outrage that while medical technology improves, "governments pursue policies that have already led to a worldwide economic disaster."
"It's very, very unrelenting," says Robert Fox, an English theatrical producer who was married for several years to Natasha Richardson. With most actors, he says, "it's a phase, and then they marry Ted Turner." With Redgrave, it is an identity that has ossified into hard, cold granite.
In fact, it is Redgrave's art, not her activism, that she says she occasionally questioned, wondering if it were important enough. "I did always feel that theater was important, but I didn't realize that it was absolutely vital to civilization until about 1992 or 1993," Redgrave says, explaining that theater provides both moral lessons and psychic balm in times of hardship. "I think theater is as essential to civilization as safe water," she says.
Through such reasoning, she has transformed her work with the Moving Theater -- a politically minded, ethnically diverse company that she and several other actors in England founded two and a half years ago -- into a public service of the highest order. This is where her current production of "Antony and Cleopatra" had its genesis. Redgrave conceives Shakespeare's narrative as a commentary on imperialism triggered by events around him, and thus sets the play in the Elizabethan era, "which is very close to ours in many, many ways," Redgrave says. "Assassination is the order of the day in every country. There are millions being impoverished, war everywhere." Her fascination with the part of Cleopatra, which she has scaled three previous times, turns out to be as much didactic as it is dramatic.
But what of the simple thrill and beauty of a thing well done, of a role expertly realized? Do these mean nothing to Redgrave? One afternoon, over coffee, I remark that it must feel like an extraordinary privilege to be blessed with such an artistic gift. She bows her head, falling silent. When she looks up, her usually flinty gaze is dewy, and I sense, for the first time in many hours with her, that I am seeing something candid and intimate.
So I revisit the topic on my last night with her, over dinner at an Indian restaurant. I observe that during a curtain call for "Borkman," tears welled in her eyes, and that after all these years, the applause seemed as important to her as ever.
"It means even more to me," Redgrave says. But then, predictably, the oracle emerges from the cave, veering off toward some impersonal horizon with the words: "Maybe it's because I've realized all that theater can mean to people." For Redgrave, pride in her own accomplishment would be venal and mundane; she is caught up in larger forces and higher purposes, seeing herself as a vessel for the good of humankind.
I understand then that for a woman who still defends the hoisting of that Kalashnikov rife as "destiny," who defines the characters she plays by the political and scientific climates in which they lived, who believes that a person does not so much march toward barricades as be beckoned by them, second thoughts and second guesses -- let alone regrets -- are luxuries best avoided. Redgrave seems safe from them even at this late and lonely hour, on the far side of midnight, as an air of exhaustion settles over her and exaggerates the stoop in her shoulders, already sagging from the weight of the world.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 3; Column 4; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 672 words

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY;
CYBERSCOUT

BYLINE: By L.R. SHANNON 

 BODY:
It is possible to get travel information on the World Wide Web by using a search engine like Alta Vista, Yahoo or Lycos. It is also bound to be time-consuming and probably fruitless. Luckily, several companies have already done the preliminary work.

BUSINESS OR PLEASURE
Landseer Online
http://www.landseer.com
 Landseer Online describes itself as a source for the international business traveler, but you don't have to be traveling on business to use it. It contains four main divisions -- message center, information, services and products -- plus subdivisions and additional sites of potential interest. You can get exchange rates and weather information, ask questions or provide answers, plan a trip and, of course, buy stuff.
Since I was about to play host to guests from Aarhus, Denmark, I imagined that I was thinking of making a trip there. In the information category I selected world facts, and got the World Factbook produced by the Central Intelligence Agency, a Government publication widely available both in print and on Web sites. I selected Denmark and saw a small black-and-white map, followed by a presentation divided into geography, people, government, economy, trans portation, communications and defense forces. It was too long to read on screen while the meter was ticking, but it would be easy enough to download a copy and read it later or print it out. 
 There were some nice touches. That Denmark's land area is 42,370 square kilometers hardly paints a picture in one's mind, but that it is "slightly more than twice the size of Massachusetts" does.
Next I tried destinations, which turned out to be a link to the City.Net site. I selected Denmark, then Aarhus, then travel and sights. That led to a large new listing. After a couple of failed tries, the Daimi Guide to Aarhus appeared, a comprehensive guidebook with the touchingly honest admission that it, like any such guide, "will always be more or less outdated."
Three attempts couldn't raise the exchange-rates site, so I switched to Trip Planner, which promises to "lead you through a series of checklists where you tell us your destination and exactly what you want in the way of hotels, restaurants, travel info and more." The choices are used "to build a personalized guide that you can print out for easy reading or to take with you on your trip."
I did not go through the checklists, but I did look at the destinations offered. There were 65, from Acapulco to Washington; Aarhus was not among them. Copenhagen was there, and it should do. Denmark, as everyone knows, is only about twice the size of Massachusetts.
 
WORK IN PROGRESS
Biztravel.com
 http://www.biztravel.com
 When you buy a book, magazine or newspaper, you expect it to be finished. Publishers do not put out such things before they are complete, although the realities of deadlines, production schedules and human frailties may mean they are less than perfect.
Web sites, however, intentionally go on line in an incomplete state, since they can be changed so much more quickly and easily than traditional printed media.
Biztravel.com, which started late last year, is, like Landseer, intended for the business traveler. When I checked in earlier this month, the three main components -- Biztraveler, an on-line magazine; bizcityinfo, and bizmiles, which keeps tabs on frequent-traveler miles -- were more or less complete. Two other sections were not: bizreservations was in "final beta testing" and V.I.P. lounge was "coming soon."
Travel Alerts contained timely information about airports, roads and weather in the United States. Travel News consisted of short reports about airlines and airports, car rentals and the like.
Bizcity was still in progress. From two lists of cities, divided into American and foreign, I selected Copenhagen and got a short profile with two photographs. A click on the hotels section of a subsidiary menu brought a pretty good listing. Biztravel.com is worth keeping an eye on. L.R. SHANNON

HEADLINE: Q. & A.

 BODY:

Sponsor's Selling a Co-op Unit
 
Q I am currently renting an apartment from the sponsor of a building converted to a co-op in 1985. Before my occupancy in 1995, there were renters in my apartment for at least 10 years. The sponsor currently owns 59 of the 288 units in the building. I am interested in purchasing my apartment. What criteria does a sponsor use to determine if he should continue to rent or to sell an apartment? Do the rest of the shareholders have any say in the matter? Is it in their interest for the sponsor to sell? . . . Cheri Mersey, Manhattan.
 
A Donald M. Klein, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, explained that in the situation described, the sponsor is most likely considered a "holder of unsold shares," a legal designation that carries with it certain special rights.
For example, Mr. Klein said, while co-op shareholders usually have to obtain the consent of the co-op board before renting or selling an apartment, a holder of unsold shares needs no such permission. And though a holder of unsold shares must allow rent-controlled and rent-stabilized tenants to remain in their apartments at their regulated rents, Mr. Klein said, any tenants who succeed such regulated tenants can be charged free-market rates for their apartments. 
 As a result, he said, the criteria a sponsor uses to determine whether to rent or to sell an apartment are typically driven by simple economics. "If the rent is high and the maintenance is low," Mr. Klein said, "then it's probably a nice investment to keep."
In other words, he said, if the rent being collected on an apartment exceeds the maintenance charges being imposed by the co-op, then the sponsor has little incentive to sell the unit -- particularly if a sale would result in a taxable gain for the sponsor. Moreover, Mr. Klein said, although shareholders in a co-op have little control over a sponsor's right to rent or sell, the sponsor's decision can indeed have a significant impact on those shareholders.
"If the sponsor holds too many unsold shares," he said, "banks will be hesitant to lend in the building."
As a result, Mr. Klein said, it is in the best interest of shareholders to have as many owner-occupied units in the building as possible.
In fact, at least one co-op, 200 East 16th Street Housing Corporation in Manhattan, has taken its sponsor to court for failing to sell units. James G. Samson, the lawyer who handled the case for the co-op, said it was settled out of court when the sponsor agreed to sell a certain number of units each year.
 
Moving-Out Fees In Co-op Buildings
 
Q When my friend was moving from a rental apartment in a co-op building, she was told that there was a new house rule that required a $300 deposit to cover any damage to the elevators or hallways that might occur while moving out. However, even if there was no damage done, only $200 would be returned. The remaining $100 was going to be used for upkeep of the newly renovated areas of the building. I can understand a deposit against damage, but can the board's keeping of the $100 be legal? . . . Jean H. Dorsett, Manhattan.
 "As a general rule, co-op boards are given wide discretion in the imposition of fees relating to their co-op tenancies," said Dean M. Roberts, a Manhattan lawyer who specializes in co-op and condominium law. "As long as the rule imposing the fee is enacted pursuant to the bylaws and is uniformly applied to all shareholders, then the fee would most likely be found to be legal."
However, Mr. Roberts said, there may be some question as to who is responsible for paying the fee because such fees can only be assessed to shareholders by the co-op.
Generally, Mr. Roberts said, a rental tenant in a co-op would be required to pay a fee assessed by the co-op only if the terms of the agreement governing the tenancy required it. Tenants renting from sponsors, Mr. Roberts said, are even less likely to be responsible for such fees because the sponsors themselves are usually not required to pay them. And finally, Mr. Roberts said, such fees cannot be imposed on rent-controlled or rent-stabilized tenants -- regardless of whom they are renting from -- because the fees would be considered rent overcharges.
