HEADLINE: A Federal Grant for Greenwich Avenue?

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH 

 BODY:
FASHIONABLE stores and restaurants as well as a boulevard-like air have caused Greenwich Avenue to be thought of as Fairfield County's version of Fifth Avenue. Indeed, with a Saks Fifth Avenue store and a goodly number of specialty shops catering to the tastes of the affluent, Greenwich Avenue and its side streets may be the toniest shopping district in Connecticut.
So, to many of Greenwich's residents, the news that town officials might be getting a $500,000 Federal grant to help finance the face lift of one block of the mile-long shopping thoroughfare came as something of a surprise and left many townspeople bemused. A Federal grant to beautify a piece of Greenwich Avenue? Surely, someone is jesting or there's some mistake. 
 It is no joke and no mistake. Officials of the state's most affluent community are serious about seeking a Federal grant for half a million dollars for the portion of the avenue between Lewis and Elm streets, and perhaps millions more to upgrade the rest of the avenue with new sidewalks, street lights, benches and potted plants, along with more trees. But in the opinion of some members of the 240-member Greenwich Representative Town Meeting, which must vote on such a proposal, the beautification of Greenwich Avenue is far from being a high-priority item.
"Can you imagine the reaction if people in Greenwich picked up The New York Times and read that Beverly Hills was getting a half-million dollar Federal grant for palm trees to be planted along Rodeo Drive?" said James Boutelle, a member of the R.T.M. "Well, I think some people might think that giving Greenwich that much Federal money to beautify Greenwich Avenue would be similar."
"The avenue does need some improvements -- mostly sidewalk repairs -- but I don't think we need ornate street lamps and expensive benches," said Mr. Boutelle, who is the vice chairman of the town's Community Development Block Grant program. "Certainly such money can be spent on far more important things, like schools and low- and moderate-income housing, which we need in Greenwich contrary to popular thought."
But town officials, including First Selectman Thomas Ragland, maintain that Greenwich Avenue, for all its cachet, needs a face lift, and that improvements on the block between Lewis and Elm -- where the Saks store opened last fall -- would be a start.
"Giving a face lift to Greenwich Avenue is distant in the sense of town priorities -- school projects and new sewers, for example, are much more important -- but while it may not be our biggest concern, it will be the most controversial," said Mr. Ragland, who is an architect and planner. "And while Greenwich Avenue may be at its zenith now -- I don't think you'll find a vacancy on the avenue -- it's best to do your work in such a situation when a place is at its peak."
Mr. Ragland continued: "Also, we send tons of money to the Federal Government and to the state every year, so why shouldn't we get some of it back?" The First Selectman noted, however, that if Greenwich did request and receive a Federal grant, the money would not be available until the next fiscal year, which begins on July 1.
Town officials point out that Federal funds are available for such purposes.
"Some may argue that we should not tap into such funds, but the money is specifically earmarked for streetscape improvement," said the town's Public Works Commissioner, Marcos Madrid, in referring to the Federal Intermodal Surface Transportation Enhancement Act (I.S.T.E.A. and usually referred to as "Iced Tea"), which allocates funds to municipalities for improvements.
John Pugliese, a chairman of the Greenwich Architectural Review Committee and a member of the Greenwich Avenue Enhancement Committee, agrees with Mr. Madrid. "In the past, we've done repairs on the avenue in bits and pieces, and that's been unsatisfactory," said Mr. Pugliese, who is an architect and a real estate broker. "What we need is a master plan for the whole avenue, and this would be a start. But the townspeople are going to have to buy into the project."
That could add up to a sizable amount of money. Leslie Peoples of Vollmer Associates -- the Manhattan-based firm of engineers, architects and planners that has drawn up a master plan for sprucing up the entire avenue -- said the overall cost would be $3.7 million.
The first block's rehabilitation alone is estimated at $750,000; town officials hope that $500,000 would come from the the Federal Government. The plan drawn up by Vollmer Associates calls for installation of street lamps similar to those that graced the avenue more than 50 years ago, along with cast-iron and wood benches.
To many residents of Greenwich, the avenue -- and its police officers directing pedestrian and vehicular traffic -- looks just fine already. "I love it as it is," said Lisa Vitiello, whose restaurant, Mare e Monte, is on the block targeted for the initial improvements.
On the other hand, she said, "I would be willing to contribute as long as the cost is not prohibitive."
Mrs. Vitiello, like several other business owners interviewed, regards inadequate parking space as a "far bigger concern."
"There's been a big drop-off in the customer count on the avenue because there aren't enough places to park," said Irving Grannick, who has owned Grannick's Pharmacy on Greenwich Avenue since it opened 55 years ago. "I don't think a face lift is going to bring people back. It's the lack of parking that keeps people away. We're making more and more deliveries because people call and say they can't find parking places."
Jerry Baxendale, the owner of the D. W. Rogers department store (which has been on Greenwich Avenue since 1890) said, "Greenwich Avenue is a very unique street and I'd be willing to contribute toward improvements, but we have to be conservative about it."
Some Greenwich residents feel that spending millions of dollars to enhance an already-attractive thoroughfare does not make sense in light of other needs. "The cost could be staggering, even with Federal help," said John Anner, a lawyer and the chairman of the Finance Committee of the Representative Town Meeting.
"We're now in the process of spending $45 million for capital improvements at the high school," he said, "and we have to spend millions to provide more space at other schools as the school population grows. So how can we justify spending a lot of money to beautify Greenwich Avenue? It seems frivolous."
But John Margenot, who stepped down in 1995 after serving five two-year terms as First Selectman, said a face lift for Greenwich Avenue was a necessity. "The avenue is the spine of the town, and we have to keep it esthetically pleasing to attract people," he said.
Mr. Margenot first proposed such a plan four years ago, only to have it rejected by the R.T.M. on the ground that it would cost taxpayers too much money.
"I know some people are leery of asking for Federal assistance," said Mr. Margenot, alluding to past reluctance by Greenwich officials in seeking Federal funds for projects at town beaches or other recreational areas for fear that such financing would force the town to allow non-residents to use the areas.
"But I don't think we should expect the merchants to pay for the face lift," he said.
"There's no reason why we shouldn't take advantage of Federal money if it's available.
"After all, Greenwich people pay taxes, too. And contrary to what some people think, we're not all Rockefellers in Greenwich."

HEADLINE: The Venerable History of Incivility

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES 

 BODY:
INCIVILITY in bipartisan politics and government in America is as old as the Republic.
Benjamin R. Barber, the author of "Jihad vs. McWorld," about the impact of tribalism and the global economy on civility and democracy (Times Books, 1995) said political discourse in America has always been, to a degree, fairly raucous but with certain limits. 
 When Alexis de Tocqueville toured America in the mid-1830's, Professor Barber said, he was impressed with "the local spirit of liberty" and the "powerful participation" of citizens in local government, whether at a New England town meeting or a gathering of settlers at a frontier fort.
There always has existed "a rhetorical incivility within the boundaries of bipartisan politics which is a healthy manifestation of political conflict and disagreement," Dr. Barber said. "That's what democracy is about."
But, said Dr. Barber, the Walt Whitman Professor of Political Science at Rutgers University, those boundaries have eroded and a second kind of incivility has emerged.
"Divisive rhetoric has become not only disagreement between parties but a rejection of the legitimacy of the other side, validating a position that your opponents are immoral, un-American and possibly worthy of being subjected to violence," he said. Opponents become "enemies of the Republic and the political process itself."
Professor Barber added, "We've seen the results at abortion clinics, in the far right militia movement and in Oklahoma City."
Ernest Reock, former director of the Center for Government Services at Rutgers University, said that the Open Public Meetings Act that took effect in New Jersey in 1976 may have inadvertently provided more of an opportunity for confrontation.
The law was designed to open to the public governmental meetings that had been closed, but, Professor Reock said, "while there were lots of negative aspects to closed meetings, you didn't have people coming out and shouting at their officials because their officials just weren't there to shout at."
Historically, Professor Barber said, alienation and willingness to indulge in uncivil oratory have increased the higher up the political ladder one goes. In recent years, there has been "a trickle-down effect" to the local level.
Even on respectable national forums like the McLaughlin Group and Crossfire, incivility substitutes for discourse, he said.
"People yell at each other," Dr. Barber said. "They talk at the same time. There's almost no listening and no visible modification of opinion and there is a vilification of opponents, all of which is taken as ordinary discourse. It's hardly a surprise then at the local P.T.A or block meeting people mimic that form of discourse. It's that trickle-down effect."

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2988 words

HEADLINE: Point of Disorder

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY

 BODY:
COUNCILMAN Thomas A. DeGise sat in his shirt sleeves for three hours in City Council chambers, under the blank gaze of mayors dating to 1838, in portraits, and in front of the often hostile glare of 100 taxpayers, on wooden benches.
In the course of the hearing -- on the budget -- he and his Council colleagues heard themselves characterized as "puppets of the mayor" and "politically expedient," ramming through a financial package that was "a sham," "a boondoggle" and "a gimmick to get re-elected." 
 "It could have been worse," Mr. DeGise, who is council president, said afterward. "This was very tame compared to some hearings we've had."
He had had only two hours' sleep and, after working all day as a job placement officer at the city's Snyder High School, he felt tired. He took off his eyeglasses now and then to rub his eyes.
"This is the fourth budget I've voted on," Mr. DeGise said, after 21 speakers had walked to the microphone and the budget was adopted. "One raised taxes a lot. One cut them a lot. And one kept them the same. The reaction was always the same. They yelled and told us how stupid we are."
Things aren't always as cordial in other New Jersey municipalities. At a meeting in Carteret a few years ago, the mayor punched a resident who he claimed had insulted his wife. In East Brunswick, a man whose shop had been taken over by the town for nonpayment of taxes threatened to shoot officials with a ray gun. And in East Orange, a resident who was arrested while speaking often refers to the council president as Big Bird.
Frustrated and hostile residents; churlish officials; rancorous public meetings. Welcome to democracy, local-government style.
It is an image that runs counter to the notion of participatory government as a sacred tradition whose hallmark is the painting by Norman Rockwell of a dignified American Everyman exercising his constitutional right of free speech at a town meeting while his neighbors listen respectfully.
Today, the artist might have decided to paint a wild-eyed curmudgeon thumping his fist on the lectern to the cheers and jeers of irate taxpayers as he excoriates his elected officials as thieves, scoundrels and knaves.
"We haven't had a war in some time where people have been able to express pent-up aggression on an enemy on the battlefield," said John K. Rafferty, longtime mayor of Hamilton Township. "And so, we zero in on politicians and government."
But Sam Perelli, state chairman of the United Taxpayers of New Jersey, says sometimes extreme action by citizens is warranted to jolt officials out of arrogance and complacency.
"What they're doing is responding to those elected officials who we call 'The We Know What's Best For You Gang,' " Mr. Perelli says. "I believe in civility, but I've also seen where in many cases being civil and respectful got you a laugh behind closed doors and no action."
He added, "It's also been my experience in most cases that councils getting these kinds of abuse have it coming because they do a lot of things behind closed doors and they don't answer questions."
Is this a sign of increasingly hostile times? Or is it just the latest incarnation of a political system that has always suffered from -- or gained zest from -- an in-your-face quality?
It is popular sport for cultural commentators to bemoan the end of civility, or decorum, or courtesy or tact. No longer do we simply register our disapproval in a letter or a petition or with a ballot. We chant, we march, we perform street theater, we even riot. The more outlandish the better, if it lands the participants and their cause on the 6 o'clock news.
MANY officials sit back and let the people have their say, including the gadflies who relentlessly attack them. Many towns put limits on the amount of time a resident can speak. Five minutes has been upheld in court, said Michael Pane, who is the former deputy general counsel of the New Jersey League of Municipalities.
But, in truth, Mr. Pane and other experts on local government say, there is nothing in the law requiring governing bodies to set aside a time for the public to speak at public meetings, except at second reading of an ordinance or at a public hearing on a specific matter under consideration by the governmental body.
At its reorganization meeting last month, the East Orange Council, by a 7-to-3 vote, passed a measure that requires anyone who wants to speak at a regular Council meeting to notify the clerk before 3 P.M. the day of the meeting. Three minutes is the limit. Allowing a person to speak who does not register is at the discretion of the chair.
Only Newark is believed by experts to have a more stringent requirement: potential speakers must sign up 48 hours in advance, but at the meeting the chairman will take a roll-call on whether the person can speak.
The Newark City Clerk, Robert Marasco, said the rule dates to the mid-1950's and is necessary because the state's largest city has a much larger agenda for each meeting, sometimes 200 items.
In East Orange, where strong anti-tax and civic groups have grown and shown opposition to the Mayor and Council in recent years, proponents defend the measure as a way to maintain order and keep meetings from running too long. Critics say it is aimed at quelling dissent.
"No personal attacks will be allowed," the measure says. But what is the difference between personal attack and a legitimate criticism?
"It's a line that's very difficult to define in the abstract," Mr. Pane said.
The lack of civility appears to be growing across the country, according to a poll conducted for U.S. News and World Report last April. Of 1,005 adults polled, 88 percent saw it as a serious problem and 80 percent said it has worsened in the last decade. Those polled blamed political campaigns, as well as television, talk radio and rock music.
In a survey by the National League of Cities released last month, in which public officials were asked to rate conditions in their communities, 18 percent said civility in public life had declined in the last year, while 23 percent said it had improved.
Some New Jersey officials also report an increase in discourtesy, with people becoming more frustrated as towns faced with decreased state and Federal support look for ways to cut expenses. They also appear more cynical about the ethics of officials from the President on down.
"I believe they have become more abusive, but there's also a frustration on the part of the public that they feel they can't reach their elected officials," said Betty Kiss, the East Brunswick Township Clerk and president of the New Jersey Municipal Clerks Association.
"People don't want to spend a lot on taxes and are more cautious about spending," she said. "I think they've become more leery of government because it seems everyday you pick up the newspaper and read where a local or county official has done something illegal."
It is logical that local government is the lightning rod for voter unhappiness. It is the level closest to the people.
"The Mayor and members of the governing body are the most accessible," said William G. Dressel Jr., executive director of the New Jersey State League of Municipalities. "They live in town, they go to the same churches, and their children go to the same schools.
"In these changing times when state and Federal governments are forcing decisions down to the local level, I see the frustration level getting higher," he said. "So the citizens take it out on the mayor and elected officials. They're the ones who send out the tax bill."
This is true even when the issues are those over which the local governing body exercises no control.
"We've been talked to about nuclear disarmament, the NAFTA treaty -- we have nothing to do with that," said Mr. DeGise, the Council President in Jersey City. "If they're mad at the mayor, they come to yell at us. If they're mad at President Clinton, they come yell at us."
Mayor Rafferty, who has been Mayor of Hamilton for 22 years, said that increased media coverage of politics and government has made constituents better informed about the issues and also more aggressive.
That does not necessarily translate into better knowledge of how government works. In the League of Cities survey, two thirds of elected municipal officials said that citizen involvement in their communities is good or very good. But, they added, residents lack good understanding of the functions of government or their responsibilities.
Marilyn Roman, a former Hudson County freeholder and former Jersey City councilwoman who served briefly as acting mayor, said there are deep-seated problems in Jersey City like an 11 percent unemployment rate and changes in funding formulas that make governing complicated.
"People don't really understand how government works and where the money comes from and what the money is needed for in order for the city to work," Ms. Roman said.
Usually, the discourse at meetings centers on proposals that might affect a neighborhood or a resident's pocketbook: a change in a zoning law that increases traffic, a tax increase. Sometimes comment from citizens causes the governing body to reconsider a course of action and influences the outcome. This is the way local government is supposed to work.
But often the public meeting becomes a stage for a personal drama whose central conflict is us against them.
"I've been accused of everything," Mayor Rafferty said. "From being a thief, being in collusion with every developer in the township, of owning land everywhere from the beaches of North Carolina to the Jersey coast to interest in almost every business in town. It always seems to deteriorate to that point."
Last spring, during debate over rezoning some land for a Walmart store, Mr. Rafferty recalls being called a "raging old bull."
"I didn't mind the raging bull part," he said. "It was the old bull part that got to me."
At a Council meeting in Carteret in June 1992, Mayor Peter J. Sica, who is 56, bolted from his seat and punched a much larger and younger man who had insulted his wife.
As the Mayor tells it, it was during a heated meeting and he was going through the fairly innocuous business of appointing citizens to unpaid positions on a board that would make municipal buildings accessible to the disabled. His wife, who had been serving as the unsalaried chairman of a municipal commission for the disabled for years, was the last. As he said her name, he heard a man in the audience call Mrs. Sica "a whore."
"So I said," Mayor Sica recalled, 'I'm going to come down from here and knock your head right off your shoulders.' And he said, 'Come on.'
"So I did."
During his 15 years as Mayor, Mr. Sica said, he has been called every name in the book and even spit on, but that insult crossed the line.
"I can take any kind of abuse anyone wants to throw at me personally," he said. "I will debate with anybody on the issues, I have no problem with that, and I think that's every American's God-given right."
BUT, the Mayor said, "Unfortunately, a lot of people abuse politicians' rights not realizing we have as many rights as they do." And he added, "There is a point where you overstep reasonable bounds, like when you say something against my wife."
Found guilty in Municipal Court of disorderly conduct, Mr. Sica paid a $300 fine.
"I'd pay $600 to hit him another," Mayor Sica said, chuckling. "But you know, subsequently in all honesty, the guy I hit apologized. He said he was misled by my detractors and has become a good friend of mine. He even worked to get the vote out for me in the next election."
When Betty Kiss took over as clerk of East Brunswick in 1980, a man who had lost his junkyard for nonpayment of taxes stormed into a public meeting. "He said he had a ray gun in his briefcase," she recalled. "I was getting ready to duck down because you just don't know." In December 1995, an East Orange resident, Paul Barnes, was arrested on a charge of disrupting the public meeting by refusing to yield the floor. Seeing the arrest as an attempt to silence him, Mr. Barnes says, "They claim I spoke three minutes overtime."
His conviction in Municipal Court was overturned, but his treatment has made him furious. At a recent meeting, he handed out a flier that pokes fun at the baldness of the chairman who had him ejected and has the head of the present chairwoman imposed on the body of the Sesame Street character Big Bird.
Carol Y. Clark, one of three councilwomen who voted against the measure requiring an early sign-up to speak, said many residents feel as Mr. Barnes does: "disenfranchised."
"I believe," Ms. Clark said, "that was put in to deter citizen participation and to try to shut citizens up and curb negative responses to certain legislators and politicians."
But Councilman Phillip Thigpen, one of seven who voted for the measure, denies the Council has any ulterior motive.
"There are 70,000 people in East Orange and that's not a representative sampling of how the people feel," Mr. Thigpen said. "I think everyone wants to see orderliness. There is no restraint on freedom of expression as some people have characterized."
Municipal officials say they listen to residents who appear to have legitimate concerns and no hidden agendas. They say they also listen to gadflies, regulars who can go through a laundry list of grievances.
"Usually, they have a completely negative stance, no matter who the government is," Ms. Roman said. "They're not there so much because they're good citizens but because they're nitpickers."
Yvonne Balcer, who says she has attended just about every Jersey City Council meeting for the last 10 years, would disagree that she is nitpicker. She calls herself an activist.
At the recent budget meeting, she accused the Council of complicity with Mayor Bret Schundler, attacking a measure she said it was a financial gimmick to cut the municipal portion of the tax rate and assure the Mayor's re-election.
"They see me as a thorn in their side," she said outside the Council chamber. "But if they're going to follow the dictates of the Mayor and not use common sense then I'm going to go up there and say this is wrong."
State Senator Byron Baer, who sponsored the open public meetings act, known as the sunshine law, which requires that governing bodies meet publicly, said that citizens in a democracy should not be spectators but participants. He added that government officials can benefit from their input, even if at times the input is unpleasant and "crosses the line of decency."
ANY chair at a public meeting has the right to see that decorum is maintained," Senator Baer said. "But it doesn't mean that criticism is out of bounds. Just because something is criticism doesn't necessarily make it misconduct, and misconduct doesn't become permissible because it's done to express criticism."
Frank Askin, a general counsel to the American Civil Liberties Union and founder of the Constitutional Litigation Clinic at Rutgers University, said political life dating to the American Revolution has often been "unruly" and "provocative."
"This country was born in provocative and robust debate and discussion, and it wasn't always polite." Mr. Askin said. "The First Amendment doesn't just protect polite speech."
But the strain of hostility in public life can take its toll.
"It winds up you go home, your emotions are upset from the meeting where it became so hostile, and you can't fall asleep," Mrs. Kiss said. "It takes a long time to unwind."
Mr. Dressel said that many people enter government because they want to contribute to their communities but can become disillusioned by the public response to them.
"I hear people in government saying they want to get out," he said. 'It's not fun anymore. Why should I stay involved for a citizenry that is not understanding?' "
Henry Coleman, director of the Center for Government Services at Rutgers University, which is one of the sponsors of an annual contest aimed at fostering better communication between municipal governments and residents, said "lots of good things" are taking place in town government but the residents are not always aware of it.
"Frankly, the contest isn't going to do much for a government that is determined not to communicate with its citizens," Dr. Coleman said. "The closer the government is to the people and the more opportunity people have to interact, the better they understand and appreciate it."
About 25 percent of the municipalities in New Jersey now televise their governmental meetings on cable, Mrs. Kiss said, a development that should mean increased understanding and perhaps more meaningful citizen participation.
But frustration and incivility may increase, too, as the role of the Federal Government diminishes and the burden of programs like welfare is absorbed by the states with the problems hitting closer to home.
Mark Schwartz, president of the National League of Cities, thinks that although incivility has been on the rise in recent years, it has ebbed. He was so concerned with what he saw as increased fractiousness in public life, that as as president-elect he commissioned a study of the issue.
The report, "Connecting Citizens and their Government: Civility, Responsibility and Local Democracy," came out in December and provides examples of how communities around the country are instituting programs to make the relationship between government and citizen more harmonious and constructive.
What prompted Mr. Schwartz's concern was the bombing in Oklahoma City, where he is a councilman.
"After the bombing," he said, "a lot of us would sit around and talk and wonder what would make somebody do something so horrendous as to kill so many people and attack the government when the government is really our neighbors."
He added: "We're all the government."

HEADLINE: A Pillar of City Housing: Tax Relief

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
IN the prosaic parlance of officialdom, they are deadeningly designated: the J-51 Tax Exemption and Abatement Program and Section 421a of the New York State Real Property Tax Law. But for Henrietta Cohen, an 84-year-old widow, and Azizur Rahman, an emigre from Bangladesh, they are lifelines to a decent, affordable home.
And for New York City, they are girders in a jerry-built framework for preserving and creating habitable housing through a system of tax incentives. 
 The J-51 program is intended to encourage the rehabilitation of older housing; the 421a program is designed to stimulate the construction of new buildings. In their present forms, they have evolved because of two judgments about the role of government in housing.
One, which underlies the J-51 program, is that the income of thousands of New York City tenants is insufficient to afford the rents or rent increases that would allow a landlord to finance major rehabilitation work.
The other, underlying the 421a program, is that in much of Manhattan the rents or prices for newly built apartments are high enough to justify a quid pro quo: tax benefits to the market-rate development in return for some new or gut-rehabilitated apartments for lower-income households.
Now the Giuliani administration is preparing to propose a change in the 421a program that would, if previous patterns hold, rekindle the controversy that the abatement programs have historically generated. Critics of the programs have long contended that tax abatements are not needed to generate new construction in the most affluent areas -- particularly midtown Manhattan -- and should not be used there.
At present, the 421a program is available to most of Manhattan south of 96th Street (the so-called exclusion zone) only if developers also create low-income apartments within the building or somewhere else in the city, or if they completely gut and then rehabilitate existing low-income apartments.
Under the proposed change, which requires approval by the State Legislature, developers could also be granted a Section 421a benefit for new construction in the exclusion zone if they contributed money to refurbishing already occupied low-income buildings elsewhere in the city. The Giuliani administration hopes to use those contributions to save distressed buildings that are at risk of abandonment.
"The Federal Government has walked away from budgeting for low-income housing, but the need is still there," said Lilliam Barrios-Paoli, Commissioner of the Department of Housing Preservation and Development. "We are trying to marry the idea of getting new market-rate housing and creating a funding stream for low-income housing at the same time." Martin Oestreicher, the deputy commissioner for the property division in the city's Department of Finance, said that 45,013 apartments in the city were receiving 421a benefits last year, and approximately 650,000 units were receiving benefits under J-51.
And since 1990, Mr. Oestreicher said, the two programs have resulted in approximately $2.2 billion in forgone tax revenue -- $1.3 billion under J-51, and $963 million under 421a.
The building in Jamaica, Queens, where Mrs. Cohen lives vividly illustrates how J-51 directly affects people's lives.
"Hey, Kenneth!" Mrs. Cohen piped up to her landlord, Kenneth Subraj, one recent Friday afteroon. "The elevator needs a cleaning."
In her housecoat and slippers and leaning on her aluminum walker, Mrs. Cohen had just come down to the lobby from her seventh-floor apartment to pick up the mail. As the original tenant in the nine-story, red-brick building on Merrick Boulevard, she has donned the mantle of unofficial ombudswoman for her building. She moved in 39 years ago and has since seen several landlords come and go.
But none quite like Kenneth, George and Jay Subraj, three Guyanese brothers of Indian descent who came to the United States in the 1970's and 80's, founded Zara Realty and began buying buildings in Jamaica and neighboring Hollis. They now own nine.
"They put a lot into this building," Mrs. Cohen said of the Subraj brothers. "Before, sometimes heat, sometimes no heat, comme ci, comme ca, you know what I mean?
"The other landlord, the roof leaked," Mrs. Cohen said. "It's a good thing I had a lot of newspapers, The New York Times, to soak it up. No more problems since."
Not only have the Subraj brothers rebuilt the roof, they have replaced that capricious old boiler with a new dual-fuel heating system, hung dual-pane thermal windows throughout the building, refurbished the elevators, remodeled the lobby and installed a garbage compactor and chutes -- all with the help of J-51.
THE program has allowed the Subrajes, along with hundreds of other landlords, to renovate their buildings and, thereby, sustain their livability. "These are not rich Manhattan rents," Mr. Subraj said of his nine rent-regulated buildings where a studio goes for about $450 and a two-bedroom for, maybe, $900. "These are working-class neighborhoods, low-income. So we are limited. Given that kind of rent, we are able to do the improvements with J-51."
There has been "quite a bit of rejuvenation in Jamaica" in the last two decades, Mr. Subraj said, spurred, in part, by the tax-incentive programs. "Without the improvements, these buildings would definitely be rundown and will not attract a decent tenancy. And we will end up being the type of landlord you don't want to be."
Both J-51 and 421a "were created to deal with a problem that has plagued New York for decades -- the shortage of housing for households of all income levels," said Michael Schill, director of the Center for Real Estate and Urban Policy at the New York University School of Law. And what they try to do is "harness the private sector to provide that housing, recognizing that government can't and shouldn't do it all by itself."
Given the high costs of land and construction in New York City, as well as the "extraordinary maze of regulations that developers must navigate" in order to build, Professor Schill said, the tax incentives offered by the programs are vital to preserving and increasing the city's housing stock.
"Increasing our stock is particularly important today," Professor Schill said, "because, unlike most other large, older American cities, the population of New York is increasing, partly due to the influx of immigrants." After sharp declines between 1960 and 1980, according to the Census Bureau, the city's population grew by 3.5 percent during the 80's, from 7,071,639 to 7,322,564. The influx continued during the first half of the 90's.
Under J-51, owners pay no increase in property taxes attributable to major building improvements for 10 years; then taxes are phased in over the following four years. In addition, owners are entitled to an annual 8.33 percent reduction of the taxes they had been paying based on the pre-rehabilitation assessment -- up to 90 percent of the "certified reasonable costs" of the work. The caveat is that apartment assessments after completion cannot be greater than $38,000 a unit, which effectively makes the J-51 program unusable in high-value locations, including most of Manhattan.
Under 421a, a building is exempt from property taxes while it is being constructed. After that, taxes are phased in under a schedule that differs in various parts of the city.
In the Manhattan exclusion zone, taxes are phased in over 10 years, until the building pays full taxes. When financing is obtained from tax-exempt bonds, as has been the case with much recent Manhattan construction, the property-tax abatement period lasts 20 years, with a full exemption for 12 years, followed by a phaseout. Such tax-exempt financing is obtainable only when 20 percent of the apartments in the building are made available to low-income families -- the so-called 80/20 program.
In other parts of the city, the 100 percent exemption period lasts for 10 years, followed by a five-year phaseout (in Manhattan outside the exclusion zone and in the four other boroughs) or 100 percent for 20 years, also followed by a five-year phaseout (in a neighborhood preservation area or for a project that has tax-exempt financing).
The housing generated or preserved under the two programs is particularly important in the current market, housing analysts say. According to "Housing N.Y.C., '96" a report by the city's Rent Guidelines Board, the city's rate of new construction has hit a longtime low.
Over the last 35 years, the report said, "the number of certificates of occupancy issued for newly constructed buildings in the city has plummeted from an average of 37,000 per year in the 1960's to a mere 7,900 in the 1990's." And fewer units were issued certificates of occupancy in 1993 (5,510) than in any year since 1945. In 1993, the last year for which data were available, the city's vacancy rate stood at 3.44 percent, with 5 percent or below the statutory standard for declaration of a housing emergency.
Without 421a, market players say, the crunch would be worse.
"We've been involved since the inception of the program in the early 70's," said Gary Jacob, executive vice president of Glenwood Management, which has built about 2,000 apartments in nine buildings, mostly on the East Side of Manhattan, under 421a. "It was the only program at the time that permitted rental housing to be built," Mr. Jacob said. "I'm not aware of any rental housing built since 1971, absent 421a."
Only last month, on West End Avenue between 61st and 64th Streets, construction was completed on West End Towers, a 1,000-apartment complex that was built with 421a incentives. "Included in those 1,000 apartments are 200 low-income units, which I think is some of the best low-income housing in the city," said the developer, Daniel Brodsky, president of the Brodsky Organization.
"They've been very good programs for the city," Mr. Brodsky said of J-51 and 421a, with the latter, particularly, giving the city "the ability to have low-income housing built and managed without the city having the responsibility of operating it. It integrates people racially, economically and socially in a set of buildings, and it works very, very well."
Among the beneficiaries of the 421a program are Mr. Rahman, the Bangladeshi native, his wife, Husna, and their sons, Minhaj, 16, and Fayaz, 8.
Mr. Rahman earns $12,000 a year as a waiter -- with tips. He pays $438 a month for a two-bedroom apartment in West End Towers. "Before, I used to live in Astoria, a very small, one-bedroom apartment, and I used to pay $700," he said. "My sons used to sleep on the floor. The living room was so small, I could not put beds in there.
Mr. Rahman won his new apartment in 1994 after spotting a newspaper advertisement, placed by the Brodsky Organization, announcing a lottery for the 200 units that was being run by the city's Housing Development Corporation.
"Thanks God, I get this one," Mr. Rahman said. "This building is very fancy. We have a dishwashing machine, a microwave that came with the building. It is a dream for me because I am a very low-paid person and cannot afford to buy this stuff. Here I am able to give my children a little better food."
THE 421a program has, at times, been a lightning rod for controversy. The law creating the program in 1971 stipulated that the tax incentives were supposed to promote construction of housing on "vacant, predominantly vacant or underutilized" sites. When, in the 1980's, Trump Tower on Fifth Avenue qualified for 421a benefits, the battle that eventually led to creation of the exclusion zone was joined.
Distant echoes of that conflict were heard only two months ago when the City Council voted, 29 to 17, to extend 421a incentives to sites zoned for the city's biggest buildings -- including the 3.4-acre site at Columbus Circle where some of the city's most high-profile developers have proposed building residential and office towers of up to 750 feet in height.
As she had more than a decade ago, Manhattan Borough President Ruth W. Messinger weighed in against what she considers misuse of the 421a program. "A desert doesn't need sand," she said, "a jungle doesn't need trees, and this site -- probably the single most valuable piece of real estate north, south, east or west of the Hudson River -- doesn't need your tax dollars, my tax dollars or anybody else's tax dollars to be developed."
In a recent interview, Ms. Messinger said that, as she had in the mid-80's, "I am always going to ask the same questions" about the two programs: "Where do you need tax breaks to encourage construction or renovation of housing and where can it proceed on its own?
"In exchange for providing some special tax breaks, we want to end up with some more affordable housing," she said. "These programs do that, but we get only a limited number of units at a fairly high cost in forgiven taxes."
The forgone revenue, in the estimation of Councilman Archie Spigner, chairman of the Council's Housing Committee, has been worth it. "I believe, when in doubt, we've got to come down on the side of giving the incentive, because there's a spinoff," Mr. Spigner said. "A new project provides employment opportunities to the construction industry; that's a plus. The taxes derived from the sales of goods and services in putting the project together, that's a plus. And the physical improvement to a community is also a plus. Then when the incentive expires and the property is fully taxable, that's the goal."
Posing the questions asked by critics of the programs -- "Have they been used prudently? Would the developers build without the incentives?" -- Mr. Spigner, a Democrat from Queens, said:
"Given the competition for capital and the opportunities available to developers across the river in New Jersey, in Westchester, in Stamford, Conn., in Nassau and beyond, my answer is that the stakes are too high for a casual roll of the dice on whether or not a project would go forward with or without the subsidies."
And of Columbus Circle, in particular, he said: "You can argue until you're green that they would go forward without it, but there are some of us who are not ready to take that chance."
Several of the developers who have submitted proposals for the Coliseum site said the need for 421a benefits depends on the proportion of housing to commercial space envisioned for the project.
Christopher Jeffries is a principal of Millennium Partners, which is putting the finishing touches on the 33-story Grand Millennium, one of three buildings in the company's Lincoln Square complex, all of which were built with 421a benefits after 150 low-income units were first constructed in other boroughs.
"Our project is heavily weighted toward housing, so we believe 421a is needed for the Coliseum," Mr. Jeffries said. "Remember, development of the Coliseum project with 421a will guarantee a significant number of low-income units being created somewhere else in the city by the private sector. It would be at least 100 units under our program."
But Richard LeFrak, president of the LeFrak Organization, said his company's proposal for the Coliseum "does not, at this time, contemplate requesting a 421a tax abatement. Our program has a very high commercial component, more than all the other proposals, so 421a is not as critical."
Critics of 421a argue that, despite the exclusion zone -- which runs from 96th Street to 14th Street on the east and Houston Street on the west -- Manhattan continues to be the prime beneficiary of the program. And data from the Department of Finance lend some credence to that contention. Last year, 54.7 percent of the 45,013 units receiving 421a benefits were in Manhattan, 20 percent were in Queens, 11 percent in Brooklyn, 8.9 percent on Staten Island and 5.4 percent in the Bronx.
Despite that distribution, the city's overall need has not slackened. Because of the real estate market collapse of the early 90's, applications for 421a have decreased in recent years. "Housing N.Y.C., '96," the Rent Guidelines Board report, states that an average of 5,865 apartments qualified for 421a benefits each year during the 1980's. But in the first half of the 1990's, the average declined to 1,796 each year, a reduction of 69 percent.
At the same time, the city's already constricted housing supply is facing a further crunch as the Federal Government struggles to cope with a crisis in its major subsidy program for the poor. The Federal program -- Section 8 -- covers the gap between 30 percent of a tenant's income and the rent for the apartment.
With Congress focused on deficit reduction, the Section 8 program is facing deep cuts, imperiling the renewal of contracts for buildings with up to 50,000 units that are due to expire over the next 10 years. Section 8 expirations in the city will peak at about 5,000 a year by 2002 before phasing down to zero in 2007, said Victor Bach, director of housing research for the Community Service Society, a nonprofit organization, who has written a report on the issue.
If the contracts are not renewed, owners of some subsidized buildings are likely to convert to market rents, while others may be forced to abandon buildings because, without the subsidies, they will not be able to meet operating expenses, Mr. Bach said.
Is the city's already taut housing stock facing a pincer action from above, because of the dropoff in 421a applications, and from below, because of the Section 8 crisis?
RONALD SHIFFMAN, director of the Pratt Center for Community and Environmental Development and a former member of the City Planning Commission, believes so. Mr. Shiffman pointed out that rent regulation may be weakened by the Legislature in the coming months and housing allowances are going to be cut under the new Federal welfare law.
"So, both of these," he said, referring to the contractions of 421a and Section 8, "will contribute to the crunch over the next five years. Many people will have to either double up or use the streets."
With all those factors coming into play, N.Y.U.'s Professor Schill sees 1997 as "a year of decision for housing in New York City." And, while not discounting the value he and many others see in both 421a and J-51, the professor wonders whether measures "other than tax incentives are necessary to build and maintain private-market housing."
Proposals to relax residential zoning requirements and give more favorable property-tax treatment to multifamily dwellings could be important steps toward increasing the housing supply, Professor Schill said. "Directly attacking the high cost of housing construction and renovation might be better than piecemeal attempts to subsidize development through tax concessions," he said.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
Job Security Dwindles as Rent-a-Job Companies Surge

BYLINE: By KIT R. ROANE 

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
Like more than 43 million others over the past two decades, Douglas E. Owens was downsized, unemployed, rented out, and basically left to survive by his wits. His resume went out to hundreds of companies and his feet walked miles of carpet in and out of interviews after he was cast out of the cradle-to-grave corporate world that he had e inhabited for 23 years.
Unlike many others still grappling with the uncertainty of today's labor market, Mr. Owens, 50 has a real job again. More importantly, he knows he probably won't keep it. 
 And he knows the same thing is true for a lot of the people he hires in his new job as vice president of human resources at Origin Technology in Business.
"It used to be that if you saw a resume full of two-year stints at different companies, you were shocked. Now it's normal," he said at his Murray Hill office, where he now sits perusing hundreds of resumes. "I would like to say I will keep this job forever, but I know the percentages aren't there anymore and that I will probably end up working interim on into retirement. That's the way the world works now; we are all disposable."
Mr. Owens has seen both sides of one of the fastest-growing sectors of the American economy. The growth is spurred by the need for new workers at downsized companies that are unwilling to take on additional full-time employees. Instead, they outsource the work, hiring outside contractors. Besides making the labor market more fluid and allowing business to operate more efficiently, the practice has spurred a new line of work: companies that channel workers into a series of jobs that are rarely permanent.
According to Federal labor figures, the number of temporary workers in New York and New Jersey rose by 35,000 in the first half of the decade, with 151,007 workers registered in 1995, the last full year that such statistics are available. During that period, the number of temporary hiring offices (many owned by the same company) increased from 1,522 to 1,874.
Nationally, the trend is much the same, with temporary work moving from a $16 billion to a $31 billion industry from 1990 to 1995. And now Manpower Inc. is the largest employer in the nation, offering up 750,000 temporary workers a year.
"It is part of the great economic transformation that we are going through," said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Blousteinready School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers, adding that New Jersey, with its concentration of manufacturing, communications and pharmaceutical companies, has been at the center of the trend. "It is the result of a drive for efficiency, an attempt to insure that a company is only paying for work that is done and not for workers who are idle."
Outsourcing has many facets, but the chief aim is to cut employment at a company to a core of individuals focused on its main business. All other activities, from handling mail and copying to accounting, information services and building maintenance, may be farmed out to other companies or individuals on contract. Even in the core business, if projects require additional hands, the company often opts to hire an engineer or executive as a consultant, rather than put him on the payroll.
According to Mr. Owens, who saw his own salary nearly halved during his two years of temporary jobs, one in six of the employees his company now asks him to hire are project workers who will never be put on the company payroll.
The crush of workers looking for jobs combined with the need of companies to find quick sources of labor, has caused a staggering growth in job clearinghouses, including those that specialize in executive and management positions. The Ascher Group, a Roseland company that began in 1981 as an executive head-hunting firm, began channeling its energy into temporary placements six years ago. Since then, revenues have approached $5 million, nearly five times what they were in 1992.
The company is itself a model of outsourcing, hiring other contractors to do its payroll, accounting, advertising, printing, legal and travel services. Susan P. Ascher, the company's president, added that one of the companies that uses her executives is itself an outsource firm that runs warehouses for other companies.
Many economists and business specialists believe that the trend may have reached its peak, that companies have cut to the bone, and in some cases trimmed too many workers from their staff.
"They are finding out that they can't move the raw data up the chain of command after they have carved out much of the chain," said Stanley Deetz, a professor of communication at Rutgers who has studied the corporate culture of downsizers such as AT&T. "And there is some thought at major corporations that things went too far, too fast."
But the business world is unlikely to revert to its old ways. Downsizing and outsourcing have been one of the chief bolsters of the American economy and American stock prices in recent years. economists say. It has also helped to further weaken unions and reduce wage inflation, with median wages now 3 percent below what they were in 1979. And while companies may slow their outsourcing of existing jobs, economists say they are likely never to internalize many of the jobs that will be tomorrow's boon, particularly those in information technology.
"Most of the obvious outsourcing targets have been consummated already, but technology is moving so quickly that few companies will be able to develop these as internal functions," said Mr. Hughes, noting that up to 43 percent of the jobs lost in corporate America over the past decade were later outsourced. "Everything from the Internet, to data processing and information handling will probably be purchased outside from ground zero. This is the future."

HEADLINE: MAKING IT WORK;
In 2002, Mr. Speaker?

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS

 BODY:
AH, youth. A. Gifford Miller has plenty. When he was elected Council member from the Upper East Side last year, Mr. Miller, then a 26-year-old Democrat, earned an asterisk next to his name by becoming the youngest person ever elected to the city's decidedly middle-aged legislature. Politically astute beyond his years, Mr. Gifford outmaneuvered three other Democrats during a special election last winter to fill the seat vacated by Charles Millard, who resigned to become president of the city's Economic Development Corporation.
In 10 bitterly cold days, Mr. Miller and his supporters gathered nearly 7,000 signatures, more than triple the required number, and he went on to trounce a Republican twice his age by 14 points. "Gifford came out of the gates quicker than anyone else," said Jerry Skurnik, a Democratic political consultant. "In some respects, he was at the right place at the right time." 
 He is also extremely lucky. Because he has yet to serve a full four-year term, Mr. Miller will be the Council's sole surviving Democrat when term limits sweep away the 44 other Democrats four years from now. Vito Fossella, a Republican from Staten Island, will be the only other Council member left standing.
Assuming he wins re-election this fall, something that is almost certain in a body where turnover is rare, Mr. Miller will be the Council's senior Democrat on the first Monday of January 2002. With that advantage, and assuming he plays his cards right, supporters say he stands a good chance of becoming the Council's Speaker, second only to the Mayor in power and prestige.
"Gifford is bright, energetic and asks the right questions," said Peter F. Vallone, the Democrat from Queens who has led the Council since 1986. "I guess you could say he has the qualifications for a good Speaker."
With his boyish side part, prominent ears and gee-whiz smile, Mr. Miller, who lives in an East 81st Street co-op, doesn't quite exude blind ambition. "Everyone is always ribbing me, calling me Mr. Speaker," he said the other day as he picked over the remains of his fried chicken lunch at Ellen's Cafe near City Hall. "Believe it or not, I have a strong sense of my own irrelevance."
During his first 12 months, Mr. Miller's impact on the Council has been minimal, and he has yet to see any of his bills made into law. Before he was elected, his only other job after graduating from Princeton University in 1992 was as an aide to Representative Carolyn B. Maloney.
While his Council colleagues seem to like him well enough, many say it is too early to handicap his chances for Speaker. "Gifford works extremely hard but he still has a lot to learn," Councilwoman Kathryn E. Freed of lower Manhattan said. "I can't quite imagine him as Speaker. I think the situation shows up the problems of term limits."
Chris Meyer, a lawyer for the New York Public Interest Research Group, agrees that Mr. Gifford's ascendancy to the post is not a sure thing. "People assume that longevity equals primogeniture and they're wrong," he said. "Gifford may know how to work the system and he hasn't made enemies yet, but he has a lot of work to do if he wants the Speaker's job."
That means building a broader base of support, especially in the boroughs outside Manhattan and among Democratic party bosses whose influence on the Council will be greater after term limits take effect. "Gifford needs an issue on which he can make a name for himself," Mr. Meyer said.
So far one of his more prominent maneuvers has been something of a blunder. When Mayor Giuliani announced plans for ferry service between the East Side and Yankee Stadium, the Councilman ridiculed it as a windfall for only one person: the Mayor's son, Andrew. "Maybe it's a way for Andrew to get home from the games safely, but I don't think the community wants it," he said then. That remark earned him the Mayor's enmity and former Deputy Mayor Peter Powers made a point of telling him so.
Mr. Miller says he now regrets the comment. "I guess I was being flip," he said. "I didn't mean to offend the Mayor."
Nevertheless, the incident has made little impression beyond City Hall, and Mr. Miller enjoys wide support among his constituents, many of whom are visibly charmed by his youth, his energy and his earnestness. Mention his name to allies, and comments like "handsome," "promising" and "Kennedy esque" flow freely.
"Sometimes he's annoying as hell because he asks so many questions but he's basically a nice kid," said Norman Adler, a political consultant and an informal adviser. "He comes from money but he's not snotty about it."
Raised on 98th Street and Fifth Avenue, Mr. Miller was surrounded by politics. His father, Leigh, was a State Department official in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations. His mother, Lynden, is a prominent garden designer. Both his parents, whom he describes as "yellow dog Democrats," have served on Community Board 8 in East Harlem. "Dinner table conversation was often political in nature and fairly heated," his father said. "But we never imagined that he would become a politician."
During a recent visit to the Lenox Hill Senior Center on East 70th Street, Mr. Miller was greeted like visiting royalty by the lunchtime crowd as he handed out a flier on crime prevention. Sydelle Seelenfreund-Gorlick, 81, trailed him like a proud grandmother. "He's so thoughtful and every time he sees me on the street, he kisses me," she said, adjusting the ladybug pendant on her sweater. Asked if Mr. Miller wasn't just being a politician, she snapped: "I've been around a long time and know the difference between a phony and the real thing."
A few days later, in a Park Avenue apartment thick with judges, elected officials and the Silk Stocking district's Democratic elite, Mr. Miller was the guest of honor. As four candidates for Manhattan borough president furiously worked the party, sponsored by the Lexington Democratic Club, Mr. Miller appeared relaxed. Stepping to the front of the room, looking out over a sea of beaming faces, he brought the crowd to a polite roar when he spoke of the Democratic Party's responsibility to the poor and disfranchised. "The last chapter, I'm sure, has not been written for Gifford," the evening's host, Joe Rosenblatt, announced.
Even his rivals have trouble criticizing him. "It's not his fault that he went to the best private schools and never had to work a day in his life," said Samuel D. Morell, who lost his Council bid to Mr. Miller last year. "He has no fire in his belly. But on the other hand, if I had kids, he's the kind of guy I would want to marry my daughter."

GRAPHIC: Photo: For A. Gifford Miller, term limits could be the key to the Council Speaker's job. (Philip Greenberg for The New York Times)
 
 
Chart: "TIMETABLE: The Governing Body, Ever-Morphing"
 
1898 -- Forty local governments are consolidated into a legislature called the Municipal Assembly with jurisdiction over the five boroughs.
 
1901 -- The Assembly, seen as too unruly, is dissolved and replaced with a Board of Aldermen, composed of members from 73 districts. Another body, the powerful Board of Estimate, is also created, made up of the five borough presidents.
 
1937 -- The Board of Aldermen is replaced with a City Council of 26 members.
 
1963 -- To promote political pluralism, a new charter creates 10 at-large members, two elected from each borough, to sit alongside the Council members that represent districts.
 
1981 -- The at-large seats are ruled because they violated the principle of "one man, one vote."
 
1989 -- A new charter abolishes the Board of Estimate, increases the number of council seats from 35 to 51 and transfers land-use and budgetary powers to the council.
 
1993 -- In a referendum, voters limit the city's elected officials to two successive four-year terms.
 
1995 -- Voters rebuff an attempt to amend term limits, meaning that all but two of the council's members will be cast out the first week of January 2002.
