LENGTH: 3889 words

HEADLINE: Like Oil and Water: A Tale of Two Economists

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
THEY have met only once since Paul Krugman returned last summer to the prestigious economics department at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. It was a brief, accidental encounter among the file cabinets and secretaries' desks near Lester Thurow's office. "We exchanged pleasantries," Mr. Thurow said. "He was telling someone about a trip he had made to the far south of Argentina, and I listened politely."
The small talk left so much unsaid. For the two men -- from offices one floor apart that look out on the Charles River -- are not so much colleagues as high-profile combatants in a struggle to explain the very nature of the national economy. With all the authority of their profession, they have gone public with strikingly different explanations of an economic phenomenon bedeviling not only the experts, but everyone else, too. Why have so many Americans fallen behind in the last two decades, while an affluent minority has so visibly prospered? Why has the resulting income gap become so glaring and persistent, even with six years of steady economic growth under our belts? 
 What Mr. Thurow and Mr. Krugman have done is translate into vivid metaphors, riffs of sarcasm and doomsday prose the dry, technical debate of their colleagues at a time when many Americans have taken sides, telling pollsters that they think competition from the rest of the world is the big cause of their income troubles. For Mr. Krugman, representing the majority of economists, that view is wrong. The big culprit, he argues, is new technology right here at home, requiring so many well-paid, college-trained workers, and so few of the less skilled. But for Mr. Thurow and other challengers of this view, the rapidly evolving global economy is indeed mostly to blame, with its hundreds of millions of low-wage workers sending what they produce to the United States and pulling down the pay of average Americans.
Mr. Krugman, 43, and Mr. Thurow, 58, are not alone in this debate, of course. Politicians, pundits, historians, sociologists and Wall Street analysts have jumped in. The debate pops up all the time, in articles and books and on talk shows. Policy prescriptions fill the air: regulate trade, restrict immigration, levy higher taxes on the rich to subsidize the poor and improve educational standards in an attempt -- perhaps vain -- to make everyone highly skilled and well paid.
Pat Buchanan, who sought the Republican Presidential nomination last year, exploited the issue. Bob Dole tried to make wage troubles a campaign theme, and even President Clinton, while just issuing a report suggesting that the rising income gap may be reversing, has nonetheless singled out this inequality as the current economic problem. But Mr. Krugman, so often described as a shoo-in for a future Nobel Prize, and Mr. Thurow, who became an M.I.T. economics professor while Mr. Krugman was still a teen-ager in well-to-do Merrick, L.I., have emerged as the loudest and most articulate public voices of the profession that, above others, should have answers.
As they go at it, never face-to-face -- always in writing and public speaking, sometimes from the well of the same M.I.T. lecture amphitheater, although on separate days -- they offer very different versions of the economy, as if they were cardiologists differing over heart disease, with one citing stress as the primary cause and the other a fat-rich diet.
"The fact this debate exists means no one knows who is right," said Robert Heilbroner, an economics historian who has written books with Mr. Thurow. "The economics profession seems to have a split personality, with the Lester Thurows trying to see a larger picture, and the Paul Krugmans in the business of trying to measure hard-and-fast cause and effect."
The jockeying for the upper hand in this debate sometimes becomes personal. While serving as the defender of the mainstream viewpoint among economists, Mr. Krugman cultivates a firebrand image. He refers to "startlingly crude and uninformed" views of those he criticizes, often by name -- Robert B. Reich, the former Labor Secretary, is a favorite target -- or to experts who "offer a logic no more confused than usual." He included Mr. Thurow in that last epithet. And so when Mr. Thurow was told last summer that Mr. Krugman was returning to M.I.T., after two years at Stanford University, he requested that Mr. Krugman refrain from disparaging his M.I.T. colleagues -- a request that Mr. Krugman has honored so far. "He is too personal," Mr. Thurow said. "He makes it hard to have a debate."
Mr. Thurow, on the other hand, offers broad declarations that go far beyond the equations, diagrams and mathematical models that are, in Mr. Krugman's view, the essence of respectable economics. Mr. Thurow, for example, offers sweeping statements about the impact of the global economy on Americans. "Those with third-world skills will earn third-world wages," he declares, and "anything can be made anywhere on the face of the earth and sold everywhere else on the face of the earth."
For Mr. Krugman, who declined to be photographed with Mr. Thurow, such statements are more seat-of-the-pants judgments than testable economic logic. They are, he wrote recently, expressions in a war "between the essentially literary sensibility that we expect of a card-carrying intellectual and the scientific-mathematical outlook that is arguably the true glory of our civilization."
Such differences enliven the buzz among their colleagues at M.I.T. "Paul's style is still that of the enfant terrible, while Lester speaks more like someone on the mountaintop telling you how it is," said Richard L. Schmalensee, the deputy dean of M.I.T.'s Sloan School of Management.
Still, there is common ground. Both men see themselves as liberals, fighting not over ideology but over what constitutes good economics. They favor similar policies -- strengthening unions to give labor more bargaining power, pushing education to improve Americans' workplace skills and income redistribution via Government policy to reduce inequality. They once even taught a basic economics course together at M.I.T., although they lectured on alternate days. (Mr. Thurow was more fun for the students, but Mr. Krugman covered the curriculum, Mr. Krugman said.)
Both acknowledge that they shifted their attention from academia to the public arena after being shut out of top slots as advisers in Democratic administrations -- Mr. Thurow after Jimmy Carter was elected President and Mr. Krugman in the early Clinton days.
"My epiphany, came at that famous economic summit in Little Rock in 1992," Mr. Krugman said. "A lot of stuff said there was clearly silly. I had been aware that pop economics writers had a much bigger audience than good economists. But I did not take that seriously because I thought that anyone who really mattered would know the difference. That turned out not to be the case."
Mr. Thurow and Mr. Krugman also share an uncertainty, even a pessimism, about the future. Mr. Krugman is doubtful that any policy can improve much on the market's self-correcting, if sometimes fallible, ways. And Mr. Thurow worries that without a new central challenge -- something to replace the cold war -- Americans will let the economy deteriorate by failing to support Government money for research and necessary public investment that business shuns because the payoff is not direct and immediate. In his latest book, "The Future of Capitalism," he even foresees, in the absence of this central challenge, a decline into a modern-day Middle Ages.
"My brother in Chicago, whom I respect very much, called me and said I had written the most depressing book he had ever read," Mr. Thurow said. "I was surprised. I thought I had laid out solutions. But maybe they stick in my mind and not in the reader's."

Wooing the Crowd
The names appear alphabetically, in modest black letters, outside the suite where Mr. Krugman has his office, and he jokingly points out that his name is first, ahead of the Nobel Prize winners Paul Samuelson and Robert M. Solow, two giants of American economics who happen to be Mr. Krugman's suite mates. "I ought to take a picture of that while it lasts," he said. He need not rush. His imprint on mainstream economics is already well embedded.
Mr. Krugman, the only child of an insurance company manager, achieved luminary status in less than a decade as an economist. Finishing at Yale in 1974 and receiving his Ph.D. from M.I.T. in 1977, he soon plunged into teaching and research, producing path-breaking findings on the interplay of Government and industry in trade. Although he worries about Government interference in markets, he nevertheless has demonstrated with mathematical precision how an assist from Government can give an industry a competitive advantage in, say, manufacturing and exporting commercial jets or computer chips.
With his reputation as an expert economist firmly in place by the early 90's (he won the John Bates Clark Medal in 1991 as the nation's most outstanding academic economist under 40), Mr. Krugman cut back on original research and turned his attention to a wider public, displaying a rare knack for explaining the discipline and logic of economics if not to every subway straphanger, at least to the educated layman.
"There is no question that the polemics cut into the research," Mr. Krugman said. "I like to think that like Keynes" -- John Maynard Keynes, the legendary British economist who juggled scholarship, essay writing and public service -- "I can step back and do deep thinking again, but who knows. It is one of the things I wake up and worry about."
Mr. Thurow, 15 years older than Mr. Krugman, actually blazed this trail from academia to a wider audience. The eldest of three sons of a Methodist preacher in Montana, he went east to Williams College and won a Rhodes scholarship to Oxford. He earned a Ph.D. at Harvard in 1964 and four years later, at 30, found himself at M.I.T., holding professorships in both the economics department and the Sloan School of Management, where he later became dean. Pioneering work on income distribution helped get him to the top. But he, too, shifted to capturing public attention after being shut out of government. He had helped in the Carter election campaign but, like Mr. Krugman 16 years later, lost out for a top advisory position in the new Democratic Administration.
"I decided that if I could not have the king's ear, I would talk to the public," Mr. Thurow said. "That's the other way to have an impact on the economic system." And he certainly has talked to the public, in best-selling books, magazine articles, television appearances and on the lecture circuit -- at $30,000 a speech, he says, nearly double Mr. Krugman's speaking fees.
But for all their similarities, and their common home base, the chasm separating their economic theories seems unbridgeable.
Mr. Thurow applauded -- and still likes -- Mr. Krugman's early research suggesting that the Government can help create an export advantage for industry. That fits Mr. Thurow's preference for a market system leavened by Government. But Mr. Krugman objects that his research is all-too-often loosely invoked as justification for an intrusive industrial policy by people "who don't understand its limits."
Mr. Thurow says that when the Mexicans or Chinese export shirts or tires to the United States, for example, less-skilled American workers are edged out or forced into lower-paying service jobs. Mr. Krugman responds that imports from low-wage countries represent only 2 percent of the national income, not enough to have much of an impact on American labor. In fact, he says, trade in its entirety is too small a percentage of the gross domestic product to greatly influence wages.
Trade is a cause of income inequality, Mr. Krugman acknowledges, but he says other factors are more important -- primarily the onslaught of new technology. Because of that, the demand for highly skilled people -- from computer programmers to top executives -- has soared, and their wages have gone up relative to the less skilled.
The Thurows of the world misunderstand another dynamic, he adds. As the Mexicans and Chinese shift into shirts and tires, American industry produces jet aircraft, cellular phones and other high-technology products to pay for the imports. "We raise the wage of skilled people who produce planes," Mr. Krugman said, "and lower the wage of those who are unskilled."
But, he said, the unskilled will probably not suffer over the long run. Incomes will rise in Mexico and China, Mr. Krugman said, as workers there become more productive. That was Japan's experience after World War II, and South Korea's more recently. The global pie, in effect, becomes bigger.
"If you can shift machinery from the United States to Mexico, why should you think that would level American wages down rather than Mexican wages up?" Mr. Krugman asked. "If a Mexican worker's output goes from one widget to 10 widgets a day, his wage rises to that level. If you strip the story down, this is the only explanation that makes sense."
Mr. Thurow offers an entirely different tale. With capital so mobile and transportation and communications improving constantly, companies can place their operations almost anywhere, he says. Even their high-technology operations are vulnerable as educated Russians and Eastern Europeans, for example, bid for work. Adding salt to this sore, low-wage countries focus their exports more than ever on the United States. In addition, the influx of immigrants is very similar to shifting production abroad, bringing the low-wage labor here instead of sending the work there. As a result, wages are driven down in areas like Southern California or Texas or Florida where there are many immigrants. And everywhere in the country, there is downward wage pressure simply from the threat of American companies' relocating or producing abroad.
"Russia has 800,000 scientists and engineers," Mr. Thurow declared in an M.I.T. lecture last month. "Why pay an American physicist $75,000 a year when you can get a Russian for $100 a month?" Moments later he invoked the image of a dress manufacturer with 18 factories around the world, linked by "high-definition television to control quality." This manufacturer, Mr. Thurow said, "tells customers: 'Don't worry whether the dress is made in Bangladesh or New York. It's the same item, same quality, same delivery time.' "
 
Growth, the Great Divide
Still, Mr. Thurow would not intervene in the global economy by restricting trade or impeding the flows of people and investment across borders. Nor would Mr. Krugman. They are both free traders. The best solution, they also agree, is more economic growth both here and abroad. But they are worlds apart on how to achieve that growth, or whether it is even possible.
The divide is over productivity, or output per worker, which has not been rising all that much lately in the United States and the rest of the industrial world. Ultimately, the only way to generate more growth, or national income, is to put more people to work or to find some way for each worker to produce more each hour.
Mr. Thurow would try to lift productivity in stages. He would start by stimulating the economy, perhaps through Government spending or lower interest rates, a Keynesian approach that is now considered by mainstream economists as more likely to produce inflation than real growth. For Mr. Thurow, however, the stimulus would open up opportunity, and the opportunity would pull up productivity.
A machine shop, for example, might open to serve a growing demand for auto parts. A waiter in a nearby diner, seizing an opportunity, takes a job as a grinder. Grinding auto parts produces more income than the same time spent waiting on tables. So the worker's output, measured in cash, rises. The diner raises its output per worker, too, by putting in a buffet. The customers, in effect, serve themselves, a form of automation.
"Productivity comes out of an economy that is pushed," Mr. Thurow said. "It is the result of what people do in response to the opportunities that growth makes possible, not the cause of growth."
Mr. Krugman calls this "wishful thinking." He, and most mainstream economists, say they do not know why the annual rise in productivity, or potential output, has slowed so much since the early 1970's. Nor do they claim to know how to reverse this poor performance. The math and the evidence, Mr. Krugman says, are inexorable. Whenever America's economic growth rate goes much above 2 percent -- its long-term ceiling -- the unemployment rate invariably falls. Workers are added to increase output, until the unemployment rate gets too low and the labor supply is exhausted -- simply bidding up wages without substantially increasing the nation's potential growth rate.
"All this seems pretty ironclad," Mr. Krugman writes in an article recently submitted to the Harvard Business Review.

Metaphors and Hypotheticals
Lester Thurow is a loner at M.I.T. He rarely attends the Wednesday lunches of the economics department or other faculty gatherings. His most prominent allies are not other academic economists but high-profile outsiders like Mr. Reich, the former Labor Secretary, and Robert Kuttner, a writer and editor of The American Prospect, a liberal magazine. For that matter, Mr. Thurow is seldom on campus. His new assistant, on the job since Dec. 3, saw her boss on fewer than five days through late January. He had visited London, Abu Dhabi, Istanbul, Mexico City, Aruba and Davos, Switzerland, among other stops, attending conferences, promoting foreign-language translations of "The Future of Capitalism" (William Morrow & Company, 1996) and speaking, always speaking. "As a traveler, he puts Jules Verne to shame," said Mr. Heilbroner, the economics historian and Mr. Thurow's sometimes co-author.
Yet, when the criticism comes, it is almost always preceded by praise. As dean of M.I.T.'s Sloan School of Management from 1987 until 1994, Mr. Thurow was by all accounts a big success, as a fund-raiser, promoter and prominent economist whose frequent television appearances made the school much more widely known. "Lester is a great citizen," said Rudiger Dornbusch, an M.I.T. economist. "You want anything done for the school, and he is there to do it."
That said, the criticism from mainstream American economists is rather blunt: Mr. Thurow's sweeping conclusions and forecasts are often wrong. He predicted, for example, that the international organization that supervises free trade, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, would fail. Under its new incarnation, the World Trade Organization, it thrives. Observing the rise of the Internet and television home-shopping channels, he predicted during a recent lecture that "a lot of conventional store shopping will disappear," a pronouncement that brings frowns of doubt to his mainstream critics.
In "Head to Head," a best seller published in 1992, he described a global struggle involving three antagonistic trading blocs, centered in the United States, Europe and Japan. Bill Clinton, then running for President, was photographed with the book in his hands. But the regional trading blocs have not emerged. "Are they even plausible today?" asked Robert Z. Lawrence, a trade economist at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government. (Mr. Thurow says they might yet materialize.)
The back-and-forth between Mr. Thurow and Mr. Krugman extends to their writing styles. In writing about economics for the public, both resort to metaphors or tales to make their point. But Mr. Thurow gets no peace here from Mr. Krugman, who says he misused the two key metaphors in "The Future of Capitalism." One was plate tectonics, comparing global economic forces to the earth's steadily moving plates. The other was punctuated equilibrium, drawn from evolutionary biology and used by Mr. Thurow to illustrate rapid and fundamental economic change punctuating the normally slow evolutionary process.
"I happen to know a fair amount about plate tectonics and a lot about punctuated equilibrium," Mr. Krugman said. "The latter is not taken seriously by good biologists. And if he is going to use plate tectonics, he must take into account that small events can unleash huge consequences. I am amazed he did not use plate tectonics in that sense."
Mr. Krugman, whose most recent popular books were "Peddling Prosperity" (W. W. Norton, 1994) and "Pop Internationalism" (M.I.T. Press, 1996), employs simple stories to illustrate economic theory -- a favorite being a baby-sitting cooperative with payments made in Popsicle sticks. But sarcasm is also a hallmark of the Krugman style, sometimes leveled gratuitously, even friends say.
He pleads guilty, at least in part. "If I am trying to get across an idea that people find hard to wrap their minds around," Mr. Krugman said, "one way to do it is to find an influential person who is saying something quite silly because he does not grasp the idea."
"That jolts people into trying to grasp the idea," he said, "and avoid sounding silly themselves."
 
The Tenacious Two
M.I.T. welcomed Mr. Krugman back last summer like a lost son. In 1994, he had gone off to a Stanford professorship with the woman he would soon marry, Robin Wells, an M.I.T. economist who had also landed a job there. By last spring, both wanted to return.
"I convened the faculty and notified the administration," said Paul Joskow, chairman of the M.I.T. economics department. "Within a few weeks, we put an offer together. Paul is very important to us."
Soon he was back on campus, a tenured professor again, reoccupying his old office in the suite with Mr. Solow and Mr. Samuelson, both fans of Mr. Krugman as a rising star in mainstream economics. But some of the mainstream economists in Mr. Krugman's camp are nevertheless critical of his view that the global economy has only limited impact on American wages.
Technology might have a greater impact on wages than the global economy does, said Michael J. Piore, a Harvard economist, but many factors play a role -- weaker unions, deregulation, job insecurity -- and assigning weights is futile. "The right position is agnostic," he said.
And Edward Leamer of the University of California at Berkeley has found that Chinese apparel makers do indeed exert downward pressure on wages here. When apparel workers lose jobs in this country because of the Chinese competition, they end up competing for jobs as gardeners, waiters, maintenance workers and the like. "So the Krugman view that trade is not a large share of the gross domestic product is completely irrelevant, in my view," Mr. Leamer said. "I've told him that, but when he gets committed to a viewpoint, he doesn't let go."
The same might be said of Mr. Thurow.
"Lester provokes, he challenges, he takes chances with ideas that are often wrong, blindly wrong," said Mr. Lawrence of Harvard, an ally of Mr. Krugman in the economics debate. "But he is a very original guy, and you need those people. You ask, 'Would I like to see the world run by Lester Thurow?' No. Nor Paul Krugman, for that matter. But do I value his creativity? Yes."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Lester Thurow, 58. Attended Williams College, went on to a Rhodes scholarship and earned his Ph.D from Harvard. Snared M.I.T. professorship when Paul Krugman was still a teen-ager and also served as a dean of M.I.T.'s business school. Since then, he's been a loner on the faculty, often closer to outside personalities than M.I.T. colleagues. In an effort to capture the big picture, he has gained a reputation for sweeping, hard-to-prove statements. Makes $30,000 a speech, and his total income exceeds $500,000. Paul Krugman, 43. Grew up in Merrick, L.I., and attended Yale. Earned Ph.D. from M.I.T., establishing himself quickly as a brilliant researcher. Named country's most outstanding economist under 40 in 1991 and is considered by fellow economists as a shoo-in for the Nobel prize. More partial to what can be measured and proved and fond of taking swipes at those who dispute him. Makes only $15,000 a speech, but his fees are rising, and his total annual income is around $250,000. (Photographs by Michael Quan for The New York Times) (pg. 1); Lester Thurow and Paul Krugman are handled by the same speakers' bureau, but are positioned differently. Mr. Thurow is presented as the doyen who can make economics "compelling for lay audiences." Mr. Krugman, his fellow M.I.T. economist, meanwhile, is being sold in the bureau's marketing book as the "outspoken and iconclastic" bad boy of the beat. (pg. 10)
 
Chart:
 
WHAT THUROW THINKS
The global economy, offering a huge supply of low-wage, foreign workers, is the principal cause of income inequality in this country, pulling down the wages of low-skilled American workers.
Greater economic growth is the solution. This requires more output from each worker, or higher productivity. By pushing the economy through measures that stimulate growth, opportunities will arise to increase productivity, and workers and companies will seize them.
 
WHAT KRUGMAN THINKS
Technology, not global competition, is the principal cause of American income inequality. The problem is here at home. The onslaught of technology, however, puts a premium on highly-skilled people, driving up their wages, but not those of the less skilled.
Trade represents is too small a portion of the American economy to greatly affect wages.
Greater economic growth through higher productivity is the solution, but no one knows how to raise productivity.
 
WHERE THEY AGREE
Both see income inequality and wage stagnation as big economic problems.
They see themselves as liberals, favoring stronger unions and more education and training to raise workers' skills. They also favor the redistribution of income through taxes to close the gap between rich and poor.
They are free-traders.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;
Overshadowed by 125th, 116th Street to Polish Image

BYLINE: By JANET ALLON

 BODY:
While planning for economic development in northern Manhattan continues, East 116th Street, the main commercial thoroughfare in East Harlem, is being overlooked, local leaders say. In fact, they say, it has been overlooked for quite some time.
"The street looks about the same way it did in the 30's," said Eddie Baca, executive director of the Local Development Corporation Del Barrio and chairman of Community Board 11. "People always talk about 125th Street, and 116th Street gets lost. It just has not been a priority." 
 The development corporation is promoting plans to revitalize East 116th Street. They include forming a unified merchants association, helping local businesses and stores get financing to fix up their facades and interiors, adding trees, making signs and lighting uniform, and studying whether to form a business improvement district.
"Right now, the street is a hodgepodge of signs and worn-out canopy frames from the 70's," said Raymond Plumey, an architect and planner who worked with the development corporation to create a plan for a more unified look on East 116th Street. "Some merchants use the sidewalk for display area, which adds to the congestion. There's absolutely no cohesiveness."
The development corporation has applied for an $800,000 block grant from the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone Development Corporation, which would provide about half the money for renovating stores and helping merchants. The Empowerment Zone is expected to decide on the application on March 7.
A few development projects are under way that could improve the street's fortunes. The street's eastern anchor, the old Washburn Wire factory, was recently purchased by the Blumenfeld Development Group, a Long Island-based commercial developer, which plans a retail and housing complex on the site.
Several housing developments are also planned or are already under construction. On the western end, construction is to begin this fall on Millennium on Fifth, a condominium. Project Return, a nonprofit social service group, is completing 90 units of housing for the elderly between First and Pleasant Avenues. The East Harlem Building for the Community, a nonprofit housing group, is putting together financing for 200 units of housing above commercial space on an empty lot between Park and Madison Avenues.
The development corporation is also suggesting a new use for La Marqueta, the small shopping bazaar underneath the Park Avenue viaducts at 116th Street. "We're suggesting that that be a Latin jazz and entertainment district," said Mr. Baca, who is calling for the city's Economic Development Corporation to commit $3.5 million that it had once promised, then revoked from La Marqueta. JANET ALLON

HEADLINE: Goodbye, Divorce Court

BYLINE: By BERNARD STAMLER

 BODY:
EVERYBODY likes to talk about divorce. If not their own, then their sister's, brother's, cousin's, friend's. Or you-know-who's or what's his-name's. At social gatherings I attended over the last several years, strangers would invariably turn to me with eager eyes once they found out I was a divorce lawyer. Clucking sympathetically at "how hard it must be," they were nevertheless hungry for dirt. And full of questions.
"Have you ever represented anyone famous?" they would ask. (I have, but I'll never tell you whom.) "Do you represent more men or more women?" (About a 50-50 split.) "What's the worst, nastiest case you ever handled?" (Hard to choose among so many miserable candidates for the honor.) Followed, of course, by, "Let me pick your brain about this situation. . . ." 
 Well, no more. I've been out of the divorce business since September, burnt out after 17 years in practice and 16 in the field of family law. I'm a full-time student at Columbia now, hoping to add an M.S. in journalism to my J.D. Now when people ask me what I do, the answer doesn't intrigue them nearly as much as it used to. I'm no longer the focus of everyone's prurient interest, and I confess that I miss the attention a bit.
Otherwise, to say that I have no regrets is to put it mildly.
Of course, I didn't leave the law on a whim. Going back to school in your mid-40's and starting from scratch is not necessarily the most appealing of prospects. The loss of income, the thought of the long years needed to build a new career and the possibility of failure kept me awake through many long nights. My wife, bless her, encouraged me as best she could, but it was ultimately my decision to make.
At last, I made the decision because I was tired. Tired of all the lawyer-bashing by headline-hungry politicians and appellate judges who in fact bear much blame for many of the problems for which they hold lawyers responsible. Tired of the indifference and ineptitude of many of the trial court judges, and the costly chaos many of my clients endured as a result. And, yes, tired of some of those clients, too, the ones whose anger and bitterness blind them to the folly of their conduct and who blame everyone but themselves for their problems, most especially their lawyers.
Don't matrimonial lawyers deserve some of the blame for the lamentable state of the divorce courts today? Of course. There are plenty of unethical and incompetent divorce lawyers, and lots of fee-gougers, too, all of whom contribute to a less-than-flattering public image. But to condemn the entire matrimonial bar for all the problems with New York family law is just flat-out wrong. For the real problem is not the lawyers; it is the Alice-in-Wonderland system in which they work.
The trip through the looking glass starts with the very basis of the divorce itself. New York is not a "no fault" state; unless you've been legally separated for at least a year, you have to have grounds to get a divorce. The grounds are adultery, abandonment for more than a year and "cruel and inhuman" treatment. Once you've proven one of these, you are entitled to a divorce and to a financial settlement. Yet, by law, the judge must decide how to divide your property and award support without any reference to your spouse's bad acts, which you've just taken such pains to prove.
Confused? You've got lots of company. This contradiction confuses most people. How can it be that fault is required for divorce, but that it has no bearing on other decisions in the divorce case? I can't begin to estimate how many times I was asked that question by unhappy clients whose spouses had truly done them wrong. I never had a decent answer.
 
Lie? In a Court of Law?
The Judge Demands It
 In any event, the practical consequences of this legal bifurcation are enormous. People are not allowed to get divorces on consent, as they are in other states, so they often make up a ground and swear to untrue allegations of misfeasance just to get unhitched. Everyone -- that includes the judges -- knows just what they're doing, too, and the practice is universally allowed. More than that: it is encouraged. Innumerable are the times a judge has warned me in conference that my client will be "punished" if he or she dares to "waste the court's time" by introducing evidence of the real fault in the case.
Others use the issue of grounds as a sword to gain financial leverage. I had a client whose husband of many years had left her for a much younger woman. He had no ground for divorce, but desperately wanted one so that he could remarry. My client -- who had the grounds -- refused to use them until he anted up.
There are even times when a spouse just won't go along with a divorce no matter what. That's exactly what happened in one of my cases. The marriage was as lousy as it was long, but the husband had never done anything overtly bad. Instead, for years, he had criticized his wife and driven her crazy with his complaining. Still, he was loyal, hard-working and a good provider. The wife sued for divorce and lost, with the judge finding that there was not enough evidence of cruelty. For all I know, these two are still married, living in separate homes and not speaking to each other.
As bad as that sounds, at least their case was heard. In this city and its suburbs, where there are simply not enough judges handling matrimonial cases, that's no easy task. Ask any divorce litigant about the problem. Everything takes forever, or so it seems to parties who can wait months for the resolution of requests for temporary support or custody, and years for a trial. Arguing a motion can be a daylong exercise, as the lawyers wait for endless lists of cases to be called. Conferences also take far longer than they should, as the lawyers wait for judges to finish other conferences or, in some cases, for the judge to show up in the first place.
As for the conferences -- well, many are colossal wastes of time. As the clients sit fretting outside, wondering what can be taking so long in the chambers to which the judge and lawyers have retreated, the latter are more than likely telling each other jokes or talking about how much the judge hates matrimonial cases. "They're all liars," he or she will say about the litigants, without benefit of knowing a thing about the case. "They'd better settle, or else!"
Like all New York judges, those who hear divorce cases, whether elected or appointed, are products of local party politics. Since the public at large pays almost no attention to judicial elections or to judicial selection, politicians pretty much choose the judges at their whim.
Are there any qualifications for divorce judges that set them apart? None. There are no prerequisites for becoming a matrimonial judge, and many who preside over divorce cases have never practiced matrimonial law in their lives. Indeed, since family law cases are considered to be messy, "bottom of the barrel" sorts of things, they are often given to the most inexperienced judges, those who don't have the seniority to protest. Or they are farmed out to judicial hearing officers, who are retired judges, or to special referees, who are lawyers who work for judges, and not judges at all.
What a nightmare! More than once I have had to remind an elderly hearing officer of the names of the parties sitting before him, or the testimony he has just heard but already forgotten. And I have often been told by a newly assigned judge that he or she knows nothing about divorce law, even as he or she sits in judgment over my client. Imagine hearing something like that from your doctor just as you begin surgery!
Furthermore, regardless of whether they have experience, many judges have deep-seated prejudices against either men or women. Depending on whether you are a man or a woman, you wouldn't want certain judges presiding over your divorce because you wouldn't stand a chance, no matter what the circumstances of the case.
In one case of mine, for example, a Manhattan judge who was legendary for her anti-male bias ordered a husband to pay so much more in child support than his wife said she needed that he panicked and left town, absconding with his retirement funds to Mexico. Another Manhattan judge ordered a client to pay his wife tens of thousands of dollars in support more than he earned. He had decided that the man could earn at least $100,000 a year and ordered him to get a job paying that much, as if such positions could be had for the asking.
It was, in fact, this kind of injustice that finally provoked the authorities to begin rotating judges in and out of the matrimonial courtrooms. As a result, the roster of divorce judges in Manhattan has changed three times in the last two years, and cases have been assigned and then reassigned. This creates even more problems and delays, as new judges have to learn old facts and lawyers have to go over the same ground again and again.
For which repetition they must charge their clients.
 
A Lawyer's Lot:
Hurry Up and Wait
 Matrimonial lawyers bill on the basis of time expended, usually $250 to $500 an hour in Manhattan. They charge whether the time was wisely spent or stupidly imposed on them. When a lawyer has to wait three hours to spend five minutes with a judge or has to repeat things that were said long before, the client foots the bill. Often, the bill becomes enormous. Yet while various customer groups and judicial commissions have pointed fingers at lawyers' billing practices as the cause of the astronomical legal fees now all too common in divorce cases, they rarely acknowledge the sheer magnitude of the time lawyers spend attending to judges who are accountable to no one for the lawyers' time, and clients' money, that they waste.
Nor do they acknowledge the responsibility the clients themselves bear for the fees about which they so bitterly complain.
To be sure, clients face an intimidating task when they enter the matrimonial arena. They are generally angry and upset, understandably so, and they are also suggestible. And as many people have pointed out, wives are often more vulnerable than husbands, both emotionally and economically, since they may be financially dependent on their husbands and occupied with the care of the children. These women don't know the law, or quite understand it, and yes, there are some lawyers who take advantage of that fact by urging their clients to take costly and unnecessary action.
But most clients, men or women, need little urging to act foolishly. As a result, much of a good lawyer's work involves preventing the client from giving in to his or her most self-destructive impulses.
I suppose it is human nature to want validation or even revenge when one feels wronged by a loved one. Yet many people are so angry that they lose all perspective, and demand that their lawyer help them in "destroying" a spouse through financial or custodial battling. And if the lawyer suggests a more rational or humane approach, or one more likely to succeed, this kind of angry client is likely to accuse him or her of weakness, incompetence or even complicity with the other spouse.
When it comes to anger, I've seen it all. There was the couple who hurled cigarette-filled ashtrays across a conference room as the lawyers ducked for cover. There was the wife who threw herself down the stairs and pretended she was pushed, and the wife who sold their house out from under her husband by having an impostor appear at the closing.
Then there was the Manhattan husband who insisted that he could retire and take care of their child, with his soon-to-be ex-wife supporting him. (I'll never forget the moment he said to the judge -- a woman -- that working women were by definition incapable of raising children properly.) There was the father who enlisted his sons in an "army" so that they could physically attack their mother and get medals and promotions for doing so. And there was the Brooklyn mother who refused to let her husband, a clergyman, see their small son because, she said, she alone in the world knew how to care for him. At the custody hearing, she fell to irrational pieces, much like Captain Queeg in "The Caine Mutiny."
Yet, as crazy as it sounds, every one of these people will probably swear to you, even today, that what he or she did was morally right.
As a lawyer, you are supposed to represent your client and obey the client's wishes. Too often, their anger forces you to sally forth like Don Quixote, your lance dipped in vitriol. Whether you have a reasonable chance of winning is beside the point to the client, who may well cite the all-too-predictable failure of your efforts as a justification for not paying you later on.
Which brings up another sore point: lots of clients don't pay their bills. As a small-business man, I grew tired of carrying accounts receivable on the scale of a multinational corporation. And I grew tired of clients' telling me to litigate issues on credit that should never should have been litigated at all, or telling me why financing their Caribbean vacation was more important than paying me.
Finally, the problem of over-litigation by many clients is compounded by the near-total anarchy that has lately come to define the law on custody and finances. After decades of rarely deigning to smudge its fingertips on the nasty problems of divorce litigants, the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, now seems hellbent on changing many precedents the lower appellate courts established in the field. As a result, everything is changing, and not necessarily for the better. It's become a free-for-all, and many clients seem to believe that anything is worth a shot nowadays.
 
When in Doubt,
Fight It Out
 Examples of the chaos abound. A parent may now be allowed to move with a child to a distant place even though that would violate the other parent's visitation rights, something that was not allowed very often in the past. Now, because the Court of Appeals says it might be all right after all, parents have another reason to fight over custody and the possible departure of their children for inaccessible places.
At one time, child support was fixed by law at a certain percentage of gross parental income up to $80,000 a year, and apportioned between parents based upon their respective earnings. But the Court of Appeals has now approved applying the percentages to a couple's total income. Unfortunately, the court established no clear-cut criteria for making this determination.
As a result, fathers with financial means, fearful of losing their prosperity, are now thinking about custody fights far more than they ever did. Where mothers once might have settled cases, they are now refusing, hoping to hit the jackpot. The practical consequence again: more litigation, more delay, more expense.
More fighting. In our adversary system, after all, that's what you're supposed to do in court: fight. Except that fighting costs more than it ever did before. Clients are confused and angry, and because anything seems possible, their expectations are often unrealistic and are rarely met. The clients are therefore almost never happy with the results of their lawyers' labors. A "thank you" in the divorce business has become as rare as snow in July.
So I gave it up. To a person, every colleague who learned of my decision last year congratulated me. They envied my escape from what has become a depressing and an aggravating business. They are still in the practice of law today, and they all confirm that I did the right thing.
In fact, by giving up my law practice, I have attained the kind of celebrity with my peers that I lost with the public at large. When we meet, it is they who gather round, eager to see if it's true that there's life after matrimonial law.
Believe me, there is.

How a Bad Law May Have Become Worse
DIVORCE law has always been something of a stepchild in the family of New York jurisprudence.
The influence of the Roman Catholic Church restricted the availability of divorces for many years. Until 1967, the only ground for divorce in New York was adultery. And to avoid collusive divorces, the courts required corroboration, meaning that an admission of adultery was not enough. You needed a third party -- a private eye, usually -- to confirm that a tryst had occurred.
So New Yorkers who wanted divorces were often obliged to go elsewhere. Depending on the era, that might have meant Mexico, the Dominican Republic or Reno, Nev. George Cukor's 1939 film "The Women" is all about rich New Yorkers moving to Nevada for six weeks to be divorced.
Eventually, the Divorce Reform Law was enacted 30 years ago, expanding the grounds to those of today, which do not include any kind of no-fault ground. Couples were no longer required to attend state "conciliation bureaus," which were intended to encourage divorce-bound couples to reconsider their decision.
Still, until 1980, the law concerning marital property remained archaic. In New York, property belonged by law to the person who held title, regardless of what was fair. So, for example, if a couple's home or a husband's business was in his name alone, it became his in the divorce, period. To even the score, a wife could receive alimony for life, unless she was found at fault.
The 1980 Equitable Distribution Law changed all that. Marital property was to be evaluated and distributed "equitably," regardless of title. Either a husband or a wife could get maintenance (the word alimony was abandoned), but not necessarily permanently. The law was trumpeted as a solution to the economic injustice that wives often suffered in a divorce.
But the law never defined "property." Did it include licenses and educational degrees? How about professional practices that could not be sold, like law practices? Since these and many other kinds of small or family businesses are not usually bought and sold, how do you determine market value?
While divorces were never cheap, the confusion following the 1980 law caused costs to explode. Because of all the uncertainty, most of the early cases involving substantial assets were litigated extensively and appealed. While a consensus eventually emerged, the Court of Appeals now seems to be changing some of the rules.
In almost every case now, there have to be accountants, appraisers and actuaries as well as lawyers. If there are custody disputes, there have to be psychologists and psychiatrists. Economists have been called in some cases to establish the value of homemaking services or the likelihood of a person's ability to enter the workplace. In many cases, where dishonesty is suspected, there is endless detective work, and there can be long, drawn-out depositions.
The resolution of such complex issues takes time, perseverance and money, all of which may be in short supply for the economically dependent spouse, usually the wife. As a result, some advocates say the Equitable Distribution Law has actually resulted in more injustice for women, not less. BERNARD STAMLER

1546 -- First civil divorce granted by special act of Parliament. There are no divorce lawyers, just members of the House of Lords.
 
1787 -- Adultery becomes the only ground for divorce in New York. For the next 200 years, divorce lawyers will have to peep through keyholes. Disdained by establishment lawyers, the practice is dominated by groups like Jews and women who are also disdained by the establishment.
 
1972-1979 The Marvin v. Marvin case is litigated in California. Marvin Mitchelson coins the word "palimony," and being a divorce lawyer becomes glamorous. Mitchelson will later be convicted of tax evasion.
 
1986 -- "L.A. Law" premieres on television. Corbin Berson plays Arnold Becker, the high-powered, lecherous divorce lawyer with looks, money and women all over him. Fantasy television.
 
1991 -- "Civil Wars" makes its television debut. In the first episode, Eli Levinson, a divorce lawyer played by Alan Rosenberg, has a nervous breakdown because of the crazy clients and all of the stress. Reality television. (pg. 12)

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;
City to Consider Allowing Merchants to Run Market as a Co-op

BYLINE: By JANE H. LII

 BODY:
In its latest effort to quell mounting discontent among merchants at Mart 125, the city-owned indoor market, the city has agreed to consider the merchants' request that they be allowed to buy the building and run the market as a co-op.
Councilwoman C. Virginia Fields said the agreement came during a meeting between her and the Commissioner of the Department of Business Services, Earl Andrews. 
 But both Ms. Fields and Deputy Mayor Rudy Washington say it is premature to assume that the city will agree to a co-op plan. Mr. Washington said the merchants first had to improve their balance sheets and show that they could manage a joint operation. "Until people can demonstrate they can run something successfully," he said, "we are not going to do anything."
Since opening in 1986, the market has had many problems including a leaky roof, uncollected garbage and a broken air-conditioner. A city audit in 1994 showed that the former sponsor, the Harlem Urban Development Corporation, owed the city more than $2 million.
Richard Hollins, president of the Mart 125 Merchants Association and the owner of the R & B Jewelry stall, attributes the problems to the city's refusal to give the merchants a stake in the market. "Instead of helping us to achieve our goal, the state and the city have forced one management company after another on us," Mr. Hollins said.
Last April, the city, which owns the mart building on 125th Street between Frederick Douglass and Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevards, brought in the the Masjid Malcolm Shabazz mosque as sponsor to repair the roof and air-conditioner and to buy radio advertisements to publicize the mart, Mr. Washington said. The city also recently adjusted rents to better reflect the size of the stalls. A few rents were raised but most were lowered, some by as much as $200 a month. Most rents are now $400 to $800 a month. Still, some merchants are continuing a rent strike under way almost since the mart opened.
Merchants were also angry when they found out that the Department of Citywide Administrative Services, which manages the building, applied last August to transfer the property to the Department of Economic Development. The city said the transfer was a necessary step for offering tenants long-term leases. But many vendors say they think the city wants to sell the building to private investors.
Some merchants, even those who support the co-op say they are worried about whether the concept could work.
The owner of a bath oil stall in the mart, Alvin Reid Jr., said he did not want to borrow money to buy into the co-op. "To me, the most important thing is to get business back to normal," Mr. Reid said. "Unless business picks up, I don't want to incur more debt." JANE H. LII

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
The Not-So-Invisible Hand In the Great Dow Climb

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
THE mutual fund industry has been going to great lengths to deny responsibility for the stock market's boisterous rally, which last week took the Dow Jones industrial average above 7,000 and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index over 800, each for the first time.
At a recent meeting with reporters, Don Powell, the chairman of he Investment Company Institute, the industry's leading trade group, and of Van Kampen/American Capital, a family of mutual funds owned by Morgan Stanley & Company, tried to dismiss the notion by saying that mutual funds owned only 14 percent of corporate equities in this country, far less than the amount owned by individuals and pension funds. 
 John Rea, the chief economist of the trade group, concurred, telling the meeting that the institute's studies showed "no correlation between the performance of the equity market and mutual fund flows."
But plenty of people believe otherwise. For evidence, look at what happened on Wednesday, when the institute reported that $24 billion flowed into stock mutual funds in January. Within a half-hour, the Dow industrials doubled their gain for the day. On Thursday, the Dow industrials continued their rally, moving above the latest thousand-point mark before falling to 6,988.96 at Friday's close.
That Wall Street traders and brokers are watching mutual fund cash flows is clear to Melissa Brown, a quantitative analyst at Prudential Securities, who each week sends Prudential's brokers and traders a summary of the cash flow reports provided by AMG Data Services, an independent fund-tracking company in Arcata, Calif.
"We crunch the numbers every week, and if our report is five minutes late, people get upset," Ms. Brown said.
At Smith Barney, professionals ranging from equity traders, who must make minute-to-minute investment decisions, to brokers, who presumably work with a longer-term perspective, are "all pretty interested" in how much cash is coming into the firm's mutual funds, said Jessica Bibliowicz, who oversees the mutual funds unit.
"Does mutual fund cash flow affect the market?" she asked. "I think it definitely does."
To be sure, the $24 billion that flowed into equity mutual funds, as estimated by the Investment Company Institute, was not a record for inflows in a single month. That accolade belongs to January 1996, when $28.9 billion moved in. And when measured as a percentage of assets already invested in stock funds, last month's inflow of 1.37 percent fell below the level recorded in each of the first five months last year.
OTHER factors have also have helped keep the market moving ahead. Corporate earnings are robust. The economy is humming. The dollar is strong. Consumers are confident and intent on saving for the future.
Since late 1990, those factors have combined to fuel a nearly unbroken rise in stock prices. During that time, the Dow industrials have not fallen more than 10 percent below their peak level.
Only one thing has changed: the portion of corporate equities held by mutual funds.
According to the Federal Reserve, that percentage has more than doubled since the end of 1990, to 14.3 percent from 6.6 percent. (Like most Government statistics, the Fed's numbers are somewhat dated. The most recent figures measure holdings through the third quarter of 1996.)
Over the same period, the portion of equities owned by individuals directly rather than through mutual funds fell only slightly, to 47.7 percent from 49.9 percent. The portion owned by pension plans, both government and corporate, and insurance companies edged down from 30.2 percent to 28.6 percent. Foreign ownership fell, too, to 6.1 percent from 6.9 percent.
Some of the transfer of stock ownership from individuals to mutual funds might simply be money going out of one pocket and into another. Assume, for example, that John Q. Public's employer replaces the employee pension plan with a 401(k) retirement plan, and Mr. Public decides to sell those utility stocks left to him by his aunt and use the extra money to increase his contributions to his 401(k) plan.
In the Federal Reserve's data that would register as a decline in personal holdings of securities and a rise in mutual fund holdings, although the net result would, in fact, be a wash.
But if Mr. Public's employer matches a portion of his contribution, as many employers do, that would increase the mutual fund holdings of equities. And over time, as those mutual funds performed better than those stodgy utility stocks favored by Auntie Public, the fund's portion would grow further.
THE growth of the mutual fund industry has affected the stock market in other ways, too. Individuals who own stocks are far less likely to be active traders than are mutual fund managers. According to Morningstar Inc., the Chicago fund trackers, nearly one-quarter of the mutual funds that invest in a broad array of American stocks turn over their entire portfolios each year.
And increasingly, the fund managers are focusing on the stocks of the biggest American corporations. To keep up with the soaring returns of the Dow industrials and the S.& P. 500, many managers have been bidding up the prices of the largest stocks while ignoring their smaller cousins.
The difference is stark. While the S.& P. 500 index of big-company stocks gained 9.6 percent from the beginning of the year through Thursday, the S.& P. index of 600 small-cap stocks had grown just 1.4 percent.
Few fund managers can find a reason, it seems, not to own popular stocks like those of the technology leaders Intel and Cisco Systems, or of long-term blue-chip corporations like I.B.M. and Merck. To illustrate, those four companies are among the top 10 holdings of both the Fidelity Blue Chip Growth fund, which focuses on stocks of well-known and established companies, and the Fidelity Emerging Growth fund, which aims to buy developing companies.
Looking at such trends makes people like Ms. Brown, the Prudential analyst, scoff at the fund industry's notion that flows to mutual funds are not driving the market's gains. "People are paying a lot of attention to those numbers," she said.
Which raises the question: What happens if the cash flow to mutual funds slows down?
"One week's or one month's data truly don't tell you anything," Ms. Brown said. "But a lot of people are nervous about the valuation levels of the market. They may be betting that the underlying support of the mutual fund flows will continue." So, she said, "If those flows dry up, it's Katy bar the door."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "A Different Perspective"
This chart, plotted on a logarithmic scale, gives the same visual weight to comparable percentage changes. A 100-point rise when the Dow Jones industrial average is at 1,000 looks the same here as a 700-point rise when the Dow is at 7,000. Through this lens, the Dow's recent run-up looks less extraordinary.

HEADLINE: Our Best Defense

BYLINE: By James A. Baker 3d; James A. Baker 3d, Secretary of State under President George Bush, is honorary chairman of the James A. Baker 3d Institute for Public Policy at Rice University.

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
The Chemical Weapons Convention an international treaty that commits member nations to destroy their chemical weapons and to forswear future production, acquisition or use of them -- is before the Senate for approval. Despite the fact that the treaty was negotiated under Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush, a number of Republicans have expressed reservations about it. I respect their motives, but their concerns are misplaced.
For instance, some have argued that we shouldn't commit to the treaty because rogue states like Libya, Iraq and North Korea, which have not signed it, will still be able to continue their efforts to acquire chemical weapons. This is obviously true. But the convention, which has been endorsed by 68 countries and will go into effect in April whether or not we have ratified it, will make it more difficult for these states to do so by prohibiting the sale of materials to nonmembers that can be used to make chemical weapons. 
 In an ideal world, rogue states and terrorist groups would simply give up the use of chemical weapons. But ours is not an ideal world. The Chemical Weapons Convention recognizes that, and so should its opponents. It makes no sense to argue that because a few pariah states refuse to join the convention the United States should line up with them rather than with the rest of the world.
Others have argued that if we ratify the treaty, we will not be able to verify that all members will abide by it. No international agreement, of course, is perfectly verifiable -- just as no domestic law is perfectly enforceable. But the treaty sets up a verification system, including international inspections on short notice, that will be far more effective than what we possess today. Moreover, the treaty would strengthen information-sharing among member states. It would increase, not diminish, our understanding of chemical weapons threats.
Some opponents of the treaty claim that it would create yet another costly international bureaucracy and place an onerous regulatory burden on American business. Both assertions are overstated. Our share for administering the treaty would be about $25 million a year, a truly modest amount in a Federal budget of about $1.7 trillion. Only about 140 companies would have significant reporting requirements, while some 2,000 others would be asked to fill out a short form.
Moreover, failure to ratify the treaty would actually cost the American chemical industry hundreds of millions of dollars in sales by making United States exporters subject to trade restrictions by convention members. Our joining the convention could help American business -- which is why the chemical industry supports ratification.
Other critics assert that the treaty would somehow infringe on our national sovereignty -- in particular, the Fourth Amendment ban on unreasonable search and seizure. In fact, it explicitly permits members to abide by their constitutional requirements when providing access to international inspectors. Under the treaty, involuntary inspection of American manufacturing and storage sites would still require legally acquired search warrants. The idea that ratifying the treaty would repeal part of our Bill of Rights is simply wrong.
But by far the most important argument against the treaty is that ratification would somehow undermine our national security.
Nothing could be further from the truth. Let me be blunt: The idea that Ronald Reagan and George Bush would negotiate a treaty detrimental to this nation's security is grotesque.
The United States does not need chemical weapons as a deterrent. Any nation or group contemplating a chemical attack against us must reckon with our overwhelming conventional force and vast nuclear arsenal. Each is more than sufficient to deter a chemical attack.
Chemical weapons are relatively easy to develop and cheap to manufacture, so it is no coincidence that the rogue nations now seeking to build chemical arsenals are economically impoverished and technologically backward. Unlike Iraq or Libya, we don't need such weapons to project our influence. In fact, we are already committed -- under a law signed in 1985 by President Reagan -- to destroy our existing chemical weapons stockpile by 2004. We will do this whether or not we ratify the treaty.
What we need is a way to limit the risk that American troops or civilians may someday face a chemical weapons attack. The convention can help do precisely this by controlling the flow of illicit trade materials and by making it easier to marshal international support for the political, diplomatic and economic isolation of countries that refuse to ratify it.
If we fail to ratify the convention, we will not only forgo any influence in the continuing effort against chemical weapons, we will also risk postponing indefinitely any progress on an international ban on the equally dire threat of biological weapons. More generally, we will imperil our leadership in the entire area of nonproliferation, perhaps the most vital security issue of the post-cold-war era.
Today we face a monumental choice requiring a bipartisan consensus, just as we did in ratifying the North American Free Trade Act in 1993. Failure to ratify the Chemical Weapons Convention would send a message of American retreat from engagement in the world. For this reason -- and because our national interest is better served by joining the convention than by lining up with pariah states outside it -- I support the treaty and urge my fellow Republicans to do the same.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
South Africa Slips in Role Of a 'Tiger'

BYLINE: By GREGORY JORDAN 

 BODY:
THREE years ago, South Africa seemed on the verge of stealing the "economic tiger" title from its Asian counterparts. Its peaceful transition to majority rule and a booming, liquid stock market looked promising. Three closed-end funds began for eager American investors, and a couple of open-end funds followed suit.
But last year, the market tumbled on inflation and political uncertainty, and the South African rand wobbled. Talk died down of South Africa eclipsing the high-growth Asian economies, which represent three-fourths of emerging-market stock holdings. 
 Managers of funds with an African focus have responded in part by spreading their assets among other nations, including Ghana, Mauritius and Zimbabwe.
Jaideep Khanna, who manages the Morgan Stanley Africa Investment fund, says South African equities dropped to about 40 percent of his portfolio in the last quarter of 1996, from nearly 70 percent in 1994.
"Right now, South Africa is bouncing back, but we're also moving into Botswana, Egypt, Ghana, Mauritius, Zimbabwe and others," Mr. Khanna said. "They're going in cycles -- you can't really say the Asian tiger growth has taken hold."
Partly because of its shift away from South Africa, the Morgan Stanley fund, the biggest of the group at $304 million in assets, had a total return of 9.9 percent for the 12 months ended in January, while the South African stock market, as tracked by the Financial Times Actuaries, was down 24 percent in dollar terms.
Among the three closed-end funds that began in early 1994, the best performer has been the Southern Africa Fund. From its inception through January, it had a total return of 75 percent, versus 58 percent for the Morgan Stanley fund and 19 percent for the New South Africa fund, reported Lipper Analytical Services, the fund trackers.
 These three funds have been trading at about a 20 percent discount to the value of their underlying assets. Closed-end funds issue a set number of shares, which trade on a stock exchange, usually at a discount or a premium, depending on investor interest.
AMONG the region's open-end funds, which continuously issue new shares, the Merrill Lynch Middle East/ Africa fund kept its loss small last year. The fund, with $7.8 million in assets, has made big bets on Egypt and South Africa, with the latter slipping to 23 percent of holdings last November from 28 percent a year earlier.
 "These African countries are still very early in their reforms," said Grace Pineda, the fund's manager. "But fundamental changes in Africa now justify investment in the whole region, not only South Africa."
 Other open-end funds that focus on the area are Calvert New Africa and Lexington Strategic Investments, which buys South African mining stocks. ASA Limited, a closed-end fund that dates to 1958, similarly invests in mining concerns and has a big stake in South Africa.
Funds that invest in emerging markets around the world often provide a little exposure to sub-Saharan Africa, too. According to Ian Wilson, editor of Micropal Emerging Market Fund Monitor, these funds had $4.4 billion in Africa in the third quarter, and two-thirds of them have African holdings.
Still, managers note the speculative nature of investing in Africa and the painful transition from an economy based on agriculture and natural resources to one based on manufacturing. They cite political instability in Nigeria and Zaire and tie growth in countries like Zimbabwe to good weather and agricultural output. "You can't really compare African economies with other emerging markets yet," Mr. Khanna said. "It's the last place capital goes."

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: James D. Oelschlager;
White Oak Growth Stock Fund

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
TIRED of trailing the Standard & Poor's 500?
Plenty of investors are. In frustration, many are flocking to funds that mimic the index. 
 But among those still trying to beat the benchmark, a few have planted their money in the tiny White Oak Growth Stock fund, which invests in large growth stocks and has outperformed the index handily over the last three years.
Last month alone, the fund's assets rose more than 50 percent, to $62 million, said James D. Oelschlager, who manages White Oak, which is not yet five years old, and the Pin Oak fund, its small-capitalization stock counterpart, from Akron, Ohio.
No wonder White Oak is getting attention. Fund investors generally consider a large-capitalization growth fund a core holding in their portfolios. Such funds tend to own the biggest blue chips -- like I.B.M. and Coca-Cola -- whose earnings are growing quickly.
Among these funds, White Oak has been an exception. Only 11 of 108 large-cap growth funds beat the S.& P. over the three years, according to Morningstar Inc., the Chicago fund researchers. White Oak gained 30.4 percent a year, on average, in the three years ended in January, versus 20.7 percent for the S.& P. and 16.8 percent for the average large growth-stock fund. White Oak, a no-load fund, rose 39.4 percent in 1996, versus 26.3 percent for the S.& P.
Mr. Oelschlager, 54, does battle daily not only with fund rivals, but also with a personal demon, multiple sclerosis. He swims each morning in his indoor pool before leaving for work at Oak Associates, his $5 billion money management firm. It is one of the few forms of exercise available to him since he was confined to a wheelchair in 1985. But he brushes off his misfortune. "Everyone gets dealt some good and bad cards in life," he said, "and I've gotten lots of good ones."
Investments piqued his curiosity in the seventh grade, when he reaped the princely sum of $25 a week on his Cleveland Plain Dealer paper route. His father introduced him to a stockbroker, who helped him invest his earnings. Except for several years attending law school and then a short stint practicing law, he has remained enamored of the investment business.
As a manager, Mr. Oelschlager runs a tight ship. White Oak owns just 22 stocks, with technology accounting for 65 percent of the portfolio, financial services 25 percent and health care 10 percent. Broad diversification is not his fund's goal. "We're concentrated in areas and number of issues," he said, adding that he would run a $300 million individual portfolio the same way.
Over all, he is optimistic about stocks. "I don't think that valuations are excessive like they were in the early 1970's," he said. "People will be surprised how strong earnings reports will come in in 1997."
In particular, he is looking for technology stocks to gather momentum after their slump last summer. The most attractive area, he said, is wide-area networking, the business of linking computers around the world for a company or an enterprise.
When he picks stocks, Mr. Oelschlager looks for a price-earnings multiple lower than the company's projected rate of earnings growth. The stocks in his portfolio now trade at 25 to 30 times anticipated earnings for 1997. He also likes to buy when the multiple is near its five-year low.
Once he buys, he tends to hold. White Oak's annual turnover is roughly 25 percent, versus 90 percent for stock funds over all.
Because the market tends to be irrational in the short term, he said, "we don't get too concerned if a stock misses its quarterly earnings estimate by one or two cents."
"If a stock falls," he said, "we view that as a buy opportunity."

A Software Specialist
Whenever the stock price dips, he is adding to his stake in Parametric Technology, a software company in Waltham, Mass., with a market capitalization of $7.7 billion. It specializes in computer-aided design and supplies programs for mechanical engineers. Its markets are growing rapidly, especially abroad.
Mr. Oelschlager calls the company "a bit underfollowed" by Wall Street stock analysts and says it has a "record like clockwork" for earnings and revenue growth. Wall Street expects its earnings to grow about 35 percent a year, but he is even more optimistic about the company's managers. "They consistently do better than promised," he said.
Parametric, coming off a fantastic 1996, is trading at about 34 times his projected earnings for the year that will end in September. That multiple should drop to the mid-20's based on 1998 estimates, Mr. Oelschlager predicted, as earnings grow.

Riding a Chip Rebound
Another favorite is Applied Materials of Santa Clara, Calif., which makes equipment for the semiconductor industry and has a market capitalization of nearly $10 billion.
The ups and downs of semiconductor stocks may be too extreme, in his view. "We're seeing a pickup in the semiconductor markets after last year's slowdown," he said. "I think the semiconductor market is stronger than most, because people tend to overdo things on the downside."
Shares of Applied have recovered from their plunge last summer and absolutely soared last week. "There's more interest in this stock," he acknowledged, "but it still has a lot more room."
On Wednesday, stock analysts revised earnings estimates upward about 20 percent for the stock based on an improving outlook and first-quarter results. Mr. Oelschlager expects, however, that even these expectations will prove conservative. The stock price, now at $52.875, remains relatively inexpensive, he contends, at 25 times earnings estimates for the fiscal year ending in October and 16 times earnings for the next year.

A Big Bank, and Getting Bigger
In the financial services sector, Mr. Oelschlager is adding to his stake in Nationsbank, the Charlotte, N.C., banking giant with a market capitalization of $47 billion.
The company is well positioned to make more acquisitions, he said, and to expand its territory beyond its base in the Southeast. Last month, it acquired Boatmen's Bancshares of St. Louis for $9.76 billion. Nationsbank has "smart management with a good record of acquisitions in the South and Southwest, and enjoys the benefits of economies of scale as it consolidates," he said.
He expects annual earnings growth of 15 percent over the next three to five years. The stock is trading at about 13 times his expected earnings. Stock analysts expect Nationsbank to earn $8.57 a share this year, a modest increase from $8.01 in 1996. The stock has risen sharply since the Boatmen's acquisition was announced in August and since the recent announcement of a 2-for-1 stock split, to take effect on Feb. 27.
