HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Mets' McIlvaine Feels No Pressure as He Looks for Improvements

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH

DATELINE: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 15

 BODY:
Mets General Manager Joe McIlvaine will not entertain for a minute the thought that he might be the general manager on the griddle in New York.
Such an idea indicates pressure, self-induced and otherwise, and the 49-year-old executive refused to bite, his smile and his confidence as bright as the players' steps were lively during the Mets' first workout for pitchers and catchers today. 
 "I'm not the type that is going to put pressure on myself," McIlvaine said. "All I can do is, every day when I come here, every day when I go home, is think of some way to make the team better."
This refusal to acknowledge fledgling demons, or help them hatch, comes even though McIlvaine and the world know that he is in charge of the New York ball club that did not win it all last year, even though the view from the bleachers is that the Mets are undeniably "his team" now and that Manager Bobby Valentine is "his guy" -- phrases McIlvaine all but despises.
Yes, McIlvaine knows that from the moment he brought in Valentine to take over the Mets' Class AAA affiliate in Norfolk last year, most thought it only a matter of time before Valentine moved up. And Valentine did, in August, replacing Dallas Green, the manager McIlvaine inherited from Al Harizan in 1993 when he was named general manager.
" 'Your guy' -- I don't like that," said McIlvaine, even as the man he promoted led pitchers and catchers through their first spring training workout. "He's not Joe McIlvaine's manager; he is the manager of the New York Mets. And I expect from Bobby what I expect from any manager: to run the ball club, to see improvement, to see hard work and a good work ethic, and to see him utilizing his staff in the best way possible."
As for the idea that the last vestiges of Harizan's regime are gone and that this is McIlvaine's creation, good or bad, that is wrong, too, the general manager insisted.
"I've never looked at things that way because I think that you can profit from what was before you and you can add to it," McIlvaine said, even as such new acquisitions as relievers Greg McMichael, Toby Borland and Ricardo Jordan limbered up. "The main thing is, these are all New York Met players, no matter what source they came from, so I never look at it -- and never have -- as this being my team or anybody else's team."
Still, there is no denying that whatever improvements the Mets make, or do not make, they will be more likely linked to McIlvaine and his program, from the kind of acquisitions he made to what he does with the money allotted in the new economic realities of baseball.
It is a program McIlvaine stubbornly defends, from his disdain for checkbook baseball and the blind pursuit of free agents to his nursing of the minor league franchises.
Green may have grumbled at the end of his stay about McIlvaine's yearly visits to the minor league teams, which require 35 days each season. But, McIlvaine says: "The general manager is in charge of the organization. Bobby's been in the minors; he understands. Dallas did, too. He was a development guy, a scouting guy, too."
Even though McIlvaine played down the pressures that most likely will come his way this season, he did not mind continuing to turn up the dial on expectations. Earlier this month he said he expected the club to reverse last year's record. When the natural assumption was made that McIlvaine was therefore calling for a 91-71 finish, he avoided the numbers. Today he again backpedaled off the 91 victories, but only slightly. "I would never make predictions -- I never do," McIlvaine said. "I said that was our best goal -- that's all."
He then added: "But when I wrote to our players when we sent the contracts out, I said in order for us to be a contender, we need to reverse our record. We need a 20-game swing; it's as simple as that."
When asked whether needing, wanting and expecting were three different things, McIlvaine was blunt. "It's time to turn it up here and get going in the right direction."
McIlvaine knows that to improve, second baseman Carlos Baerga and the newly acquired first baseman John Olerud have to duplicate their best seasons in the American League. And young players, such as shortstop Rey Ordonez, right fielder Alex Ochoa and third baseman Butch Huskey, have to show measurable progress.
"If we do those things, we'll be fine," McIlvaine said. If not, then McIlvaine's resolve will surely be tested in the cauldron that is New York, a place where pressure has been known to singe even the most impervious of souls.
 
INSIDE PITCH
Manager BOBBY VALENTINE continued to prepare the Mets for life without JASON ISRINGHAUSEN, BILL PULSIPHER and PAUL WILSON, even though the first two of the injured pitchers hope to be ready by opening day. "They have to do an awful lot, and unless everything falls perfectly, I don't think there's time to put the injuries behind them," Valentine said.

HEADLINE: 68 NATIONS AGREE TO WIDEN MARKETS IN COMMUNICATIONS

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Feb. 15

 BODY:
More than 60 countries endorsed a landmark agreement today to open up their telecommunication markets to all rivals. The move legally commits governments to unlock the state telephone monopolies that still control well over half of the world's communications business.
The agreement here came after weeks of bruising negotiations, in which the United States pushed relentlessly for greater liberalization and slowly coaxed concessions from countries around the world. 
 The pact should lead to steep price reductions in many segments of the $602 billion worldwide annual market for communications. It marks a big vindication for the United States, which essentially vetoed a much more modest agreement in April.
The United States did not get everything it wanted. It failed to persuade Canada and Japan to end restrictions that block foreign companies from buying a controlling stake in their dominant telephone carriers.
But the United States announced modest restrictions on Japanese and Canadian companies -- including the blocking of Canada's ability to send direct-broadcast television signals into the United States -- to prompt further concessions before the accord goes into effect on Jan. 1.
In Washington, Charlene Barshefsky, the acting United States trade representative, said at a news conference, "U.S. companies are the most competitive telecommunications providers in the world, and they are in the best position to compete and win under this agreement."
Officials of AT&T, MCI, Sprint and other major telecommunications companies agreed. They noted, for instance, that under the agreements their subscribers on a business trip would eventually be able to call from Tokyo to Paris across an American company's telephone network, without using the state-dominated telephone systems of either country.
Ms. Barshefsky said today that the accord would "save billions of dollars for American consumers."
The Federal Communications Commission has estimated that the average cost of international telephone calls will drop over the next several years by 80 percent, from an average of $1 a minute to about 20 cents. Some cuts are already in effect.
The pact may also speed the introduction of new services that span the globe. Robert W. Kinzie, the chairman of Iridium, a company that is launching 66 satellites that will enable users of small "pocket phones," similar to cell phones, to call one another from anywhere in the world, called the agreement "absolutely critical."
"It means that no country can prevent us from allowing subscribers to call or be called, no matter where they are in the world," he said.
American officials in Washington also called today's agreement the largest accomplishment yet of the two-year-old World Trade Organization, which is both a negotiating forum to lower trade barriers and the arbiter of international trade disputes.
But it remains unclear how muscular the organization will prove to be, and whether it will have the authority to order countries that are slow to carry out the agreement to change their behavior under threat of suffer economic sanctions.
Nor does the agreement affect international restrictions on ownership of broadcasting and other media. That remains an untouchable issue for many countries, as for many members of the United States Congress, and was excluded from this agreement.
To a great extent, the agreement exports the regulatory principles that revolutionized the American long-distance market in the 1980's and are now being extended to unlock local telephone monopolies in the United States.
The biggest impact on consumers is likely to be in Asia, Latin America and Africa, where most governments have done little or nothing to reform the creaky state-controlled monopolies that provide shabby service at home and charge wildly inflated prices for international telephone calls.
The Institute for International Economics, a policy research organization in Washington, has estimated that the savings from new competition could total a staggering $1 trillion by 2010.
The deal will also force the United States and Europe to follow through on their plans to open every part of their own markets to wide-open rivalry: local and long-distance telephones, international service and wireless communications. Through the World Trade Organization, the agreement also creates a binding legal weapon for countries to enforce deregulation.
The most fiercely contested part of the agreement would do away with restrictions that prohibit a company based in one country from acquiring a controlling stake in the telephone carrier of another country. That is almost certain to intensify the frantic scramble among industry titans like AT&T, BT of Britain and NTT of Japan to buy or build their way into markets around the world.
The agreement is not expected to have much impact on the proposed merger between BT and MCI Communications, America's second largest long-distance company, because the United States and Britain were well on the way to an agreement on lowering restrictions between themselves.
But the pact could increase the competitive pressure to form "me too" alliances and mergers, perhaps linking major Asian, North American and European operators.
"We see this as a really defining event," said Gerald Taylor, chief executive of MCI. "It's not something that is measurable tomorrow, like a gun going off at a race. But what it is is a shift in attitude toward embracing deregulation, open markets and competition."
Jeffrey Lang, the deputy United States trade representative, who led the negotiations, said the agreement marked a milestone in both international trade and the communications industry.
"The most remarkable aspect of it, and what is truly an American idea, are the pro-competitive regulatory principles," he said today. "We knew from the very start that unless you could challenge the franchises of monopolies, you could never get real access."
The agreement provides a powerful new weapon to challenge countries that continue to shield their telephone companies, he said.
"The regulatory principles are enforceable just like a tariff agreement," he said. "You get the benefit of a W.T.O. dispute-settlement and enforcement mechanism on the process that countries use when they decide who gets a license."
Ian Taylor, Britain's Minister of Science and Technology, said the agreement would usher in a sea change in the choices and prices available in global communications.
"The order of magnitude is massive," he said. "There are estimates that the U.K. market alone will increase by $20 billion a year by the year 2010."
Though there have been some rumblings of mistrust from Congress in recent weeks, the new agreement is not expected to be blocked in Washington. The Clinton Administration contends, and most lawmakers agree, that it already has the necessary authority to negotiate a deal and does not need additional approval from Congress.
Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, has been hostile to the agreement, and indeed to almost any agreement involving the World Trade Organization. But the House and Senate are controlled by Republicans, and key Congressional Republicans were quick to voice their firm support.
Thomas J. Bliley, Republican of Virginia and chairman of the House Commerce Committee, said the deal would be a boon to American communication workers who would "enjoy an expansion of high-paying, high-technology jobs" as America exports more advanced technology.
The agreement was a clear vindication for the United States. After months of grueling negotiations in early 1995, most members of the World Trade Organization were ready to support an agreement that fell considerably short of the one reached today.
But to the shock of many, the United States abruptly announced just a few days before the negotiating deadline last year that it would not go along. American negotiators, led by Ms. Barshefsky, complained that too few nations had made meaningful offers to deregulate and reform.
The decision infuriated many European governments, which warned that the United States was holding out for too much and would wreck the prospects for a good, if imperfect, move toward freer trade.
Despite the criticism, the gamble paid off. When negotiators went back to the bargaining table last month, American negotiators led by Mr. Lang successfully pressed for one concession after another in a long series of one-to-one negotiations with countries like Mexico, Korea, Malaysia and Indonesia.
A result was that 68 countries made firm commitments today to liberalize their markets at least to some degree, double the number that had done so when the talks collapsed in April.
In recent days, moreover, one country after another has improved its earlier offers. Mexico and South Korea, for instance, agreed to let foreign companies own up to 49 percent of telephone carriers within their borders. Indonesia and Malaysia agreed to adopt the broad regulatory program of allowing competition within their borders, as did a host of smaller countries.
Several European countries agreed to deeper liberalization as well. Spain, Portugal and Italy, for instance, had refused to unravel their state monopolies until the year 2000, two years after most other members of the European Union had committed to take that step. But those countries decided to move up their schedules as well, and will now open up their telephone monopolies on Jan. 1, 1998.
"I am glad we waited," said Renato Ruggiero, Director General of the World Trade Organization. "We have now made much more progress than we had last April, which means that this was a good time to do a deal."
Executives of AT&T echoed that view. "The willingness of the United States and Barshefsky to step back from a deal last April put the United States in a position to get a much better agreement," said Gerry Salemme, AT&T's head of regulatory affairs in Washington.
What the United States failed to get was movement from Canada and Japan on the issue of foreign ownership. Japan insisted on prohibiting foreign companies from acquiring more than 20 percent of either the NTT Corporation or Kokusai Denshin Denwa, the companies that dominate the domestic and international telephone business, respectively, in Japan.
Canada refused to let foreign companies own more than 46.7 percent of any land-based telecommunication carrier in the country. It also insisted on preserving the current monopolies in satellite telephone services for three years and international telephone calls until October 1998.
In the end, irritated American negotiators gave up and resorted to the face-saving measure of retaining selected restrictions against companies from those countries.
Canadian negotiators, who had been under relentless pressure from the United States for weeks, were modest today about their success.
"It's a balanced agreement," said Michael Binder, Canada's Assistant Deputy Minister for Telecommunications. "Just ask the Americans. Even they will tell you it's a good agreement."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Highlights of Pact"
A total of 68 countries made commitments to open their telecommunications markets to competition, including from foreign companies.
 
AGREEMENT
Countries agree to end protections for telephone and satellite monopolies, in most cases before the year 2000.
 
ENFORCEMENT
More than half of the countries, including Japan and all members of the European Union, agree to adopt legally binding regulatory priniciples that force traditional telephone monopolies to let new rivals connect with their networks at "cost-based" prices.
 
COMPLAINTS
Countries may take complaints to an independent panel of the World Trade Organization, whose decisions are legally binding.

HEADLINE: DISPUTE AT AMERICAN AIRLINES: NEWS ANALLYSIS;
Weighing Clout of Pilots Against Economic Costs

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15

 BODY:
Because the economic reach of the pilots' union vastly exceeded its political grasp, President Clinton was free to intervene almost instantly to keep the jets flying when the pilots struck American Airlines just after midnight on Friday.
In making his decision, Mr. Clinton had to weigh the potential fury of tens of thousands of holiday travelers, the pleas of Republican and Democratic lawmakers from states like California and Florida, and the prospect of a blow to the economy costing up to $200 million a day, against the wishes of 9,000 pilots who are mostly Republicans and are not even concentrated in one state, but spread out around the country. 
 Still, President Clinton resisted making a final decision so long that his staff prepared remarks in the event he decided not to intervene. In part, he was worried about setting a precedent that would warp future airline bargaining, senior White House officials said today.
But by late Friday night, aides said, he was convinced that a strike's economic damage would be too severe. "Fine, I'll do that," President Clinton finally said as midnight approached, when Bruce R. Lindsey, the deputy White House counsel, called to recommend the intervention as the labor talks broke down, Mr. Lindsey said.
After the strike was announced, Mr. Clinton was in his second-floor study, playing solitaire at his desk and watching basketball on television, when Mr. Lindsey brought him the necessary orders.
By signing them, Mr. Clinton invoked his extraordinary powers under the 1926 Railway Labor Act, suspending the strike for up to 60 days while a newly convened emergency board develops a proposed agreement and the two sides consider it. The last President to intervene this way in an airline strike was Lyndon B. Johnson, in 1966.
Mr. Clinton was given room to maneuver by his allies in organized labor. The A.F.L.-C.I.O. had recommended that he not intervene, but the labor federation made no public fuss about it on Friday as the strike deadline loomed. And today, the organization seemed to shrug off Mr. Clinton's decision, which undermined the pilots' bargaining position by snatching away, at least temporarily, their most powerful lever.
"We support the collective bargaining process," said Denise Mitchell, a spokeswoman for the A.F.L.-C.I.O. "It seemed as if the process was moving forward, but it had not yielded a contract at that point. There are a lot of workers involved, and a lot of consumers who would be affected, and we respect the decisions that were made."
Asked whether union members would view Mr. Clinton's decision as violating a union principle by heading off a strike, Ms. Mitchell said: "I don't think you can express it that clearly. I think that people probably had points of view that were all over the map."
The Allied Pilots Association is not a member of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. In fact, it is isolated even within the airline industry, representing only the pilots at American. In 1963, the American pilots split away from the Air Line Pilots Association, which is a member of the labor federation and still represents pilots at most major carriers. If the American pilots succeed in achieving their desired contract, they would put enormous pressure on the leadership of the pilots association, which has not won such substantial gains.
Even the other unions at American were not lining up to support a strike by the pilots, who earn on average $120,000 a year. In a strike, American had planned to put most of its 81,000 other employees on leave. The union may have isolated itself even further, because of a comment made by its president, James G. Sovich, in a presentation to Wall Street analysts last week.
To help explain a point that the pilots respected American Airline's managers but did not trust them, Mr. Sovich said many Americans had similar feelings about President Clinton: "They think he's doing a great job, but they don't think he's ethical." The comment apparently reached Mr. Clinton's ears.
While the American pilots may have had few political allies, they have enormous economic power -- too much, Mr. Clinton decided, to permit a strike. Much like a strike at a single, critical parts plant can shut down most of General Motors' assembly lines, the pilots had the power to ground American.
The President himself spelled out the potential costs of a strike in a lengthy statement this morning, explaining his decision to intervene a statement that, like the executive order permitting the intervention, the White House had ready to go when the pilots struck.
Mr. Clinton noted that American is the country's second largest airline, carrying 220,000 passengers daily. The Department of Transportation, he said, had estimated that during a strike, about 43,000 passengers a day would not be accommodated by other airlines. Mr. Clinton also pointed out that most of American's workers would have been put on leave.
"The majority of these employees are based in Texas, Illinois, New York, California, Florida and Oklahoma," he said. Many of the elected officials from these states, he said, "have made it clear to my Administration that a strike would severely affect their economies."
Today, Senators from those states -- even some of Mr. Clinton's leading antagonists in Congress -- sounded gratified by the President's decision. "We are certainly pleased that there is no strike on today," said Larry Neal, a spokesman for Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas.
Still, White House officials said, Mr. Clinton would have much preferred not to have intervened. All week, officials reviewed the history of such interventions in airline disputes, wondering why there had been 33 up until 1966 -- and 3 in that year alone -- but none since.
They concluded that deregulation, combined with the rise of the airlines' use of hub cities, had changed the industry, making it harder for other airlines to step in and provide service in the event of a strike.
The internal debate then turned to the future, and whether intervention would change the nature of bargaining throughout the industry. But, Mr. Lindsey said today, "we thought some of the circumstances were unique, for example the timing of it coming over one of the busiest weekends" for airline travel.
The case for intervening was stiffened by a Transportation Department study given to the White House on Thursday. It showed the strike's effects rippling through the economy, punishing the tourism industry in South Florida and the Caribbean.
Some staff members argued that the strike should be permitted to run for two or three days, but Mr. Clinton rejected that idea, saying that if he would intervene he would rather do so immediately.
By intervening, Mr. Clinton may have merely delayed a strike. It would take an act of Congress to postpone it beyond the 60-day period. But he has done what he sought to avoid -- inject himself into the negotiations, and perhaps subject himself to blame if they ultimately fail. Today, the White House was still trying to distance itself from the talks.
"We're not in the negotiations," Mr. Lindsey said. "We don't feel it's appropriate to be in the negotiations."

HEADLINE: DISPUTE AT AMERICAN AIRLINES: THE PILOTS;
Despite Anger Over the Strike Ban, a Pledge to Do Their Best

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Feb. 15

 BODY:
These were grim, tight-lipped men, in their crisp blue uniforms with the four stripes of a captain or the three of a co-pilot on their sleeves, pulling their bags on wheels back into Miami International Airport just hours after President Clinton stopped the strike that many were prepared to wage for a month or more.
With Mr. Clinton's decision today to set up a Presidential Emergency Board to keep American Airlines and the Allied Pilots Association bargaining, pilots say he has robbed them of their one effective lever in stopping American's chairman, Robert L. Crandall, from turning over many jobs to a new corps of much lower-paid, less-experienced pilots. 
 "President Clinton has denied labor the only legal recourse we have today," said Bob Ames, 50, an Airbus pilot and the strike coordinator for the 1,400 Allied Pilots Association members who fly out of Miami. They represent about 15 percent of American's 9,300 pilots and the most militant of the lot.
"But we're going to do what we do," Mr. Ames said. "We're going to go fly airplanes."
These men, and the tiny minority of women among them, are not automobile workers or supermarket checkout clerks, whose rote jobs take little expertise, who work under the gaze of a supervisor and who can be replaced by just about any applicant from an unemployment line.
These elite of the unionized labor force, earning an average of $120,000 a year, thought they were special. Independent spirits who believe they assume responsibilities as intense as any surgeon's, they operate in the solitude of the sky, in a cockpit where no President Clinton, no Chairman Crandall can intrude.
"We've always owned the flying," said Nick Galyon, 40, who flies Boeing 767's on international routes. "We don't talk to managers. We operate unsupervised. We are totally unsupervised around the world, around the clock."
Michael Oliver, 34, a co-pilot who flies Boeing 767's, said the decision to appoint an emergency board means more of the uncertainty that has persisted for over two years, since the pilots and the company began discussions on a four-year contract.
"I think it's going to perpetuate the roller-coaster we've been on, and putting our families through all of this," Mr. Oliver said. "We're still a considerable distance apart at the table."
The emergency board is to study the dispute and recommend a solution within 30 days. The pilots and unions will then have 30 days to study the proposal, after which the pilots can decide to strike. But Congress could take action to prevent a strike.
Talk to any one of these pilots or co-pilots, and the same dream is heard, that of every red-blooded American child who hops off a fence with an umbrella open and who, with training and perseverance, finds that flying is actually possible.
"It was like a destiny," said Alex Garmendia, 51, a captain on Airbus 300's. He wears an "AA" lapel button with two diamonds, one for each decade of flying for American.
"When I was a little boy," Mr. Garmendia said, "a friend of the family was an Air Force pilot. I tried on all his equipment. I went to the Air Force base with him and his son." From then on, he said, there was only one thing he wanted to do: fly. Mr. Garmendia went to junior college in Miami and received a two-year degree in aerospace technology.
"I realized I was underqualified to be a pilot," he said, "so I went to San Jose State in California and got a bachelor's in finance with a minor in aviation. I went into the Air Force and stayed for six years. I was hired by American Airlines in 1976. They hired only 100 guys that year; I was the 51st."
Don Siciliano, 38, is a 747 captain who has been with American for 13 years and who started learning to fly when he was 18.
"Where I grew up, near Pittsburgh, we lived under the flight path to Allegheny County Airport," Mr. Siciliano said. "My five brothers and two sisters and I would be outside playing, and a plane would go by. I would stare up there. I was mesmerized. Basically all I wanted to do was fly airplanes."
Kim Kenny, 37, a first officer, or co-pilot, on a 727, said that as a child, "I loved planes." Her father could fly, Ms. Kenny said, "but there were no women role models, so being a pilot didn't enter my mind." Then, after graduating from George Washington University in Washington, she took a flying lesson.
"The minute I took off, it was pretty much what I wanted to do," she said. "I just loved it. It gave me a sense of freedom, a sense of challenge that would make it fun."
But the current conflict has brought American's pilots down to the tarmac of the changing relationships among management and labor. In the interest of holding down costs to meet competition, American wants to add sophisticated jets, smaller versions of those these pilots typically fly, to its regional routes.
The company would extend the routes to bigger cities and give the jobs to subsidiary companies that are not bound by the contracts with the mainstream pilots. Like American's pilots, its flight attendants, mechanics, baggage handlers and ticket agents could also be affected.
This is another version of "outsourcing," the practice among many unionized companies of hiring subcontractors to do jobs previously done by the companies' organized workers. American's pilots say the company's plan devalues their skills and the trust that has bound them to American.
As yet, Mr. Crandall has not won the opprobrium of Frank Lorenzo, the man unions blame for bankrupting Eastern Airlines in the late 1980's. Some take pride in Mr. Crandall's fierce assaults on competitors.
"He has been an innovator, a real marketing innovator," Mr. Garmendia said. "But that has changed. Beating up labor has become his main objective."
Rich Rubin, 47, a captain who flies 767's on international routes, said: "This is about trust. I don't want to slam him just to slam him. Bob Crandall is a very astute businessman. He thinks in terms of warfare. I just wish he'd realize that we are not the competition."

HEADLINE: DISPUTE AT AMERICAN AIRLINES: OVERVIEW;
Clinton, Stalling Strike, Averts Travel Chaos for Holiday Weekend

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15

 BODY:
Travelers won a reprieve today from a potentially crippling strike by American Airlines pilots after President Clinton intervened, shifting attention to a board that will try to resolve the dispute between airline executives and union leaders within 60 days.
American Airlines said its operations had for the most part returned to normal. At some airports there was more confusion at other airlines' ticket counters as passengers had switched carriers in anticipation of a strike. [Page 25.] 
 Many travelers said they were pleasantly surprised that their travel plans had not been disrupted.
"It was incredible relief," Elena Musso said while waiting for an American flight at Kennedy International Airport. "I didn't want to miss my sun and ski in Tahoe."
But American Airlines pilots were generally unhappy about Mr. Clinton's decision, contending that it had undermined their negotiating power.
"I understand why the President did what he did, but basically he castrated the union," John Manganaro, an American Airlines pilot, said today at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago.
The pilots' dispute now goes to the emergency board established by President Clinton. The board, made up of three mediation and arbitration experts, faces a difficult task in sorting through the complex aspects of the dispute before making a nonbinding recommendation within 30 days.
The two sides will then have another 30 days to study the proposal, after which the pilots can invoke their power to strike.
Despite President Clinton's action, James G. Sovich, the president of the Allied Pilots Association, said, "We may have to go another 60 days and then go out on strike a second time." But Congress could take further action to prevent a strike, either by extending the cooling-off period or mandating a settlement.
The decision by Mr. Clinton, the first time in 31 years that a President has invoked the power of the Railway Labor Act of 1926 to halt an airline dispute, averted wide disruptions for about 40,000 travelers this weekend.
American Airlines, based in Dallas, said the threat of a strike had already cost it about $100 million in profits because so many travelers had booked with other airlines.
Hoping to win back its business quickly, American said today that it would offer discounts of up to 50 percent off its low leisure fares but require no advance booking.
The airline also said it would double frequent-flier mileage awards on domestic flights.
"We thank President Clinton for his wisdom in preventing a strike that would have been very harmful to American's many constituencies and to the nation as a whole," said Robert L. Crandall, the chairman of American Airlines and its parent company, the AMR Corporation.
In a statement issued this morning, President Clinton explained his decision, saying: "A strike would cause a severe disruption to both domestic and international air transportation. I was also particularly concerned that a strike would be especially disruptive over a holiday weekend, when hundreds of citizens rely on our air transit system."
Although he was concerned about creating an expectation of Presidential action in future airline disputes, Mr. Clinton had been widely expected to intervene, in large part because the airline industry has consolidated in ways that make big carriers like American essential to commerce and tourism.
The Transportation Department had estimated that the strike would cost the nation's economy about $200 million a day, but some economists called that figure far too high.
To head off such damaging effects of a strike again, the emergency mediation board must try to find common ground between the pilots and airline executives.
That may be easier to do on the issue of raises than on the issue of regional jets.
American Airlines wants its commuter subsidiary, American Eagle, to fly the same planes that some commuter operations at other airlines like Delta are already using. But American Airlines pilots say they fear that the airline will use the planes to replace bigger jets on routes that they now fly.
People close to the negotiations said today that the pilots realized the company would not budge from its position but that the pilots wanted more compensation for giving ground on the issue. People close to the negotiations on both sides gave differing views today of the proposal under consideration in the negotiations last night.
According to a person with knowledge of discussions on the pilots' side, the union received a proposal for a 6.5 percent raise over four and a half years. It also called for pilots to receive five million stock options, each valued at $10 below market value, on signing a new contract and one million more shares at market value in August 2000.
The company demanded that American Eagle pilots fly the regional jets, but that -- to give some comfort to the union that their jobs would not be threatened -- only 20 percent of the commuter flights would be more than 1,000 miles.
The pilots have apparently come to understand that although a strike would financially cripple American Airlines, the airline will not budge from its demand that the jets be flown only by the lower-paid pilots at American Eagle. That demand explains why Donald J. Carty, the airline's president, repeated early today in a news conference that the dispute, in the final hour before the strike, was about money, not the regional jets. But it appears to have been about both.
According to a person familiar with the company's position, its proposal included four million stock options, each valued at $10 below market value, and a 6 percent wage increase over the life of the contract. Chris Chiames, a spokesman for the airline, did not confirm those figures but said, "I can say that the pilots rejected far and away the best compensation package in the industry."
The two sides can offer new, or earlier, proposals to the emergency board, but its job is to suggest a plan within 30 days for them to consider. The board has no power to force a deal on them, and the pilots will be free to strike again after another 30-day period.
The board's chairman is Robert O. Harris, a former chairman of the National Mediation Board; and the board's members are Anthony V. Sinicropi, a University of Iowa professor and former head of the American Arbitration Association, and Helen M. Witt, also a former chairman of the mediation board.
Depending on the board's efforts, and the willingness of the two sides to compromise, travelers may not need to worry about another strike 60 days from now. If a strike eventually occurs, several economists estimated that the cost to the nation's economy would be less than $50 million a day, only a small fraction of the more than $200 billion in income that the nation generates daily.
Rather than lost air travel, the economic damage from a strike by American would center on the lost wages as a result of layoffs and canceled business, particularly at the airline, economists said. American Airlines and American Eagle had announced that in the event of a strike, 90,000 employees would be placed on unpaid emergency leave, at a cost of $590 million in wages to the workers during a 60-day strike, nearly half of it in the Dallas area.
"I would not expect a strike to show up in any major way in the gross domestic product numbers," said Joel Prakken of Macroeconomic Advisers in St. Louis. "Those who don't spend their money on travel would stay home and spend it in other ways."
But that does not take into account the emotional cost of disappointed travelers during a strike, a cost that was largely averted today.
At Miami's airport, Alex Benincasa, a hospital administrator, and his wife, Ana, were headed to San Diego on an American flight. They were among those who had not been able to make other travel plans, so they were relieved at the last-minute turn of events.
"We started to pack," Mr. Benincasa said, "and then we had stopped packing and seven seconds later, we started packing again."

HEADLINE: Albright Flies Toward Vexing Issues

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15

 BODY:
In advertising terms, Madeleine K. Albright has had her national rollout as the new Secretary of State. She has laid down her themes of bipartisanship, global responsibility and public diplomacy, and through appointments and symbolism has tried to yank the center of foreign policy-making back into the State Department.
Today she took her show on the road, to nine countries in Europe and Asia, mixing traditional allies with foreign policy challenges. Though her first trip abroad as Secretary of State will have ample symbolism, these 10 days also mark a first serious effort to grapple with the issues. 
 "If the first couple of weeks were filled with press and ceremony and symbolism," a senior official said, "now she really wants to get into substance in a big way."
That will be unavoidable, and grueling. Relations with Russia and China are defining the first year of President Clinton's second term, and Ms. Albright is going to both countries.
In Moscow, she will be the first American official to see the ailing President Boris N. Yeltsin since Vice President Al Gore last July.
Ms. Albright will also go to Beijing, one of Washington's most vexing relationships, arriving at the very end of a trip that is bound to tire even someone known for her stamina.
This trip will break down roughly into halves, and Russia and China will define them. While there are some important bilateral issues with various European countries, the prevailing topic of her visits to Rome, Bonn, Paris, Brussels and London will be European security -- the expansion of NATO and the effort to create a parallel understanding with Russia, ideally before NATO leaders meet in July to name prospective new members.
The recent meetings of Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin of Russia and Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore at least gave the Russians a better understanding of what an expanded NATO might mean, officials say.
It was a telling indication of Russia's current confusion, the officials said, that Mr. Chernomyrdin had not really grasped that the NATO meeting will only invite new members, who would not actually join until April 1999 at the earliest.
In her dealings with the Russian Foreign Minister, Yevgeny Primakov, and Mr. Yeltsin, it will be Ms. Albright who will be speaking for the alliance, after she meets with NATO foreign ministers in Brussels. She is expected to be able to present a united NATO position on a new round of talks to modify the outdated treaty on Conventional Forces in Europe.
A modified treaty is an important part of a package intended to help assure Russia that an expanded NATO, with smaller forces, will have less armor arrayed; that new members will not have NATO forces, conventional or nuclear, stationed on their soil except in emergencies; that Russia will have full rights of consultation, though not of veto, on questions of European security and on any joint actions, as in Bosnia.
Perhaps most important, NATO is preparing what would effectively be a promise to Russia that it will not use force outside the NATO area without international authorization, like United Nations approval -- and Moscow has a veto there.
Persuading the Russians to slide down this funnel will not happen overnight, but Ms. Albright will start making the case in earnest, preparing for a summit meeting between Presidents Clinton and Yeltsin on March 20 in Helsinki, Finland. Her meeting with Mr. Yeltsin is particularly important because, American officials say, his decision remains the crucial one on security issues.
While Russia is trying to strike its best bargain through Mr. Primakov's adept diplomacy and even to divide the alliance, it is Mr. Yeltsin who will finally make the decision as to whether the bargain available is good enough for Moscow to seek a new relationship with a NATO that will expand in any case. The American challenge, officials understand, is to give Mr. Yeltsin a good enough package of promises, consultation and high-level acknowledgments of Russia's importance that the Russian President can sell the result at home as a victory, not a defeat.
[After arriving in Rome early Sunday, Reuters reported, Ms. Albright said of Mr. Yeltsin and his health problems: "Obviously he himself and the role he has played in democratizing Russia and reform is important. But there are other elements within the Government who are also increasingly dedicated to democracy and economic reform."]
 But Ms. Albright has also started making the case for NATO expansion at home and among allies, contributing a long article to this week's Economist magazine and giving interviews to European newspapers, like Le Monde, that will appear in the capitals she will visit.
While she is away, the State Department is expected to release estimates that put the cost of NATO expansion to American taxpayers at about $200 million a year, officials say. While that number will be questioned and criticized by critics, it represents less than 0.1 percent of the Pentagon's $265 billion budget.
In France, she will smooth relations that got patchy at the end of Warren Christopher's term and discuss possible solutions to the French wish for a more visible European command within NATO. In Germany, she will reassure the Government of Helmut Kohl that bilateral relations are in order, and that State Department criticism of German restrictions on the Church of Scientology will not be allowed to define relations with Europe's most important country.
There will be hand-holding and reassurance in Seoul and Tokyo, as well. South Korea, under economic strain, is always nervous about the American commitment to its security, no matter how often restated.
Debate continues about how much Ms. Albright will emphasize economic and trade disputes with Tokyo. There will be emphasis on security ties, particularly given instability on the Korean Peninsula and a more assertive China.
But Beijing will be the climax of the Asian part of the trip, with Ms. Albright expected to meet President Jiang Zemin and Prime Minister Li Peng as well as Foreign Minister Qian Qichen. In part, she will prepare for Mr. Gore's visit in March.
American officials are looking for some gestures from the Chinese -- a willingness to ratify international human rights conventions, the release of prominent prisoners if even on medical grounds, and the resumption of talks about Red Cross visits to Chinese prisons -- that will let Washington claim some success on human rights as it discusses all the other key issues of their relationship.

HEADLINE: Blame Judges, Not Voters, for California's Declining Schools

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Brent Staples decries the fiscal condition of public education in California (Editorial Notebook, Feb. 10). I would not dispute this, but he is wrong to blame Proposition 13, which capped property tax rates at 1 percent of value and rolled back assessments. This 1978 voter initiative did not restrict California's ability to substitute state taxes for local taxes in paying for education. 
 The real sources of the problem were the "share the wealth" decisions by California's Supreme Court. Serrano v. Priest (1971 and 1976) said that school spending could not vary among districts on the basis of taxable property wealth. For most high-spending districts, this meant that a vote to increase spending from local sources was unconstitutional. The voters obliged the court two years later by rolling back local property taxes and effectively sending the obligation for schools to the Legislature.
What is sad about California's plight is not just the poor education offered one-eighth of the nation's public school students. It's that Serrano v. Priest continues to be emulated by state courts. The resulting reforms have invariably led to a loss of local fiscal control over education. Let's stop impugning Californians as short-sighted hedonists and look at the more likely cause of their problems: judges who think they know better than voters.
 
WILLIAM A. FISCHEL
Hanover, N.H., Feb. 11, 1997
 
The writer is an economics professor at Dartmouth College.

HEADLINE: Blame Judges, Not Voters, for California's Declining Schools

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Feb. 12 letters responding to Brent Staples's Editorial Notebook (Feb. 10) seek to blame the collapse of California's schools not on the "tax revolt" and lack of money, but on teachers and teaching methods. How do they account for the similar decline of what was the finest system of public higher education in the world? 
 The system was designed to provide a place in college for every California high school graduate. Did the professors suddenly become corrupt and lazy under this regime? I saw no evidence of that.
Friends in the system in the 1970's and early 1980's paid a few hundred dollars a year. In 1992 my son qualified for the University of California at Berkeley, but it was more economical to attend the most expensive private college in the nation (with financial aid) than Berkeley, where tuition was thousands per semester and he didn't qualify for aid. Now tell me again that funding cuts were not a big part of the problem.
 
LINDA M. MALONEY
St. Cloud, Minn., Feb. 12, 1997

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING 

 BODY:

STOCK MARKET
A Dow Record: This Is News?
What, exactly, constitutes news? By the old rule, man must bite dog -- the opposite occurrence being so commonplace that it's not worth noting. So how about when the Dow industrials put another 1,000-point notch in their belt? The first few times it was sort of exciting -- but the milestones are being toppled so regularly now that it's rapidly sinking to the dog-bites-man category. The Dow topped 7,000 last week, you say? Hmmm. That and 20 redials might, if you're lucky, get you onto America Online. Why do stocks keep rising? Oh, round up the usual suspects: mutual fund money, low inflation, corporate profits, blah blah blah. And the pundits, with remarkably precise hindsight, are scrambling to say that, well, the rules have changed about what defines an overpriced market. Famous last words?
 
WAGES
A Raise? What a Thought
Inflation's all but dead. The grim downsizing reaper still loiters on the street corner. A cost-of-living raise? Ha! Just be thankful you have a job -- and, while you're at it, grovel a bit. Yes, this is the way it was, but guess what: it's not really true any more. Employers nationwide are finding that they simply can't afford to keep being stingy, and wages are now rising at an annual rate of 3.8 percent, half a point above the inflation rate. No, that can't match the solid raises of the good old days -- the 60's and 70's -- but it's quite a change from the past few years, when raises all but vanished for many workers. So go ahead. Ask for a raise. For a change, the statistics are on your side.
 
WALL STREET
Lamborghinis? I'll Take Two
Lest we forget, though: there are wages and there are wages. Light-years apart from the real world of pinched pennies and juggled bills lies the funny-money world of Wall Street, and it's never been funnier. It's the height of bonus season, and we're not talking about a few $100's in an envelope -- not by a long shot. After a giddy year in the markets, the securities industry's 150,000 workers in New York are getting about $8.1 billion in bonuses, far above the previous high of $6.2 billion, with perhaps 1,500 people making $1 million or more. So if you see some smooth-faced hotshots with million-dollar suits and fire in their eyes, better step aside: they've just received their bonus checks and are sprinting for the Lamborghini dealer.
 
PHONE COMPANIES
Good Service? Try Asking
When Nynex merges with Bell Atlantic this spring, Bell Atlantic, it seems, will be setting the pace -- and that's probably just fine with Nynex customers. In a recent F.C.C. customer-satisfaction ranking, Nynex was a distant last. And last week, in fact, the New York Public Service Commission ordered Nynex to pay $109.6 million to its customers in the state for what it called a decade's worth of bad service. Here's a thought, though: in those droning long-distance wars, bargaining is creeping into the formula. If you don't like, say, 15 cents a minute, call and offer 10 -- and they just might take it. So just take this you've-gotta-ask-for-it approach a step further: Call Nynex (or whomever), and after you've lined up package rates and call-waiting, simply say, "I'll go for the good service, too, please."
 
FOREIGN POLICY
A Compromise on Cuba?
When historians sum up America's late-20th-century foreign policy, the comic relief will surely be supplied by our mounting frustration with Cuba. Our delicate sensibilities are so offended that this little island, practically on our patio, won't dance to our deafening tune that we come up with all manner of bizarre and convoluted laws to wreak our symbolic vengeance. One of the more bizarre: the Helms-Burton Act, which, basically, decrees that the rest of the world join us in ostracizing Fidel's ruffians -- or else. European nations, not at all happy being bullied this way, planned to take their outrage to the World Trade Organization. And Washington has countered by warning that it would argue -- this gets really strange -- that little Cuba actually poses a security threat. Last week, though, still hoping for a compromise, Europe postponed its challenge.
 
CELLULAR DISTRACTION
If You Talk, Don't Drive
Status-conscious go-getters wouldn't dream of cruising along in their Grand Cherokees without talking with great earnestness into their cell phones. It's vital, after all, to stay in constant contact with your broker or lawyer or wine consultant -- or at least appear to be. But is this a high-risk status symbol? Common sense has long indicated that it is, but there's been no scientific backing -- until now. A study published last week in The New England Journal of Medicine, in which Canadian researchers studied 699 phone-equipped drivers who'd had accidents, found that the risk of an accident rises fourfold when you're talking -- about the same as being legally drunk. There is some talk about restricting drivers' use of phones, but such a drastic step does not seem to be likely. Still, you can almost hear the new terminology: Stop D.W.C. -- driving while chatting. Or C.I. drivers -- conversation-impaired. And, now, it's no joke.
 
GOVERNMENT SPENDING
Funds for Family Planning
Is family planning just another term for abortion? Abortion foes in the House have long thought so -- or voted so, at any rate, putting tight reins on money for family-planning programs around the world. But last week, prodded by President Clinton, the House voted to speed the release of family-planning money. "American dollars shouldn't be used to kill innocent little children," one Republican argued. But another Republican countered that during every hour that he and his colleagues yammered about the issue, 250 women around the world would die during pregnancy -- deaths that could have been prevented by contraception. This stance won the day, as the House voted 220 to 209 to release $215 million in family planning funds on March 1. If the measure had failed, it would have been just $92 million -- on July 1.
 
SHIFTING ECONOMICS
And the Sand Goes Round
There's really not much ambiguity left. A beach is washed away, you spend millions to dump more sand on it in a futile attempt to outsmart Parent Nature, and the new sand in turn is washed away. And on and on. But have we learned that beaches simply don't stay put? Of course not. Even now, $450,000 is being spent to dump 50,000 cubic yards of sand on Brant Beach on the New Jersey shore.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 21, 1997, Friday

 CORRECTION:
A front-page chart on Feb. 13 showing recent modest gains in average hourly wages, adjusted for inflation, carried two incorrect labels, and a chart on Sunday with the Diary column of the Money and Business reflected the errors. The figures were for nonsupervisory workers, not all workers, in private industry; they were given in fourth-quarter 1996 dollars, not December 1996 dollars.

HEADLINE: Research Firm Joins Rush to Sell Its Stock

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
Last year, when executives at Forrester Research, an information technology research firm, went looking for a senior analyst to bolster a critical new-media and technology service, they thought they had found the perfect candidate in Bill Doyle. Mr. Doyle was a longtime designer and builder of on-line services and had an impressive resume working for the likes of AT&T and Citibank.
In a Boston-area market clamoring for such talent, however, Mr. Doyle was a hot property. And at the age of 39, with four children, Mr. Doyle was seeking more than just a good salary. 
"I'd gotten to the point where I figured I was worth something," he said. "The Forrester opportunity was the best of both worlds for me: growing operations, a profitable company, a good salary, and they were able to give me some skin in the game."
The skin referred to stock options in Forrester, which filed an initial public offering just before Thanksgiving. Had there been no options, Mr. Doyle said, "I wouldn't have considered the job."
For George F. Colony, the 43-year-old founder and chief executive of Forrester, going public had never been a priority. He had happily run the profitable firm since 1983 without the attendant pressure and headaches of public ownership.
But in recent years, the rules of the game have changed. Forrester Research competes head on in the lucrative computer research and analysis market with firms like the giant Gartner Group and META Group, both based in Stamford, Conn., and both now publicly traded companies. The successful initial public offerings of Gartner in October 1993 and META in December 1995 forced Forrester's hand.
In a reputation-based, brand-name business dependent on brainpower, stock options have become a priority for talented prospects like Mr. Doyle. "When Gartner went out as successfully as it did, people starting looking for stock options," Mr. Colony said in a recent interview. "We live in a high-tech world that is driven by stock options and in order to attract and keep great people, we had to be public, too."
To fuel the firm's growth, most likely through acquisitions, Forrester needed to deepen its war chest as well: the initial public offering brought in $37 million. Mr. Colony, who owned 100 percent of the stock at the time of the offering, was not complaining about the $120 million in net worth of his own shares. He immediately divested himself of 25 percent of his stock for his management team and to create a pool for bonuses and options for employees.
The $394 million Gartner Group initiated this trend when it went public in 1993. Gartner's public performance has thus far been a stunning success, with its stock splitting three times and its value increasing elevenfold since the offering. The company has profit margins above 20 percent; more than 300 of Gartner's 2,100 employees are now millionaires.
Gartner continues to grow at 30 percent annually. META, at No. 2 with $42 million in revenues, has shown steady growth and profits. Forrester, with $25 million in revenues, got off to a fast start as well. The firm continues to grow at 50 percent, but, after surging to $28.875 in early January, the stock has drifted back close to its value at the end of its first day of trading; it closed Friday at $21.875.
Firms like Gartner and Forrester had long been viewed as consulting firms and thus not likely candidates for going public. Such technology prognosticators have a very different business model than consulting firms. Manny Fernandez, the chief executive of Gartner, said that when Gartner went public, he was forced to spend extensive time educating financial analysts "about the nature of the business" and its value.
"This is an extremely profitable, subscription-based, annuity business," said Richard Shaffer, head of Technologic Partners, a New York-based research firm. "You build it with customer money; you are paid in advance for subscription services you fulfill over time and the renewal percentages are highly predictable. You have all the cash flow advantages and predictability of a subscription-based business and also the cachet of being related to one of the fastest-growing industries in the world, the computer industry."
And once Gartner, founded by Gideon Gartner in 1979, went public, staying private was no longer an option for its competitors. Some highly visible players like Dataquest and the Yankee Group chose to sell themselves to public companies rather than go through the pressure-packed process of going public on their own. Dataquest was acquired by Gartner itself in late 1995 and the Yankee Group was gobbled up by Primark in 1996.
A New Hampshire native and Harvard graduate, Mr. Colony has spent the last 13 years tracking the volatile information technology industry at Forrester and earned a reputation for his willingness to make bold, sometimes brash, predictions about technology trends. (He coined the term client/server computing in 1987 and helped fuel the widespread acceptance of this networked computing model; but he also predicted enormous success for I.B.M.'s OS/2 operating system, which flopped.)
Mr. Colony said that Forrester was right in about 7 out of 10 instances, which is a good enough batting average to please its clients. He boasted of the firm's "good brand name" but also said that he cautions his staff of 125 analysts and sales representatives that "if we have six months of lousy research, we're out of business."
Forrester customers can purchase subscriptions for $5,000 each to any of 10 strategic services like Computing Strategy or Network Strategy and receive regular monthly written or electronic reports. They can also pay up to $65,000 for face-to-face two-hour meetings with Forrester analysts to apply the research to specific business strategies.
Catherine J. Baker, an analyst with Robertson, Stephens in San Francisco, estimates that Forrester takes in an average of $30,000 a client in revenues with an average client buying four to five of its services.
In contrast to the consulting business in which must continually book new engagements, Forrester's subscription-based business is open-ended and continuous, and insures a highly predictable revenue stream. Forrester has 860 client companies and a renewal rate of more than 70 percent.
Gartner has 7,500 clients and an 85 percent renewal rate while META has 1,100 clients and a 75 percent renewal rate. By Jan. 1 of each year, Forrester, META and Gartner have booked and billed up to 80 percent of their revenues for the entire year.
At Nationsbank in Charlotte, N.C., for example, Janey Place, the chief information officer, spends up to $500,000 a year on services from Gartner, META and Forrester. Ms. Place said the research firms provided crucial input into her technology decision-making, though she insisted she did not make final choices based on reports or recommendations.
"Forrester is one of the influences on how I think about the direction of technology and what we ought to be doing," she said. "They've indicated industry directions a number of times that I didn't agree with and they were right."
The advent of the Internet and the ever-increasing complexity of technology's role in business have created a surge in demand for the information supplied by these firms. "The number of decisions users must make today is an order of magnitude higher than 10 years ago," Mr. Kutnick of META said.
And with increasing demand comes opportunity for new players in the market. Mr. Gartner, for example, had severed ties with his original company in 1973, but now has returned to the industry he helped create. However, his new firm, Giga Information Systems, had to pull back its initial public offering last fall.
Meanwhile, Mr. Colony has been urging his staff to catch the next big technology wave. "Unlike most companies, change is our friend; change fuels our growth," he said.
Customers say the public offering has had little impact on their relationship with Forrester. "I don't care much if they are wrong" occasionally, Ms. Place said. "I am looking for high-quality thinking and input. It's as much as you can expect in a crazy time."

HEADLINE: Taking In the Sites;
Cities and States Go Cyber In Hunt for New Business

BYLINE: By SREENATH SREENIVASAN 

 BODY:
Cities and states are using the Internet to escalate their competition for new businesses and investment.
More and more economic development agencies are now boasting on line about their incentive packages to attract companies to relocate to their areas. The World Wide Web's interactive nature allows companies and individuals looking for facts about different regions to get information that only used to be available, if at all, through the mail and in-person visits. 
 "For an economic development agency to not have a Web site nowadays is the equivalent of not having a fax machine," said Leonard Fuld, a co-author of "Regional Web Wars," a study of economic development Web sites.
His consulting firm, Fuld & Company, of Cambridge, Mass., awards Web Warrior awards to economic development agencies with sites that provide information efficiently and effectively. Current winners include the sites of South Carolina, Delaware, Ohio and Arizona. Each of these sites offers facts about its state's economic development strategy in a clear and easy-to-understand manner.
States are not alone in their hunt for new business. Cities of various sizes have gone on line, announcing their wares. New York City, for example, has an in-depth business resource guide on its site, complete with details on tax abatements, international assistance programs, and a sales tax suspension effort.
The Interactive Economic Development Network is a logical place to hunt for useful information. Its comprehensive site is filled with resources about economic development links, wired communities, financing sources and technology transfers.
Some foreign economic regions are also keen players in the game of attracting business and investment. Fuld gave the top award in its overseas category to the Cote d'Azur. This French region of the Riviera has focused considerable energy on business development and its site reflects that, making good use of maps and lists. But most overseas economic development sites are less sophisticated than the top American sites.
Not surprisingly, even a building in Silicon Alley in Manhattan has gotten into the act of attracting tenants through the Internet. The New York Information Technology Center at 55 Broad Street (www.55broad.com) advertises itself as a "wired" building that pushes the technology envelope. Its site has a virtual reality tour of the building and a list of financial incentives offered to tenants.
Some of the leading publications in the corporate relocation business have made their way onto the Web and offer executives another source of information. Area Development, a magazine that deals with planning company relocations, has a site with reprints of its articles as well as state-by-state economic profiles and a listing of state tax incentives. Site Net, a venture of Site Selections magazine, has a comprehensive site that allows corporate relocation planners to learn more about regions. The site also features a useful "tool kit" that provides a checklist for picking an optimum site, along with in-depth lease information.
Companies interested in learning more about the demographics of American counties and cities may find the University of Virginia Social Sciences Data Center's site useful. It offers extensive marketplace information that can be searched by more than 200 variables, including age groups, household incomes, and even the votes cast for Ross Perot in the 1992 Presidential election.
Acknowledging that businesses base their relocation decisions on standard of living factors as well as fiscal concerns, some of the sites highlight favorable human factors. The site of the Roanoke Valley of Virginia, for instance, has a page dedicated to its "low crime." There are selective lists of crime statistics that, naturally, favorably compare Roanoke to 20 other cities in Virginia and across the country. It does not ignore financial concerns: a similar selective list of comparative electricity rates is available.
Since moving a business or a factory to a new location involves changes for employees, two sites provide features that can show employees and management what it is like to live in different cities.
Money magazine's site offers plenty of information about its annual list of "best cities" to live in the United States. Most useful perhaps is its interactive "Find your best places" feature, that allows users to provide preferences about different factors and get back a list of suggestions for places that match their criteria.
The Homebuyer's Fair international salary calculator provides an interactive peek at the salary levels needed to provide a given living standard in different cities. Want to move from, say, a $50,000 salary in Manhattan to Geneva? The site will tell you that you need to earn $68,875 just to keep pace. On the other hand, you'll need only $17,851 to live in Kiev, Ukraine.
Commercial Real Estate Network, a GE Capital Services company, has a free search function for anyone looking to rent or buy office space, and links to various commercial real estate sites.
Unfortunately, many states and cities have not made good use of the interactive nature of the Web and have basically published their brochures on the Internet. As more and more businesses use this medium for their initial scouting, sites that are not current or well designed will lose traffic and business.

HEADLINE: A Dangerous Skirmish Over Cuba

 BODY:
The American economic strangulation of Cuba is a cold war anachronism that is now threatening to upend a carefully constructed international system for resolving trade disputes. Fidel Castro will be the only winner if Europe and the United States undermine the new World Trade Organization in a needless fight over Cuba.
That fight revolves around the Helms-Burton Act, a 1996 law that compels the United States to impose sanctions against foreign companies that do business in Cuba. The law is a misguided attempt by Congress to impose its foreign policy on others, and European leaders are right to resent it. But they are wrong to turn to the World Trade Organization to resolve what is essentially a political dispute. Last week European officials wisely decided to postpone their legal challenge in the trade organization. They would do themselves and their trading partners a favor if they dropped the case altogether. 
 The Helms-Burton Act, passed last year after Cuba shot down two civilian planes over international waters, invites lawsuits against foreign companies that use Cuban property that previously belonged to American citizens, including those who fled after Fidel Castro took control. President Clinton, as the law allows, has temporarily suspended that provision and no company has been taken to court. But the Administration is required by the law to deny American visas to executives of foreign companies that do extensive business in Cuba.
The Europeans, Canadians and Mexicans believe that economic engagement with Cuba is the best way to undermine Mr. Castro's grip, much as the White House believes that trade with China will eventually make that country more democratic. In its case before the World Trade Organization, the European Union accuses the United States of violating its free-trade obligations under the international trade accord. That is a shaky assertion. The core purpose of the world trade accord is to prevent countries from adopting protectionist or discriminatory trade practices for commercial advantage. No one argues that Congress passed Helms-Burton for protectionist purposes.
The United States, for its part, may claim exemption from the trading rules on grounds that the Helms-Burton law protects vital American national security interests. Washington, in effect, would argue that the law is an expression of American foreign policy and as a result does not fall within the trade organization's commercial purview.
A victory for Europe, giving it the right to impose trade sanctions against the United States, would undermine support for the World Trade Organization in Congress and might encourage Senator Jesse Helms and others to campaign for American withdrawal. An American victory would lead other countries to misuse the same national security defense in future cases. Japan already defends its restrictions on rice imports as a matter of food security.
Europe and the United States should try to settle this conflict on their own rather than going to the World Trade Organization. If that fails, the Europeans would be wise to hold their fire. Skirmishing over Cuba is not worth the potential risk to the World Trade Organization.

HEADLINE: Vermont Survey Finds Support For the Legalization of Hemp

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: BURLINGTON, Vt.

 BODY:
Despite strong opposition from Gov. Howard Dean, most Vermonters favor legalizing hemp as an industrial crop, according to a University of Vermont study.
The study, conducted last year in response to a mandate from the Vermont Legislature, also found that a large number of Vermonters would buy products made with hemp. Hemp is a low potency, fibrous variety of Cannabis sativa, the species from which the flowers and leaves are harvested as marijuana. But it can also be used in fabrics, paints, edible and inedible oils, and for a variety of other uses. 
 Several states are testing the feasibility of marketing hemp, said Roger Clapp, Vermont's Deputy Commissioner for Agricultural Development. Such a test has also been mandated in Vermont.
Public opinion aside, Governor Dean, a Democrat, is strongly opposed to legalizing hemp, asserting in a recent interview: "The real question is this: Does the public support the legalization of marijuana?
"I don't think it's in anybody's best interest to do that. It sends the wrong message to our kids. I think the principal interest of the advocates is to legalize marijuana."
State Representative Robert Starr, the Democratic chairman of the Vermont House Agriculture Committee and a longtime advocate of hemp as an industrial product, disagreed with the Governor.
"The big problem is that our government, state and Federal, expects people in the 1990's to think the way they did in the 1930's," Mr. Starr said. "They've forgotten that it's up to us lawmakers to make the laws and to see that they're enforced. They think they know more than the people do."
Another hemp advocate who welcomed the findings of the study was Dennis Lane, founder and chairman of the Vermont Grassroots Party, a political party dedicated to ending the ban on growing cannabis. In 1996, three of Mr. Lane's fellow party members each won at least 5 percent of the vote in elections for statewide office, which means the Grassroots Party is considered an important one in Vermont.
"The psychoactive component is just the tip of the iceberg in terms of the economic potential of cannabis," said Mr. Lane, referring to the chemical known as THC, which causes a high among marijuana smokers. "I'm pleased to see such support. The drug warriors keep using the same old tired lines, but our efforts to educate the public are getting through."
The production of industrial hemp was made illegal in the United States in the 1930's by the Uniform Narcotic Act and the Marijuana Tax Act. To this day, the only legal growing of cannabis in this country is done under special permit from the Drug Enforcement Administration.
As a practical matter, the important difference between marijuana and hemp is that marijuana has a THC level of 8 percent to 13 percent, whereas hemp has a THC level of less than 1 percent. Marijuana has a bushy growth while hemp is a tall, single-stemmed plant.
A concern expressed by opponents of legalization, including Governor Dean, is that law-enforcement officers would be unable to distinguish the two growing in a field.
Another worry, Mr. Clapp said, is that "local drug dealers will commit fraud by mixing the low-potency hemp tops in with the marijuana that's already being sold on the black market here."
The hemp issue surfaced in Vermont in the spring of 1996 after four legislative committees, including Mr. Starr's, began to consider legislation that would have instructed the University of Vermont to grow test plots of hemp, an idea that died under a veto threat by the Governor.
The compromise legislation, which took effect without the Governor's signature, instructed the university to survey public opinion and report back by Jan. 15, 1997. That was to be followed a year later by a study on marketability and suitability of soil types, the latter based on the results of hemp tests under way in the Canadian Province of Ontario.
The University of Vermont report was based on responses to a survey in May 1996 of 402 residents, with a margin of sampling error of plus or minus six percentage points.
